HEADLINE: Stockholm Journal;
In Years Since Palme Killing, a Loss of Innocence

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: STOCKHOLM

 BODY:
The site is so modestly marked that it is easy to miss. Perhaps appropriately, one must bow one's head to see it.
The simple brass plaque in the pavement at the Tunnelgatan entrance to the Hotorget subway station reads, "On this spot Sweden's Prime Minister Olof Palme was killed." 
 People by the scores find it daily, though, drawn to the site where many Swedes think their country began to lose its way.
"When Palme was killed, we were an innocent, virgin country," said Nina Ersman, a Swedish diplomat, expressing the common view that the assassination profoundly altered Sweden's view of itself as the unassailable guardian of the world's social conscience.
Mr. Palme, a statesman who aroused intense opinions by speaking out forcefully against apartheid in South Africa, United States actions in the Vietnam War and intolerance in general, was shot in the back by a lone gunman on the night of Feb. 28, 1986, as he was walking home from the movies with his wife.
The 12 years since that convulsive event have not been kind to Sweden's sense of itself as decent, efficient and distant from the tensions and treacheries of the rest of the world. If a certain fatalism took hold of the country at that moment, it has been deepened by the hapless performance of the police, which has left the case still unsolved.
"While the act itself was a national catastrophe, what has turned out to be an enormous setback is that the authorities have been unable to handle the case in a way that has not been open to criticism," said Defense Minister Bjorn von Sydow. "It has proved to be too great an event for our local police."
Arne Ruth, an author and former editor in chief of the newspaper Dagens Nyheter, was more blunt. "After the assassination," he said, "the total failure of the judicial system to handle the case was in a way an even worse disaster for Sweden."
The inquiry has been repeatedly sidetracked by disputes and scandals that have forced the resignations of a Justice Minister, a police chief and other officials.
In recent years, self-styled "private investigators" have produced increasingly bizarre versions of who was behind the killing, variously accusing the Central Intelligence Agency, the Mafia, NATO, Kurdish rebels, the renegade Italian Masonic lodge P-2, the Israeli intelligence agency Mossad, South African defenders of apartheid, local right-wing businessmen, Stockholm police officers angered at wage cuts, a Finnish bodybuilder and an unnamed member of the staff of former President George Bush.
"These are mostly made up by sick people," said Marten Palme, the late Prime Minister's 36-year-old son, who was with his father the night he was killed. "I've had some of them call and apologize to me after they received medication and got better."
Marten Palme, an associate professor at the Stockholm School of Economics, said the remaining family -- his mother, Lisbet, 67, and brothers Joakim, 40, a sociologist, and Mattias, 30, an architect -- were largely able to ignore the continuing furor now. "The most important thing for our family is to know what happened that night," he said, "and we feel we do."
They are convinced that the killer was Christer Pettersson, 51, a confessed drug addict and alcoholic who was convicted of the murder and sentenced to life in prison in 1989 but then freed later that year by an appellate court. He had spent much of the previous 20 years in jail, with a record of 63 arrests, including one for having stabbed a drug dealer to death with a bayonet in 1970.
Swedish criminal law is heavily weighted toward defendants' rights, and the higher court said the evidence used to convict Mr. Pettersson was too circumstantial. He received about $40,000 compensation for wrongful jailing.
An effort by prosecutors to reopen the case against him this spring failed when a Supreme Court panel ruled on May 27 that new witness testimony did not justify a new trial.
The justices also faulted prosecutors for failing to establish a motive or find the .357 Magnum that fired the bullets recovered from the scene. For years police divers have been looking for the pistol in the canals and waterways of Stockholm, a city built on islands in the Baltic Sea.
As for the motive, Swedes have wrestled with reconciling themselves to the notion that a society they long proclaimed to be the world's most rational may have been transformed by a senseless act.
Swedes have burdened the Palme assassination with being the inspiration for a series of unrelated accidents and violent episodes in the last dozen years. It has become a familiar if disjointed recital here -- the sinking of a ferry in 1994 that killed nearly 1,000 people, the machine-gun killing of seven people by a berserk army lieutenant the same year, the attack a year later that killed 4 people and wounded 20 by a young man retaliating with an assault rifle for having been denied admittance to a discotheque.
"The Palme assassination introduced a kind of criminality that we hadn't had before," a Swedish diplomat said.
Toivo Sjoren, research head of the Sipa opinion survey group, said a majority of Swedes thought Mr. Pettersson was the killer and distrusted the conspiracy theories. But the theorists persist.
The night he died, Mr. Palme had gone to the downtown Grand Cinema with his wife, his son Marten and Marten's girlfriend. On leaving, the Palmes said good night to the young couple and turned to walk down Sveavagen, a broad, tree-lined central boulevard. They were headed for the subway station three blocks away to take a train home.
It was not a remarkable thing for a Swedish Prime Minister to move about unprotected, a fact that was to be recalled repeatedly and ruefully after the killing, as permanent security guards were assigned to the country's leaders.
As they passed an artists' supply shop on the corner of Tunnelgatan, a figure emerged from the shadows, fired a shot that passed through Mr. Palme's back and upper chest and a second shot that grazed Mrs. Palme. Then the assassin ran along the dark side street and up a flight of stone stairs at its end two blocks away.
No one has ever come forward to say he or she saw the man fire the gun. At the 1989 trial, Mrs. Palme identified Mr. Pettersson as a man who had glared at her with a hostile expression as her husband lay dying on the snowy street. The accuracy of her recollection was challenged by defense lawyers because three years had passed since the killing.
In court, Mr. Pettersson greeted her claim by shouting out, "Olof Palme is in his heaven, and he would not like what you are saying, but if you believe it, it is O.K.!"
Mr. Pettersson has maintained his innocence, saying that at the time of the shooting he was on a commuter train headed for his suburban home.
The new evidence that prosecutors presented to the Supreme Court in December came from four witnesses, two of whom knew Mr. Pettersson before, who said they had seen him both outside the movie theater and running down the cross street after the shooting.
"The Palme investigation is not over," Lars Nylen, the National Police Commissioner, said in response to the court's refusal in May to permit a new trial. Tuve Johansson, one of 15 detectives still working the case, said his men would continue to seek the weapon and follow up leads.
"We get lots of tips," he said. "They're coming in all the time, but they are mostly ones we have seen before. It's very important to find the weapon." Asked if they were pursuing anyone besides Mr. Pettersson, he said, "We're not investigating just him, but he is a very interesting one."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Marten Palme, who was with his father, Prime Minister Olof Palme of Sweden, when he was slain on Feb. 28, 1986, says family members believe that the killer was the man who was convicted in 1989 but freed on appeal. (Ola Torkelsson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
From Japan, a Securities Firm With a Spiel of Radical Change

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
Yoshinari Hara, president and chief executive of Daiwa Securities, is on a mission to New York this week to sell ratings agencies, financial institutions and investors on the merits of a purely Japanese securities firm.
It's going to be a hard sell. 
 Japanese securities firms have struggled ever since the bubble economy burst nearly a decade ago. Now, deregulation has made things worse, opening the firms to intense competition from foreign concerns with expertise in products and services they know little about.
Outsiders have already made big gains in Tokyo Stock Exchange trading and pension-fund management. Merrill Lynch has taken over Yamaichi Securities, and Salomon Smith Barney is in a joint venture with Nikko Securities.
Only Nomura Securities, the brawny leader of Japan's securities firms, has a chance to survive as an independent, many analysts suggest.
So in July, when Daiwa, Japan's No. 2 brokerage firm, announced an alliance with Sumitomo Bank, it was greeted with something verging on disappointment.
Sumitomo, Japan's No. 2 bank after the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, is the core of the keiretsu, or business group, that includes Daiwa, and the alliance was largely seen as just another case of circling the wagons.
Moody's Investors Service, which had already put four Daiwa subsidiaries on notice for a possible downgrade, said the announcement did little to dispel its concerns.
"Sure, it lends credibility and substance to the group," Leslie Muranyi, senior analyst at Moody's in New York, said of the alliance. "But it doesn't provide any new products or services, it doesn't create a new management structure, and it doesn't provide a substantial inflow of new ideas and know-how."
And Ayako Sato, an analyst at Warburg Dillon Read, wrote in a report, "We should not expect too much from this merger."
Mr. Hara and his new adviser, Wilbur Ross, a high-profile turnaround strategist at Rothschild Inc., beg to differ. They see room for a purely Japanese firm and say Daiwa is redesigning itself to compete.
"We might get higher marks from overseas markets if we tie up with overseas partners," Mr. Hara said. "But since we will be focusing our business in the Japanese market with Japanese customers and clients, it is their evaluation that is important."
That is only partly true. A downgrade by Moody's would push the ratings of Daiwa's four subsidiaries to junk bond status, greatly raising the cost of borrowing abroad.
And with Japanese companies increasingly reliant on capital markets, not banks, for financing, global investors cannot be ignored.
That is why Mr. Ross was retained. "We wanted to know how we look from the viewpoint of an overseas business consultant," Mr. Hara said.
In Japan, foreign consultants are usually retained merely as window dressing. But so far, Mr. Ross has operated much the way he would if working for an American company, calling reporters, analysts and creditors to sing the praises of the Sumitomo alliance and pushing Mr. Hara to do interviews, including this one.
"This is a huge operation in an industry undergoing immense change," said Mr. Ross, who has branched out from advising creditors in bankruptcy cases to representing some of Asia's deeply troubled corporations. "Daiwa is undergoing probably the most radical change of any of them."
Analysts and reporters, he argued, have missed the fact that the Sumitomo alliance will bring $1.25 billion to $2 billion to Daiwa above and beyond the capital that will be transferred to the three joint ventures Daiwa will form with the bank.
That chunk of change -- which Mr. Ross said would be largely tax-free, when counted against previous tax losses -- would buy Daiwa the technical infrastructure it needs, with enough left over to lure a few foreign professionals to manage new businesses like derivatives and other exotic securities.
Moody's Mr. Muranyi, though, said there was nothing in the numbers he had seen to indicate that Daiwa would get anything close to that amount from Sumitomo. He is expected to meet with Daiwa officials and Mr. Ross soon.
Mr. Ross also said analysts had not taken adequate account of Daiwa's strengths in retail brokerage and investment banking and of the way they would be enhanced by an overhaul.
"They, meaning Daiwa, haven't done a very good job of telling people what this means," he said.
Mr. Muranyi and other analysts agree that theoretically there are benefits to the structure Daiwa is adopting, but they say the proof will be in the pudding.
The alliance is predicated on a reorganization of Daiwa Securities into a holding company, a structure illegal in Japan until recently.
That structure, set to be in place by spring, is regarded at Daiwa as an open invitation to foreign partners, and Mr. Hara says he is in discussions with several foreign firms about running the new asset management subsidiary.
Making an alliance with a separate subsidiary carries far less risk of exposure to the parent's liabilities, which has been a major concern of foreign investors.
Seven subsidiaries will reside under the Daiwa Securities Group umbrella. A retail brokerage firm will be a wholly owned subsidiary while ownership of three other subsidiaries -- in investment banking, asset management and risk management -- will be shared with Sumitomo.
With 300 billion yen in capital, the Daiwa-Sumitomo investment bank will have the biggest cushion in Japan, Mr. Hara said. The combination of Sumitomo's and Daiwa's asset management groups will bring together some 3 trillion yen, or almost $21 billion, in assets -- a drop in the bucket next to the more than $1 trillion controlled by Merrill Lynch but a decent-size pool for Japan.
As a holding company, Daiwa may be better able to control costs by more accurately assessing return on capital for each subsidiary and using the flexibility the structure gives it to cut labor costs.
Mr. Hara regards Daiwa's commitment to the structure as a clear sign of its commitment to new ideas. "It takes a lot of courage to go ahead and establish a holding company when no one else has done it," he said. "But we have decided to become a trend-setter. We have to."

LENGTH: 397 words

HEADLINE: A Bitter Airline Strike

 BODY:
It is hard to imagine a less sympathetic union than one made up of high-salaried pilots. Northwest Airlines, in a move to exploit that vulnerability, has launched a large advertising campaign denouncing the pilots, saying they get a lot of money for very little work. The pilots have their own, smaller campaign blasting management as being greedy.
This kind of open warfare between management and employees has damaging precedents in the airline industry. The bitter warfare between management and labor at Eastern Airlines ended in the bankruptcy and death of the airline. 
 Northwest's current labor problems have their origin in one of the last great leveraged buyouts of the 1980's. In that transaction, Gary Wilson, now Northwest's chairman, and Al Checchi, who went on to mount an expensive but unsuccessful campaign to be governor of California, took control of the airline.
Northwest soon ran into a crisis caused by the recession that arrived in 1990 and intensified by the company's highly leveraged capital structure. By 1993 the company faced possible bankruptcy, averted only by getting creditors to accept deferred payments and employees to grant givebacks.
Then things turned brighter. The economy recovered, profits in the airline industry improved and there was a boom in Asia, an area in which Northwest has concentrated. Under the 1993 contracts, wages were supposed to snap back to old levels in 1997, as they did, and new contracts were to be negotiated. Those negotiations have failed.
This strike comes at a difficult time for Northwest. The Asian recession has reduced its profitability, and its stock has lost half its value since March. At the same time, management fears that any concessions it makes to the pilots will come back to haunt it in negotiations with other workers. The result is a bitter deadlock particularly damaging to the Midwestern communities where Northwest is the dominant -- in some cases, the only -- carrier.
President Clinton has so far refused to invoke a law that would enable him to impose a 60-day cooling-off period. It is clear that cooling off would help, but it is not as clear that postponing this strike to early November would accomplish much cooling. This is a strike that both sides need to settle -- and on terms that do not result in an embittered work force that will only alienate customers.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Latin America Is Buffeted, but Seems Stronger Than in '94

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 31

 BODY:
The demons of financial crisis are haunting Latin America again, unleashed by tumult in Russia, Japan and, now, the United States. Markets and currencies across the region are sinking as panicky investors retreat to the safe haven of American Treasury bonds and dollars.
Most of the major Latin economies are far better fortified to withstand external battering than they were four years ago. That was when a disastrous devaluation in Mexico engulfed several Latin economies into what economists, investors and politicians called the tequila effect. Since then Mexico and Brazil have taken sober measures to build foreign reserves and control inflation, while Argentina and Chile persevered in tough programs already in place. 
 Among the big players only Venezuela failed to buckle down to austerity, and it is now paying the price. Venezuela is in a full-scale emergency, as reserves have been dropping; short-term bank interest rates have been soaring, to 120 percent, and the stock market has fallen, 37 percent in the last month.
Because most of the underlying economies are solid, the turmoil might have milder effects in Latin America than appearances augur, economists and analysts said. But they cautioned that if markets outside the region continued to dive for long or if investors fled the emerging markets en masse without regard to the strengths of individual countries, the outcome could be devastating.
If the slide in the United States results in a sluggish American economy, the damage will be even greater in Latin America, which sends most of its exports to the United States.
As if to demonstrate the point, on a day when the Dow Jones industrial average plummeted 512.61 points, or 6.37 percent, the Mexican stock market was down 5.14 percent.
Mexico canceled a regular Monday auction of Government treasury bills, known as cetes, saying, "The offers received were not consistent with the macroeconomic situation of the country."
It was the first time that Mexico had canceled the auction since the days after the devaluation in 1994.
The leading index of Brazilian stocks was off by 4.06 percent. Even the stock market in stolid Chile was off 3.01 percent. Venezuela, surprisingly, was not hit, with its stock market in a modest rally of 0.18 percent.
"Latin America is the good neighbor in a bad neighborhood," Riordan Roett, director of the Western Hemisphere program at the Johns Hopkins University, said.
The region "should not be affected, but they will be," Mr. Roett said.
A top economist at the Instituto Tecnologico Autonomo de Mexico, Alejandro Hernandez, said: "Nobody has any really perfect defenses. This is the challenge of the smaller economies in a globalized world."
In 1994 the region's problems were largely self-inflicted, and the United States, then growing robustly, and the International Monetary Fund were ready to step in with loans to help.
Now Latin America is paying for mistakes made in Moscow and Tokyo that rattled the markets and also sent prices for many important Latin commodities like wheat and oil to their lowest real rates in decades. And neither the United States nor the cash-strapped I.M.F. can do much to rescue any country here.
Mexico has done the most to clean up since 1994. Although the peso has slipped -- it recovered slightly today, to 10.02 cents, up 0.4 percent -- many analysts say it is fairly valued.
Oil revenues make up 37 percent of the Government's income, and President Ernesto Zedillo responded quickly to the drop in petroleum prices by slashing the Federal budget three times, maintaining a modest deficit of 1.25 percent of the gross domestic product.
Growth, which boomed in the first half of the year, is generally expected to slow through next year but remain healthy. The Government continues to promise growth of more than 5 percent this year. But economists have revised their estimates down, to 4 and 2.3 percent, by Bursametrica Management in Mexico City.
Interest rates climbed today, to an annualized rate of 38 percent for the overnight cete. But after the drubbing that Mexican banks and indebted citizens took in 1994, far fewer loans are out. Foreign reserves have remained at record highs, with the influx of long-term investment in factories and infrastructure, which now accounts for about 70 percent of foreign investment, helping to keep the reserves strong.
Mexico's big weak spot is its ailing banking system. The Congress, which opens a new session next week, is angrily divided about how to pay for a multibillion-dollar bailout for the banks.
On Sunday three million Mexicans voted against the Government proposal in a symbolic referendum organized by an opposition party, the Party of the Democratic Revolution.
"This is very far from classifying as a crisis," an economist with Latinsource Mexico, Jonathan Heath, said. "There is a lot of noise, a psychological crisis. But while the financial markets are reflecting what is happening in the rest of the world, the real economy continues to grow."
Elsewhere political factors are central. At the outset of the Asian financial crisis in October, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso of Brazil marshaled through a package of changes that doubled interest rates and imposed steep tax increases and spending cuts.
But the fiscal deficit remains at nearly 7 percent of the economy. The Brazilian currency, the real, is traded in a fixed band and is said by analysts to be overvalued by at least 10 percent. The Central Bank said $7.7 billion left the country in the four weeks before Aug. 28.
Mr. Cardoso appears to determined to forestall any devaluation and even cut interest rates, at least until after elections on Oct. 4. Polls show that he is most likely to win a second four-year term easily in the first round.
Brazil has huge foreign reserves of $72 billion, and several valuable Government properties to sell in a crisis.
"We are going to face this crisis, as always, calmly, without any new package, without any scares," Mr. Cardoso told reporters in a brief appearance on Friday.
Venezuela faces the most severe problems, analysts said, primarily because neither of the two most prominent candidates in presidential elections in December hold much promise of bringing tough solutions to a wayward economy.
The front-runner, Hugo Chavez, 44, is running on a populist platform of broadside repudiation of the political elite for years of economic instability.
Another contender is Irene Saez, 36, a former Miss Universe who has no experience in economics.
Venezuela has done little to reduce its dependence on petroleum, which accounts for three-quarters of exports.
In the longer term, economists are worried that investors' confidence will be so shattered by a new round of losses in the emerging markets that Latin countries will have trouble returning to the international markets to help to pay their debts next year.
"It may be a long time before investors can differentiate and say that Brazil is different from Russia," Sylvia Maxfield, a strategist on emerging markets at Lehman Brothers, said. "We could be in for a period when nobody is willing to touch the emerging markets."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Traders at the Sao Paulo stock exchange near the end of the session yesterday. Brazil, along with Mexico, has taken sober financial steps. (Agence France-Presse)

LENGTH: 1157 words

HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN RUSSIA: THE AMERICAN PRESIDENT;
Beyond Personal Faults, The Power of the Office

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 31

 BODY:
In the eyes of many of his fellow leaders and ordinary people around the world, President Clinton has lost personal stature since investigations into his private life and his admission of an inappropriate relationship with a White House intern. But he has lost little of the authority and power conferred on him by the Presidency.
Some, particularly in the Muslim world, fear that Mr. Clinton no longer has the moral authority to use his power in ways they would like to see. 
 Others, in the Middle East and Africa, say they believe that he ordered military strikes against reported terrorist targets in the Sudan and Afghanistan to divert attention, and that he may be tempted to respond similarly in future crises.
But leaders everywhere say that whatever Mr. Clinton's private life, his position as leader of the world's most powerful economy and the only military superpower makes him indispensable in dealing with international problems from terrorism to turmoil in Russia.
New York Times correspondents on five continents report that the people, regardless of their personal feelings about Mr. Clinton, stand in awe of the power of the Presidency -- if somewhat less in awe of the character of the man now occupying the office.
But because Mr. Clinton has been taken down a notch in the last month, leaders in some countries are quicker than usual to take issue with American policies.
For example, one high-ranking European official criticized the President's determination to travel to Russia in the face of the political and economic turmoil that has hobbled President Boris N. Yeltsin. "It's a completely useless meeting," the official said, "but neither Yeltsin nor Clinton could afford to be the first to say, 'Let's call it off.' "
The worst outcome of the Russian crisis, most European leaders agree, would be abandonment by Moscow of a commitment to democracy and to a free-market economy. In their eyes, despite the personal revelations, Mr. Clinton is still capable of conveying that the West will continue its support if Russia keeps trying.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, who is fighting against the odds for re-election on Sept. 27, would have perhaps the most to lose if Russia changed course; the German Government and banks have lent billions to Moscow.
As Mr. Kohl said in a television interview a week ago: "Bill Clinton is the No. 1 in the world. Whatever American domestic politics are, he has his responsibilities. In contact with Russia, Indonesia or Japan, to name only a few problem areas, it's absolutely necessary. There is no letup, not for the President of the United States."
President Jacques Chirac of France referred to his "personal friendship" for Mr. Clinton in a speech to French ambassadors in Paris last week. But he also ticked off a list of differences between the United States and France, saying Washington had an isolationist and unilateral streak that complicated international issues.
Everywhere, it seems, there is bafflement about a country where a President's foes can use his sex life to attack him politically. "Is this an advanced form of democratic political conduct?" the French Foreign Minister, Hubert Vedrine, mused.
John Biehl del Rio, chief of staff to President Eduardo Frei of Chile, said, "Outside the United States, we do not give this issue the same importance. We are all praying, or at least crossing our fingers, that he is not hurt by this. The world faces a recession, and the United States is holding the economy of the world together almost alone."
The Mexican writer Jorge Castaneda said, "There are a lot of problems in the world that only the U.S. can fix, and there's a sense among Mexicans that there wouldn't be this worldwide mess if there was somebody in charge in Washington.
"How can a successful President who has brought prosperity and well-being to the U.S. be weakened, destroyed or crippled by this silly story?"
Tumi Mahabane, deputy editor of Y, a magazine for young people in South Africa, said: "I don't think people should look to presidents for moral authority. Presidents should steer countries. Their morality is peripheral."
But in the Arab world, the dominant view is that Mr. Clinton's relationship with the intern, Monica S. Lewinsky, has weakened the Presidency and Washington's ability to press Israel to negotiate with the Palestinians. "It is no longer possible to plan any policy with them," said a senior official in Saudi Arabia.
It is widely thought in some Muslim countries that Ms. Lewinsky was an Israeli agent placed in the White House. Without his troubles over her, some Palestinian and other Arab officials contend, Mr. Clinton might have been willing to criticize Israel earlier this year for not agreeing to an American proposal for an accord with the Palestinians.
Hemi Shalev, a commentator for the Israeli newspaper Maariv, wrote: "The weakening of the President was a boon to the right wing. They quickly translated Bill Clinton's troubles into local currency and reached the conclusion that a President up against the boards is one who cannot pressure Israel to implement the second redeployment."
Reaction in much of the Islamic world was also critical of the bombings in the Sudan and Afghanistan, and inclined to see a connection with Ms. Lewinsky.
Sarote Phaksumlee, a leader of Ban Krua, the biggest Muslim community in Bangkok, Thailand, said: "The timing is very strange. Nobody has heard of Osama bin Laden before," a reference to the Saudi who Washington says planned the bombing of American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania.
"It is obvious the attack is staged to divert attention from Bill Clinton's sex scandal," Mr. Phaksumlee said. "If America can do what it did in the Sudan and Afghanistan, tomorrow it can bomb northern Thailand by saying we are growing opium and manufacturing heroin and exporting it to America."
Dr. Mansor Mohammad Noor, former leader of a fundamentalist Islamic group in Malaysia and now a lecturer at University Science Malaysia, said: "Clinton has discredited himself even though he might be right. The greatest error is that Clinton is sowing fear among people throughout the world. He has shown the might of the United States and it can hammer anyone anywhere.
"The United States can bomb anyone anywhere. This is a very dangerous precedent: the world is at the mercy of America. Clinton has frightened the world. A frightened world is a dangerous world."
But Mukhtar Baki Kizginkaya, the leader of Emirgan, an Istanbul neighborhood, offered a different opinion: "Clinton is a very valuable man. He did what was necessary in the Sudan, responding to terrorism."
Whatever the outcome of his trip to Russia, Mr. Clinton can apparently expect a warm welcome afterward in Ireland, where he is very popular. He plans to visit both North and South, then relax for a few days to play golf before he goes back to Washington.

HEADLINE: Decline in New-Home Sales Is a Bit Steeper Than Expected

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Sales of new homes fell more than expected during July, a sign that the housing market may be settling down after its record growth in June.
The Commerce Department said today that sales of new single-family homes declined 1.6 percent in July, to 886,000 units at an annual rate. The increase in June, which was originally reported as a 935,000-unit annual rate, was revised downward to a 1.1 percent gain, or an annual pace of 900,000 units, still a record. 
 Analysts had expected an 929,000-unit annual rate for new-home sales in July. Still, they said the July decrease, although larger than expected, did not point to significant weakness in housing activity. Over the last four months, the annual rate of new-home sales has stayed between 886,000 and 900,000 units.
The July statistics still "indicate a lot of strength" in housing activity, said Marilyn Schaja, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities in New York. Sales near the 900,000-unit level "are more sustainable" than the 935,000 units previously reported for June, she said.
Demand for labor is strong, incomes are steady, consumers are confident and interest rates are low. The average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage in August was about 6.92 percent, down from 6.95 percent in July and 7 percent in June.
New-home sales in July rose 1.4 percent in the South, to a 432,000-unit annual rate. They fell 11.7 percent in the Midwest, to a 144,000-unit rate; four-tenths of 1 percent in the West, to a 236,000-unit rate, and 1.3 percent in the Northeast, to a 74,000-unit rate.
The median price of new homes rose to $147,900, from $145,800 in June.
The inventory of new homes for sale at the current sales pace rose to a four-month supply in July from a revised 3.9-month supply in June. The low supply of new homes suggests builders will be busy through the end of the year, analysts said.

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "Prices of New Homes" tracks median price for new homes, from February 1997 through January 1998; "New-Home Sales" tracks private homes sold monthly, at seasonally adjusted annual rate in thousands, over the same period. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: Reporter at The Times to Receive Award for Decades of Journalism

 BODY:
A reporter for The New York Times has won the 1998 John Chancellor Award for Excellence in Journalism, the Annenberg Public Policy Center at the University of Pennsylvania plans to announce today.
John Kifner, 56, now a metropolitan reporter for The Times, won for the body of his work, for both foreign and domestic reporting. The Annenberg School for Communication, which administers the award, cited his ability to translate "complicated changes in the political, economic and cultural landscape for American readers." 
 In more than 30 years at The Times, Mr. Kifner covered the Iranian revolution, the Persian Gulf war and the assassination of Yitzhak Rabin. He also covered the 1968 Democratic convention, the Kent State shootings, the busing crisis in Boston and the Oklahoma City bombing. He won two George Polk Awards, most recently in 1989 for his coverage of the Palestinian uprising.
A seven-member committee of journalists and others chose the winner. Sander Vanocur, a veteran television journalist, said, "We wanted to honor a working reporter who was still slugging it out -- who gives you facts over punditry."
Jack Nelson, chief Washington correspondent of The Los Angeles Times, said, "I've had to compete against him; I know he's hard-hitting."
The award is given in honor of John Chancellor, the NBC television correspondent and anchor who died in 1996, and will be presented at a dinner in Philadelphia on Oct. 21. It carries a $25,000 prize.

HEADLINE: At N.Y.U., the Clintons, Gore and a Mini-United Nations

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
In what is shaping up as a remarkable lineup of domestic and foreign leaders at New York University, President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton have agreed to lead a day of discussions on the global economy at a conference later this month, with guests including the prime ministers of Britain and Italy, the White House said yesterday.
Vice President Al Gore is also likely to attend the daylong session at the New York University School of Law, a White House official said on condition of anonymity. University officials said the event would be an historic concentration of political power in Greenwich Village. 
 The Sept. 21 event coincides with the opening session of the United Nations General Assembly, which accounts for the university's success in drawing other heads of government to Mr. Clinton's afternoon discussion. The law school dean, John Sexton, is a longtime friend of the President and Mrs. Clinton, which in part accounts for the Clintons' agreement to appear.
The conference promises to be a notable moment even for this President. Although Mr. Clinton has repeatedly demonstrated an affinity for extended discussions of policies with scholars -- this one will go at least 90 minutes, Mr. Sexton said -- it is the first time he has attempted something like this with a panel of foreign dignitaries.
It also promises to be a notable moment for the N.Y.U. School of Law, which is sponsoring the forum, titled "Strengthening Democracy in the Global Economy." If all goes according to plan, a group of its students, selected by lottery, and faculty members will in the space of the day witness a morning seminar led by the First Lady, a luncheon speech by Mr. Gore, and an afternoon discussion of international affairs with a panel that is to include, at least, Mr. Clinton, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and Romano Prodi, the Prime Minister of Italy. The leaders of Canada, Brazil, Bulgaria, Sweden and the Netherlands have also been asked to attend, school officials said.
The conference promises to be interesting for both political and logistical reasons. As a rule, the General Assembly's opening sessions, with their influx of foreign dignitaries, motorcades and security details, bring traffic tie-ups and disruption to the streets and sidewalks around the United Nations. The conference promises to extend that confusion to Greenwich Village.
And the fact that Mr. and Mrs. Clinton will be attending the same conference, though not necessarily appearing together, during a time of public scrutiny of their private life could mean an unusual amount of attention to a conference devoted to the arguably dry theme of global economics and politics.
Whatever the case, White House and N.Y.U. officials said they were delighted with the way the conference was shaping up. University officials said it would draw attention to the new Global Law School Program, which is devoted to the study of how democratic governments have been affected by the global economy.
And Mr. Clinton's aides said it would give the President a chance to be spotlighted talking about policy.
Each of the discussions will be open to about 275 people, including the students, faculty members and outside guests invited by the university. "We are aiming for a sizable group of people from the general intellectual, business and labor community," said Prof. Norman Dorsen, the chairman of the Global Law School Program.
Members of the audience will be allowed to ask questions or make comments, either by passing the questions forward on sheets of paper or by going to an open microphone.
Mrs. Clinton will lead the morning forum, which will be called "Civil Society and the Future of Democracy."
Mr. Clinton will lead the afternoon forum, which will be a general discussion by the government leaders on themes that were raised during the day.
"What the President will talk about -- your guess is as good as mine, if I may be only slightly facetious," Professor Dorsen said.
Mr. Clinton's communications aide, Sidney Blumenthal, said the President's discussion would be devoted to "strengthening democracy in the world economy. Globalization. Everything from a civil society to how you create more opportunity for people in the new economy. How you respond to new realities."
"There's never been an event like this," Mr. Blumenthal said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL;
Mexican Stocks Fall Sharply Over Interest Rate Concerns

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Mexican stocks tumbled for the eighth day out of nine as traders dumped securities on concerns rising interest rates will stall the consumer spending engine that's been driving economic growth.
The Bolsa index fell 162.21, or 5.14 percent, to 2991.93, its lowest level in more than two years. The index plunged 37 percent in dollar terms this month. 
 "Everybody is talking about significantly slower growth in 1999 and that's part of what the market is considering," said James Barrineau, a Latin American equity strategist with Salomon Smith Barney.
The rout was lead by retailers as higher interest rates threaten to dry up consumer purchases on credit.
Overnight rates on Treasury bills shot up 650 basis points, to 38.50 percent, their highest level since March 20, 1996. An auction of Government debt scheduled for today was canceled, the central bank said, but it did not give a reason why.
Rates on the benchmark 28-day Treasury bill were expected to jump 824 basis points, to 35.40 percent, their highest level in two years.
Retailers were also hurt after an industry trade group said supermarket sales rose 2.5 percent in July from the same month a year earlier. Even though July's sales rose at a faster pace than 1.6 percent in June, the pace was smaller than in May and April, hinting that consumer demand is slowing.
A plunge in United States stocks also dragged down Mexican shares as United States investors dumped Mexican American depository shares in a 512-point selloff of the Dow Jones industrial average.
 Telefonos de Mexico S.A., which makes up about a quarter of the Bolsa index, dropped 4.7 percent, to 35.6875 in New York trading.
Investors continued to pull money out of Mexican securities as a Russian devaluation and threat to renege on debt drives up risk in other emerging markets. On the year, the Bolsa index has dropped 54 percent in dollar terms.

HEADLINE: GRADING THE SECRETARY: A special report.;
Albright, a Bold Voice Abroad, Finds Her Role Limited at Home

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Aug. 31

 BODY:
With her bold public stands undermined by irresolution in the White House and her experience rendered less relevant by new economic crises, Madeleine K. Albright has had a tough 20 months as Secretary of State.
Ms. Albright remains the Clinton Administration's principal foreign-policy voice and the liaison with a recalcitrant Republican Congress, and is greeted like a celebrity very popular in the country beyond Washington. But a President averse to military risk, preoccupied by the fallout from his relationship with an intern and unwilling to offend core Democratic constituencies has not supported her on key issues like the Middle East and Kosovo. 
 Her assiduous courtship of Congress was instrumental in winning Senate ratification of NATO expansion and the Chemical Weapons Convention from a Congress verging on isolationism. But Ms. Albright has had little to do with the few other Clinton successes of the second term: a settlement in Northern Ireland and a reinvigoration of relations with China.
And now, as Russia melts, tainting one of the relationships of which Mr. Clinton has been proudest, this is a particularly vulnerable period for the Administration's foreign policy. Russia was part of widening international crisis that has now hit Wall Street, threatening the booming economy that has kept his popularity afloat.
But Ms. Albright and the State Department have not been crucial players, White House officials say. With Mr. Clinton so distracted, it is not immediately clear who is in charge.
The evidence appears to favor the national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, and the Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, though, instead of Ms. Albright.
In a recent interview, Ms. Albright bristled at specific criticism, but says it is only natural that the economic experts take the lead on their issues.
"For me, what's important is what people think in years hence," Ms. Albright said. "Whether I used this four-year period in a way that ultimately accomplished what I want: to create the underpinnings for the American role in the next century, while taking care of what needs to be done to problem-solve."
Ms. Albright attended only one recent meeting of the National Economic Council, the functional equivalent of the National Security Council, and that was on Japan.
She and her officials did regularly urge a broader view of American interests in Asia than simply the financial, including security and the stabilization of democratizing Asian allies, and coordinated interagency aid packages for Thailand and Indonesia.
But her call for President Suharto of Indonesia to step down occurred only hours before he did so anyway, and in general, Ms. Albright and her department have let Treasury run the show.
Was this an opportunity missed, or simply, as Ms. Albright and her aides contend, the most efficient and collegial way to coordinate a post-Soviet world with new, nontraditional challenges?
In the Middle East, on the other hand, Ms. Albright has been central, trying to coax and cajole Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel into a compromise that would refresh a deterioriating peace and help restore American credibility in the Arab world. But her intensive efforts have not yet produced the clear personal triumph that zero-sum Washington seems to require.
In May, she gambled that public pressure and an ultimatum would move Mr. Netanyahu, but the White House failed to support her in the face of a lobbying firestorm stoked by the American Israel Public Affairs Committee.
She kept the Administration engaged in Bosnia, where it could not reasonably retreat.
Here in Sarajevo on Sunday and again today, Ms. Albright spoke passionately and effectively about the effort required to make a multinational, democratic Bosnia come to pass, and she was eager to make it vividly clear that American aid would only come to those who worked to carry out the Dayton accords.
But her advocacy of an aggressive approach -- including a credible threat of air strikes -- toward the Serbian leader Slobodan Milosevic, over his crackdown on ethnic Albanian separatists in Kosovo Province did not find wide support within NATO and was rejected by Mr. Clinton in the spring.
Her vow in March that "we are not going to stand by and watch the Serbian authorities do in Kosovo what they can no longer get away with doing in Bosnia" has proven hollow.
Other American threats have seemed equally empty -- against Iraq to defend United Nations weapons inspections, for example.
That has called into question the American commitment to a sustained war on terrorism, a commitment Ms. Albright and others pledged would begin with the missile strikes against Afghanistan and Sudan.
 
Some Early Victories For a New Secretary
Ms. Albright's accession as Secretary of State, becoming the highest-ranking woman in American history, prompted enormous popular and media interest. She attracted attention for her newly discovered Jewish background as well as for successful efforts to expand NATO and to her push to articulate a more forceful American position than her dry, quiet predecessor, Warren M. Christopher.
She quickly earned respect from her French, Russian, Chinese and Arab colleagues. Early victories in Congress were hailed, and she has won important policy shifts on Iran and Cuba, while helping to prevent a trade war with Europe over sanctions.
But with domestic problems undercutting Mr. Clinton's international credibility, the Administration foreign policy seems ever more reactive. And with the bombing of American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, followed by missile strikes in Afghanistan and the Sudan, with civil war in Kosovo, nuclear tests by India and Pakistan, the Russian economic and political problems and the unresolved crisis in Iraq flaring again, the world seems a more dangerous and unstable place than when Ms. Albright came to office.
Ms. Albright's greatest virtues -- clarity and an intelligent, forceful voice connecting with the public and Congress -- have not diminished, said a senior White House official who admires her. But as the Administration faces diverse and less manageable problems, many due to the economic problems that began in Asia, "her virtues seem less impressive or timely," the official said, "because neither economics nor strategy are her strengths, and her depth lies in European issues, not Asian ones."
Even Ms. Albright's hard work with Congress -- in particular with Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina -- has not yet produced a deal to repay Washington's debt to the United Nations or funds to replenish the International Monetary Fund reserves, both described as high priorities by her aides. Compromises have been stymied by a fight with House Republicans over abortion policy.
"My predecessors had a different world to deal with in which the parameters were fairly set," Ms. Albright said. "They had the possibility of focusing all their attention on one or two issues." By contrast, she said, she is trying to "put into play a lot of issues that I see as challenges we're facing," like nuclear nonproliferation, economics and the effective use of sanctions, issues that were at the center of a January review of priorities.
 
The Land Mines And the War Crimes
Ms. Albright has failed to achieve some of the human-rights goals she described as among the most important to her. She was an early champion of a ban on land mines. Last year, however, in Ottawa, the United States was nearly alone in opposing a treaty.
As a Central European whose family fled first the Nazis and then the Communists, she has been especially concerned about crimes against humanity. She created an Ambassador for War Crimes and lobbied for a permanent international tribunal to prosecute them.
But at a Rome conference to accomplish that goal, the United States was part of a small minority refusing to sign a treaty to create a permanent tribunal. In both cases, the Pentagon and Congress successfully argued that the only superpower required special exceptions.
Ms. Albright said she continues to champion her principles, but she cannot forget America's responsibilities. "I have to balance enunciating the principles and leading the way with the pragmatism of getting things done and the power of the United States," she said.
But there is now a new expression in diplomatic circles -- "to pull an Ottawa" -- which means to promote a new initiative and then abandon it at the end.
Ms. Albright's fierce rhetorical battles with the Iraqis at the United Nations helped catapult her into the Secretary's elegant office on the seventh floor. And in a corridor leading off from it, she keeps a comic shrine, a collection of cartoons, newspaper cuttings and other mementos of her tussles with Iraq.
But the Iraq problem persists. The latest crisis is an outgrowth of the inconclusive standoff last March, which did little for the reputation of Mr. Clinton's foreign-policy team.
Iraq continues to serve as a reminder of the limits of American power, of the post-Soviet difficulties in orchestrating allies and of the continuing reluctance of Mr. Clinton to use force in risky circumstances.
 
The Big Fiasco In Columbus
But the televised town hall meeting in Columbus, Ohio, in February, was the most visible fiasco. Ms. Albright and Mr. Berger, the security adviser, and Defense Secretary William S. Cohen were unable to silence hecklers or to sound convincing about why a nearly isolated United States might need to bomb Iraq.
The Ohio meeting -- organized by the White House to use Ms. Albright's skills and popularity -- began the erosion of her reputation among the foreign-policy elite of which she has been a member for so long.
"If you look around the world for the big challenges now, where's the Secretary of State?" asked Robert B. Zoellick, former Under Secretary of State for James A. Baker 3d, who enjoyed a level of access to his President, George Bush, and influence over him that seems denied to Ms. Albright. "To an outsider, she's M.I.A. People run issues case by case, but there's a sense the show is being managed by Berger."
The Administration manages crises but has no clear strategic framework, Mr. Zoellick said. "How do different problems relate to one another? It starts with the President, but it's not her forte or Berger's. If you don't have a sense of where you want to take the country, you won't get there."
Michael Mandelbaum, of Johns Hopkins University, who criticized first-term foreign policy as "social work," thinks the current team is doing decently at managing the smaller crises of the post-cold-war era, which have less to do with national security and diplomacy.
"Certainly in this second presidential term, by far the most important figures in foreign policy" are Treasury Secretary Rubin and his deputy, Lawrence H. Summers, Mr. Mandelbaum said. "For that we should be grateful. A world with a financial crisis is far safer than a world with a military crisis, and they've been doing pretty well. But Albright doesn't seem to be a player in all this."
 
Success With China: Who Gets Credit?
Richard N. Haass of the Brookings Institution, who was on the National Security Council staff under President Bush, said "the one significant accomplishment in the second term" has been to renew relations with China. "There you can see a policy initiative and presidential investment," he said. "One senses that the engine for that has been the President and the National Security Council."
In the interview, Ms. Albright defended her involvement and that of her strong team in the full range of foreign policy, from Asia and China to Iran and Cuba. On financial matters, she said, she has been working to insure that the diplomatic, human and security aspects are fully grasped.
As a former academic, she has been happy to reach down to the regional assistant secretaries and to urge them "to think outside the box," wanting career officers to compete for ideas with outsiders. She has encouraged Under Secretaries Thomas R. Pickering and Stuart E. Eizenstat, and Deputy Secretary Strobe Talbott, "to drive policy and make things happen," an official said.
"Economic issues we have brought right into the department," Ms. Albright said, "and we have an Under Secretary who's strong -- Stu Eizenstat -- really working on sanctions issues and on trying to meld the financial with the assistance part of the Asian financial crisis."
She has pushed hard, as she promised him she would, Mr. Eizenstat said, to make State a serious player again on economic issues. Treasury gets the headlines over Asia, he said, "but we and she have been intimately involved with the humanitarian and political dimensions."
She is confident about her managing role as Secretary of State, as the prime foreign-policy spokesman for the Administration and as a formulator of key policy. And she rejects the notion that Mr. Clinton's choice of Richard C. Holbrooke to be chief American delegate to the United Nations -- someone who was said to have been a candidate for Secretary of State before Ms. Albright was chosen -- is a sign that her own star is waning or wanting.
"Washington is what it is," she said, shrugging. "People think you're terrific, and then they think you're too terrific, so then they let you know that you're not. You can't be in a position of being the visible voice for the United States and not be out there to be praised and criticized."
Ms. Albright and Mr. Berger have a friendship dating back to the presidential campaign of Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, when Ms. Albright was the chief foreign-policy adviser to a candidate who took almost unremitting heat for not having a strong foreign-policy view. Despite moments of annoyance -- usually over personnel -- presidential briefings or second-guessing about the results of specific diplomatic missions, Ms. Albright and Mr. Berger are each other's closest advisers. They hash out policy in advance and speak many times a day -- a sharp contrast to the tension between Mr. Christopher and Anthony Lake, or the raging warfare under Jimmy Carter -- the last Democratic President -- between Cyrus R. Vance and Zbigniew Brzezinski.
 
Albright and Berger Are Both Pragmatists
"This is not the foreign-policy President who wakes up thinking what notes he can pen to his foreign colleagues," a senior Administration official said, a reference, apparently, to Mr. Bush, who was famous for his hand-written correspondence to world leaders. "So Berger becomes the guy who doesn't make foreign policy so much as broker it."
In meetings, another senior White House official said, "she is pragmatic and a consensus builder, like Berger, despite her reputation outside as an uncompromising, six-gun shooting moralist." She arrives well-briefed and armed with a collective department view, in contrast to Mr. Cohen, whose well-armed Pentagon often gets its way regardless. She is "articulate on issues she knows well, and tends to put aside the talking points and draw from her own experience, and she's best when she does that."
Ms. Albright dealt movingly with the emotional and security crisis surrounding the bombing of the American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania and the deaths of many of her employees, and she has handled Mr. Clinton's personal troubles with dignity.
But her finest policy moment lately has been a shift in the treatment of Iran after the election of the moderate Mohammad Khatami as President. While maintaining demands for a halt to terrorism and Iran's nuclear, chemical and missile programs, she pushed Mr. Clinton to a more receptive Iran policy.
"It was hard and had internal criticism, but she got it done with Sandy and the President," avoiding an interagency battle, an official said.
After her recent speech laying out the new policy -- to which Iran has not yet responded -- the President took her aside to congratulate her, she said, "for threading the needle."
Similarly, she used contacts with Pope John Paul II, the Congress and Cuban exiles in Miami to allow direct relief flights from the United States to Cuba to resume and to let relatives send money.
Ms. Albright is also praised for her work with the Russian Foreign Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, which helped forge a new relationship between NATO and Russia.
At one point, aides remember, as Mr. Primakov argued for secondary military status for new NATO members, Ms. Albright said: "Neither the President nor I will negotiate over the heads of the peoples of Central Europe. That happened once before and it's not going to happen again."
Mr. Primakov was silent, then diverted the conversation, and never pressed the issue so hard again, the aides say.
But Russian policy is generally run by Mr. Talbott and is dominated by the economic and political crisis, making Mr. Primakov -- and Ms. Albright -- less important.
Ms. Albright also pushed the Pentagon to act more decisively in support of political goals in Bosnia and to keep troops there without a deadline.
Her conversations with the Bosnian Serb President, Biljana Plavsic, were crucial in encouraging her to challenge Radovan Karadzic.
On Kosovo, she argues that -- unlike in Bosnia -- Washington and NATO were involved early and got Europe to act. A resolution is not yet clear, she says, but the ground is prepared.
Ms. Albright is also proud of using her unprecedented telephone relationship with the Chinese Foreign Minister to organize the Security Council's five permanent members -- the United States, Russia, China, France and Britain -- to condemn nuclear tests by India and Pakistan.
At their June meeting in Geneva, she told the others that they are "always talking about a multipolar and not a unipolar world."
This was their chance to prove it, she said, "so one country doesn't take a principled stand and the others sign up the contracts."
 
She Will Await History's Judgment
With all the "profound ideological confusion" facing a post-cold-war Secretary of State, said Moises Naim, editor of Foreign Policy, this is not a period for "grand strategy." Ms. Albright's role, he said, is inevitably one of a goalkeeper.
But Secretaries of State are often defined by challenges. Mr. Baker, for instance, had a great crisis thrust upon him, the Persian Gulf war, and a great opportunity, the collapse of Communism.
So far, Ms. Albright has not had such a test or made such an opportunity of the growing world economic problems.
"I can't operate on the basis of instant gratification on any part of my daily work," she said.
"The policies that are being put into place are longer term. It may be the next Secretary of State will reap the rewards of what I've done. Sitting in this chair you get the sense that you are a part of history."
She noted her recent induction into the national Women's Hall of Fame. "When they say I'm the highest-ranking woman in the history of the United States, that's pretty amazing. I don't mind occasionally having someone criticize me."
Judith Kipper of the Council on Foreign Relations, while a fierce critic of United States Middle East policy, praises Ms. Albright for showing the way.
"She can be soft with her children, motherly and nice, and go shopping and be all the things a decent person can be," Ms. Kipper said.
"But when it comes to the work, she's tough and serious. There's no gender in the work."

HEADLINE: Strike Apparently Settled, Workers Return to U S West

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: DENVER, Aug. 31

 BODY:
With nonunion companies competing hungrily for telephone business in booming cities of the Rockies, U S West tentatively settled a two-week-old strike today, putting employees back to work at the region's Bell company.
The settlement, which faces a ratification vote by the 34,000 striking members of Communications Workers of America, gives workers gains in pay and pension benefits, among other things, and allows for a voluntary pay-for-performance program. 
 The deal came as U S West is scrambling to keep control of an exploding market in fax, pager and telephone lines in Denver. Starting Tuesday, all local calls made within the Denver area will require 10-digit dialing. In October, greater Denver is to get a second area code, 720.
"The Bell companies are preparing to face increased competition from fairly lean, nonunion companies going after their market share," said Boyd Peterson, an analyst with The Yankee Group, a telecommunications research company in Boston.
Mr. Peterson said that although U S West remained strong -- its stock fell only seven-sixteenths of a point today in the face a sharp market decline -- it could not afford a protracted fight with an equally strong union.
Earlier this month, Bell Atlantic reached a settlement after only a two-day strike by the Communications Workers of America. In Connecticut last week, workers from that union rejected a contract offer by the Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation.
"C.W.A. is probably doing better than any union in the country," said Gregory Tarpinian, executive director of the Labor Research Association, a New York consulting company for unions. "They have a tremendous amount of leverage because most of the telecom companies downsized in the mid-80's and early 90's."
At U S West, the number of employees dropped to 53,000 this year, from 66,000 in 1984, the year of the company's creation. The strike found the company without enough mid-level managers to perform unionized tasks -- directory assistance, repair and installation. At the same time, the region's urban customers enjoy unprecedented choices for phone service in the deregulated environment caused by the Telecommunications Act of 1996.
Faced with a tight labor market -- unemployment in the U S West service area is nearly one percentage point below the national average of 4.5 percent -- and an increasingly competitive business environment, U S West agreed to wage increases of 10.9 percent over three years, slightly above inflation forecasts. In addition, it agreed to cut in half mandatory overtime, to a maximum of eight hours a week by January 2001.
On the most contentious issue, the company agreed to make a pay-per-performance incentive plan voluntary for eligible employees. Before the strike, the company had sought to make this plan mandatory for new workers as a way of improving efficiency and making the company more "customer friendly."
The union considered the company's final position on the pay-for-performance issue as a victory.
"Pay for performance is totally voluntary," Sue Pisha, vice president of Communications Workers of America District 7, said today, adding that the union "is not going to recommend that our members get in that plan."
But David Beigie, a U S West spokesman, called the union's acceptance of even a voluntary plan as "a breakthrough for the industry."
In a company where union workers on average earn $37,900 annually, some may go for the extra money.
The three-year contract, which also includes a 21 percent increase in pension benefits and a $500 ratification bonus, is expected to be ratified by the company's rank and file in September. Ms. Pisha said that on Sunday night, officials of the 65 striking locals "overwhelmingly" supported the new contract. All strikers are expected to back at work by midweek.
The strike affected service to about 25 million customers in 14 states. Because of automation, phone service was largely uninterrupted, though customers did encounter problems in trying to get directory assistance, new service and repairs.
Reflecting the retail nature of a telephone company, both sides in the strike sought to win public opinion with competing opinion polls and newspaper and television advertisements.
Although there was no major violence on picket lines, the company reported 130 incidents of vandalism during the 15-day strike.

HEADLINE: Not Your Grandfather's State Fair;
Leaping Llamas and Low-Cal Jams in an Agrarian Bastion

SERIES: RITES OF SUMMER: At the Fair

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: SYRACUSE, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Just next door to the display of the state's largest squash and only a flight of stairs above the room where assorted jams vied for glory, Kate Broderick struck a pose.
Her exuberantly purple gown was neither the worst nor the best of the 42 outfits worn by as many teen-agers in a fashion revue Saturday morning at the New York State Fair, but Miss Broderick, 16, of Rensselaer County, stood out nonetheless. Unlike most of the other 4-H Club girls and boys on the stage, she had not stitched, dyed, beaded or brocaded what she was wearing. 
 The totality of her accomplishment had been to purchase it for a really, really good price.
As she sidled back and forth, beaming and iridescent, an announcer explained that Miss Broderick had sought an affordable dress and had come across this one "when she was almost about to give up."
"She was stunned to find that the price was only $29.99," the announcer marveled. "She just couldn't beat it."
Intrepid shopping on a par with intricate sewing? It spoke volumes not only about the tenor of the times, but also about the way the New York State Fair has endeavored to keep pace with them.
For many city slickers familiar with state fairs only through old movies or television programs, the annual, end-of-summer events are anachronistic bastions of quaint pastoralism. To some extent, that's accurate.
The wonders of cultivation, from monstrous zucchini to mammoth swine, are still celebrated. The divine arts of pickling, canning, cookie baking and jelly making still garner intensely coveted blue ribbons.
But while the 152d New York State Fair includes cows trotted out by breeders eager to show off their livestock, it also features llamas leaping over a gradually raised bar for no purpose other than entertainment.
And while there are displays paying tribute to the homespun ingenuity behind hat decorating and flower arranging, there are also events and exhibitions honoring bicycle acrobatics, chain-saw sculpturing and, in Miss Broderick's case, keen-eyed trips down the aisles of Marshall's.
"We take everybody into account when we prepare the fair," said Peter Cappuccilli Jr., the director of the New York State Fair. "We've had to make it interesting for all people."
The numbers suggest that fair officials have succeeded. Last year, 865,000 people attended the 12-day event, second only to 1995, when 882,000 went. Those numbers represented sharp increases from the 1960's and 1970's, when attendance was usually about 500,000.
This year, the fair, which began on Thursday and ends on Monday, is on a pace to draw an all-time high of more than 900,000, state fair officials said. The fair is held every year at the permanent fairgrounds in Syracuse.
The officials estimated that less than 5 percent of today's fairgoers actually make their livelihoods from agriculture or livestock and said that New York's fair, like scores of others across the country, has evolved to reflect that.
It has become a dizzying, all-purpose entertainment extravaganza, replete this year with hard rock concerts, helicopter rides and the tedious but awe-inspiring construction of what is intended to be world's largest sand castle, which should top out at about 35 feet and more than 400 tons by the time the fair closes.
It's a kitsch-a-palooza, where people can drop by the Pan African Village to purchase lilliputian African figurines that function as refrigerator magnets, then amble over to the Center of Progress for Hawaiian-style leis of flowers they select themselves.
And it's a helter-skelter smorgasbord of such dubiously nutritious concoctions as snow cones, cotton candy, saltwater taffy and, of course, golden, greasy funnel cakes. Fried dough is to state fairs as chocolate is to Valentine's Day.
"The state fair is an orgy of consumption," said Mark Ritson, a marketing professor at the University of Minnesota who is studying state fairs. As such, Mr. Ritson said, it captures the world around it as well as it ever did.
Americans once defined themselves by what they produced, and the state fair's parade of newfangled tractors, plump tomatoes and fleecy sheep paid tribute to that. Americans now define themselves by what they purchase and consume, and the state fair exalts and indulges their ravenous, sometimes indiscriminate appetites.
State fairs began in the early 19th century as American adaptations of European harvest festivals, which reveled in the bounty of the land. They were vital to the agrarian economy, serving as trade shows for farmers who needed to familiarize themselves with the changing tools and methods of production or advertise their goods to potential customers.
But as the country industrialized and the number of small farms and farmers dwindled, state fairs were threatened with irrelevance. By the late 1980's, many state legislatures were cutting off tax money for the events and insisting that fairs become economically self-sufficient.
Joe LaGuardia, the marketing director for the New York State Fair, said it stopped receiving public money for anything but major construction work in 1990. While the fair is still its own quasi agency within the State Department of Agriculture and Markets, it now supports itself, in part through aggressive courtship of corporate sponsors. Every other pavilion or event at the fair seems to wear the tag of a company or brand name, from Coca-Cola to Pizza Hut, Mikasa to Motorola.
Fair officials have also devised ways to sell its most traditional elements to a modern audience by framing the fair as a sort of living museum, a child-friendly educational bridge to a simpler era.
The buildings devoted to cows and dairy products include not only the animals themselves, but also a painted wooden effigy at which children can mimic the task of milking, and a refrigerated sculpture of a milk deliveryman made with 1,000 pounds of butter.
There are tours of working barns that leave regularly from the fairgrounds. Matt and Linda Clark and their three sons had just returned from one when they sat down for a brief rest in the goat and swine building on Friday night.
"Most kids don't realize where everything comes from, and we learned that 98 percent of a beef cow is used for different things, not just for food," said Mr. Clark, a nuclear engineer from Parish, N.Y.
His wife nodded her agreement. "A lot of people from New York City don't know anything about this stuff," she said with more than a touch of rural pride. "They only know about the restaurants where the beef ends up."
Nostalgia draws many people to the fair. Carol Koller of Rockville Center, N.Y., came for a second year in a row and dwelled upon a jar of award-winning pickled vegetables in the Art and Home Center on Saturday morning.
"This is the way our grandparents lived," she said. "Who has the time today? Everybody runs around."
But the march of progress was evident even in the culinary judging booth just feet away, where a panel of four women size up the fruitiest pies, fluffiest cakes and fudgiest brownies.
"We have more and more low-sugar categories," said Candy Crider, a home economics teacher on the panel. "Grilled vegetables are new this year."
"That's very trendy," chimed in another judge, Carol Bradford.
The judges were in a delicate mood, for it was jam and jelly day, not among their favorites.
"It's so sweet and unrelenting," said Ms. Bradford, who received a nutrition degree from Cornell University and studied at the Cordon Bleu in Paris, as she steered her plastic spoon toward a paper plate with several gelatinous smears.
Some of the jam entries had to be eliminated at the outset. "One of the rules is that we won't eat anything that has a foreign object in it, like hair or debris from the kitchen," Ms. Bradford said.
"Those are the ones we can identify," said Ms. Crider, who clucked appreciatively over a blueberry-spearmint entry in the "herb jelly or jam" category and a cranberry-jalapeno melange in the "favorite jelly" field.
Still to come was Spam day, rewarding the contestant who uses the processed luncheon meat in the most ingeniously delectable fashion with a $100 prize from Hormel Foods and the chance to compete in the company's national Spam contest. One year, the contest was won by someone who used Spam in a chocolate cake.
Also ahead was the macaroni and cheese bake-off, which Sharon Potucek of Skaneateles, N.Y., a regular fairgoer who was hovering near the judging area on Saturday morning, said she was hoping to win. "You can do a lot with macaroni and cheese," said Ms. Potucek, an office manager for a heating fuel company. "And I'm not telling you what I'm doing."
She said that in a new twist for her fair-obsessed family, she and her husband were competing against each other, and not just in one cateogry. Both were submitting macaroni and cheese dishes and fruit pies. "I think we're headed for divorce," Ms. Potucek said.
But for every fairgoer who approaches the event with the utmost seriousness, there are several who revel in its sheer goofiness. Events like the leaping llamas, staged on Friday night to a recording of the Pointer Sisters song "Jump," cater shamelessly to that crowd.
"What you have to do is pick out your favorite llama and cheer 'em on to victory," explained Valerie Podet, a graduate student in geology at the State University of New York at Buffalo. Ms. Podet had a special interest in the outcome; her department chairman, Michael Sheridan, owned one of the llamas in the contest.
One by one, the serene beasts of burden, several of them shorn and groomed to look like gargantuan poodles, were led on leashes toward a horizontal wooden pole. Some simply planted their feet and refused to budge. Some blithely barged into the bar.
Mr. Sheridan's llama did fine at 28 and 30 inches, but failed at 32. By 36 inches, the field of about a dozen llamas had been narrowed to two, and "Jump" was on its third or fourth replay. The winning height was 40 inches, nearly as high as the triumphant llama's back.
There were peals of laughter, hoots of delight and robust applause. Then the 200 spectators scattered into the night. Candied apples, laser tag games, a live shark exhibit and a show by the Wallflowers, part of the Molson Concert Series, awaited them.
 
Rites of Summer
Previous articles in this series have looked at the emerging motorcycle culture in Manhattan, visiting day at a sleepaway camp, the West Indian sport of netball, a religious tent revival in Queens and a marina in the Bronx.
