HEADLINE: Tax Takes a Holiday for Some Back-to-School Shoppers

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
In a back-to-school gift to shoppers and retailers, the fourth tax-free shopping week in the last two years begins today in New York State, with state sales taxes eliminated on all clothing and shoes costing less than $500.
New York City has suspended its own tax as well, meaning that through next Monday, city shoppers will not have to pay the normal 8.25 percent in sales tax on most types of apparel. The reprieve is intended in part to keep shoppers from taking their business elsewhere, as lower-tax states like New Jersey have often drawn people at peak shopping times like the holidays and before the opening of school. 
 Some retailers are worried, however, that the recent turmoil on Wall Street and other factors may undermine the impact of this week's tax cut.
"During past tax-free shopping weeks, United Colors of Benetton stores citywide saw a dramatic surge in sales," said Carlo Tunioli, general manager of Benetton U.S.A. "However, this tax-free shopping week may be impacted by the recent instability in the financial markets and the unrelenting hot weather, making customers reluctant to shop and thereby affecting a normally profitable sales period."
The 8.25 percent sales tax in New York City is made up of three components: a 4 percent state sales tax, a 4 percent city sales tax, and a 0.25 percent tax levied by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. During the last legislative session, lawmakers approved the gradual elimination of the state's sales tax on certain clothing.
Under the measure, the state share of the sales tax on clothing will be eliminated on clothing and footwear for items under $500 from Jan. 17 to 24, 1999, and will be permanently eliminated for clothing and footwear sold for less than $110 beginning Dec. 1, 1999. .
Ethel Sloan, marketing director of the Manhattan Mall, at Broadway and 33d Street, said that past tax-free weeks have drawn a sharp increase in shoppers. "We are anticipating an extremely strong response," Ms. Sloan said. "The past times we have had the tax-free week, our retailers have reported substantial increased traffic and sales, particularly stores like Modell's, Children's Place and Express."
The accounting and consulting firm KPMG Peat Marwick, which has studied past tax-free weeks, has forecast that retail sales volume in New York City would rise 125 percent during the week, in part because of normal back-to-school shopping. The figure was higher than the increase in sales in 1997, in part because of an improved economy and the inclusion of footware as a tax-free purchase, the firm said.
The firm also noted in its report of January's tax-free week that the tax reprieve prompted additional spending on taxable items while consumers were purchasing clothing, shoes and other items. This week, the items that are still taxable include watches, umbrellas, Rollerblades, sunglasses, handbags and helmets, among other items.
Not all cities in New York State are following the state's lead in suspending taxes for the week. The local 2 percent sales tax in White Plains remains in effect, though shoppers will still get a break on the state taxes.
Elliott Ettenberg, chief executive of Bozell Retail Advertising, said the tax elimination was a great boon to parents shopping for school supplies for their children. "If you do the math, at back-to-school time alone, the city loses $40 per child -- that's the cost of another outfit," he said.
"It's a mistake to have this tax at all," he said. "The city should get its tax money from hotel taxes, from the visitors who are clogging the city, instead of hurting the people who live here."
The tax-free week started symbolically on Sunday when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani knocked down a stack of milk bottles with "tax" printed on them and then went shopping at Modell's in midtown.
"We have already seen a sharp increase in the sales of both footware and apparel during tax-free shopping week, especially with the New York Yankees merchandise line," said Michael Modell, president of Modell's Sporting Goods.

HEADLINE: Russia on the Verge

 BODY:
Boris Yeltsin's hastily arranged deal with the Communists last weekend was troubling, but Sunday night's sudden collapse of their bargain could prove even worse. Its first negative consequence was yesterday's parliamentary rebuff to Mr. Yeltsin's nominee for prime minister, Viktor Chernomyrdin. Russia is left without a government at a moment when urgent action is needed to check the country's vertiginous financial free fall. A prolonged vacuum in Moscow could fracture the geographically sprawling Russian Republic.
Such a troubled country would be an uncertain environment for a politically healthy American leader. President Clinton, in his weakened state, runs the risk of appearing ineffective and surrounded by chaos wherever he turns. Yet, having chosen not to postpone his trip, Mr. Clinton will have to address the crisis that will swirl around him in Moscow. He must speak forthrightly to the Russian people and to Russia's riven political leadership. 
 Yesterday's 253-to-94 parliamentary vote against Mr. Chernomyrdin is part of a bargaining process that could still produce agreement between Mr. Yeltsin and the Communist-dominated legislature. The Communist leader, Gennadi Zyuganov, rejected the political truce his subordinates worked out because he feared that once Mr. Chernomyrdin was confirmed, Mr. Yeltsin might renege on his commitment to yield some presidential powers. Mr. Chernomyrdin has two more chances to be confirmed before Mr. Yeltsin can call new parliamentary elections. The Communists presumably will use these votes to bargain for firmer guarantees.
But Russia has no time for such gamesmanship. Confidence in the ruble and the Government's ability to pay its obligations, including salaries, is near zero. Private foreign investors are pulling out. Russia needs infusions of money from Western governments, but they are saying that no new help will be forthcoming until Russia has a stable government with a serious economic program.
The most urgent task facing the next Russian government is not repaying foreign bankers or politically powerful domestic tycoons. It must regain the confidence of Russia's people, many of whom, including soldiers and nuclear scientists, have not been paid in months. Assuaging their anger will require the cooperation of all three elements battling for power in Russia -- Communists, business barons and Western-oriented reformers. All stand to lose if the current disintegration proceeds. They need to coordinate their efforts under the leadership of Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Chernomyrdin to pull Russia back from the precipice.
This is primarily a challenge for Russian politicians. But Mr. Clinton, while there, should take every opportunity to encourage the Russian people and tell Russian leaders that they can no longer look to Western bailouts as a way to avoid fundamental economic challenges at home. If Mr. Clinton cannot command the respect that once was his, he can at least mix reassurance with necessary candor.

INTERNATIONAL A3-12
 
Parliament Rejects Yeltsin's Choice
Russia's Parliament emphatically rejected President Boris N. Yeltsin's choice of Viktor S. Chernomyrdin for Prime Minister after an acrimonious debate, leaving the nation virtually rudderless in the midst of its deepening economic crisis.A1 

Although the vote against the confirmation of Mr. Chernomyrdin came as no surprise -- after the Communist opposition pulled back from a power-sharing agreement that would have salvaged his candidacy -- there was a striking lack of urgency about the debate. A11
 
President Clinton's visit to Moscow for a summit meeting with President Yeltsin was met with indifference by many Russians. A11
 
North Korea Launches Missile
North Korea fired a two-stage ballistic missile that crossed northeastern Japan, which strongly protested the action. The test added to the apprehension about security in the region by suggesting that North Korea had increased the range of its missiles.
 A6
 
North Korea's test of a medium-range missile capable of reaching targets in Japan and beyond represents a technological breakthrough that has raised new fears about the spread of ballistic missiles, said Administration officials and arms control experts. A6
 
Holocaust Laborers File Suit
Lawyers in the United States and Germany have filed a class-action suit against Germany's biggest industrial companies on behalf of workers forced into slave labor during Hitler's regime. The outcome of the suit could amount to billions of dollars being paid by companies like Daimler-Benz, Volkswagen, BMW and Siemens. A9
 
Latin American Markets Drop
Markets and currencies across Latin America are sinking as panicky investors retreat to the safe haven of American treasury bonds and dollars. But because most of the underlying economies are solid, the international financial crisis might have little effect in Latin America, economists and analysts said. A3
 
Uncertainty for Panama
Panama's presidential politics were thrown into a free-for-all after voters defeated a proposal that would have amended the Constitution to allow President Ernesto Perez Balladares to serve five more years and thereby control the Panama Canal when the United States relinquishes the waterway at the end of next year. A8

The I.R.A. also rejected demands that it disarm soon and declare an end to its war against British sovereignty. A12

Public Service Made Mandatory
The Chicago public school system has become the largest district in the nation to require students to perform community service to receive a high school diploma, starting with this year's sophomore class. The students will need to spend at least 40 hours in public service, like tutoring young people or helping the elderly, during high school, and submit an essay, a video project, an oral report on their experience. HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN RUSSIA: THE SUMMIT;
Moscow Mood: What if They Ascended a Summit and No One Cared

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Russia's top network news program, "Vremya," led off tonight with Parliament's rejection of Viktor S. Chernomyrdin as Prime Minister, the ruble's continued wobbliness and the anniversary of Diana's death. Then it flagged fascinating plans by Muslim extremists for several villages in rural Dagestan.
And oh, yes -- the President of the United States arrives Tuesday morning for a summit meeting with the President of Russia, Boris N. Yeltsin. That item was relegated to the second half of the newscast. 
 Such meetings used to be called summits for a reason. One can harken to Reykjavik, where Reagan and Gorbachev nearly disarmed, or Vienna, where Khrushchev took Kennedy to the woodshed, or even Washington, where Mr. Yeltsin ascended to the world stage on the arm of George Bush.
It would hardly be fair to call the latest meeting a nadir. There still are important issues to chew on. But in Russia, at least, it is close to a non-event.
Four newspapers published Monday issues in Moscow (most newspapers take the day off), including two serious journals, Sevodnya and Komsomolskaya Pravda. Not one mentioned the next day's meeting -- not merely on page 1, but anywhere.
"There's no enthusiasm," said Sergei Karaganov, a foreign policy specialist and sometime adviser to Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov. "It's not an issue for the simple reason that there are more important issues on the agenda. Most people, even in the political class, do not even suspect or remember that there is a meeting."
Indeed, the most spirited comment on the summit meeting came today from Russia's wildest-eyed nationalist, Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, who said people with Russia's high moral standards had no business meeting "with a man who cannot settle his relations with a secretary."
To an extent, Russians can be excused for their indifference. In the judgment of most experts, the country is in its worst political crisis since 1993, when Mr. Yeltsin's tanks shelled Parliament to put down a rebellion, and perhaps since the Soviet Union dissolved in 1991.
The great national issues these days, discussed everywhere, are the number of rubles a dollar will buy and the odds of a civil war or a putsch.
Mr. Clinton's arrival seems trivial in comparison, especially since he has little but moral support to lend Russia's democrats after their calamitous seven-year experiment with capitalism.
Mr. Clinton's three-day visit will cover the usual bases, from international terrorism to the spread of nuclear weapons to disarmament. To average Russians -- indeed, to Russia's Parliament and much of its executive branch -- none of them hold a candle right now to the 40 percent rise in the cost of cooking oil at local markets or their almost complete inability to tap savings accounts at the neighborhood bank.
For Mr. Clinton this visit is also a comedown.
His advisers first held out the meeting as a glittering prize for Russia should it finally ratify the Start 2 nuclear weapons treaty. Unfortunately, the get-togethers are not so prized anymore, and the Communist-controlled Parliament was more than happy to let the treaty languish, even if it kept Mr. Clinton out of town.
And so the President's trip has been recast primarily as an economic pep talk for Mr. Yeltsin and his troops, urging them to stay the agonizing course to free-market prosperity.
"What I want to do is to go there and tell them that the easy thing to do is not the right thing to do," Mr. Clinton said today in Virginia, in an apparent reference to alternatives to capitalism. "The easy thing to do would be to go back to the way they did it before, and it's not possible."
If there is a problem with this message, it is that Russians have heard it several times from virtually every Western leader, and with the ruble's drop of nearly 40 percent this month alone, it may be starting to ring a bit false.
The West may have had the best of intentions, Mr. Karaganov, the policy specialist, said today, but its advice and Mr. Yeltsin's Western-trained advisers "have brought about the total collapse of the economy and effectively bankrupted most of the Russian bourgeoisie in the last few days."
As so the little summit news that is playing in Moscow this week, on talk radio and even in some newspapers, is more often the refrain sung this afternoon by Kazbek Tzikou, a Communist legislator from the depressed southern region of Kuban.
"Yeltsin stands over everyone like a cobra and forces them to do what his friend Bill wants," Mr. Tzikou told the lower house of Parliament today. "Tell Clinton not to come. People would tear him to pieces if they could. Let him go to the moon with his advice and his dollars."
Nothing personal, of course. "Tell the American people that we wish peace and accord with them," Mr. Tzikou added.

HEADLINE: Many Ways Seen to Ease Property Tax

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
The State Property Tax Commission, created by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman after her narrow re-election victory last fall, has agreed on dozens of recommendations intended to lower real estate taxes in New Jersey.
At the Governor's request, the commission did not consider statewide tax increases to offset property tax bills, but panel members said one proposal would give the state's largest cities and towns new taxing authority. 
 Instead of relying on property levies alone, municipalities might be able to raise revenue by taxing parking, payrolls, hotels or even entertainment and sporting events. The recommendation would require approval by the State Legislature, where word of the proposal has already met with some skepticism.
The panel is also expected to recommend placing a cap on the salaries of school, municipal and county employees, a proposal that is guaranteed to draw strong union opposition. Other suggestions include state incentives for local governments to share services and having the state pick up the $200 million cost of New Jersey's 21 county prosecutor offices.
During her hard-fought campaign last year, Governor Whitman vowed to tackle the issue after polls showed that voters did not think she had answered their concerns about paying the highest property taxes in the nation.
The 24-member panel, made up of local and state government officials, as well as business and academic leaders, is expected to outline its recommendations to Governor Whitman early in September. Many of the suggestions would require legislative action, panel members said.
While some panel members said there was no single suggestion that would immediately deliver significant property tax relief, they also said that the recommendations, taken together, could reduce property tax bills over time.
The commission is expected to point out that New Jersey's longstanding tradition of home rule, including the reluctance of communities and school districts to share costs and control, is one of the biggest reasons property tax bills are so high. The report notes the hundreds of layers of local government: 566 municipal governments, 21 county governments, 188 fire districts and 611 school districts.
"There are no easy answers," said Barbara Cannon, the Mayor of Old Bridge Township and chairwoman of the commission. "Nothing is simple. There are going to have to be some choices made here."
One possible solution was off limits, at Mrs. Whitman's request: a statewide tax increase. "We did not want to increase the state's overall tax burden," Ms. Cannon said.
New Jerseyans pay the highest per-capita property taxes in the nation. The average property tax bill for homeowners is $4,000 a year, with public schools taking the largest chunk of that money. The state covers about 40 percent of the cost of local schools; the national average of state assistance to public schools is 50 percent of the total cost.
Although some experts say that significantly increasing state aid, particularly to schools, would be the most direct way to reduce local property taxes, New Jersey voters have already voiced their disapproval of that approach.
Former Gov. Jim Florio was widely criticized for pushing through a state income tax increase in 1990 to bolster state assistance for local schools and provide property tax relief. He lost his re-election campaign three years later to Mrs. Whitman, who promised to roll back the income tax rate increases. She kept her promise in her first term, but critics contend that she helped pay for part of the tax cut by not increasing state aid to municipalities.
In addition to offering specific suggestions, the commission's recommendations are also intended to raise awareness among taxpayers about the cost of various programs and policy decisions, particularly those concerning land use.
The panel is expected to issue a warning to municipalities about the high cost of some new development projects. For years, cities and towns embraced development to expand their property tax bases, but the panel notes that unchecked development can often end up adding to the tax burden of municipalities and school districts.
The panel is also expected to urge municipalities to follow the state's master development plan when making land-use decisions. The plan tries to guide growth away from environmentally sensitive and rural areas to parts of the state with existing roads and sewers that can support new development.
Since many of the commission's recommendations would require action by the State Legislature, some lobbying groups, including the state's largest teachers' union, are already preparing for battle.
Karen Joseph, a spokeswoman for that union, New Jersey Education Association, said the association did not think that the best approach to lowering property taxes was capping public employees' salaries, as the panel suggests. "We would be opposed to such a move," she said.
In the Legislature, it remains uncertain which recommendations are likely to win the backing of state lawmakers.
"There is not a silver-bullet solution to this," said Assemblyman Richard H. Bagger, a Republican from Westfield and chairman of the Assembly Appropriations and Budget Committee.
"It is a combination of a lot of different ideas," Mr. Bagger said. "But I am a dedicated incrementalist. And I am very confident that there will be a series of proposals that the Legislature can act upon and that will have some positive benefits for property taxpayers."
Assemblyman Joseph J. Roberts Jr., a Democrat who has been long involved in state fiscal matters, said he agreed with some of the recommendations that have been made public, particularly those urging local governments and school districts to consolidate some services. "I have tried to keep an open mind until I see a final document," he said.
But Mr. Roberts, whose legislative district includes the troubled city of Camden, said he was concerned about the recommendation that would allow cities and large municipalities to impose new taxes.
"It skirts the issue, which is the over-reliance on property taxes," Mr. Roberts said. "That is what is plaguing a place like Camden. If you have a community that is going to place greater burdens on the people who live there and work there, it is only going to cause businesses and residents to flee."
A few cities -- Newark, Elizabeth, and Jersey City -- already have authorization from the State Legislature to impose some levies beyond property taxes, including payroll and parking taxes. The recommendation would allow those cities to expand their taxing authority and enable other large municipalities to impose new taxes. In some cases municipalities may look to shift the burden from residents to people who work or visit but who do not live there.
Newark's Mayor, Sharpe James, said that he welcomed the recommendation because it would give cities more flexibility and help relieve the tax burden on residential property owners. "There has been a shrinking residential base," Mr. James said. "You are talking about helping those brave souls who have not abandoned the cities."
At the same time, Mr. James said that Newark and other cities had to be careful about not imposing any taxes that would hurt the city's economic development efforts.
State Senator Joseph M. Kyrillos Jr., a Republican from Middletown Township and a member of the Senate budget committee, said that the property tax problem, in some ways, was similar to the automobile insurance problem that lawmakers tackled earlier in the year. After much discussion and debate, the Legislature finally approved a package of bills earlier this year that was intended to lower auto insurance rates.
"There is really no easy answer to this," Mr. Kyrillos said. "With auto insurance, you had to change the product to change the cost. With property taxes, we may not be able to afford all the government that we now have. We are going to have to make some real choices, and hopefully, people will allow us, and encourage us, to make those types of choices."

HEADLINE: Transportation Secretary Calls for Meeting in Pilots' Strike

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 31

 BODY:
At the request of President Clinton, Transportation Secretary Rodney E. Slater asked officials of Northwest Airlines and its striking pilots union today to meet with him in Washington on Tuesday.
Mr. Clinton has the power to order the pilots back to work for a 60-day cooling-off period, but the chief Federal mediator, who is responsible for recommending such action, said she did not think such an order would be a good idea now. 
 Northwest today canceled all its flights for Wednesday and some international flights for Thursday as the strike by its 6,173 pilots went into its third day with no movement by either side.
No negotiations were scheduled, as both sides stuck to their final stances before the walkout.
Mr. Clinton called on both sides to "redouble their efforts to resolve their differences," but said, "it is up to the negotiating parties to reach an agreement."
Northwest said its chief executive, John H. Dasburg, planned to meet with Mr. Slater. A spokesman for the union, the Air Line Pilots Association, said the union's president, J. Randolph Babbitt, would also attend.
The Transportation Department emphasized that the meeting was not a resumption of the negotiations.
"The Secretary has called Babbitt and Dasburg to meet with him to explain why the negotiations are not going on right now when both sides have said they want to talk," said an official who insisted on anonymity.
Mr. Slater, who met today with Erskine B. Bowles, the White House chief of staff, is being careful not to press the two sides too hard to return to the table because Magdalena G. Jacobsen, the Federal mediator who has been supervising the talks, and who briefed him today, believes that further negotiations when neither side is willing to compromise would be counterproductive, and might even prolong a strike.
"What is the point of pulling people together if there is nothing to talk about?" Ms. Jacobsen, who is chairwoman of the National Mediation Board, a Federal agency that oversees labor matters in the airline and rail industries, said in an interview today. A meeting now could relieve some of the pressure on both sides without advancing the negotiations, she said, and it could also anger workers at the airline by raising false hopes of a settlement.
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, criticized President Clinton today for not intervening, saying that the strike had already caused serious economic damage. The President has the power to order the pilots back to work while an emergency board tries to resolve the strike. Mr. Clinton used that power last year, when pilots walked out at American Airlines.
But Ms. Jacobsen, who is responsible for making the recommendation of intervention to the White House, said she did not think it was a good idea now because the pilots could simply reject the emergency board's proposal and walk out again in two months, on the eve of the Thanksgiving holiday. "What we are interested in is a resolution that translates into a contract," she said.
Northwest said today that as the strike continues it would cancel flights 48 hours in advance. The carrier is still hoping that the White House will order the pilots back to work before the busy Labor Day weekend, -- though the prospect is fading given Ms. Jacobsen's remarks -- and so it does not want to cancel flights too far in advance.
Disruption from the strike, which was anticipated for more than a month before the pilots walked out early Saturday, was lighter than expected over the weekend, but it became more serious as business travelers faced their first day without the airline. "We are facing a much bigger challenge rebooking our passengers," a Northwest spokesman said.
The airline, which is the country's fourth largest carrier, reiterated its negotiating stance in a teleconference with Wall Street analysts today. It said that it was willing to pay its pilots as much as their counterparts at Northwest's three larger competitors -- United Airlines, a unit of the UAL Corporation; American Airlines, a unit of the AMR Corporation, and Delta Air Lines -- but that the pilots' demand for an "industry-leading" contract would cost too much and would compel Northwest to give equally generous increases to five other unions that are negotiating contracts.
Northwest is offering a 9 percent raise over four years, a lump sum of $57 million, the reduction of a two-tier pay scale to three years from five years, and profit sharing.
The pilots say the package will still pay them less than what pilots receive at the other airlines. They want a 15.5 percent pay increase over three years, a lump sum of $86 million, elimination of the two-tier wage structure and greater job security.
The pilots say the difference between the two sides amounts to $70 million a year, but the airline told analysts that it believed the number was closer to $170 million
Northwest also said that it was losing $10 million to $15 million a day as a result of the strike. Kevin C. Murphy, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, estimated that the company lost $250 million in the month leading up to the walkout because passengers fearing a strike booked flights on competing airlines.
Citing these and other factors, Standard & Poor's, the bond rating agency, said today that it would take a closer look at Northwest's credit rating and possibly downgrade it.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Northwest Airlines luggage counters at Detroit Metropolitan Airport were closed yesterday as a pilots' strike continued into its third day. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Taking a Political Detour, Unions Shift Into Neutral

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 31

 BODY:
About this time in election years, the political gears of New York's powerful labor unions begin turning -- grinding out mailings, setting up phone banks, organizing rallies and issuing endorsements. In statewide elections, those blessings are usually bestowed on Democrats.
But in the governor's race this year, the unions have been mostly silent, and many labor leaders say they will remain neutral. Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, spent his first 18 months in office in pitched battles with unions. But over the last two years, he has effectively neutralized the unions. That has not only denied the Democrats one of their most potent allies, but has also given Mr. Pataki a tactical advantage in not having to defend against a well-financed and organized attack from labor. 
 There is still no political love fest between labor and Mr. Pataki. But union leaders have calculated that the Governor is almost certain to win re-election and that going to war with him would be pointless and would harm their future dealings with him.
Labor chiefs have concluded, warily, that Mr. Pataki is someone they can work with. They point out that since 1996, Mr. Pataki has eased up on budget cutting and has signed a handful of labor-friendly bills.
"This Governor has a lot of drawbacks, but he's trying, and we're trying to work with him," said Danny Donohue, president of the Civil Service Employees Association of New York, which represents 265,000 state and local government workers.
But underlying such judgments is the calculation that a popular governor is too powerful an enemy to make.
"That's certainly a consideration and I'm not going to deny that," said Roger E. Benson, president of the 53,000-member New York State Public Employees Federation, a union of white-collar state workers that does not plan to make an endorsement in the race. "We have to maintain a relationship with the Governor. We're not interested in being at war."
Alan Lubin, executive vice president of the 400,000-member New York State United Teachers, said: "Some unions endorse an incumbent, or stay out of it, because they know he's going to win. Why waste your money when you can have more of an impact in close races that you can make a difference in?"
Zenia Mucha, Mr. Pataki's campaign manager, argued that labor leaders view the Governor more favorably because "they've decided that the Governor's policies are working for their members."
"The basic factor is that more of their members are working," she said. "The Governor's been able to improve the economy, where union members are now employed."
Many union officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, say they prefer Peter F. Vallone, a Democrat, to Mr. Pataki, but do not think he can win. Mr. Vallone, the New York City Council speaker, is a leading candidate for the Democratic nomination for governor.
A handful of unions, including the Buffalo Teachers Federation, are in the Vallone camp. But leaders of many of the state's largest and most politically active unions say their groups will probably not make an endorsement in the governor's race. Mr. Donohue said his group might actually endorse the Governor. The state A.F.L.-C.I.O., representing 2.5 million union members, is likely to remain neutral in the governor's race, according to several of its board members.
District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the umbrella organization for 120,000 New York City employees, is working for Mr. Vallone in the Democratic primary, but Stanley Hill, the council's president, said he was unsure whether it would play a role in the general election.
Kevin McCabe, Mr. Vallone's campaign manager, contended that the unions' neutrality is actually a sign of the Governor's weakness.
"If you're this powerful incumbent and things are going so well, why isn't labor out there endorsing him?" he asked. "By definition, some of the public employee unions aren't going to go with us because they've got to work with the other guy to negotiate a contract. But they can't go to their members with Pataki's record and convince people that he's the right person."
Of course, Mr. Pataki is not the first politician whose power and popularity have discouraged potential antagonists from taking sides. Business groups that disliked Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a Democrat, were loath to take him on at the height of his popularity.
Mr. Pataki's one-time mentor, United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, has proved to be an expert at co-opting his opponents. But Mr. D'Amato, who has less direct power than the Governor to influence the issues labor cares most about, has not managed to silence unions the way Mr. Pataki has.
"Right now, I'd probably guess we're going to come out against D'Amato, go with whoever wins the Democratic primary" in the Senate race, said Ed Cleary, president of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O.
Another Republican, New York Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who never had the fierce fights with unions that Mr. Pataki did, was endorsed by District Council 37 when he ran for re-election last year, while the United Federation of Teachers was neutral.
Lately, the Governor's relations with unions have seemed downright cozy. He was invited to speak earlier this month at the annual state A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention, where he gave as rousing a pro-labor speech as any old-time liberal, declaring, "I value what you do."
The Governor has also been invited to march in the front row of this year's Labor Day parade in Manhattan, a first for him.
In 1995, his first year in office, Mr. Pataki did battle with unions over his proposals for deep cuts in state spending. He eventually won enough trims to force the elimination of 20,000 jobs. He came under a harsh union attack, including a television ad campaign, that hurt his popularity in polls.
In 1996, there was a new round of budget cutting and clashes, and the Governor set out to outlaw a class of lawsuits stemming from workers' compensation cases, again running into stiff opposition from labor before a compromise was reached.
Later that year, Mr. Pataki reached out to labor as he sought support for his $1.75 billion environmental bond act. Unions enthusiastically supported the measure, the first real thaw in their relationship with the Governor.
Since then, with the state running record surpluses, Mr. Pataki has allowed spending to grow rather than proposing the kind of cuts that threaten union members' jobs and wages. He has also expanded programs dear to the unions, including state-funded day care and health care for poor children.
This year, the Governor signed into law an increase in unemployment benefits for all workers and an increase in pensions for retired state employees, measures that had been avidly sought by labor.
He also vetoed $800 million in spending approved by the Legislature, much of it for programs unions had fought for, including supplementing teacher salaries, building housing for the mentally retarded and accelerating the expansion of day care for low-income families. Still, the budget increased more than 8 percent this year over last, with enough money to keep nearly everyone content. Democrats' efforts to stir up anger over the vetoes failed to get much of a response, or much assistance from the unions.
Some union leaders, speaking on the condition of anonymity, express fear that Mr. Pataki's conversion to moderation is one of convenience, meant to win him re-election and perhaps endear him to labor if he runs for president in 2000. Others say they think that in an economic slowdown, the Governor would return to his old budget-cutting ways.
"We think the Governor's trying to move more toward the center," said Mr. Donohue, president of the civil service union. "All the political pundits can argue about why, but we're hoping it's a permanent move."

HEADLINE: Queens Rivals to Meet Again in Primary for Assembly

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
When Pauline R. Cummings was selected by Queens Democratic Party leaders as their candidate in a special election for an Assembly seat five months ago, she was backed by the party's elected officials in that borough.
Despite that support, her victory in the race -- to fill the Assembly seat vacated when Gregory W. Meeks was elected to Congress -- was a surprisingly slender one. Only 211 votes separated her from her closest rival in a four-person race. 
 Now, in an eagerly watched contest in the Democratic primary, Ms. Cummings is running against the man who came close to snatching that victory.
In part, the primary will be a test of the might of the Queens Democratic organization that has officially embraced her. But it is also being watched because it has the potential of illustrating the continued vitality of the black church in the local political process.
Ms. Cummings's opponent is the Rev. Evan D. Gray, a 29-year-old Baptist minister who is the pastor of a church in Far Rockaway. Mr. Gray showed his electoral strength in the special election not only by drawing nearly as many votes as Ms. Cummings, but also by doing so as a candidate on the Liberal Party line in the overwhelmingly Democratic 31st Assembly District, which includes the neighborhoods of South Ozone Park, Richmond Hill, Springfield Gardens and, across Jamaica Bay, Far Rockaway, which accounts for the bulk of the district's voters.
Once again, Ms. Cummings, 53, has the support of the Queens Democratic organization and its chairman, Representative Thomas J. Manton, as well as the City Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, and her predecessor in the Assembly, Mr. Meeks.
But Mr. Gray is not without support himself. He is the pastor of the Macedonia Baptist Church, which has a congregation of more than 500, an overwhelming number of whom live within the Assembly district. He has also been endorsed by the Rev. Al Sharpton and one or two union locals. Moreover, Mr. Gray has been the beneficiary of support, all given surreptitiously, from a few Queens politicians who do not want their assistance to become public.
Although both candidates have had several years of involvement in civic and community organizations in the Far Rockaway section of the 31st Assembly District, they are both new to politics.
A bookkeeper in the Manhattan garment district for nearly 30 years, Ms. Cummings has also been the chairwoman of the economic development committee of her local community board. Her principal political benefactor is City Councilwoman Juanita E. Watkins, who approachedMs. Cummings about running for the Assembly seat.
When asked to discuss the issues she considered most important, Ms. Cummings cited education and economic development. Her goal, she said, is to meet with city and state education officials "to see how we can best elevate the level of schooling."
Her five months in Albany, Ms. Cummings said, have been active ones in which she was a co-sponsor of two bills. "I spend a lot of my time talking with my constituents," she said. "I listen to their needs, so that when I get back to Albany, I will know what they want me to do."
Mr. Gray started a civic association in the Arverne section of the Rockaway peninsula and is on the board of a local hospital. Through his church, Mr. Gray has developed a number of programs, some for young people and others for low-income residents.
If Ms. Cummings speaks of the district's needs in broad brush strokes, Mr. Gray examines them with an eye toward details. Driving through the district in his black Grand Marquis on a recent morning, Mr. Gray pointed to everything, from the need to repair a bulkhead along a section of Jamaica Bay to controlling the mosquito population to installing drainage systems in some streets in the district.
It is not that Ms. Cummings is ineffective, he suggests, but merely that he would be more diligent.
"To be honest, I don't have anything negative to say about her," Mr. Gray said. "I just think I'm better for the job because I am a community leader."
His major campaign theme has been the need for jobs in a district where the unemployment level is higher than the city's average.
"I want to sit down with major corporations and entice them to do business in the 31st Assembly District," Mr. Gray said. "We have a lot of vacant land for companies to use for their businesses."
Mr. Gray uses as his model the campaigns of the Rev. Floyd H. Flake, whose resignation from Congress last year opened the way for Mr. Meeks's campaign for the Congressional seat. "We don't have the support of the Democratic organization," he said, "but we'll have the support of the people of the district."
Mr. Gray's predictions have not been widely shared by Queens Democratic politicians, who say that the party's support, coupled with the active involvement of several large unions, will make Ms. Cummings the more formidable candidate.
"He's popular and he's been active and he's a lifelong resident of the peninsula," said Mr. Meeks, who represented the district in the Assembly for five years and is endorsing Ms. Cummings. "He's not someone to be sneezed at.
"For that reason," he added, "Pauline must work hard. But she has shown in a short time that she does have the people's concerns at heart. That needs to be rewarded with her re-election. In the meantime, it will be an active campaign in this district."

HEADLINE: Union Pacific to Limit Traffic on Its Tracks

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Aug. 31

 BODY:
The Union Pacific Corporation, still recovering from some of the worst congestion in the industry's history, announced a plan today to improve and, in some cases, ration its service.
Even as the railroad makes extensive investments for expansion, executives acknowledged that the company would not be able to reliably, or profitably, accommodate all that want to use its tracks. 
 Richard K. Davidson, the railroad's chairman, stressed his primary goal was to recover the 10 percent of its traffic lost in the last year -- not chase customers away.
"Rationing the business really isn't the main underpinning of what we're getting at here," he said in an interview. "It's how can we best satisfy our customers and maximize the potential for revenue growth."
But Union Pacific is beginning to study what sorts of traffic might be dispensable, or whether to charge more for shipments through crowded corridors at peak seasons, just as airlines would charge the most for a last-minute seat before Christmas.
The railroad plans to organize a new department to make sure its eager marketers do not sign up business and make commitments train operators cannot reliably fulfill.
"It's a more educated approach than we've ever taken before," Mr. Davidson said. "In the old days, when the marketing guys brought business in, whichever wheel squeaked the loudest would get attention."
The tie-ups were chiefly a result of Union Pacific's difficulties in absorbing the Southern Pacific Transportation Corporation, which it bought for $5.4 billion in 1996 to form the nation's largest railroad.
Having then tried to centralize its vast system at an Omaha command center, the railroad recently reversed itself and began farming some operations back out to the regions, appointing three regional vice presidents.
As Union Pacific heads into its own busiest season, with fall grain harvests and Christmas merchandise shipments, the congestion is only gradually easing. Improvements in Texas and elsewhere have raised average speeds throughout the 36,000-mile system to 15 miles an hour, from less than 12 in December, the company reported today.
But continued delays with shipments of chemicals, lumber, agricultural feed and other products in California are keeping speeds below the railroad's 18- or 19-mile-an-hour standard.
 After decades of cutbacks in the industry, Union Pacific is bent on expanding along with the economy as the amount of cargo grows. The company is adding about 550 locomotives over two years to a fleet now at 7,200, and building additional tracks through crowded corridors in states like Nebraska. It has agreed to buy back a track in Kansas it sold and maintain a mountainous route in Colorado it was planning to abandon.
But, as railroad executives like to say, you cannot build the church for Easter. "We've certainly learned the hard way that the days of seemingly unlimited capacity are behind us, and before we sign a contract we'd better be careful," said John Bromley, a company spokesman. "That's a sea change in our thinking. We can't be all things to all people."
Ed Rastatter, a policy director for the National Industrial Transportation League, said some well-planned rationing might be preferable to the unplanned rationing that resulted from the railroad's congestion. Noting he had not seen the Union Pacific announcement, he expressed doubts about whether all customers would benefit.
"This seems like a way of leaving out the little guy to make sure the big guy gets better service," he said. Mr. Davidson, however, said his railroad planned to carry additional smaller shipments as well, adding that chemical companies would continue to be major elements of his company's business.
Randy Speight, the Chemical Manufacturers Association distribution manager, said Union Pacific had already unsnarled its traffic around Houston, an industry hub.
But with tie-ups elsewhere on the rail system, he said, "It's like squeezing a water balloon. The danger is that it's going to flood back to the original problem area."
The Surface Transportation Board, criticized by many shippers for approving the Southern Pacific acquisition, lifted an emergency order in July that had required Union Pacific to share its Texas tracks with competitors.
A board spokesman said today that nobody there would have a comment on the company's latest plans.

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: WALL STREET;
Losses Pile Up On Wall Street As Markets Keep Eroding

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Wall Street is starting to count the cost of the recent turmoil in financial markets.
Salomon Smith Barney, one of the country's biggest investment banks, said yesterday that in the last two months alone, it lost an estimated $360 million after taxes, in its arbitrage and Russian-related credits businesses. After allowing for profits from its private client and funds management business, Salomon said that it expected its overall after-tax loss for the last two months to be about $150 million. 
 Such losses may spell the end of a long run of bountiful profits for Wall Street, a time when stocks, financial markets and the fortunes of financiers have risen steadily. Another Wall Street firm, Credit Suisse First Boston, said last week that its first- half profits would be down $250 million because of losses on its Russian and Russian-related businesses.
Wall Street is having to adjust to the possibility of a sea change in the financial markets. The recent gloom over the markets has already spread to such areas as advising on big mergers and acquisitions and initial public offerings.
And there already is speculation -- denied by the principals yesterday -- that such high-profile planned transactions as Citibank's $70 billion merger with Travelers Group Inc. -- the parent company of Salomon Smith Barney -- may be postponed. Page 8.
Arda Nazarian, a spokeswoman for Salomon, the investment bank subsidiary of Travelers, said the merger, which would create a company called Citigroup, was on track. Richard J. Howe, a Citicorp spokesman, said: "We remain confident that the Fed will grant to Citigroup bank holding company status in the third quarter. But only the Fed knows the exact timing."
Many on Wall Street also expect Goldman, Sachs & Company to postpone its planned multibillion-dollar sale of a slice of its shares. A spokesman for the firm said yesterday that it would not comment on such rumors, and that Goldman's plans remained unchanged.
Still, if the financial markets continue to deteriorate, there may be more profound changes on Wall Street. Firms could start considering cutting back on expenses, and jobs in particular. Wall Street typically takes such measures when it falls on leaner times, as it did after the October 1987 stock market crash, during the bear market of 1990 and after the bond market rout of 1994.
If there are similar rounds of sweeping job cuts, that, in turn, would have a significant effect on the New York City economy, which has come to rely heavily on its brokerage firms, banks and insurance companies for tax revenues and well-paid jobs.
In a statement about its recent losses in arbitrage and Russian-related credits, Salomon said yesterday that they resulted from the recent "extreme volatility in the global fixed-income and equity capital markets." The brokerage firm estimated that for July and August it would have $60 million of Russian-related credit losses, $120 million of losses on its United States bond arbitrage portfolio and $180 million of losses on its international arbitrage business.
Profits from more successful areas, such as the firm's private client and fund management businesses, have so far helped to offset losses from arbitrage and Russia-related credits. Such profits must have totaled as much as $210 million in the last two months to cut the overall loss in the period to $150 million.
For the moment, several of Salomon's big competitors are keeping mum. "As a matter of policy we do not comment intra-quarter on results," said Tim Gillis, a spokesman for Merrill Lynch & Company. Jon Diat, a spokesman for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said his firm would have no comment on its results for July and August, or on what effect recent falling financial markets may have had on its performance.
In an interview yesterday afternoon, Jamie Dimon and Deryck C. Maughan, the co-chairmen of Salomon Smith Barney, were guarded about measures they may take to try to improve profitablity, and would not say whether their firm plans to cut back its staff, always one of the biggest expenses on Wall Street. "The answer is you don't cut people because of losses," Mr. Dimon said. "We have been probably reducing risk around the company for a while. You pray for the best and you plan for the worst. You have to know your risks and exposures."
Mr. Dimon was also quick to stress that "the rest of Travelers is doing great," and that Salomon's business with Main Street Americans had "not seen a dramatic decrease in retail volume."
But both Mr. Maughan and Mr. Dimon sounded cautious. "You'd be foolish not to worry," Mr. Dimon said. "Beware the Ides of August," Mr. Maughan said, adding that the month of August, in recent years, had ceased to follow financial folklore and be a quiet month for the markets. Mr. Dimon should know; he cut short his family vacation in the eastern Mediterranean to return to New York to discuss the recent losses.

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: MARKET PLACE;
Rumors of the Death of Bears Were, It Seems, Exaggerated

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
As they surveyed their outsized stock market gains over the last three years, some investors may have thought to wonder, on occasion and in an idle sort of way, just what a bear market felt like.
Now they know. 
In another day of relentless selling that took the Dow Jones industrial average down 6.37 percent, stocks of all kinds disintegrated. As a demise, it was orderly. But it was also indiscriminate. "Today was really different," said Douglas Cliggott, United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan in New York. "Very high-quality companies with no visible sign of earnings weakness were taken down brutally." Indeed, the selling hammered stocks both in and out of favor with investors.
Yesterday was different in another way, however. It marked the first time in years that the three most popular market indexes -- the Dow Jones, the Standard & Poor's 500 and the Nasdaq Composite -- actually lost ground for the year. Until now, the declines in the indexes, unpleasant though they were, had still left investors ahead of the game.
No longer. Investors, playing with the house's money all year, are now faced with the prospect of giving up some of their own. Even those who own index funds, which had registered gains until yesterday, are now eating into last year's gains.
There was no stopping the selling. No "circuit breakers" to stop trading on the New York Stock Exchange to give investors time to regain their reason before they resumed the furious unloading of shares. Under the new rules instituted by the exchange last October, it would take a fall of 900 points for trading to be halted.
No one expects a decline of that magnitude to happen. Indeed, many strategists anticipate a rebound in stocks today. Investors who had been moving their money into cash or money market funds could easily decide that stocks at these levels looked attractive.
Still, yesterday's action was a harrowing reminder to investors of how the law of gravity works in the stock market: shares of the same high fliers that had propelled the market to its triumphant heights led the decline. Dell Computer closed down 15.8 percent, Yahoo ended the day 16.9 percent lower, America Online lost 14.8 percent of its value. Those are breathtaking moves, one-day declines that might have taken months in less frothy markets.
What fueled the decline? Yesterday's economic news wasn't great, but it wasn't awful either. A report from the National Association of Purchasing Management showed that increasing numbers of domestic manufacturers said their business was deteriorating. And sales of new homes fell 1.6 percent in July, a signal that the housing market may be slowing. Both reports contributed to the view that the United States economy was weakening.
Of course, inasmuch as a weaker economy translates to diminished earnings, these figures were not welcome news to stock market investors. Still, they were not the triggers necessary for the all-out collapse seen yesterday.
What appeared to be happening yesterday was the unwinding of two significant patterns of investor behavior. One was the shift from investors' being able to shrug off all bad news, what Wall Street calls climbing the wall of worry, to a newer concern. Maybe the economic problems in Asia, Russia and Latin America combined with the strong dollar will indeed have a deleterious effect on already weakening earnings of American companies.
"What we're looking at here is a rolling realization that there are a lot of problems in the world," said Alan Kral, portfolio manager at Trevor, Stewart, Burton & Jacobsen, an investment management firm in New York. "The sum total of a number of small problems has become a major problem for us. You can't take away growth opportunities in half the world's economies and blithely conclude that American stocks at 25 times earnings are cheap."
But an even greater contributor to yesterday's carnage, strategists say, was the reverse effect of what has come to be known as momentum investing. This strategy, characterized by investors chasing stocks simply because they are rising in price, with little regard for sensible valuations, pushed shares of the favored companies to levels unseen even in the hottest of markets. Now that these stocks are no longer rising, to stay true to their discipline, these investors must sell. And this selling feeds on itself.
"When you're buying something at a very high price-earnings ratio, you've always got your finger on the trigger," said Peter Tanous, investment consultant at Lynx Asset Management in Washington.
In choosing to pull that trigger yesterday, investors seemed to see several things on the horizon they did not like. First were the whiffs of third-quarter earnings disappointments, anecdotal only at this point, but a worry nonetheless. Companies have learned to warn investors when prospects look grim; the warning period for the third quarter begins in two weeks.
Neither have lower interest rates helped the market. This is a turnabout for investors who have come to expect that when rates fall, stock prices rise.
An increasingly bearish sentiment among investment newsletter writers may have contributed to yesterday's selling. According to Mark Hulbert, editor of the Hulbert Financial Digest in Alexandria, Va., at the end of July newsletter writers recommended on average that their readers maintain an exposure in stocks of 63 percent of their portfolio. Yesterday that recommended level had dropped to around 20 percent.
Still, Mr. Hulbert said he was not yet seeing people really throwing in the towel. "Even though there has been a big drop, I thought we'd have seen even more," he said.
The stock market has been largely a confidence game of late, said Fred Hickey, editor of High Tech Strategist. "Since investors have been so certain about their stocks for so long there's a shock factor. People have leveraged themselves, taken risks they shouldn't have taken because these stocks seem so invincible. You're seeing a reversal of these excesses."

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: WHITE HOUSE;
Market Is No Longer Staunch Clinton Ally

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
He had good reasons to go to Russia, President Clinton told a friendly audience in an elementary school gymnasium in Virginia shortly before noon today. "We have learned the hard way," he said, "that problems that develop beyond our borders sooner or later find their way to our doorstep."
Sooner, it turned out. 
 Less than three hours after he left the gymnasium, while in Air Force One high over the Atlantic, the President received word from the White House that his staunch political ally, the stock market, had gone south.
"We are living in a smaller and smaller world," Mr. Clinton had said in Virginia, sounding a cherished theme about the economy that might apply as well to how the political walls seem suddenly to be closing in on him.
Later, after hearing of the market's drop, Mr. Clinton spoke by telephone with the Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin. It has long been an inside joke at the White House that the famously overstating President has been forbidden by his understated Treasury Secretary to boast about the astonishing performance of the stock market in recent years. Still, every now and then -- as he did in meeting with workers in Palo Alto, Calif., on May 1 -- he has let slip the observation that "the stock market has gone from 3,200 to 9,000 since I've been President and there's no precedent for that in history."
Today in Virginia, as he usually does, Mr. Clinton confined himself to boasting about other economic indicators. "We've benefited a lot from this global society of ours," he said. "We have over 16 million new jobs in the last six years, and we're about to have our first balanced budget surplus in 29 years."
With Mr. Clinton and many of his senior economic advisers up in the air, it fell to Mr. Rubin today to provide the Administration's calm reaction to the steep drop, after consulting with the President. "The world is currently working its way through a difficult period," he said.
Mark Mellman, a Democratic poll taker, said there might be no direct connection between stock market conditions and Presidential popularity. "Historically, there is very little relationship between stock market gyrations on the one hand and people's evaluations of the economy on the other," he said.
But Frank Luntz, a Republican pollster, said, "The weakness of the stock market will soon be tied into attitudes toward him." Mr. Luntz said that in a survey he conducted last week, 54 percent of likely voters this November said that they owned stocks or mutual funds of some kind. He said the poll had a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Charles Cook, an independent political analyst who is a particularly close observer of Congress, said he could not predict what effect the drop in the market would have. But he said that combined with the possibility of more damaging information emerging from the inquiry into Mr. Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, the stock market performance did not bode well for the President.
"I was absolutely certain a week ago that Clinton was going to survive this thing, and that the impact on the elections wasn't going to be that great," he said. "And now I'm like totally shaken."

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: DEJA VU -- The Shadow of Black Monday;
Wall St. Has Come a Long Way Since '87, Hasn't It?

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
In the stock market, the sky is falling -- again.
Share prices are plunging, gurus are opining, and rattled investors are biting their nails. Just as they did after similar Mondays in October 1997, July 1996 and, yes, October 1987, the day that Wall Street still calls Black Monday. 
When the bottom finally fell out of the stock market on Oct. 19, 1987, more than one-fifth of the market's value was wiped out in a single day. This year, by contrast, most of the major market indexes -- including the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue-chip stocks -- have not yet lost that much from their peaks in July.
Nonetheless, investors can only hope that this Monday is another case of deja vu -- because that would mean the worst is over. After all of those historic blue Mondays, the stock market recovered, in some cases very quickly. In 1996 and 1997, stocks regained their previous peaks within a matter of months.
It took almost two years for investors to recover their losses from the crash of 1987, but recover they did -- and then some. Hard as it may be to remember, back then the Dow Jones industrial average fell to 1,739; even after yesterday's carnage, the Dow still stood at 7,539 -- a 333 percent gain from the bottom nearly 11 years ago.
O.K., that is over more than a decade, far longer than a lot of Americans have been investing. At the end of 1986, for example, fewer than 30 million shareholders had mutual-fund accounts; today, there are more than 135 million such accounts, according to the fund industry's trade group, the Investment Company Institute.
But to some old hands on Wall Street, some of the similarities between the stock market of today and that of 11 years ago are striking. "I was just saying, last Saturday, that it's starting to look like 1987," said Steven C. Leuthold, a money manager and market watcher in Minneapolis.
For those who missed the ugliness at the end of the 1980's, here are some of the similarities -- and the differences -- between those days and today.
SIZE -- Yesterday's decline, though bigger than 1987's one-day drop in points on the Dow, pales on a percentage basis. The 508-point drop in 1987 was a sickening 22.6 percent plunge; this 513-point fall amounts to only 6.4 percent.
SPEED -- Though many investors remember only the awful excitement of that October Monday in 1987, the market had started to fall apart long before it took the final plunge. It peaked in August and took two months to fall 36 percent.
This year, the market peaked in July and has taken six weeks to fall 19 percent.
BREADTH -- This is Wall Street jargon for how strong the market is, based on the number of stocks rising versus the number falling. When breadth is good, the generals and the troops are all marching in the same direction, said James B. Stack of Investech, a newsletter and research firm in Whitefish, Mont. When breadth is bad, the generals are still marching forward, but the troops are in retreat.
In the recent past, as in 1987, breadth has been lousy, Mr. Stack said. While blue-chip stocks continued to make gains, smaller stocks have been tumbling for months.
VALUATION -- This is an effort to compare stock prices to the underlying values of the companies they represent. And by these measures, stocks in 1998 are far more "overvalued" than they were even in 1987, Mr. Leuthold said. In 1987, he said, stock dividends, on average, paid a modest 2.8 percent, and shares were trading at 2.6 times the value of companies' net assets (or book value) and 16.8 times their operating earnings. Today, the dividend yield is a meager 1.8 percent for the Dow stocks, which are trading at 3.4 times book value and 18.3 times operating earnings.
VILLAINS -- Many commentators in 1987 attributed the market crash to program trading and portfolio insurance, which was supposed to protect its users from losses by prompting them to sell shares at the first sign of weakness. Unfortunately, such selling may have exacerbated the declines already under way, which prompted more selling, which worsened the fall, and on and on.
Portfolio insurance has pretty much gone out of fashion, although it may have been replaced by derivatives, which are complex financial contracts that allow buyers and sellers to bet on all kinds of things, including things that no one understands or can predict. Some of the decline yesterday, though, was carried out by computer programs that generate large and rapid sell orders.
GLOBAL TENSIONS -- In 1987, Russia was still the Evil Empire (a.k.a. the Soviet Union). It did not have a stock market, much less a market that could roil America's. Whether Russia's economic problems are really the cause of the current market malaise or just a convenient scapegoat remains unclear. Nor were the smaller so-called emerging markets in Asia and elsewhere a key factor in the 1987 decline.
Germany was seen as the culprit the last time, as Washington and Bonn clashed over the direction of interest rates and economic policies. Angry words from Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d about Germany's decision to raise interest rates were cited at the time as one cause of the market meltdown in the United States.
INTEREST RATES -- The bond market is almost as different as it could be from the way it was in 1987. Then, interest rates were soaring; the yield on long-term Treasury bonds topped 10 percent at the time of the crash. Today, yields on the same bonds have fallen to less than 5.25 percent, the lowest level since the 1970's.
MUTUAL FUNDS -- In 1987, a large fund complex -- commonly believed to be Fidelity Investments -- contributed to the carnage by dumping huge blocks of shares, according to a report by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Heavy selling by mutual funds may also have been at work yesterday. Laszlo Birinyi, who manages money and tracks the market from Greenwich, Conn., said the pattern of trading led him to believe that many funds sold shares shortly before the close of trading, after hoping for most of the day that the market would rebound. Funds try to keep cash on hand to meet redemption requests but must often sell shares to fulfill customers' orders.
SENTIMENT -- The sentiment of those customers may ultimately turn out to be the most important factor in whatever happens in the market today. In 1987, some investors panicked, sold at the lows and regretted it thereafter. Since then, the watchword among amateur investors has been "buy on the dips," no matter how severe. Their staunchness has served as a bulwark in the more recent market meltdowns.
Until now, perhaps. While there are few reports of panic selling, big fund companies like T. Rowe Price and Vanguard confirm that many investors have switched at least some of their holdings from stock funds to bond funds. And chatter -- on the Internet, in offices, and on the omnipresent financial television shows -- suggests that many investors are at least considering a move to the sidelines.
One thing to look for to tell if the party is really over: Street vendors will be selling watches from Timex, not "Rolex." Like a lot of other things related to the stock market, it has been known to happen before.

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: STOCKS;
DOW OFF 6% IN WAVE OF SELLING, ERASING MARKET'S GAINS FOR '98; PRESSURE FOR RATE CUT LIKELY

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Waves of selling by investors large and small engulfed the stock market yesterday.
The selloff erased the last of the market's gains this year and sent stock prices down more than 19 percent from their peak set just six weeks ago, the sharpest decline in eight years. 
 The frenzied selling dashed the hopes of investors who had expected the market's recent slump -- which began with worries over economic conditions in Asia and accelerated as financial troubles ensnared Russia -- to be stayed by the fundamental strength of the American economy.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 512.61 points, or 6.4 percent, to 7,539.07, leaving the bellwether index 4.7 percent below where it started the year. The decline was the second largest in the Dow's history in point terms, trailing the 554-point drop last Oct. 27, but it did not rank in the top 20 when measured in percentage terms. The Standard & Poor's 500 index, a broader measure of the market, fell more than 69 points, or nearly 7 percent, to 957.28, down 1.3 percent since the beginning of 1998. The declines were the greatest among technology stocks, which until recently had been the market leaders.
The cumulative effect of the last few weeks is nearly as great as the one-day market plunge on Oct. 19, 1987, when stock prices fell 22.6 percent. But a market rebound soon followed and the national economy did not stray into recession.
While there were few signs yesterday of panic among individual investors, market participants said that selling by mutual fund companies, responding to withdrawals by individual investors that began over the weekend, played a part in the decline, including the stampede that sent the Dow average down 250 points in the last half-hour of trading.
The selloff in stocks accompanied a big rally in the bond market, where everyone seemed to be seeking shelter in securities that are backed by the Federal Government. As its price rose with demand, the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to a record low of 5.25 percent.
Economists and financial analysts said the market rout was almost certain to put intense pressure on the Federal Reserve to lower short-term interest rates. For more than a week, the rates on some short-term securities have been higher than on some long-term bonds, a situation that is a classic precursor to a recession.
In Washington, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said yesterday that the economy remained sound, although he acknowledged that "the world is currently working its way through a difficult period." Mr. Rubin and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, who is on vacation in California but who was in touch with Mr. Rubin yesterday, are scheduled to meet in California on Friday with the Finance Minister of Japan, Kiichi Miyazawa.
Whatever the cause of the financial difficulties that have plagued Asia and Russia over the last year, economists say, the stock market's recent activity indicates that those troubles have begun to wash up on America's shores.
"This is the first time in a long time where the future of the American economy hinges so much on what happens to American stock prices," said Henry Kaufman, a New York economist. "Consumers have much more than usual invested in stocks, and it has influenced their spending. That has benefited businesses enormously." With the decline in stock prices, he said, "we could begin to see the reverse."
He suggested that the situation called for a government response. "We are having a global financial problem," he said, "and it is a problem that cannot go away quickly. If there are further declines in the equity market, there should be an orchestrated reduction in interest rates by the major industrial countries." The scope of the market decline and the lurking economic threats seem to have sunk in with individual investors, who have been the stalwart supporters of the bull market for the last few years. Mutual fund companies, including Fidelity Investments, the country's largest fund company, reported withdrawals from stock funds over the weekend and yesterday, with most of those investors moving into money market or bond funds.
Bearing the brunt of yesterday's selloff were many of the technology stocks that have been the most popular with individual investors and with the mutual funds in which they invest. The Nasdaq composite index, the major market index most heavily populated with technology issues, fell 140 points, or 8.6 percent, to 1,499.25 -- its steepest daily decline in points and the fourth steepest in percentage terms. The Nasdaq index is now 4.5 percent below the level at the start of the year.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange measured 914.7 million shares, the third-busiest day on the Big Board, and the number of stocks that declined exceeded those that advanced by a ratio of more than seven to one. Exceptionally heavy volume on the Chicago Board Options Exchange caused a computer problem near the end of trading. But despite that glitch, Mr. Rubin said that the financial markets' mechanisms worked "effectively."
The Dow industrial average has declined nearly 1,799 points, or 19.3 percent, from its record closing price of 9,337.97 on July 17. That is slightly less, in percentage terms, than the 21.2 percent drop in the Dow in the bear market of 1990, which lasted from mid-June through early October.
Most other stock markets around the world posted losses yesterday, partly in response to last week's decline in the American stock market. Germany's leading market index fell 2.3 percent yesterday. British markets were closed for a bank holiday. In Hong Kong, the stock market plummeted, falling more than 7 percent after the government, which intervened to help prop up share prices last week, did not do so yesterday. Virtually alone among the world's major exchanges, Japan's market had a rise of 1.4 percent yesterday, bouncing back from last week's decline that took the Nikkei index to its lowest level in more than a decade.
To some traders and analysts, the decline on Wall Street yesterday took on some of the characteristics of a selling frenzy, the type of relentless liquidation of investors' portfolios that comes only at the point of maximum pessimism.
"The only good thing I see is that they are finally going after the sacred cows, the drugs and the retail stocks and the technology sector," said Henry Herrmann, chief investment officer at Waddell & Reed, a mutual fund company in Overland Park, Kan. Until yesterday, those stocks had proved a sort of refuge from the storm.
"When they are pounding the stocks that wouldn't go down, that tells me that the sentiment is really negative," Mr. Herrmann said. "And when the sentiment gets that negative, you can get a reversal pretty quick."
While Mr. Herrmann suggested a stock bounce might be in order, yesterday's rout, and the round of relentless selling at the end of trading, left open the possibility that further declines will follow today. Relatively few people in the market seem to believe that the downturn is finished.
"It may be that we are reaching a temporary climax," said Richard McCabe, an analyst at Merrill Lynch who tracks technical indicators. But he said that the market was just as likely to stumble further, at least as low as 7,400 on the Dow, which was the lowest point in January and is 2 percent below its current level. Last Oct. 27, on the day that the Dow industrials lost 554 points, the average fell as low as 6,971.
Market analysts and traders said there were several sources of the heavy selling that came at the end of yesterday's session. Laszlo Birinyi, an analyst who tracks program trading, the computer-driven trading strategies often employed by professional trading firms, said that much of the late-day volume appeared to come from institutions that had placed sell orders earlier in the day and needed them completed before trading ended.
Mr. Birinyi concluded that the heavy selling came from mutual fund companies responding to orders placed over the weekend and during the trading day.
There was some concern among traders that heavy selling was coming from index mutual funds, one of the few categories of stock funds that have continued to take in cash during the market's recent decline. But George U. Sauter, a managing director at the Vanguard Group who oversees the company's index funds, said in an interview that Vanguard's two big funds that track the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index did not participate in the market yesterday.
"By and large we've had positive cash flow into the funds, although certainly not to the extent we had earlier in the year," Mr. Sauter said. One of the big Vanguard index funds had a slight outflow but that was balanced out by an inflow into the other, Mr. Sauter said, meaning that the impact on the S.& P. 500 index was canceled out.
Near the end of the day, according to two traders, heavy selling of stock-index futures by hedge funds prompted some institutions to activate what are known as index arbitrage trades. In these cases, the trades involved selling the stocks in the S.& P. 500 index and buying the associated futures, in an attempt to lock in as profit the difference between the futures contract and the higher-priced stocks.
In an environment like yesterday's, few stocks were able to maintain gains; only 27 of the stocks in the S.& P. 500 rose yesterday. Among the gainers were utility companies, a traditional haven in tough times because of their high dividends, and shares of companies that sell food, beverages and other staples that consumers are expected to buy in good times and bad.
Yesterday's stock plunge knocked about $700 billion off the market value of companies in the Wilshire 5000 index. Since mid-July, the market capitalization of the index, which is made up of about 7,600 companies and is often used as a proxy for the entire stock market, has shrunk by nearly $2.5 trillion.
The rout has taken big swipes out of some longtime investor favorites. Coca-Cola, for example, lost $18.8 billion of market value yesterday, and since mid-July, the company's market value has shrunk by nearly $59 billion, or 26 percent.
