HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: POLICY;
Treasury Chief Seeks to Assure Jittery Investors

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
The sharp stock market selloff is likely to ripple through policy and politics, putting more pressure on the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates and threatening the air of prosperity that has been the foundation of President Clinton's political support, analysts and Government officials said today.
Yet unlike the much steeper stock market plunge in October 1987, the financial system handled today's fall in share prices without major problems, and the Clinton Administration hurriedly sent out Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin with soothing words about the continued soundness of the economy. 
 Mr. Rubin was back in Washington after two weeks of vacation. He said he had spoken during the day with the President, who was flying to Russia on Air Force One, during the afternoon as the market dropped precipitously, and with Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, who was on vacation in California.
A spokeswoman for the Federal Reserve, Lynn Fox, said the central bank had no comment on the market's decline. But economists said every sharp drop helped build a more compelling case that the economy could slow substantially in coming months and that a cut in interest rates would not only help avert a deeper downturn at home but also help restore confidence in badly battered world markets and economies.
"We may not be able to control the global wildfire, but by cutting rates we might be able to contain it," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis.
The Fed has until the last few weeks regarded inflation as the main threat to continuation of the nation's long economic expansion, which has driven unemployment down to 4.5 percent.
Many analysts think that the Fed will not reduce rates unless there is more compelling evidence that the domestic economy is sinking or the market slide accelerates so much that it endangers the stability of the financial system.
In 1987, Mr. Greenspan -- faced with a quicker market meltdown -- pressed lenders to make sure that they made credit available within the financial system and then cut interest rates to keep the economy from stalling.
But nearly 11 years later the banking and financial systems are much stronger than they were then, interest rates are already low by many standards, securities exchanges are better able to handle floods of orders, and officials and analysts said they saw no need for any immediate action to keep the markets functioning smoothly.
The market is different in another critical way, too. Compared with 1987, the stock market today is more broadly based, with many more households having invested in retirement programs and mutual funds. Compensation for many corporate executives is directly or indirectly tied to stock market performance through options, employee share-purchase programs and other means.
Allen Sinai of Primark Decision Economics said that the proportion of household wealth coming from the stock market was nearly 30 percent last month when the market was near its peak, up from 18.3 percent at the end of 1994.
As a result, economists said, consumers who have felt affluent and confident over the last few years as the market has surged, and therefore spent more money than they would have otherwise -- a phenomenon known as the "wealth effect" -- might now rein in their spending.
For the economy, that could mean slower growth. And any slowdown from dampened consumer spending would only compound the effects of a downturn in exports caused by the turmoil that has already sent much of Asia into recession and to a degree is now threatening Latin America.
While relatively few economists are predicting a recession in this country, even a sustained slowdown in growth could push unemployment higher, call into question the optimistic projections of big budget surpluses in coming years and leave Mr. Clinton without the bulwark of a rock-solid economy.
"The political implications are clearly related to how much consumers tighten their wallets," said Robert E. Litan, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution. If they do, he said, and output growth "slows and unemployment grows, then the bloom has come off the rose and that would affect his standing."
With most of the Administration's economic team en route to Russia today and many of Mr. Clinton's political advisers traveling or on vacation, there was almost no public reaction from the White House.
But Mr. Rubin, who made a fortune navigating Wall Street's ups and downs as a partner at Goldman, Sachs before coming to Washington in 1993, restated today what has long been the Adminstration's approach to the markets: that in the long run they will reflect an economy's underlying strengths.
"The fundamentals of the United States economy are strong, due in part to the sound policies we have been following," he said, "and the prospects for growth with low inflation and low unemployment continue to be strong. The key is to continue on the right policy path, and particularly to maintain our fiscal discipline."
He urged countries caught up in economic crisis, especially Japan, to take the difficult steps needed to restore their strength. And he again urged Congress to provide $18 billion for the International Monetary Fund, which is running short of money just as the financial crisis threatens to spread to Latin America and elsewhere.
"It is particularly important that Japan, the second-largest economy in the world, move ahead with actions to put its economy back on track so it can be a source of strength in Asia and around the world," Mr. Rubin said.
The Treasury Secretary is scheduled to meet on Friday in San Francisco with his Japanese counterpart, Kiichi Miyazawa. Finance ministers from nine Latin American countries will meet with I.M.F. and American officials in Washington on Thursday and Friday to discuss what they can do to avoid the economic state that has befallen Russia.
Mr. Rubin said officials from the Treasury and the Federal Reserve were in contact throughout the day with their counterparts in the other big industrial nations, as well as financial market regulators in the United States including the Securities and Exchange Commission.
"The world is currently working its way through a difficult period," Mr. Rubin said.
"Our consultations indicate that the payment and settlement systems and other market mechanisms are working effectively," he added.
Mr. Rubin said the only problem had been at the Chicago Board Options Exchange, and that it had been taken care of. He provided no details.

HEADLINE: After a Holiday, Gore Campaigns in Midwest

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Back on the campaign trail in Illinois and Ohio after his two-week holiday in Hawaii, Vice President Al Gore turned to his companions this morning on Air Force Two and asked, "Anything happen while I was gone?"
That was about as close as Mr. Gore came to alluding to the difficulties that are roiling the Clinton-Gore White House. Two weeks ago, there was the President's admission that he had had an improper relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky and had misled the American people about it. 
 Then, last week, Attorney General Janet Reno ordered a 90-day preliminary inquiry into whether Mr. Gore lied to investigators last year when he was interviewed about his telephone fund-raising solicitations from the White House.
And today, as Mr. Clinton headed for Moscow, Mr. Gore could not take solace in the choice of his friend, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, as Prime Minister by the embattled President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia. Mr. Chernomyrdin's nomination is in grave trouble.
But in his first interview since Mr. Clinton's disclosure about Ms. Lewinsky, Mr. Gore made clear that his strategy would be to say as little as possible about the tribulations that threaten to dog him until the November election and beyond -- to his own planned run for the Democratic nomination in 2000. He did not move beyond his statement of last week that he would be vindicated in the fund-raising matter and declined to discuss details of the Reno inquiry.
Asked whether Mr. Clinton had assured him he did not have a relationship with Ms. Lewinsky, Mr. Gore told reporters aboard Air Force Two, "I've never talked about my private conversations with the President, and I'm not going to start now."
The Vice President said he did not agree with Democrats who say they fear that the Lewinsky matter will be a major liability in this year's elections. Asked if he felt beleaguered, he said: "Not at all. Not at all."
Mr. Gore's calculation seems to be to stand close to his friend, the President, but not too close. For example, he acknowledged in the interview that he did not join Mr. Clinton in recent days in calling leading Democrats on Capitol Hill to reassure them that they would survive the Lewinsky matter.
But Mr. Gore insisted he was not distancing himself from the President, saying White House aides "didn't ask me to make a bunch of calls" because he was occupied with international issues like Russia and the American strikes in Sudan and Afghanistan.
Only when the interview turned from ethical questions to Russia did Mr. Gore appear comfortable, displaying his expertise on foreign policy.
As if to defy those who say the Administration is in trouble, Mr. Gore set off on a full round of campaign events. He started the day at a town meeting in Dayton, Ohio, with schoolchildren, then attended a fund-raising event for Mary Boyle, the Democratic nominee for senator from Ohio. Here in Chicago, Mr. Gore was the headline speaker at a convention of the Communications Workers of America, then he dedicated an AIDS prevention and care center, and ended the day at a fund-raising reception for the re-election of Senator Carol Moseley-Braun.
Though Mr. Gore said nothing about the developments that have buffeted the Administration, they were clearly on the minds of those in the audience. At the event for Ms. Boyle, the Vice President drew perhaps his most sustained applause of the day when he showed his allegiance to Mr. Clinton.
"Let me say this loudly and clearly: I am proud that Bill Clinton's policies have made this country a better place," he said. "I'm proud to serve with President Bill Clinton in helping to improve the lot of working families in America."
As if he were oblivious to his own party's problems, Mr. Gore turned his fury on the Republicans, asserting, "The Republican Party is in such disarray that the right hand doesn't know what the far right hand is doing."
But some in the audience said they feared that Mr. Clinton's ethical woes and the fund-raising questions threatened Mr. Gore's future.
"I feel for him both on the personal level and on the political level," said Jan Rudd, a veteran community worker and Democratic organizer in Dayton. "Already, you can see that Republicans across the country are using the Lewinsky issue against Democrats. Are they going to use it against Gore? Yes. Big time."
Bruce Jackson, a teacher who attended the Boyle event, said Mr. Gore might not be safe from the taint of the Lewinsky matter because "there's always the term, 'guilt by association,' but I'm more concerned that Reno says there should be an investigation."
As Mr. Gore was reciting the Clinton Administration's accomplishments in education and the economy, Mr. Jackson jabbed his thumb toward the Vice President in the distance and said, "Any time you're in politics you're going to be remembered more for the problems than the good. That's why he's harping on the good today."
But Jim Ruvolo, a former chairman of the state's Democratic Party, said Mr. Clinton's trouble over the Lewinsky matter should be the least of Mr. Gore's worries. "Gore's running mate is the economy," he said, speaking of 2000, "not Bill Clinton."

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: VOICES;
'It's Disturbing, to Put It Mildly,' But Investors Say They'll Hold On

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
Gloom, fear, pain and queasiness. Around the nation, anxieties ran high yesterday as investors big and small watched the jagged lines fall and much of the year's profits evaporate in a breathtaking 512-point plunge on Wall Street. Many called it scary, but almost no one seemed ready to panic.
The paper losses were heavy. But conditioned by years of bull-market bravado and still confident in the fundamental soundness of the nation's economy, most investors interviewed in New York, Atlanta, Boston, Denver, Los Angeles, Miami, Seattle and elsewhere voiced expectations that the market would bounce back. They also said they had no intention of getting out, not yet anyway. 
 "I'm not thrilled," Germaine Meilach, 61, an Upper East Side investor, said as she sipped a drink at a sidewalk cafe after the market's cascading close. "But I still feel things are good. I don't see a reason to panic. You can't have 28 percent earnings all the time. I think people would be foolish to get out. We have to be patient."
In Seattle, Peter Hurley, a city planner, agreed, though he lost 10 percent of his net worth yesterday. "It's disturbing, to put it mildly," he said. "But I'm taking the long view of it. The fundamentals are no different from a few weeks ago, but obviously the psychology is very different. We tend to think we're so damn logical, but we're still driven by fear and desire."
In Atlanta, Burdie Henry, who has stocks and mutual funds, sounded like a Wall Street pro. "I'm going to ride it out," she said. "I'm concerned, but I understand that if you're going to invest in the stock market you can't panic at certain things. I think you have to have a certain temperament, and if you panic with every change you probably shouldn't be in the market."
And in Stamford, Conn., Josephine C. McArthur, 52, the president of an after-school enrichment center for children, said she planned to hang tough in a market that had been good to her in recent years. "It's like childbirth," she said. "It's not easy when you're going through it, but after the pains your whole life is better. The party's not over for me."
No one seemed oracular. There were brokerage-house jokes about looking for tall buildings or jumping out first-floor windows. One investor called himself a cautious bull. Many spoke of the market plunge as a long-expected correction.
Maybe some investors were whistling past the graveyard, but many said they had sound reasons for staying in the market.
"If you look at just the fundamentals of the market place, nothing has changed," Kelly Keydel, an independent financial planner in Seattle, said. "There's low inflation, low interest rates, a very strong economy, and unemployment is low. Nothing has changed. People are nervous, but they need to stay the course."
Doug MacLennan, 28, a Merrill Lynch employee, echoed the opinion of many, saying he was in for the long haul and would only lose money if he sold out now. "It's terrible, but I'm a long-term investor and I'm going to wait it out. I try not to look at the daily highs and lows. It's too depressing. But I don't want to get out of the market because I'll realize all my losses."
Others justified what happened yesterday by noting that the market was overheated and due for an adjustment anyway. They said they were way ahead over the years and could afford to take some losses.
"It isn't surprising," Brian Shearer-Kearney, a 41-year-old Nebraskan who was passing through the Minneapolis airport, said of the market plunge. "The stock market had no reason to be doing as well as it was. Most of the country is pretty strong." As for the market, he added: "Eventually it will turn around."
No investors said the fall necessarily foreshadowed a recession, or even a much deeper plunge. And a few said they would soon be looking for buying opportunities.
"It looks like a pretty good buying opportunity," said Dennis Schouten, a certified public accountant in Denver, who stopped at a discount brokerage firm yesterday and calmly sipped iced coffee as the market dipped and dived.
Shirley G. Jarvis, 55, a saleswoman in Norwalk, Conn., said, "Maybe it'll get beaten down enough that I can sneak in and buy 100 shares of Microsoft."
"During past corrections, "I sat on the sidelines and missed my opportunity," said Ms. Jarvis, who described herself as a small investor but said she had learned some lessons from the long bull market. "Then six months later, it was back up. It always seems to be a slow, steady climb back."
Ray B. Washington, 54, a program manager for I.B.M. who lives in Stamford, went golfing yesterday to escape the grim bulletins of co-workers who surfed the Internet to take in the falling graphs. Mr. Washington, who called himself a cautious bull, quipped, "I know some guys who want to jump out of the office window, but we chain them down to desks."
Many investors, like Dilyn Loveless, a 21-year-old senior at Emory University in Atlanta who has small- company and technology stocks, said they were less jittery because they had other income to live on and did not have to depend on the market.
"If I had to live off the money I had invested," Ms. Loveless said, "I would certainly be struggling."
Daniel Thomas, a 28-year-old investment specialist in Denver, said that his own investments were long-term and that his age was a factor in his optimistic attitude toward the market. "I have about 20 or 30 years before I have to worry about retirement," he said.
Though no one was panicking, some expressed concern for small investors, and for retirees and elderly people on fixed incomes whose losses were felt disproportionately.
"For a year now, anyone over the age of 50 was nervous, and anyone under the age of 45 was still confident," said Elliot Herskowitz, 69, a former partner in a Wall Street brokerage firm. "The older people had lived through the 1970's, when the market went down 40 percent. Unless you lived through it, unless you knew the water torture where every day it goes down, little by little, you didn't know."
Brett Goldberg, an importer in Stamford, spoke of another kind of market fear: "It's sort of like knowing that your child is one of a bunch of kids playing out in the street and all of a sudden you hear a big screech and a crash and your first thought is, 'God, I hope it's not my stocks. God, don't let it be Intel.' "
For Carmen Diaz, who works at Prudential Insurance in Newark, the day's slide, which resonated with other falling markets around the world, was proof of the global interdependence of the financial world. "It tells me that we are all in this together," she said. "It makes you feel a little insecure. But what can I do? Take the money out and hide it under my mattress?"
Like many of the Wall Street experts, William H. Horton, a lawyer, said as he scanned the financial news on a tote board in a Newark office that economic problems in Russia, Asia and elsewhere were factors in the fall. But, like others, he scoffed at the notion that President Clinton's personal troubles over his affair with a White House intern constituted a significant factor.
A few more-or-less lucky investors, like Gary McFelia, who works on Wall Street, could afford to gloat a bit yesterday, having started weeks ago to withdraw from the market. Mr. McFelia began about a month ago and liquidated about half of his investments. "I wish I'd done a little more than I did," he said.
Ron Ries, an Internal Revenue Service examiner who paused to watch a tote board as he headed for a commuter train in Newark, stood in a small group and put the big issue to no one in particular: "Well, the question is are we going into a great depression, or is this an overreaction? I personally think it's an overreaction."
In Atlanta, Steven C. Moreland, a physician, seemed to sum it up for nearly everybody: "It was a bloody day, and I don't know whether it's stopped bleeding yet. The long term, I think, is really positive. I may eat those words, but it sounds good."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Auction of Kia Canceled After Low Bids

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 31

 BODY:
The auction of two South Korean auto makers was canceled tonight because none of the four initial bids met the sellers' minimum price.
Despite robust auto sales in North America and Europe, most of the world's 33 mass-production auto makers are losing money. There are enough surplus auto factories around the globe to supply the entire United States market. 
 But auto makers remain important sources of employment and symbols of national strength in many countries, making governments reluctant to allow their closure or sale to foreign investors. Such worries appeared to have played a role this week in the failed auction of the Kia Motors Corporation and its truck-making affiliate, the Asia Motors Company Ltd.
Kia and Asia Motors were put up for sale together this summer by their creditor banks after becoming unable to make payments on their many debts, which total an estimated $10 billion. But with some of the largest banks now financially troubled and effectively controlled by the South Korean Government, the terms of the auction went far beyond a conventional sale to the highest bidder. Instead, the terms required each bidder to submit a business plan to maintain exports and invest more cash. The auction's terms also required that bids include a stiff price for the auto makers' shares and an agreement to repay all of the auto makers' debt.
None of the bids, which came from the Ford Motor Company, Daewoo, Hyundai and Samsung, met all of these conditions, Korean officials announced on Tuesday morning in Seoul, when it was still Monday night here in Detroit. Lee Jong Dae, Kia's president, did not set a date for a new auction.
The apparent failure of the auction lessens the likelihood that Kia or Asia Motors will close any factories soon, despite their losses. So the global car market is likely to remain glutted, depressing prices and profits. The difficulties with the auction also represent a broad setback for South Korea's efforts to streamline its industrial sector, which suffers from heavy debts and excessive staffs in many industries.
Auto industry deals actually taking place now are unlikely to reduce excess global capacity.
The Chrysler Corporation is preparing to merge later this year with Daimler-Benz A.G., for example, but the two auto makers have almost completely different lineups of vehicles and no plans to close factories.
Robert J. Eaton, Chrysler's chairman and chief executive, said in an interview today that despite the recent plunge in stock markets around the globe, the planned merger would proceed. In the merger, shareholders of both companies would turn in their stock for shares in the combined company, DaimlerChrysler A.G.
Chrysler shares tumbled 13.5 percent last Thursday but partly rebounded on Friday. The stock fell last Thursday on speculation that the Daimler merger might not take place because Russia's economic and political troubles had caused the German stock market to plummet, dragging Daimler shares down.
But the United States market has also been battered since then. Mr. Eaton said this morning that there had been no discussion of renegotiating the merger terms. The merger would be affected only if the performance of the German and American stock markets diverged dramatically and the share prices of Daimler and Chrysler also diverged, he said, adding that he believed this was very unlikely.
"As long as the markets move relatively the same, I don't see any impact," Mr. Eaton said.
Another recently announced auto industry transaction also appears unlikely to relieve the industry's excess capacity. The Toyota Motor Corporation announced on Friday that it would spend $259 million to raise its stake in the Daihatsu Motor Company Ltd. to 51.2 percent. But Toyota's previous stake of 34.5 percent had already given it control of Daihatsu, which is strongest in the manufacture of very small cars, one of Toyota's few weaknesses.
The Kia sale has attracted international attention because American, European and Japanese auto makers have worried that a buyer that accepted the company with all of its debts could be forced to dump large numbers of low-priced Kia cars on international markets, in a possibly futile attempt to keep up with interest payments.
Chrysler did not bid on Kia, partly because it is still busy with the Daimler merger and partly because Chrysler executives were dubious about the profitability of East Asian markets even before the region's financial crisis began. "The only way Kia would be attractive to anybody would be if you restructured or reduced the debt," Mr. Eaton said today.

HEADLINE: Too Much Faith in the Fed?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Paul Krugman (Op-Ed, Aug. 30) highlights the part played by a handful of men -- Alan Greenspan, chairman of the United States Federal Reserve, and his few banking counterparts in other developed countries -- in the world's economic future. 
 What puzzles me is why the global economy is almost always considered to be a free market economy with only competition creating wealth. With less than a dozen people calling the shots, it seems that this is a distorted conception of the market. It is almost Orwellian to be so dependent on the analytical powers of a few and yet be told that the market is self-regulating.
 
PETER HIRSCHMANN
Haifa, Israel, Aug. 31, 1998

HEADLINE: Too Much Faith in the Fed?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The photographs of Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, President Clinton, Helmut Kohl of Germany, Jiang Zemin of China and Keizo Obuchi of Japan that accompany "It's a Bad Time for Weak Leadership" (Week in Review, Aug. 30) are captioned, "None of these men is Churchill." 
 Since the crises these leaders are facing are economic and financial, that is just as well. While my generation reveres Winston Churchill for defending our freedom while Great Britain stood alone before Hitler in 1940 and 1941, he was a terrible Chancellor of the Exchequer in Stanley Baldwin's Conservative Government. He returned Great Britain in 1925 to the gold standard, a move denounced by John Maynard Keynes. From this action flowed deflation, unemployment and the general strike of 1926.
In "The Private Lives of Winston Churchill," John Pearson recalls Churchill saying over dinner: "Everyone said I was the worst Chancellor of the Exchequer that ever was. And now I'm inclined to agree with them. So now the world's unanimous."
 
SANDER VANOCUR
Santa Barbara, Calif., Aug. 30, 1998

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 137 words

HEADLINE: Too Much Faith in the Fed?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
While James K. Galbraith (Op-Ed, Aug. 28) is right that wages begin to equalize during times of low unemployment and that we should aim Federal policy to minimizing unemployment, he neglects the essence of the causal relationship. Low unemployment leads to equalizing wages because with fewer candidates for jobs, there is less distinction among candidates. Employers therefore must offer more for less. 
 The equalized wages sought by Mr. Galbraith would mean there would be no benefit to bettering one's professional skills. We each compete to provide the best for our prospective employers and to demand the compensation due. Why should we strive to shrink a wage gap that is the natural and beneficial result of employer market forces?
 
KEN KLAWONN
Charlotte, N.C., Aug. 31, 1998

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
TYSON FOODS TO TAKE $196 MILLION CHARGE TO SHUT PLANTS

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
Tyson Foods Inc., the leading United States chicken processor, said yesterday that it would record charges of $196 million in its fourth quarter, ending on Oct. 3, as it streamlines production at its poultry plants and accounts for losses in Russia and Asia. Tyson, based in Springdale, Ark., announced plans last month to close plants, cut its work force and write down goodwill, but it did not disclose the dollar amounts until yesterday. Tyson also announced plans to scale down its seafood operations, which consist mainly of fishing boats. The charges will probably result in a loss for the fourth quarter, but not necessarily for the full year, Tyson said. Tyson's stock closed down $1.125 yesterday, to $16.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN RUSSIA: THE OVERVIEW;
Russian Legislators Reject Prime Minister Candidate

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Russia's Parliament today emphatically rejected President Boris N. Yeltsin's choice for Prime Minister after a rancorous debate, leaving the nation virtually rudderless in the midst of its deepening economic crisis.
Viktor S. Chernomyrdin implored lawmakers to approve his appointment as Prime Minister, saying he urgently needed to start forming a new government. 
 "Russia today is, in essence, on the verge of economic and political breakdown," he declared on a day in which Russia was still struggling to halt the slide of its currency and prevent the collapse of its banking and financial system. "Russia should not be without a government."
But the appeal drew jeers from the Communist-led opposition, which controls the lower house of Parliament. In the first of as many as three votes on his nomination, they rejected Mr. Chernomyrdin by a vote of 253 to 94 with the help of the other left-wing parties, the nationalists and the liberal opposition. Mr. Chernomyrdin needed 226 votes in the 450 seat Parliament to be approved but got only the support of his own party and an assortment of independents.
The Communists' strategy seemed to be discredit the Yeltsin Government in the hope that the embattled President would finally be driven to resign or at least agree to a more generous power-sharing arrangement. The lopsided rejection also seemed aimed at torpedoing Mr. Chernomyrdin's claim that only he could unify the splintered nation and serve as Mr. Yeltsin's heir.
But Mr. Yeltsin demonstrated tonight that he was also ready to engage in political brinksmanship, as he has so many times in the past. The President immediately renominated Mr. Chernomyrdin, and his advisers warned that the Parliament would be dissolved if it refused to yield, a worrisome prospect for many deputies who have grown comfortable with the free apartments and other perquisites of their office and who might fear a national election.
That set the stage for a new round of horse-trading over government posts and policies in the days ahead. If Parliament rejects Mr. Yeltsin's choice for Prime Minister three times, the President can dissolve the body and call for new parliamentary elections.
"President Boris Yeltsin wants Viktor Chernomyrdin to become the Prime Minister, and I do not recall a case such as this where he has changed his mind," said Boris Berezovsky, the tycoon who has sought to orchestrate Mr. Chernomyrdin's return to power.
Mr. Berezovsky should know; it was his opposition that Mr. Yeltsin defied just four months ago through three confirmation battles in the Parliament to put Sergei Kiriyenko into the Prime Minister's job from which he was dismissed last week.
On the eve of a Russian-American summit meeting, the angry standoff left the United States facing a meeting with a determined but embattled Russian leadership with no real government in place and the prospect of political, as well as economic, implosion growing by the day.
Today's acrimony marked an abrupt end to days of lofty talk of compromise and coalition government intended to secure a bloodless confirmation for Mr. Chernomyrdin.
"We got all the consent," Mr. Chernomyrdin complained to reporters after today's debate. "And all of sudden everything is destroyed."
Communist lawmakers said today that the negotiations broke down over a deadline for enacting amendments to the Constitution that shift some power from the executive branch to the legislature, among other power-sharing arrangements.
Aleksandr Shokhin, the leader of Mr. Chernomyrdin's parliamentary faction, suggested that the acting Prime Minister might still be able to mollify the Communist opposition and salvage his nomination.
Mr. Shokhin suggested that Mr. Chernomyrdin might identify his Cabinet choices and spell out his economic policy before the next vote on his nomination.
The idea would be to reassure wary lawmakers that if he became Prime Minister, he would honor his promises to left-wing politicians.
Market reformers warned that there was a danger that Mr. Chernomyrdin might now go too far in trying to placate the Communists.
Anatoly B. Chubais, who was dismissed from his post as the Yeltsin Government's negotiator with the International Monetary Fund, warned that the Kremlin would be making a grave mistake if it gave away the Finance and Economics Ministries.
"I don't know a single economist from the left side of the spectrum who is capable of proposing anything reasonable to resolve the crisis," Mr. Chubais said.
As Russia's politicians traded insults during today's debate, it was sometimes hard to tell that the nation was grasping for ways to stem the decline of its currency, fight inflation and save its banking system.
Vladimir Zhirinovsky, the strident nationalist, mocked President Clinton for his relationship with Monica Lewinsky. Sergei Dubinin, the head of the Central Bank, defended a loan he received to build a dacha.
Gennadi A. Zyuganov, the Communist leader, complained that Mr. Chernomyrdin's approval rating stood at a meager 7 percent.
Mr. Chernomyrdin derided his predecessor, Sergei Kiriyenko, 36, for leading a "kid's government" and blamed him for the nation's economic ills, even though most economists say Mr. Kiriyenko was struggling to correct policies that were decided during Mr. Chernomyrdin's first term as Prime Minister.
When Mr. Chernomyrdin addressed the financial crisis, his economic prescriptions were vague, halting and at times nearly incoherent.
He said that the Government should use credits to boost Russia's stricken industrial sector but conceded in the same breath that the government had no money.
He said that the Yeltsin Government decision to devalue the ruble was a mistake, but gave no hint of how he planned to prop up the nation's sagging currency.
He said he would not allow the banking system to collapse, but gave no details about how he could prevent the bankruptcy of some of the nation's leading banks.
His dominant policy goal since being selected as Prime Minister last week, he said, was simply to avoid a total financial collapse before he formed a new government and tried to figure out what to do. "The important thing was to hold on until the end of August," he said.
Before departing for the summit meeting in Russia, President Clinton said today that the West should help Russia as long as it continues to embrace capitalism, and he warned that any return to a centralized economy would backfire.
"What I want to do is to go there and tell them that the easy thing to do is not the right thing to do," Mr. Clinton said, in an appearance in an elementary school gymnasium in Herndon, Va., to promote his education proposals. "The easy thing to do would be to try to go back the way they did it before, and it's not possible."
But, he said, "If they will stay on the path of reform to stabilize their society and to strengthen their economy and to get growth back, then I believe America and the rest of the Western nations with strong economies should help them."
Mr. Clinton said it was in America's interest to help the Russians for two reasons: Because a strong Russia can play a role in resolving regional conflicts, such as the one in Kosovo; and because of Russia's nuclear arsenal.
"We don't want terrorists to get a hold of weapons of mass destruction," he said. "A weakened Russia, a weakened Russian economy would put enormous pressure on people who have those technologies and understandings to sell them. We don't want that to happen."
Declaring that "we are living in a smaller and smaller world," Mr. Clinton said that he had decided to go forward with his trip "because we have learned the hard way that problems that develop beyond our borders sooner or later find their way to our doorstep unless we help our friends and our neighbors to deal with them as quickly and promptly as possible."
 Mr. Clinton, looking relaxed, arrived in Moscow on Tuesday with his wife, Hillary, and was greeted by Mr. Chernomyrdin as they left Air Force One on a bleak, wet morning at the Vnukovo-2 airport, Reuters reported.
 The circus-like atmosphere of the debate in Moscow contrasted with grim economic news. Russia's stock market was so depressed that there were only three transactions during its first two hours.
Stock in Gazprom dropped sharply as word spread that Mr. Chernomyrdin's nomination was in trouble. Mr. Chernomyrdin served as head of the gas monopoly before first joining the Yeltsin Government, and investors have assumed that his return to power would benefit the company.
Some reformers were predicting the worst might be yet to come.
"A severe financial-economic rollback, lasting for years, not months, is in store for Russia," Mr. Chubais said.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Gore Sees Hope for Reform
 CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (By The New York Times) -- Vice President Al Gore, an important voice in the Administration's dealings with Russia, said today that reforms there were still possible despite the emergence of hard-line leaders.
"The Communists in Russia today are not the same as Communists of 50 years ago," Mr. Gore said told reporters on his plane traveling here. "And the idea that their participation in some coalition would represent a return to Leninism or Stalinism is just as almost certainly wrong."
He said "labels alone are not any longer the best guide to what these people are advocating."
Mr. Gore continued: "I don't want to put too bright a face on it. The fact is, we don't know what's going to happen there. But a lot of the changes in Russia that have taken place are irreversible. And the damage done by 70 years of Communism are, naturally, difficult to overcome."
Asked how weak President Yeltsin had become, Mr. Gore said, "Well, I don't want to create a diplomatic incident here. He's still President of Russia. But obviously there are negotiations under way that include consideration of how much authority he will designate to his choice as Prime Minister. And that in turn could trigger negotiations about how much power might be reshuffled from the executive branch to the legislative branch."

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: CONNECTICUT;
State's Emergency Fund Swells to $500 Million

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
Connecticut has nearly $500 million in its emergency fund after closing the last fiscal year with a $610 million surplus.
Gov. John G. Rowland yesterday handed a ceremonial check for $160 million to State Treasurer Paul Silvester, bringing the rainy day fund to 5 percent of the general fund budget. Bond rating agencies, which set the interest rates on payments made by the state for money it borrows, recommend that emergency funds reach the 5 percent threshold. 
 In addition to padding the emergency fund, the state's seventh straight surplus helped pay the $124.5 million cost of tax rebate checks that many taxpayers received this summer. It also was spent on retiring state debt, increasing payments to towns that lose money on tax-exempt property and readying state computers for the year 2000 date change.
Governor Rowland shrugged off the suggestion that a robust economy created the windfall, and instead attributed the fiscal strength of the state to his trim budgets. But State Comptroller Nancy Wyman, a Democrat, said record-setting tax revenues were behind the surplus.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Big Cinema Planned For Jamaica Center

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
National Amusements, the Massachusetts-based parent company of Viacom Inc., has announced plans to develop a 15-screen, 3,200-seat movie theater complex at Jamaica Center in Queens.
The project, which is to be built on a city-owned site bounded by Jamaica and Archer Avenues, 160th Street and Parsons Boulevard, represents the single largest private investment in the neighborhood in recent memory. In addition to the multiplex, the 500,000-square-foot-complex is to feature retail and class A office space as well as a parking garage. Construction is scheduled to begin this fall and should be completed by spring of 2000. 
 Gap and Gap Kids, Walgreens and Old Navy stores have committed to the project.
The total cost of the project is approximately $95 million. The city will provide $11 million through its Economic Development Corporation. Another $3 million will be supplied by the state through the Metropolitan Economic Revitalization Fund.
"This project will provide a real boost to the local economy activity and is expected to generate 514 new jobs and 560 construction jobs for local residents," Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said. NICK RAVO

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: BONDS;
Some Think Time Is Right for a Market-Calming Rate Cut

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
As foreign and domestic investors fled to the safe harbor of the United States Treasury market yesterday, talk was growing of a market-calming interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve.
The surge in Treasury buying came in the afternoon, as the stock market lost its footing and the Dow Jones industrial plunged to its second-worst one-day point decline ever. The yield on the 30-year bond dropped to 5.25 percent, the lowest for long-term rates in 30 years and a level that many or most of those who work on Wall Street have not experienced in their working lifetimes. The yield on the 10-year note fell to 4.96 percent, the first time it has been below 5 percent since 1967. 
 As the growing global economic crisis seems daily to impinge more on the still healthy American economy, several analysts have predicted that the 12 percent decline in the Dow in the last week would help force the Federal Reserve to lower its benchmark short-term interest rate soon.
"They can't ignore the message of the market," said John Lipsky, chief economist at Chase Manhattan Bank, referring to the fact that long-term interest rates are well below the Fed's 5.5 percent target for short-term rates. "And the message of the market is that the risks are heavily weighted on the side of a slowdown."
Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at Hoenig & Company, said the stock market fall also should prompt action by the Fed. "This now constitutes a breathtaking decline that central banks are supposed to pay attention to," he said.
The recent rapid decline in interest rates should provide some offset to the drag from Asia, as lower rates spur the housing industry.
The plunge in the 10-year note, which is a benchmark for mortgage rates, should mean that already low mortgage rates drop further.
But Mr. Lipsky argues that the economy has too much drag. At the present time, he said, the Fed's 5.5 percent target for the Federal funds rate -- the rate on overnight loans between banks -- is higher after adjustment for inflation than at the end of 1994. That was when the Mexican peso was devalued, setting off a market selloff that was serious but paled by comparison with the plunge in both developed and emerging markets around the world.
He also said that the 19 percent plunge in the Dow since July 17 was sure to make consumers more cautious, cutting into their strong spending that has kept the economy -- even though it slowed in the second quarter -- stronger than many forecasters had expected.
This slowdown by the consumer, plus the already painful drop in American exports because of the evaporation of buying from Asia, should slow the economy to no growth in the second half of the year, he said -- a reason for the Fed to ease.
Mr. Barbera argued that the Fed had to lower its interest rate to ease the pressure on the troubled emerging markets, most of which have large debts denominated in dollars that have to be rolled over soon.
Federal Reserve policy makers are next scheduled to meet on Sept. 29. At their Aug. 18 meeting they decided, as expected, to leave their short-term interest rate target unchanged.
In the minutes of the July meeting Fed officials showed no inclination toward cutting interest rates, in part because the economy was still strong and there were signs of inflationary wage pressures.
Fed policy makers can act, however, at any time between meetings. As the Asian economic crisis has spread to engulf Russia and to threaten Latin America all talk of a Fed rate increase has disappeared. But there is still a debate among economists over if and when the Fed would decide to lower interest rates.
It is possible that Fed officials could ease some concerns with just a hint, in a speech or comment, that the Fed is watching and ready to take action if necessary. The Fed did announce yesterday that its chairman, Alan Greenspan, was monitoring the markets while on vacation.
Some analysts said the Fed was unlikely to act immediately because that might be interpreted as a sign of panic. But the Fed took such action in the past with the interest rate cut after the stock market crash in 1987.
With yesterday's decline in Treasury interest rates, the 30-year bond yield of 5.25 percent, the 10-year note yield of 4.96 percent, the five-year note yield of 4.78 percent and the two-year note yield of 4.76 percent are all below the 5.5 percent Fed target for the Federal funds rate.
This is known as an inverted yield curve and has, in the past, signaled a slowdown for the economy or even a recession. That has been because the Federal funds rate moved higher than longer-term rates as the Fed raised its target to slow economic growth.
In this case, the inversion has been produced by a drop in longer-term rates as the Fed left its target rate unchanged. But while this appears to be less negative, it seems to be signaling a slowdown anyway.
One reason is that the high level of short-term interest rates, after adjustment for inflation, is a drag on the economy. Another is that the flight to a safe harbor is a signal of weakening economic prospects abroad, which, in turn, are bad for the American outlook.
Analysts said that both the flight to a safe harbor and the realization that the American economy was slowing should push interest rates even lower. But if some calm returns to both foreign and American markets, there could be a selloff that could force interest rates higher temporarily. HEADLINE: 'Titanic,' the Promotion, Lands at Video Stores

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
It is not often that the release of a video generates a promotional blitz, but when the video is that of the highest-grossing movie of all time, it is a sure bet that video stores will make the biggest splash possible to draw in as much money as possible.
And while today's 12:01 A.M. release of "Titanic," for sale or rental, probably didn't need much hype -- smitten fans of Leonardo DiCaprio alone are likely to be responsible for millions in sales and rentals -- video stores in and around New York nonetheless spent the day yesterday making it clear that the movie about the ship had come in. 
 At Video Room on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, employees were unpacking 300 "Titanic" videos, a relatively large number. The plan was to sell 200 copies and rent the other 100. By contrast, the store bought 60 rental copies of "As Good as It Gets," an Academy Award-winning film that proved to be one of its most popular rentals.
At Couch Potato on Second Avenue in Manhattan -- known primarily for its stock of foreign films and hard-to-find classics -- the owner, Michael Mark, could not ignore the potential "Titanic" profits.
"You're a video store," he said, "and this is the biggest video in the history of the world, right? It behooves me to have it."
But the splashiest, most Titanic-sized promotions were held at the 240 Blockbuster stores in New York and New Jersey and on Long Island; all had planned to stay open until 2 A.M. today. At least one of those Blockbusters -- and it seemed unlikely that it was the only one -- violated the official release date and rented the tapes over the weekend.
Last night's midnight promotions, planned months ago at Blockbuster's corporate office in Dallas, centered, naturally, on ice. Stores were to give a free rental to the customer who lugged in the largest chunk of ice, and T-shirts were frozen in blocks of ice for people to chip out.
But in some areas the hype exceeded the reality. In Manhattan, only a handful of people lined up at two big stores on Lexington Avenue: an HMV store at 86th Street and a Blockbuster store at 85th Street. Indeed, both stores were rather quiet as the clock struck 12.
And while the Bay Ridge store in Brooklyn, at 612-634 86th Street, displayed a 1,500-pound ice sculpture of the ship, only a few people bothered to stay after the sculpting to await the release of the video.
Bob Gehringer, the video chain's corporate regional manager, said a record number of people had previously put down $5 of the $24.99 purchase price to reserve a copy.
As 20 million copies of the video were shipped to stores, similar promotions were going on across the country. The Associated Press reported that managers at the Tower Video store on Sunset Boulevard in Los Angeles planned to deck out the store like a ship.
Behind the race to sell "Titanic" tapes as quickly as possible was chilly economics. The demand for the videos will probably sink nearly as fast as the ship.
"It will reach saturation point early," said Michael Becker, the owner of Video Room, at Third Avenue and 84th Street. "This movie will die off in two or three weeks, a lot quicker than most." He attributed that to the many tapes available for sale through video stores, members-only warehouse stores and big general-purpose stores like Wal-Mart.
And, Mr. Becker said, relatively few will want to rent it. People who loved it and want to see it over and over will buy, not rent, he said.
Bargain hunters should wait a few weeks, he said. "A lot of stores will be depleting their inventory soon and the rental copies will be cheaper."
But for the next week or two, even esoteric video stores are plunging in. "We ordered seven or eight to rent," said Richard Mailman, manager of Kim's Video on Avenue A on the Lower East Side. "The people who frequent this store are not the "Titanic" type -- but the price is so low we can afford a few extra to rent, just in case."
And the managers of video stores that cater to a mainstream market say they are expecting to sell record numbers of "Titanic" tapes.
Video Den in Wyckoff, N.J., has cleared eight shelves to display its 48 copies for sale and 48 for rent. "Usually we buy 12 copies to rent," said Deborah Gelok, the manager.

HEADLINE: $25 AND UNDER;
Japan by the Bowlful, Con Brio

BYLINE: By Eric Asimov 

 BODY:
FINDING a reasonably priced restaurant in midtown is almost always a compromise, which is a polite way of saying that if the food is cheap, it's usually not very good, the restaurant's not very comfortable and the service is not very polite. Then, along comes Ya Bowl to prove that even this rule has its exceptions.
This sweet little Japanese restaurant opened five months ago just on the fringe of Times Square, and while the atmosphere is unmistakably Japanese, the small dining room could almost be mistaken for any New York living room. Posters of French advertisements and an orchestra conductor adorn one wall, while another is lined with bookshelves holding such unlikely titles as "Jewish Marital Status" and "Microwave Entertaining," along with a selection of videotapes and CD's. 
 The decor is not entirely random. Kimbo Ishii-Eto, the son of the charming owner, Mien Eto, is music director of the Gemini Youth Orchestra on Long Island and has conducted with the Boston Symphony Orchestra and the New York Philharmonic. He's on the poster, those are his CD's on the wall, and when the background music isn't jazz, that's likely to be his music you're hearing.
Ms. Eto is a proud mother, but she's also proud of her little restaurant. Meals often begin with a freebie, like a little bowl of delicious pickled daikon, the mildly bitter radish complemented by a sweet sesame dressing. Or it might be a bowl of fragrant miso soup, with little chunks of tofu, or a pleasant salad.
At lunch and dinner, you can order the sushi combination for just $14.50, usually including yellowtail, shrimp, a sweet eel roll, salmon and maybe bream or snapper. It's fresh, but unremarkable, seemingly on the menu because it's expected.
The raison d'etre of Ya Bowl is the bowl meals, one-pot meals in which hot food is served over rice in a bowl, a delicious and economical method. Salmon teriyaki ($12.50) is typical -- a well-cooked salmon steak brushed with sweet teriyaki sauce, which drips into the rice below. Even better is the unusual sukiyaki ($9.75), the beef-and-vegetable stew, which is simmered in a sweet soy sauce and, this time, served with egg over rice. Chicken cutlet ($9.50), a boneless breast pounded thin and deep-fried, is crisp and greaseless and is especially good flavored with a mild curry sauce ($10.50), a popular adopted food in Japan. Ya Bowl also serves excellent soba ($10.50), brown buckwheat noodles, in a sweet sauce of soy and rice wine.
Prices are slightly higher at dinner, but the expanded menu also includes more appetizers, like edamame ($4.50), fresh soybeans that are boiled and salted, sort of a Japanese bar snack; boiled spinach served in a sesame dressing ($4.50), and gyoza ($6.50), delicate yet savory pan-fried dumplings.
Before Ms. Eto opened Ya Bowl, she lived in Vienna, where her son studied music, and her desserts show the influence of the Viennese coffeehouses: a selection of rich, creamy cakes ($6 each), including wonderful chocolate espresso cake and fair strawberry cake, served with strong coffee. If you come by Ya Bowl in the afternoon, in fact, Ms. Eto turns it into a coffeehouse, serving desserts with coffee and tea.
I've always found the service at Ya Bowl swift and pleasant, except at lunch on Wednesdays, when the throngs visiting Times Square for Broadway matinees descend. Here's a tip: Go early.
 
Ya Bowl
 
125 West 45th Street, Manhattan, (212) 764-3017.
BEST DISHES: Salmon teriyaki, beef sukiyaki, chicken cutlet, chicken cutlet curry, soba noodles, edamame, boiled spinach, gyoza, chocolate-espresso cake.
PRICE RANGE: Lunch, $ 6:50 to $14.95. Dinner, appetizers, $4.50 to $9.50; main courses, $10.50 to $14.50 (one is $21.50).
CREDIT CARDS: All major cards.
HOURS: Monday through Friday, noon to midnight; Saturday, from 5 P.M.; closed Sunday.
WHEELCHAIR ACCESS: Everything is on one level.

LENGTH: 1336 words

HEADLINE: Hard-Charging Bulls and Red Flags

BYLINE: By Ron Chernow; Ron Chernow is the author of "Titan: The Life of John D. Rockefeller Sr."

 BODY:
No bull market in American history has been so avidly tracked as that of the 1990's. For eight years, we have watched this expanding balloon with a sense of collective wonder, transfixed by our unending prosperity.
Measured purely in terms of popular participation, this market has eclipsed anything seen before. Where only a quarter of Americans dabbled in stocks before the 1987 plunge, nearly half now own stocks, either directly or through mutual funds. By comparison, the roaring market of the Jazz Age, with its paltry three million investors, seems a mere sideshow. 
 Yet for all the attention paid to this bull market, few analysts spotted the glaring symptoms of a huge speculative bubble, which was finally pricked this summer by the simultaneous crises in Russia and East Asia. These weren't subtle signals but classic indicators -- many of them seen in the 1920's and all of them sadly familiar to students of financial history.
One telltale sign was the way the stock market became ubiquitous in our popular culture, moving from the margins to the center of our consciousness. Whenever the stock market seems to drive the economy, not mirror it, we are headed for trouble. And this time, the phenomenon was more pronounced than ever before. Even during the Reagan years, the evening news programs didn't monitor the market closely, whereas in the 1990's Messrs. Rather, Brokaw and Jennings updated us nightly on the market's triumphal march. Stock market gurus grew as fashionable and recognizable as rock stars.
During the past two years, the euphoric market has become less a white-collar bastion and more a blue-collar casino. As ever in financial history, the entry of the "little people" onto the financial stage suggested that the curtain was set to drop. And again, the magnitude of the trend should have made the danger unmistakable. Small investors grew so enamored of stocks that they abandoned the musty security of bank deposits, which now hold just 26.6 percent of household financial assets -- the lowest such percentage in 50 years. Today, 57.6 percent of those assets are allocated to equities. Americans now have more personal wealth stashed away in the stock market than in their homes.
As happened in the 1920's, high-spirited contemporary pundits promised us endless blue skies, a world blessedly free of market corrections, business cycles and bear markets. Their case for the bull market hardened into a mantra, chanted ad infinitum by many brokerage house analysts: the combination of low inflation, low interest rates and slow growth might last forever. Throw in the productivity of computer technology and a balanced budget and you had an indestructible wealth machine. That a speculative bubble could coexist with a sound economic boom -- that it could, in fact, be inspired by an unusually prolonged expansion -- was scarcely mentioned as a possibility.
Once these pundits decided that the gods had vouchsafed perfect economic conditions to the United States in the 1990's, they soon concluded that all conventional methods of market valuation were outmoded. We were told that a new era justified whatever giddy prices investors assigned to stocks -- the sort of hyperbole that reverberated throughout the 20's, and that should have raised another red flag. In April, the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the market had attained its highest price-to-earnings ratio in 100 years, sure proof of speculative excess. Yet the market, immune to all such assertions of common sense, streaked ahead.
One myth of the 1920's was the ardent faith that, with the creation of the Federal Reserve Board in 1913, the United States had acquired a modern financial system that would render crashes obsolete. Similarly, in the 1990's investors endowed Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, with magical powers, assuring themselves that the central banker could curb any sharp fall with lower interest rates.
If some delusions of this bull market recall earlier ones, the 1990's have also written fresh chapters in the annals of financial lunacy. By the market's July peak many stellar high-tech stocks traded at a staggering 70 times earnings, while investors had poured billions of dollars into Internet stocks that were largely bereft of profits. Just a week ago the stock market richly valued Yahoo! Inc. at more than $9 billion, awarding it a share price more than 300 times its projected earnings for 1998.
Most significantly, stocks came to be seen as suitable both for retirement funds and retirees. Many older Americans now live off dividends from mutual funds, as if stocks were simply turbo-charged bonds. If they sat tight for long periods, analysts told them, their stocks would outperform bonds and other traditional investments. Now many of them are trying to figure out how to survive in a world of skidding stock prices and interest rates.
Tutored to buy and hold stocks and to accumulate on dips, baby boomers in their 40's and 50's have managed to neutralize the stock market's historic fluctuations. Where the Dow had before experienced 10 percent corrections at roughly two- or three-year intervals, the market surged ahead from October 1990 to October 1997 without a single 10 percent correction. Even last October's 554-point drop was quickly erased by bullish investors, making them feel invincible.
Such investor confidence was hailed as a sign of financial maturity, and for any single investor this patient view seemed sensible. But what's right for one investor can wreak strange havoc when multiplied millions of times. The stubborn bullishness of small investors prevented the market from correcting and cleansing speculative tendencies. It further guaranteed that when the day of reckoning finally came, it would be swift and bloody.
In the end, Wall Street fell back on one last consoling myth: the oceanic flow of cash into mutual funds would buoy the market. Since 1991, $1.1 trillion has flowed into the market via this conduit. By early this year, Americans were channeling $21 billion a month into stock mutual funds. But small investors, though dogged, aren't automata, and they have now started to park money in bond or money market funds instead of stocks. The recent Wall Street bloodshed may lead them to re-evaluate the portion of their savings dedicated to stocks.
Why were so many people so blind to impending trouble? Booms tend to enlist the backing of their beneficiaries, and the longer they last, the more partisans they recruit. Brokerage houses touting stocks as safe for ordinary folk tend to play down the market's periodic treachery. Investment banks favor rising markets that accelerate the tempo of mergers and acquisitions and create the right atmosphere for public offerings of start-up companies. In a boom, it becomes hard for brokerage house analysts to broadcast their secret fears lest they seem disloyal. Our financial service companies aren't always the paragons of objectivity they pretend to be.
The nation's political leaders have largely been mute about the market's vulnerability. In December 1996 Mr. Greenspan warned of "irrational exuberance," but he didn't reprise this theme as the market grew even more irrational and exuberant. During the boom, while tens of millions of people accumulated huge paper profits, Washington officialdom, afraid of being stuck with the party-pooper label, became the silent prisoner of the bull market. The scandal-plagued Clinton team has been especially solicitous of the market, since the aura of well-being created by rising stocks has covered a multitude of sins.
While the market averages bounced back smartly yesterday in the wake of Monday's drop, the 9,337-point high of mid-July seems a distant memory. It is still unclear whether the recent turmoil represents a chastening correction or the threshold of a grim bear market. But for millions of investors newly drawn to stocks in the 1990's, it surely represents a loss of innocence.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Fliers are copingwith the Northwest strike, but things could get much tougher after Labor Day.

BYLINE: By Jane L. Levere 

 BODY:
THE pilots' strike at Northwest Airlines has not caused tremendous disruption so far for business travelers, since many carriers are temporarily increasing service at Northwest's primary hubs at Wayne County Metropolitan Airport in Detroit and Minneapolis/St. Paul International Airport.
However, such flying can be more expensive than usual, say some travel agency officials, who believe the other airlines are reducing availability of less expensive fares on routes where they normally compete with Northwest, as demand for seats currently often exceeds supply. 
 And although disruptions for travelers have been minimal so far, industry officials predict they could become quite severe if the strike extends into the two weeks after Labor Day, when business travel normally picks up.
Jim Faulkner, a Northwest spokesman, said the airline was trying to reschedule passengers on other carriers; he said this had been accomplished for 70 percent of Northwest's passengers so far.
To make up for the loss of Northwest's service, AMR's American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, Trans World Airlines and UAL's United Airlines have increased the frequency of flights or started using larger planes from their main hub cities to either Minneapolis or Detroit.
In addition, Kiwi International Airlines began new service on Monday between Newark International Airport and Detroit. Added service out of Minneapolis is also coming from Sun Country Airlines, a privately held charter carrier whose fares are priced at least one-third lower than those of scheduled carriers, according to the airline. Sun Country has already increased its service between Minneapolis and O'Hare International Airport in Chicago and will increase flights between Detroit and Kennedy International Airport in New York.
Meanwhile, Northwest's competitors on its Asian routes, including Japan Airlines and Cathay Pacific, said they did not need to add flights or increase the size of their aircraft to accommodate Northwest's passengers, since traffic to Asia has been depressed.
Although the major United States airlines said they were not raising fares on routes where they compete with Northwest, it appears that they are trying to charge travelers the highest prices they offer. Unlike other big carriers -- which have been making full coach fares nonrefundable to avoid strike-related double booking -- United Airlines is offering a fully refundable coach fare that is approximately $50 higher than the normal full coach fare; the carrier is also offering a less expensive nonrefundable full coach fare. United officials acknowledged that they were making more of the refundable fares -- which were also sold before the Northwest strike -- available than usual.
"There's no question in my mind, when you have supply-and demand economics, and there's more demand than supply, the airlines are trying to raise their yields," said Travis Tanner, president of Carlson Wagonlit Travel, a major corporate travel company. "They're trying to take as much revenue on the plane as they can, and small travel agents and individuals are finding it almost impossible to get discounts."
Corporate travel agencies have scrambled to help clients stranded by the Northwest strike. Early last month, American Express, Carlson Wagonlit and Rosenbluth International started making alternate travel plans for customers in the event of a strike.
Although arranging alternative transportation has so far not been a big problem for most business travelers, the strike has inconvenienced many in small, often annoying, ways. Tom Polski, the Minneapolis-based vice president of public relations and communications for Carlson Hospitality Worldwide, was originally scheduled to fly Monday on Northwest to Brussels for a meeting; instead, he rescheduled the meeting and was to fly last night on Delta, via Atlanta. Mr. Polski said he felt "fortunate" that he was able to rearrange his plans relatively easily.
Sue Gilles, a Detroit-based marketing specialist for Genentech Inc., was to fly to San Francisco yesterday on American, rather than on Northwest, her carrier of choice. She would have preferred flying on United -- in whose frequent-flier program she participates, along with Northwest's -- but United's schedule did not fit her needs. She said she also had a layover in Chicago that made her trip three hours longer than usual.
Many in the travel industry predicted that prospects for business travelers could be far gloomier after the Labor Day holiday if the strike continues. Melissa Abernathy, a spokeswoman for American Express, said she expected a "spike" in business travel immediately after the holiday, while Mr. Tanner of Carlson Wagonlit predicted even greater disruption the following week, should the strike last that long.
"Next week will be softer because it will be a four-day week," he said. "The problem will come when people start trying to book for the following week."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Despite Wall Street's problems, many on Madison Avenue are upbeat about consumers.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
ADVERTISERS, agencies and the media are warily optimistic that the free-spending ways of American consumers, which have fueled more than three years of solid growth on Madison Avenue, will survive the wild gyrations on Wall Street relatively intact.
The advertising industry is notoriously sensitive to the whims of public mood because how people feel about themselves so often depends on how they feel about the economy. If shoppers are so rattled by a plunge in stock market prices that a national buyers' strike ensues in supermarkets, car showrooms and department stores, marketers may sharply pare ad spending. That would wound agencies, which were hard hit during the recession in the early 1990's. 
 Executives relaxed yesterday when the Dow Jones industrial average roared back, recovering part of the decline that had left the closely followed index, with apologies to George Bush, a thousand points lighter. Though the coming weeks may yet bring another tumble, they said they still believed that the advertising picture remained positive.
"I'm not all that surprised by the uncertainty, insecurity and turmoil," said Peter A. Georgescu, chairman and chief executive at Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York, "but I have yet to be persuaded that we're looking at something fundamentally calamitous."
"People still have their jobs," said Mr. Georgescu, whose agency creates campaigns for giant advertisers like Citicorp, the Colgate-Palmolive Company, the Ford Motor Company and the Philip Morris Companies. "I don't think they will go deep into bunkers and pull the blankets over their heads."
And the economic uncertainties, he added, may spur marketers "to place more emphasis on pushing the bottom line the old-fashioned way, by selling more stuff."
"That gives agencies a wonderful opportunity as well as a serious challenge: to make something concrete happen in the marketplace," he said.
Eugene P. Beard, vice chairman for finance and operations at the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York, echoed Mr. Georgescu.
"On a relative basis, we should be O.K.," he said of Interpublic, which owns agencies like Ammirati Puris Lintas, Lowe Group and McCann-Erickson World Group, "because I think we've been prudent enough to make sure we haven't stepped off the horizon."
"We had two or three meetings in the last month," Mr. Beard said, "to make sure that we stayed very, very focused."
"You've got to make your numbers, watch your cash flow, maintain your strong balance sheet and concentrate on what you're doing for clients and shareholders," he added. "If you do that, I think you have an opportunity."
The leading forecaster of Madison Avenue also predicted little fallout despite the Dow Jones falloff.
"There's no question that doom and gloom, and uncertainty, are not good things," said Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at McCann-Erickson USA, a unit of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising in New York. "But I don't think this will net out to be much of a factor in ad spending."
Mr. Coen forecast in June that marketers would spend a record $200.3 billion to advertise this year in the United States, up 6.8 percent from $187.5 billion in 1997.
"I'll be watching closely," he said, "but I'm not making any significant modification yet in my figures."
Two industry analysts offered upbeat assessments of the future.
"Consumer confidence has proven to be a very strong leading indicator of ad spending," said William Bird, who follows the advertising and publishing industries for the Salomon Smith Barney unit of Travelers Group in New York, "and I don't see anything that would alarm me at this early juncture."
The multinational advertisers that hire such large agency companies as Y.& R., Interpublic, Omnicom Group and WPP Group P.L.C. "are spending at very healthy levels to maintain top-line growth,' he added.
"There may be unhappy people on Wall Street," he said, "but the Coca-Colas are still focused on unit growth and driving that unit growth through advertising."
Alan J. Gottesman, managing director at West End Communications/Consulting in New York, played down the preoccupation with Wall Street.
"Let's talk about the real America," he said, which "is not all that affected by this. People are still working; they're not getting fired or laid off. And more people are making more money. If some yuppie can't buy a house in the Hamptons, it won't have any impact on the advertising business."
There were, of course, some cautionary notes amid the generally sanguine mood.
"The market psychology affects spending," said David Verklin, chief executive at Carat North America in New York, a media services unit of Aegis Group P.L.C., "and clients are inherently conservative."
"The one thing left up for grabs is the fourth quarter," he added, "which accounts for at least 33 percent of annual spending. Everyone will make decisions next week and the week after about the fourth-quarter spot TV and radio markets. Will they want to spend that extra $5 million to add a schedule between Thanksgiving and Christmas?"
Bill Whitehead, chief executive for North America at Bates Worldwide in New York, part of Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C., recalled a two-week trip from which he just returned, visiting dealers who sell cars for a client, Hyundai Motor America, along with more expensive marques in sibling showrooms.
"The dealers told me they could not keep the BMW's and Mercedeses and Porsches in stock," Mr. Whitehead said. "Now the question will be whether consumers sustain that, or keep that money in their pockets."
Still, "the economy is pretty damn strong," he added, "and this is a great opportunity for advertisers to be aggressive and invest to build brand equity."
Media executives said they perceived no advertiser reticence.
"People's fourth quarter looks very strong," said Ann S. Moore, president at People magazine in New York, published by the Time Inc. unit of Time Warner Inc., "and we see no impact at this point" from the stock market's turbulent ride.
Larry Goodman, president for CNN Sales and Marketing in New York, who oversees cable networks also owned by Time Warner, said: "It has been exceptionally calm. We had no cancellations. In fact, we ended up with two mutual fund companies saying, 'Get me on the air.' "
At TV Guide magazine, said Richard G. Porter, senior vice president and publisher in New York, "so far it's business as usual."
He suggested with a chuckle that there could be a silver lining in Wall Street's woes for TV Guide, which the News Corporation is selling to United Video Satellite Group: If consumers curtail spending by forgoing restaurant meals and movies, they may stay home to -- yes, watch more television.

HEADLINE: North Korea Draws Anger With Test Of a Missile

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 1

 BODY:
Congressional leaders, already angered at reports that North Korea may be building a new underground nuclear weapons plant, responded today to the firing of a new medium-range missile across Japan on Monday with threats to cut off all food aid and other assistance to the North Koreans.
In Tokyo, the Japanese suspended aid to North Korea and put off talks on normalizing relations, officials said. 
 "They fired a shot across Japan's bow and therefore across ours too," said Senator Gordon H. Smith, Republican of Oregon, as the Senate moved to toughen the certification required of President Clinton before money can be released for a nuclear energy program given to North Korea in return for pledges not to build weapons.
The United States is now the largest donor of food to the famine-plagued North Koreans.
An American delegation has been holding talks this week in New York on nuclear issues, including the intelligence reports of a possible new weapons factory, with North Korean diplomats.
The North Koreans failed to show up for today's meeting, saying that they were awaiting new instructions from their Government. American officials said that the Korean diplomats were surprised and embarrassed by the missile test on Monday, indicating that they are far from the power loop in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital.
It was the first firing of a new class of ballistic missile, the Taepodong-1, which has now proved itself capable of hitting Japan. Japanese ships and planes were searching for the wreckage of the missile today in the Sea of Japan, 240 miles off the Noto Peninsula.
In New York, the leader of the North Korean delegation, Kim Gye Kwan, also failed to attend a scheduled meeting with Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, the New York Republican who is chairman of the House International Relations Committee. This was the second time within a week that Mr. Kim agreed to meet Mr. Gilman here but then did not appear.
Mr. Gilman, speaking at a news conference this afternoon at the United States Mission to the United Nations, said that the talks were at "a very critical juncture." He had been briefed by the American delegation leader, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Charles Kartman, but would not discuss details of the talks.
Talks with the North Koreans are always held in almost total seclusion, without any public comment by the Americans. The North Koreans are seen as a very skittish and unpredictable team, representative of the world's most secretive rulers.
"I've been supporting the ongoing talks," Mr. Gilman said, "but unless there is going to be an agreement that meets Congressional requirements, the support in the Congress will dissipate."
The North Koreans have complained that Congress is already holding up millions of dollars in disbursements of American contributions to the $6 billion energy program supported by the United States, South Korea and Japan.
Mr. Gilman said today that Congress was demanding tighter surveillance of North Korea and a higher level of cooperation from Pyongyang, where Kim Jong Il, the son of the late dictator, Kim Il Sung, is expected to be inaugurated as President next week. President Clinton is required to certify that North Korea is not violating its agreement to stop developing and exporting weapons.
Two of Mr. Gilman's aides, Mark Kirk and Peter Brookes, who just returned from a trip to North Korea to assess the food situation, issued a report today that documented the existence of "hunger prisons," where people caught foraging for food are confined.
Mr. Kirk said that the outside world is now feeding 7 million of North Korea's 22 million people -- including all children under 7, the elderly and hospital patients. He described the military as a powerful institution still able to override civilian officials. Under a Stalinist-style command economy, North Korea has all but ceased to function as an industrial or agricultural nation.
"I've supported food aid to North Korea in the past to save lives," Mr. Gilman said today. "But that kind of assistance cannot continue forever without some basic reforms in the North Korean economy."
In Washington today, Republicans were bitter in their attacks on the Clinton Administration for not freezing cooperation with North Korea.
