HEADLINE: EDITORIAL OBSERVER;
President Clinton Lectures on Russia's Future

BYLINE: By ELEANOR RANDOLPH 

 BODY:
With markets crashing, banks shuddering and the Government imploding, Russians may not feel the urgent need for a lecture from President Clinton about economic reform. Despite the worthiness of his message about how Russia must ultimately follow "the fundamental economic imperatives of the global market" to flourish, the President's talk yesterday to young leaders in Moscow still sounded a little like the rich man giving a pep talk to the poor folk under the bridge: Yes, it's cold and gloomy down there, I know, and yes, it's painful now, but I promise it will be better in the long run.
Most Russians have been waiting a long time for the long run. During earlier decades, they endured Soviet five-year plans that dangled impossible promises of the golden Communist banquet where everyone would share more or less equally in the great national harvest. As the Soviet center fell apart in 1991, the old system gave way to a tender young democracy and an increasingly beastly form of capitalism. Many young Russians I talked with as a Moscow correspondent in those exuberant days saw a future where freedom was somehow accompanied by a BMW, as if democracy and a fat wallet would all arrive together in one lush Western package. 
 Now, faced with a reality that is increasingly painful to millions of people, Russia seems altogether too ready to decide that the Western reforms -- at least as their leaders and their shadow government of businessmen boyars practiced them -- were just another faulty experiment. "Stay the course?" said the Harriman Institute Prof. Steven Solnick of the President's advice. "To the extent they were on the course, they hate it. I think we need to steel ourselves for a long period of anti-Americanism."
Into this whirlwind comes President Clinton, suggesting grand needs for an increasingly needy country. Fair tax laws and fair enforcement, easier land transfers, intellectual property rights, independent courts, strong banks, security markets that protect investors, social spending that promotes hope and opportunity, a safety net for the dislocated and vigilance against "hidden ties between government and business interests" -- this was his list of lofty goals for a better Russia.
"This is not an American agenda," the President assured his young audience. "These are the imperatives of the global marketplace. . . ."
These imperatives, as worthy as they are, did not even lead the Russian nightly news a few hours later. The vacuum in the Kremlin, the fear of government upheaval, the weakening ruble, the stores with emptying shelves and the first day of school were more urgent topics for most Russians trying to survive far beyond the latest Presidential summit. Seven years after the end of the Soviet era, advice from a Westerner, especially an American President who acknowledges that he is not leavening it with financial aid, is hardly news.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES

BYLINE: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI with David Firestone 

 BODY:

A Straphanger Gets a Film Role
Somebody call ICM! GENE RUSSIANOFF, the earnest underdog lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign (a transportation advocacy group) and the New York Public Interest Research Group, (a government watchdog organization), has gone Hollywood. Sort of. 
 Mr. Russianoff abandoned his usual work schedule yesterday -- "gearing up to bash all the candidates for Governor for not giving New Yorkers enough subway and bus service," he said -- to tape a scene with MARK WAHLBERG for "The Yards," a Miramax film to be released next year about corruption in the commuter rail industry. The movie also stars JAMES CAAN, CHARLIZE THERON, JOAQUIN PHOENIX and FAYE DUNAWAY.
Mr. Russianoff, who has never appeared in a movie, arrived on the set -- a No.6 train at the Parkchester stop in the northern Bronx -- at 7 A.M. (Because he couldn't bear the thought of taking a car to get to the set of a movie about trains, he had to wake up at 4 o'clock to catch the subway from his home in Brooklyn.) He was to play the nonspeaking role of a snoozing subway rider. As Mr. Russianoff plopped into a seat across from Mr. Wahlberg -- whom the not-yet-ready-for-prime-time Mr. Russianoff still calls Marky Mark, by the way -- the assistant director told him to look as if he was sleeping. They had a brief spat.
"I told him no one would sleep on the subway unless you were semi-comatose," he said. "It's dangerous."
 
Former Politician Finds Employment
RUTH W. MESSINGER, whose long political career has been so closely associated with the borough of Manhattan, announced yesterday that she had accepted a job with larger boundaries: president and executive director of the American Jewish World Service, a nonprofit group that provides aid and technical advice to developing nations around the world.
Since her loss last fall to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Ms. Messinger, a former Manhattan Borough President and City Council member, has been unfamiliarly untethered to the political world. Though she has accepted teaching jobs at Hunter and Queens colleges, she said her new position is a natural outgrowth of her life's work.
"It's a wonderful opportunity to work in the field of social justice, which is what I believe my political and professional career has been about," she said. The 13-year-old group, based in Manhattan, provides volunteers and assistance to countries in need of aid in health, economic development, agriculture and education, as well as disaster relief.
 
Motherly Concerns
With things falling off buildings all around town, some mothers are worried. One of them is MADONNA.
In an affidavit filed in State Supreme Court on Monday, Madonna joined a lawsuit intended to stop the Y.M.C.A. on West 63d Street from building a 41-story residential tower near her apartment building on Central Park West, The Associated Press reported.
The proposed construction, according to the filing, would create a "hazard for me and my child."
Madonna, who identifies herself in the affidavit as a professional entertainer and a mother, is one of several Upper West Side mothers to file affidavits in the case, said Kevan Cleary, a spokesman for the coalition of West Side groups that filed the lawsuit on Aug. 16. The defendants include the Y and the Buildings Department.
The affidavit cited the July 21 incident in which scaffolding gave way on the north side of the 48-story Conde Nast building on 43d Street.
Elise Fink, a spokeswoman for the Department of Buildings, said the department had been working to insure the site's safety and had met with community leaders, contractors and representatives of the Y.M.C.A. ALEX KUCZYNSKI with David Firestone

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW: THE SCENE;
Summit Meeting Teeters On Edge of Self-Parody

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 1

 BODY:
As President and Mrs. Clinton prepared to retire tonight at the Marriott Hotel near the banks of the Moscow River, a car pulled over not far from the hotel entrance. The doors opened, and Vladimir Zhirinovsky, the ultranationalist who controls a bloc of seats in Russia's Parliament, climbed out.
Mr. Zhirinovsky turned toward the hotel and yelled, in so many exceptionally unprintable words, "Clinton, you are an idiot!" After applying the coarsest description of sexual relations to the President, he added, "Your dollar is dirt, and this dirt is all over the world!" 
 He then produced a dollar in his hand and told his supporters, "Burn it." They did.
This evening, Moscow television broadcast videotape of the event in its entirety, barely-bleeped epithets and all.
This sort of disgrace would never have happened if Leonid Brezhnev still ran things. But Brezhnev and the Soviet Union are dead, Boris N. Yeltsin is alive and, by several accounts still kicking, and Russian-American summitry -- still somber and inflated as ever -- now teeters at times on the slippery brink of self-parody.
Depending on one's point of view, Moscow right now is either no place for such a worldly event or the perfect place. The contrast between former summit meetings and the current state of the two countries -- and their leaders -- is simply too great to ignore.
The public aspects of this summit meeting have been scripted almost entirely for television; some events, such as a wreath-laying in Red Square this morning, were staged solely for cameras and a small pool of reporters.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin dutifully mugged for the cameras all day, exchanging bear hugs, gifts and tributes to the enduring friendship of their nations at almost every public opportunity.
Mr. Yeltsin, looking reasonably hale, good-naturedly stiffed news photographers by turning his back on them during one ceremony.
Mr. Clinton, ever gregarious, practiced staff-written Russian-language platitudes on crowds all day. Beyond the range of the lens, however, the economy is unavoidable.
As the Clintons and the Yeltsins and some 115 other luminaries dined in the Kremlin tonight on pike rasstegai, salmon, roast-beef-stuffed omelet and the obligatory wine and caviar, Muscovites a few blocks away were resting after a day of methodically picking grocery shelves clean of food and dry goods they fully expect will soon disappear.
Moscow newspapers reported today that ships loaded with imported goods, now a huge share of Russian purchases, were turning away or refusing to unload because of the fiscal uncertainty. Non-perishables like grain, oils and, in St. Petersburg, refrigerators were vanishing from stores, and prices in some instances had reportedly doubled.
Olympic-quality runners, fearful of being injured in a coup, threatened to desert a world-class track meet this weekend. The Russian Olympic Committee was hampered in responding because its electricity had been turned off for nonpayment.
And that was merely the Russian side of the equation. Moments after Mr. Clinton finished cutting a fat loaf of Russian bread this morning in Mr. Yeltsin's marble-and-bronze Kremlin study, the two men were jerked back to reality by a CBS News correspondent who suddenly asked: What about the economy?
The correspondent, Scott Pelley, was seeking a response from Mr. Clinton about Monday's 500-point drop in the stock market. But the question could just as easily have been asked of Mr. Yeltsin, whose nation's own stock market has shed 60 percent of its blue-chips' value in the last two months alone.
Mr. Pelley was escorted from the room by Russian officials and briefly stripped of his press credentials for breaking a promise to be silent.
As Mr. Zhirinovsky demonstrated, the respect usually accorded to summit participants has gone largely by the boards this week.
Mrs. Clinton played a decided second today to Naina Yeltsin as the two toured a factory, and Mrs. Yeltsin decried the lack of women's roles in business. Mrs. Clinton was even asked point-blank about her outlook in the wake of the President's admission that he carried on a sexual relationship with Monica Lewinsky.
"I've been getting along fine," Mrs. Clinton responded; reporters later analyzed her body language and facial expressions during a joint appearance with Mr. Clinton -- their first since his admission -- at a Russian public school. Mr. Clinton also suffered his share of slings. In downtown Moscow, a British manager of a fine-arts reproduction company was selling a special edition of Russian nesting dolls, featuring the likenesses of Mr. Clinton, Ms. Lewinsky and three other women with whom he has been said to have had -- or tried to have -- some involvement.
The manager, David Segal, said the $35 dolls "are being produced as fast as the people can get the stock for them."
Mr. Segal said he was merely doing his part for the Russian economy. "We're going to have most of one village turning them out," he said in an interview this week.

HEADLINE: Airline and Pilots to Weigh New Talks

BYLINE: The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1

 BODY:
The heads of Northwest Airlines and its striking pilots union met for almost five hours today with the Transportation Secretary but agreed only to consider returning to the bargaining table.
The Secretary, Rodney E. Slater, said that the Clinton Administration would not order the pilots, on strike for four days, back to work, at least not for now. "It remains the President's view that it is up to the parties to reach agreement without Federal intervention at this time," he said. 
 Mr. Clinton has the power to order the pilots back to work for a 60-day cooling-off period, but so far has been reluctant to do so.
Mr. Slater met with John H. Dasburg, chief executive of Northwest; Richard B. Hirst, another executive; J. Randolph Babbitt, president of the Air Line Pilots Association, and Steven Zoller, chairman of the Northwest pilots' union.
The meeting with the Transportation Secretary came after Northwest announced that it had laid off 177 workers and said many of its 50,000 employees could follow.
A company spokeswoman said 162 dispatchers and 15 meteorologists would be laid off. Northwest deferred a decision on its other employees until Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Rebound on Wall Street

 BODY:
The American stock market bounced back yesterday, encouraging investors around the world and reducing the pressure on central bankers to lower interest rates here and in Europe. Perhaps markets will now pause to see just how far Asia's economic woes will spread.
Until this summer, most investors had been willing to act as if the American economy would continue to hum along, despite growing problems that have plunged most of Asia into recession. Now many think it will be difficult for the world's leading economies to avoid slowing. "It is only a question of time," warned Neal M. Soss, the chief United States economist for Credit Suisse First Boston, "before even the mighty U.S. economy catches cold." 
 That said, the evidence of illness in this country is so far limited. There are signs that banks are less willing to lend than they had been, and manufacturers are seeing a slowing of orders. But American consumers have continued to spend, and overall economic activity has not fallen off a cliff.
That economic strength was cited by some analysts yesterday as evidence that American stocks had fallen too far, and those arguments helped the market recover. But an irony of the current situation is that the apparent health of the American economy may end up hurting the world. That is because the Federal Reserve is charged by law with focusing on the United States' economy, with the rest of the world a secondary priority. Yet what is happening is that much of the world is being starved of capital as investors who only recently were all too eager to invest in emerging markets are now fleeing those markets. Central banks in those countries have raised interest rates in a futile attempt to bring capital back, only to see the high rates further depress the local economy.
As Robert J. Barbera, the chief economist for Hoenig & Company, said this week, "a global central bank would drive interest rates sharply lower in response to these obvious deflationary forces." But there is no such bank. The closest thing available would be concerted action by the Federal Reserve and the major European central banks. Calmer markets make that less likely.
One Asian country, Malaysia, took matters into its own hands yesterday by announcing stringent capital controls -- hoping to stabilize the value of Malaysia's currency while allowing local interest rates to fall and stimulating local business activity. Such a move, however, will make foreign investment even less likely, and runs the risk of encouraging corruption since it will be up to the Government to decide which people, or companies, can move their money out of the country. But it is an understandable move in the current situation, and only serves to heighten the need for international action to get the world growing again.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Treasuries Register Sharpest Loss in More Than 4 Months

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
With the stock market having rebounded from Monday's decline, Treasury securities posted their sharpest loss in more than four months yesterday. Volume was heavy, as flows of capital from equity markets into United States Government debt eased.
The yield of the 30-year Treasury bond -- the benchmark for various loans -- moved sharply higher, to 5.34 percent from 5.25 percent on Monday. And the price, which moves in the opposite direction, fell 1 17/32 to 102 17/32, or about $15 for each $1,000 of bonds in the hands of investors. 
 While the decline in bonds was coupled to the rise in stocks, a falling dollar in world currency trading also weighed on the market. A weak dollar makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasuries more attractive to foreign investors because of the potential gains they could make in currency translation.
Donald Fine, the chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said the National Association of Purchasing Management index for August, which was released yesterday, was down slightly, to 49.4. But more important, he said, it was under 50 for the third consecutive month. A reading below 50 implies contraction in the industrial sector.
By late in the day the yield on a 10-year note was 5.05 percent and a two-year note was 4.86 percent. Including the 30-year bond, all the rates were below the 5.5 percent Federal Reserve target for the Federal funds rate, a situation known as an inverted yield curve.
"It is the first sign of a recession at some point in the horizon," Mr. Fine said. "But given the incredibly strong economic base, it could be 18 months or so before we feel the effects. It's not in the economic numbers yet, but the inverted yield is probably the earliest leading indicator of economic duress. And while recessions do not last as long as expansions, for many it feels like forever."
Mr. Fine said that he believed the current yield curve suggested a monetary easing of 50 to 75 basis points. "However," he added, "it may be a few months before the central bank decides to act. Certainly if the stock market plummets further it may act sooner." A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Since last month's Federal Open Market Committee meeting, market events have made the Fed's bias toward tightening an anachronism, Mr. Fine said.
"It is now likely that, in the minds of the F.O.M.C. members, their bias has been removed in favor of a neutral stance," he said. "However, the Fed will be reluctant to ease until there are definitive signs of a sustainable slowdown in both consumption and housing. These signs should appear fairly soon, and thus also point to the next Fed move as being an ease, but this might not occur for a few months."

HEADLINE: WORLD ECONOMIES: THE LENDER;
Russian Woes Increase Doubts Over U.S. Money for I.M.F.

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1

 BODY:
The current economic turbulence has widened the gulf dividing Republicans over whether to approve new financing for the International Monetary Fund.
Congress appeared certain to increase the American contribution to the monetary fund when lawmakers left on a monthlong recess in August. But with the Senate having resumed business this week, and the House due back next week, the new financing is now teetering on the brink with each day's gloomy news. 
 Critics led by Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, say the fresh financial turmoil in Russia underscores their belief that replenishing the fund's reserves now would only throw good money after bad.
"The evidence is now undeniable that the I.M.F. has played a destabilizing role in world financial affairs," Mr. Armey said in a letter to House members today. "Russia simply took the I.M.F.'s latest $4.8 billion loan installment and threw it into the currency markets, where it was instantly vaporized."
But the fund's supporters argue that the current crisis is proof that the United States cannot be shielded from other countries' problems and that Congress must act quickly to approve the Administration's $18 billion request to avert even greater financial woes.
"It's a symbol as much as anything else that the world community will try to contain the meltdown of the international monetary system," Senator Ted Stevens, the Alaska Republican who heads the Appropriations Committee, said in an interview today.
These divergent views illustrate the split among Republicans, particularly in the House, between market purists who criticize the fund's secretive practices and internationalists who say the fund is essential to help maintain stability in the increasingly global economy.
"Markets respond to confidence, and the I.M.F. is one of those confidence builders," said Senator Chuck Hagel, a Nebraska Republican.
Indeed, that is an argument that Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, have been making on Capitol Hill for months. It is a theme that has been hammered home by business groups and by farmers, who are watching their exports to Asia dwindle or disappear.
Why would Republicans, traditionally the party of big business, block something that Wall Street would embrace? Mainly because the popular notion that the Republican Party and Wall Street walk in lockstep has been steadily eroding since Republicans like Senator Arthur Vandenberg led the party away from isolationism after World War II.
"There's a very uneasy relation between U.S. corporate interests and the G.O.P. majority, particularly in the House," said Edmund B. Rice, executive director of the Coalition for Employment Through Exports, a business group that supports new financing for the monetary fund.
"They are more grounded in small-town, rural, religious, political interests," Mr. Rice said of the House Republicans. "They're much more focused on domestic issues and suspicious of international involvement and certainly of large U.S. corporations."
The more internationally minded Senate overwhelmingly approved the full $18 billion months ago and was expected to reaffirm that vote this week. But the House leadership has balked. The House seemed prepared to follow the Senate in late July, when Mr. Armey conceded that the fund's supporters probably had the votes. But his apparent acquiescence upset House conservatives, and Mr. Armey quickly reversed himself and vowed to fight on.
The about-face also grew out of the political battle over the House leadership between Mr. Armey and Representative Robert L. Livingston of Louisiana, who heads the House Appropriations Committee. Both men want to be Speaker if Newt Gingrich steps down to run for President in 2000 and have been trying to curry favor among House Republicans.
Mr. Armey counts among his strongest supporters the House's most conservative members. Mr. Livingston, who supports the fund, has been looking to business groups, who favor more money for it, for support. But the events in Russia may be giving Mr. Livingston pause.
Whether the public cares is unclear. Even as the American stock market plunges, fueled in part by the uncertainty in Moscow, lawmakers say there is no public pressure to shore up the monetary fund.
Representative Jim Kolbe, an Arizona Republican and I.M.F. supporter, said today from Tucson, "It's not exactly a burning issue with most people."

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW: THE ACCORDS;
U.S. to Use Its Missile Warning System to Alert Russians to Launchings Worldwide

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 1

 BODY:
During the frigid days of the cold war, American satellites watched for the fiery launchings of Soviet missiles, a sign that the United States might soon be under nuclear attack.
Now that the nuclear standoff is over, the United States has found a new use for its warning systems. It plans to employ them to alert the Russians about missile launchings around the world. 
 On Wednesday, President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin plan to sign a new accord under which the United States and Russia will instantly share data about the launching of ballistic missiles and space payloads.
With Russia's economy deteriorating by the day and the Yeltsin Government in political crisis, arms control no longer holds center stage.
The idea of using American military technology to help the Russians plug the gaps in their early warning system recalls Ronald Reagan's heady dreams of a world in which the United States and the Russians would team up to develop "Star Wars" antimissile systems.
The objectives of the new accord, of course, are not nearly as grand, though they are still important.
With the collapse of the Soviet Union, Washington has become increasingly worried that Russia's warning system is so frayed that Moscow might misinterpret the data and conclude mistakenly that it is under attack. The result could be an accidental nuclear war.
It is not an abstract concern. For a few tense moments, the Russian military misread its data about the 1995 launching of a Norwegian scientific rocket as a possible submarine missile attack.
"The agreement provides further protection against an inadvertent nuclear exchange triggered by misidentification of a launch," said Robert G. Bell, a senior aide on the National Security Council.
The surprise test-firing of a North Korean missile over Japanese territory on Monday underscored the potential of launchings to unnerve neighboring nations.
Certainly, the Russian early warning system has many deficiencies. The Government's cash crunch has forced Russia to limit the deployment of warning satellites. Some ground-based radars are in poor repair. Others ended up on the wrong side of the border after the Soviet Union collapsed.
The Russian radar station at Skrunde, Latvia, was closed on Monday. The Baltic state had initially allowed the radar station to operate after the collapse of the Soviet Union, but finally concluded that it no longer wanted to serve as a Russian military outpost.
Col. Gen. Vladimir Yakovlev, commander of Russia's strategic rocket forces, said closing the Skrunde station would put a serious strain on Russia's warning network. Eventually, the military hopes to build a replacement station in nearby Belarus.
However limited their data, the Russians would also provide it to the United States under the new agreement.
The missile data accord was not the only measure intended to cope with the new dangers that have arisen since the cold war. The two sides also plan to sign an agreement on Wednesday calling for the disposal of weapons-grade plutonium.
Under the agreement, Russia and the United States would each remove 50 tons of plutonium from military stockpiles and dispose of it by using it as fuel in nuclear reactors or mixing it with waste.
Most of the details have yet to be negotiated, including the pressing question of how to pay for the Russian program to use the plutonium as reactor fuel.
An American official said the program could take more than five years -- an estimate some observers regard as optimistic. Even so, 50 tons represents only a quarter of Russia's estimated plutonium supply.
Still, American officials say the accord enshrines an important idea: Plutonium is not a resource to be husbanded, as the Russian nuclear establishment often argues, but a danger.
It is the missile-data agreement, though, that is the closest to being put into action. American officials said they hoped the system would be operational in a year or two.
This is how it would work. The United States receives data about missile launchings from two sources: Early warning satellites that detect the heat from missile launchings, and powerful radars in Greenland, Britain, Alaska and along the American coasts that track the missiles.
That data is synthesized at military processing centers and transmitted to the Pentagon, American military commanders and allies.
The new accord would add a new recipient: the Russians. The missile information could be transmitted directly to a Russian command post, like the Center for Space and Military Situations near Moscow.
Or a joint American-Russian command center might be established and the data sent there. That would enable the two sides to discuss the information and provide another check against misunderstanding.
If Norway launched another scientific rocket, for example, the Americans would provide data on the origin and time of the launching, its trajectory and moment of expected impact. There would be no more tense moments when Russian commanders struggled to figure out if the launching was hostile or benign.
American launchings would be included in the data dispatched to the Russians. But the United States will probably withhold information on Russia's own missile launchings.
The concern is that the Russians might launch missiles and then use the American data they receive to determine the limits and vulnerabilities of the American warning system. Even as the United States seeks to broaden its cooperation with the Russians, the military rivalry lingers on. To supplement the system, the United States is calling for a new international arrangement in which nations would provide advance notice of their missile launchings.
Bruce Blair, an expert on nuclear command and control systems at the Washington-based Brookings Institution, said the accord would help Moscow and Washington better understand the spread of missile technology in the third world.
"It is a good idea on several levels," Mr. Blair said. "It would alleviate coverage gaps and false alarms that could be a source of trouble."

HEADLINE: Zedillo Tells Mexico Painful Economic Policies Are Farsighted

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1

 BODY:
President Ernesto Zedillo tonight made his first major statement about the effects of the world financial crisis on Mexico. Mr. Zedillo acknowledged that plunging oil prices had forced painful budget cuts and urging Mexicans to be patient and work hard to help the country continue to grow.
"I must be the first to warn that the circumstances in which our economy will operate in the near future will be difficult," Mr. Zedillo said in his annual state of the union address. But Mexico can expect to average 4 percent growth for the two years that remain in his six-year term, he said, "as long as we keep our spirits high and work hard." 
 In an hourlong speech that defended his Government's efforts to solve everything from surging crime to illiteracy, Mr. Zedillo devoted the most time to explaining his often-painful economic policies, arguing that they had so far helped Mexico to bend, but not break, with the global financial pressures.
The extraordinary recent losses in the Mexican financial markets after Russia's de facto devaluation of the ruble surrounded Mr. Zedillo's report to Congress with an air of crisis.
Politicians and analysts of all stripes delivered their own assorted report cards on the President's performance in his four years in office.
"A quick look at the economic indicators reveal that our country is sustaining itself on the pillars of deceit and the people's poverty," Senator Gabriel Jimenez Remus of the opposition National Action Party told the Congress hours before Mr. Zedillo's address. "Falling per capita income, rising inflation, the devaluation of our currency, ever rising unemployment -- all are shoving our country toward the third world."
"Fifth Year Begins in Financial Crisis" was the headline today in the newspaper Reforma. The paper featured a poll that showed that 51 percent of Mexicans approved Mr. Zedillo's Presidency, down from 60 percent in December.
"Zedillo's approval ratings have begun to decline," the newspaper reported, "and the President's fall has been caused by the poor pace of the economy."
Even so, Mr. Zedillo is more popular than the opposition Mayor of Mexico City, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, and about half the 31 state governors.
The 1994 peso devaluation, during Mr. Zedillo's first month in office, provoked a worldwide financial crisis and plunged Mexico into recession. But the tight-money policies and fiscal discipline that he imposed after that brought the broad economic indicators back to healthy growth in two years.
The new economic turbulence, originating in Asia, has been washing over Mexico since July, when plunging world oil prices forced Mr. Zedillo to preside over the third severe budget cut this year. Soon the peso, which opened the year worth 12.4 American cents, began to slide. At the close of trading on Monday the peso was worth 10.03 cents.
Interest rates have climbed, to 38 percent in the secondary markets.
Mexican markets were closed today for a national holiday, the Day of the Presidential Report.
"People are saying that the President is weakened," Sergio Sarmiento, news director of the TV Azteca network, wrote in a newspaper column. "They say, with a certain degree of truth, that the international financial crisis is eroding the only point about which Zedillo could claim success, his handling of the macroeconomy.
"Everything else seems to be in disaster. But this isn't the first time Mr. Zedillo has been portrayed erroneously as defeated."

HEADLINE: WORLD ECONOMIES: THE STRATEGIES;
The Global Search for an Economic Parachute

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1

 BODY:
Europe and the United States today shunted aside a call from Japan for an emergency meeting of the world's largest economies to deal with Russia's economic crisis.
At the same time, leaders in several nations cast about for a fresh strategy to contain virulent outbreaks of economic instability. 
 Japan's new Prime Minister, Keizo Obuchi, asked for the meeting in a telephone call on Monday to Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain. But by the end of the day today it had been dismissed by Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who is fighting for political survival in a close German election campaign and is distancing himself from years of heavy financial support for Russia.
American officials also rejected the Japanese proposal, with some officials saying it would be counterproductive to gather financial leaders when no one agrees on how to remedy the global economic contagion, whose causes and cures appear more elusive every day.
"At the moment there is a vacuum in policy," said Allen Sinai, the chief global economist of Primark Decision Economics, an economic strategy advisory group. "No one has any good ideas. At the moment, one cannot see any real turnaround in Asia, Japan is getting sicker and Russia was a throw-away of money."
"The G-7 countries," he said, referring to the Group of Seven nations, which historically have taken the lead in global economic troubles, "are at a loss for what to do."
Senior Administration officials insist that they are batting around ideas in urgent calls with finance ministers and political leaders around the world, but they were loath to discuss them publicly.
The problem is complicated by vastly differing political agendas: Japan, Germany and the United States are consumed by domestic political events that have given their leaders precious little maneuvering room in one of the most complicated economic environments since the end of World War II.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who declared on Monday that "the world is currently working its way through a difficult period," stayed out of sight today, but he released a letter to leaders of both parties urging immediate Congressional approval of new financing for the International Monetary Fund.
"Events over the last eight months," Mr. Rubin wrote, "underscore the impact on the U.S. economy of developments abroad, including in Asia and Russia. We simply cannot afford any further delay in providing the I.M.F. with the resources it requires to help contain the threat of further financial and political instability around the world."
The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, was in California on vacation. On Friday he and Mr. Rubin are to meet with Japan's Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, in San Francisco, where they are expected to increase the pressure for immediate action by Japan to clean up its banking system and spur its economy. In recent weeks, hopes that the new Japanese Government would prove more energetic than the previous one have faded.
"A bigger meltdown in Japan is our biggest single nightmare, at a time when we have plenty of nightmares," a senior Administration official said over the weekend.
Some American officials suggested that Prime Minister Obuchi asked for a Group of 7 meeting to divert attention from Japan's problems. If so, it would be a difficult trick: Japan's investors are more focused on the numbing parliamentary debate over banking reform than they are about whether Russia will be able to pay its military.
But Japan is hardly the only country suffering domestic paralysis.
While Mr. Rubin has repeatedly called for $18 billion in new funds for the I.M.F., President Clinton has discussed the subject only in passing. Administration officials insist that the President is fully committed to the proposal, arguing that the timing is simply not yet right to begin twisting arms on Capitol Hill. Other Democrats, however, say the fight over financing may be the first test of whether Mr. Clinton's powers of persuasion have diminished since his admission of an inappropriate relationship with a White House intern.
Chancellor Kohl is performing his own political pirouette.
On the campaign trail this week, Mr. Kohl defended the West's strategy of giving Russia billions of dollars in aid in an effort to turn it into a market economy.
"From a German perspective, there was no alternative," he said, a reference to both Germany's security concerns and the billions of dollars that German financial institutions loaned to their Russian counterparts, much of which is now at risk. "It was in our elementary interest that Russia finds its way."
"I never said this will be a policy without setbacks," he added.
But it was Mr. Kohl who led the movement among European nations to delay aid to Russia after its effective devaluation of the ruble two weeks ago. Stanley Fischer, the No. 2 I.M.F. official, has said this delay greatly worsened Russia's problems.
Nonetheless, in cellphone calls from vacation retreats and E-mail letters among central bankers, ideas are being discussed on how to calm the world's financial anxieties.
The most common notion is to coordinate the lowering of interest rates around the world in hopes of stimulating growth. But Japan's interest rates are already at historic lows -- around 1 percent -- and companies there complain that no bank will lend them money at any price. The only advantage of a further cut would be to signal that the Government is interested in encouraging a modest amount of inflation, in the hope that it would initiate spending by consumers.
Another experiment being discussed by several nations -- but opposed by Washington -- is to control the exchange of international currencies in the hope of preventing damaging speculation.
But such a move would violate President Clinton's repeated calls for countries to embrace open markets, an appeal he renewed today in Moscow. "No nation, rich or poor, democratic or authoritarian, can escape the fundamental economic imperatives of the global market," he insisted in a speech at a Moscow university.
Some, however, are trying. Malaysia made a complete break with the strategy of open markets today when Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad announced sweeping controls that effectively prevent investors from converting their holdings in Malaysia into other currencies, including dollars. The announcement immediately set off a run for the exits: Prices on the Kuala Lumpur stock market fell 13.3 percent, the biggest decline in more than a decade.
American officials are worried that if Mr. Mahathir's experiment in cutting his economy off from investors around the world proves even briefly successful, it could be copied in other nations, all of whom are looking for a way to prevent a huge outflow of the foreign money that has given markets enormous power over the policy of governments.
Thailand and South Korea probably could not attempt such a move while under the I.M.F.'s tutelage. But Hong Kong's leaders have discussed the issue with American officials.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW;
Excerpts From Clinton's Remarks: 'You Have to Play by the Rules'

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from remarks by President Clinton yesterday at Moscow State University, as recorded by Federal News Service, a private transcription company:
 We Americans have fought and argued with each other, as we do even today. But we have preserved our freedom by remembering the fundamental values enshrined in our Constitution and our Declaration of Independence, by continuing to respect the dignity of every man, woman and child, to tolerate those with different ideas and beliefs than our own, to demand equality of opportunity, to give everyone a chance to make the most of his or her life. 
 Russia's great ally in World War II, our President, Franklin Roosevelt, said that democracy is a never-ending seeking for better things. For Americans, that means, in good times and bad, we seek to widen the circle of opportunity, to deepen the meaning of our freedom, to build a stronger national community.
Now, what has all that got to do with Russia in 1998? Your history is much longer than ours and so rich with accomplishment, from military victories over Napoleon and Hitler to the literary achievements of Pushkin, Tolstoy, Chekhov, Pasternak and so many others, to great achievements in art, music, dance, medicine, science . . . .
Yet for all your rich, long history, it was just seven years ago that Russia embarked on its own quest for democracy. . . .
Now you are at a critical point on your journey. There are severe economic pressures and serious hardships which I discussed in my meetings with your leaders this morning. The stakes are enormous. Every choice Russia makes today may have consequences for years and years to come.
Given the facts before you, I have to tell you that I do not believe there are any painless solutions. And indeed, an attempt to avoid difficult solutions may only prolong and worsen the present challenges.
First, let me make a couple of points. The experience of our country over the last several years, and especially in the last six years, proves that the challenges of the global economy are very great, but so are its rewards. The Russian people have met tremendous challenges in the past. You can do it here. You can build a prosperous future. You can build opportunity and jobs for all the people of this land who are willing to work for them if you stand strong and complete -- not run from but complete the transformation you began seven years ago.
 
Global Markets
The second point I want to make is the rest of the world has a very large stake in your success. Today, about a quarter of the world's people are struggling with economic challenges that are profound -- the people of your country, the people in Japan who have had no economic growth for five years. It's still a very wealthy country, but when they don't have any growth, it's harder for all other countries to trade with them who aren't so wealthy -- to grow -- other countries in Asia. And now we see, when there are problems in Russia or in Japan or questions about the economy of China, you see all across the world -- the stock market in Latin America drops. You see the last two days we've had big drops in the American stock market.
What does that say? Well, among other things, it says, whether we like it or not, we must build the future together because, whether we like it or not, we are going to be affected by what we do. We will be affected by what you do, and you will be affected by what we do. We might as well do it together and make the most of it.
Now, in terms of what has happened in America, obviously it's always more enjoyable when our stock market goes up than when it goes down. But I have talked to our Secretary of the Treasury about this several times since yesterday. I want to reiterate the point that I think is important for Russia, for America, for every country. We believe our fundamental economic policy is sound. We believe our people are working at record rates. And we are determined to stay on a path of fiscal discipline that brought us to where we are.
I think that wherever there are markets, there will always be changes in those markets. But we must attempt to move in the right direction. And that's what I want to talk to you about today. How can we move in the right direction?
When I look at all the young people here today -- and I have read about you and your background, young people from all over Russia seizing the possibilities of freedom to chart new courses for yourselves and your nation, making a difference by building businesses from modest loans and innovative ideas, by taking technologies created for weapons and applying them to human needs, by finding creative government solutions to complex problems, by improving medical care and fighting disease, by publishing courageous journalism, exposing abuses of power, producing literature and art and scholarship, changing the way people see their own lives, organizing citizens to fight for justice and human rights and a cleaner environment, reaching out to the world.
In this room today, there are young people doing all those things. That should give you great reason for hope. You are at the forefront of building a modern Russia. You are a new generation. You do represent the future of your dreams. Your efforts today will not only insure better lives for yourselves, but for your children and generations that follow.
I think it is important to point out, too, that when Russia chose freedom, it was not supposed to benefit only the young and well educated, the rich and well connected. It was also supposed to benefit the men and women who work in factories and farms and fought the wars of the Soviet era, those who survive today on pensions and government assistance. It was also supposed to benefit the laborers and teachers and soldiers who work every day but wait now for paychecks.
The challenge is to create a new Russia that benefits all responsible citizens of this country. How do you get there? I do not believe it is by reverting to the failed policies of the past. I do not believe it is by stopping the reform process in midstream, with a few Russians doing very well but far more struggling to provide for their families. I believe you will create the conditions of growth if, but only if, you continue to move decisively along the path of democratic, market-oriented, constructive revolution.
The Russian people have made extraordinary progress in the last seven years. You have gone to the polls to elect your leaders. Some 65 to 70 percent of you freely turn out in every election. People across Russia are rebuilding diverse religious traditions, launching a wide range of private organizations. Seventy percent of the economy now is in private hands. Not bureaucrats but consumers determine what goods get to stores and where people live. You have reached out to the world with trade and investment, exchanges of every kind, and leadership in meeting security challenges around the globe.
Now you face a critical moment. Today's financial crisis does not require you to abandon your march toward freedom and free markets. Russians will define Russia's future, but there are clear lessons, I would argue, from international experience. Here's what I think they are.
First, in tough times, governments need stable revenues to pay their bills, support salaries, pensions and health care. That requires decisive action to insure that everyone pays their fair share of taxes. Otherwise a few pay too much, many pay too little, the Government's in the hole and can never get out, and you will never be able to have a stable economic policy.
It is tempting for everyone to avoid wanting to pay any taxes. But if everyone will pay their fair share, the share will be modest and their incomes will be larger over the long run because of the stability and growth it will bring to this Russian economic system.
 
Lessons of Experience
Second, printing money to pay the bills and bail out the banks does not help. It causes inflation and ultimately will make the pain worse.
Third, special bailouts for a privileged few come at the expense of the whole nation.
Fourth, fair, equitable treatment of creditors today will determine their involvement in the nation tomorrow. The people who loan money into this nation must be treated fairly if you want them to be loaning money into this nation 4 years, 5 years, 10 years hence.
These are not radical theories. These are simple facts proven by experience. How Russia reacts to them will fundamentally affect your future. Surviving today's crisis, however difficult that may be, is just the beginning. To create jobs, growth and higher income, a nation must convince its own citizens and foreigners that they can safely invest.
Again, experience teaches what works: Fair tax laws and fair enforcement; easier transferability of land; strong intellectual property rights to encourage innovation; independent courts enforcing the law consistently and upholding contract rights; strong banks that safeguard savings; securities markets that protect investors; social spending that promotes hope and opportunity and a safety net for those who, in any given time in an open-market economy, will be dislocated, and vigilance against hidden ties between government and business interests that are inappropriate.
Now, this is not an American agenda. I will say it again. This is not an American agenda. These are the imperatives of the global marketplace, and you can see them repeated over and over and over again. You can also see the cost of ignoring them in nation after nation after nation.
Increasingly, no nation, rich or poor, democratic or authoritarian, can escape the fundamental economic imperatives of the global market. Investors and entrepreneurs have a very wide and growing range of choices about where they put their money. They move in the direction of openness, fairness and freedom.
Here Russia has an opportunity. At the dawn of the new century, there is a remarkable convergence. Increasingly, the very policies that are needed to thrive in the new economy are also those which deepen democratic liberty for individual citizens.
This is a wealthy country. It is rich in resources. It is richer still in people. It has done a remarkable job of providing quality education to large numbers of people. You have proven over and over and over again, in ways large and small, that the people of this country have a sense of courage and spirit, an unwillingness to be beat down and to give up. The future can be very, very bright.
But we can't ignore the rules of the game, because if there is a system of freedom, you cannot take away and no country -- not even the United States, with the size of our economy -- no country is strong enough to control what millions and millions and millions of people decide freely to do with their money.
 
A Future of Ideas
But every country will keep a large share of its own citizens' money and get a lot of money from worldwide investors if it can put in place systems that abide by the rules of international commerce. And all Russia needs is its fair share of this investment. You have the natural wealth. You have the people power. You have the education. All you need is just to get your fair share of the investment.
Now, 21st-century economic power will rest on creativity and innovation. I believe the young people in this room think they can be as creative or innovative as anyone in the world. It will rest on the free flow of information. It will rest on ideas.
Consider this, those of you who are beginning your careers. America's three largest computer and software companies are now worth more than all the American companies in our steel, automotive, aerospace, chemical and plastics industries combined -- combined: our three biggest computer companies.
The future is a future of ideas. No nation will ever have a monopoly on ideas. No people will ever control all the creative juices that flow in the human spirit more or less evenly across the world. You will do very well if you just get your fair share of investment. To get your fair share of investment, you have to play by the rules that everyone else has to play by.
That's what this whole crisis is about. No one could ever have expected your country to be able to make this transition without pain. You've only been at this seven years. Look at any European country that has had an open-market society for decades and decades and decades. They have hundreds, indeed thousands, of little organizations. They have major national institutions that all tend to reinforce these rules that I talked about earlier. Don't be discouraged, but don't be deterred. Just keep working until you get it in place. Once you get it in place, Russia will take off like a rocket, because you have both natural resources and people resources.
Now, I think it's important to point out, however, that economic strength -- let's go back to the rules; it depends on the rule of law. If somebody from outside a country intends to put money into a foreign country, they want to know what the rules are. What are the terms on which my money is being invested? How will my investment be protected? If I lose money, I want to know it's because I made a bad decision, not because the law didn't protect my money. It is very important.
Investors, therefore, seek honest governments, fair systems, fair for corporations and consumers, where there are strong checks on corruption and abuse of authority and openness in what the rules are on how investment capital is handled. Economic strength depends on equality of opportunity. There must be strong schools and good health care, and everyone must have a chance to share in the nation's bounty. And economic power must lie with people who vote their consciences, use new technologies to spread ideas, start organizations to work for change and build enterprises of all kinds.
Now, some seek to exploit this power shift that's going on in the world to take advantage of their fellow citizens. When this nation went from the old communist command-and-control system to an open, free system without all the intermediate institutions and private organizations that it takes years to build up, vacuums were created. And into those vacuums, some moved with an intent to exploit their fellow citizens, to enrich themselves without regard to fairness or safety or the future.
The challenges for any citizen -- this is not Russia-specific -- this would have happened and has happened in every single country that has had to make this transition. There's nothing inherently negative about this development. It is as predictable as the sun coming up in the morning. Every country has had to face this. But you must overcome it.
You must have a state that is strong enough to control abuses -- violence, theft, fraud, bribery, monopolism. But it must not be so strong that it can limit the legitimate rights and dreams and creativity of the people. That is the tension of creating the right kind of democratic market society.
 
Growing Economies
The bottom line is that the American people very much want Russia to succeed. We value your friendship. We honor your struggle. We want to offer support as long as you take the steps needed for stability and progress. We will benefit greatly if you strengthen your democracy and increase your prosperity.
Look what our partnership has already produced. We've reversed the dangerous buildup of nuclear weapons. We're two years ahead of schedule in cutting nuclear arsenals under Start 1. Start 2, which still awaits ratification in the Duma, will reduce our nuclear forces by two-thirds from cold-war levels. President Yeltsin and I already have agreed on a framework for Start 3 to cut our nuclear arsenals even further.
For you young people, at a time when India and Pakistan have started testing nuclear weapons, America and Russia must resume the direction the world should take -- away from nuclear weapons, not toward them. This is a very important thing.
We are working to halt the spread of weapons of mass destruction. We signed the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty with 147 other countries. We're working to contain the arms race between India and Pakistan, to strengthen controls on transfers of weapons technology, to combat terrorism everywhere.
Our bonds are growing stronger. And as they do, we will move closer to our goal of a Europe undivided, democratic and at peace. We've reached agreements for greater cooperation between NATO and Russia. And our soldiers serve side by side, making peace possible in Bosnia.
We don't always agree and our interests aren't always identical, but we work together more often than not, and the world is a better place as a result. Building peace is our paramount responsibility, but there is more we must do together.
One thing we need to do more together is prove that you can grow the economy without destroying the environment. A great man, looking at the condition of the environment, charged that humanity was a destroyer. He wrote, "Forests keep disappearing. Rivers dry up. Wildlife has become extinct. The climate is ruined. The land grows poorer and uglier every day." Chekhov wrote those words 100 years ago. Just imagine his reaction to the present environmental conditions, with toxic pollution ruining our air and water, and global warming threatening to aggravate flooding and drought and disease.
 
Challenging Times
Together we can create cleaner technologies to grow our economies without destroying the world's environment and imperiling future generations. Together we can harness the genius of our citizens not for making weapons but for building better communications, curing disease, combating hunger and exploring the heavens.
Together we can reconcile societies of different people with different religions and races and viewpoints, and stand against the wars of ethnic, religious and racial hatred that have dominated recent history. If we stand together and if we do the right things, we can build that kind of world. If the people of Russia stand for economic reform that benefits all the people of this country, America will stand with you.
As the people of Russia work for education and scientific discovery, as they stand against corruption and for honest government, against the criminals and terrorists and for the safety of ordinary citizens, against aggression and for peace, America will proudly stand with you. It is the right thing to do, but it is also very much in the interest of the American people to do so.
I was amazed there were some doubters back in America who said perhaps I shouldn't come here because these are uncertain times politically and economically. And there's questions being raised in the American press about the commitment of Russia to the course of reform and democracy.
It seems to me that anybody can get on an airplane and take a trip in good times and that friends come to visit each other in challenging and difficult times. I come here as a friend because I believe in the future of Russia. I come here also because I believe someone has to tell the truth to the people, so that you're not skeptical when your political leaders tell you things that are hard to hear.
There is no way out of playing by the rules of the international economy if you wish to be a part of it. We cannot abandon the rules of the international economy. No one can. There is a way to preserve the social safety net and the social contract and to help the people who are too weak to succeed. There is a way to do that. And there are people who will help to do that. But it has to be done.
So I come here as a friend. I come here because I know that the future of our children and the future of Russia's young people are going to be entwined. And I want it to be a good future, and I believe it can be.

HEADLINE: For Some, Texas Town Is Too Popular as Waste Disposal Site

BYLINE: By RICK LYMAN 

DATELINE: SIERRA BLANCA, Tex., Sept. 1

 BODY:
Lupe Bustamante cradled a gallon of milk under her arm in the dim and sparsely stocked Guerra General Store on the main street of this dusty outpost, population 600, and wondered why the whole world seemed to want to dump on her tiny town.
First, New York City completed a deal to ship its treated sewage to a ranch outside Sierra Blanca, where the sewage has been spread on the ground since 1992. Then, a New Jersey company announced this summer that it hoped to ship New York sludge to a ranch in the nearby hamlet of Allamoore. And now, the State of Texas believes it is coming to the end of a decadelong effort to enter into a compact with Vermont and Maine to store their low-level nuclear waste, along with its own, at a site just outside Sierra Blanca. The waste would be sealed in concrete and buried beneath the rocky desert. 
 "I think maybe they choose us because we are a small town, because we are so distant from everyone and because we have no political power," Ms. Bustamante said. "I think maybe they are taking advantage of us. I believe that most of the people are opposed to it."
Many environmentalists and residents said that the town was picked only because it is poor and Hispanic. About two-thirds of Sierra Blanca's residents are Hispanic, and the per capita income is $8,000, according to Census Bureau figures.
But for others in Sierra Blanca, the waste site would bring a much-needed economic boost. Already, the town's largest employer, with 40 workers, is Merco Joint Venture, the company that has shipped 400 tons of New York City sludge every day since 1992 to a 128,000-acre ranch outside town.
A short walk down the lone commercial strip, past the ice cream parlor, a couple of auto repair shops and a boarded-up movie theater, James Schilling was putting the finishing touches on the Sierra Motel, a 67-year-old fieldstone complex that he is renovating.
"As for the low-level nuclear site, I'm all for it, and most of the town is for it, too," Mr. Schilling said. "We need progress in this town, and this facility will bring money and jobs here. I feel it will be safe."
On Wednesday, the United States Senate is expected to vote on the proposed three-state compact, which has been approved by the House.
Several residents of Sierra Blanca joined Senator Paul Wellstone, a Minnesota Democrat who has been the project's most vocal Congressional opponent, for a rally on the Capitol steps today, hoping to sway the vote. During Senate debate tonight, Mr. Wellstone said, "It is a fight for communities all across the country who don't have political clout."
If the proposal passes the Senate, as even many of its opponents believe it will, then all it will need is President Clinton's signature to become a reality. It would be the 10th such compact created since the 1980 passage of a Federal law urging states to cooperate in dealing with the disposal problems of low-level nuclear waste, which includes medical waste and parts and machinery from nuclear power plants that have become contaminated. States that enter a compact have some protection from the Federal Government's forcing them to accept waste from other states.
The passage of the compact would give Texas permission to build the site and provide much of the money for it, said Lee Mathews, general counsel for the Texas Low-level Radioactive Waste Disposal Authority, which has been looking since the early 1980's for a disposal site.
But the authority would still need a license from the state. Earlier this summer, two administrative law judges in Austin ruled that the authority's application for the license should be rejected because it failed to include a thorough geological survey of the site or a proper assessment of the proposal's socio-economic impact on Sierra Blanca and surrounding Hudspeth County.
But the Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission, comprised of three officials appointed by Gov. George W. Bush, is not bound to follow the judges' ruling and can approve the license. Many environmentalists expect the commission to do so. Governor Bush, who had supported the project, says he is "troubled" by the decision of the judges and has urged the commission to "thoroughly review this recommendation and the facts to make their decision on sound science and the health and safety of Texans."
David Frederick, a lawyer for the Sierra Blanca Defense Fund, which was formed to fight the compact, said he thought there was "a real chance the commission will uphold the judges and reject the application."
"The common wisdom, however," Mr. Frederick said, "is that they will not."
The commission can make its ruling at any time, but it is not expected to until at least the fall.
The march to a low-level waste site has been a long one for Texas.
An initial site selected in the early 1980's in northern Hudspeth County was withdrawn after a storm of protest from residents. A second plan to locate the site in South Texas, in the scrublands between Laredo and Corpus Christi, was scuttled by objections from ranchers who instigated passage of a law mandating that the site be built only on state-owned land. Since most of that land is in West Texas, it pushed the waste disposal authority back into Hudspeth County, Mr. Mathews said.
A third site was selected in 1986, this time in Fort Hancock, near the El Paso County line. But the City of El Paso fought the proposal. Finally, in 1991, a judge ruled against the site and it, too, was abandoned.
By this time, a new state law had been passed mandating that the site be situated within a 400-square-mile box of land in Hudspeth County.
The site the authority came up with was a 16,000-acre ranch outside Sierra Blanca that the state bought from private owners.
Environmentalists rose up in opposition to this new site, asserting that it was geologically unsound, that it had been developed over known earthquake faults, and that it was chosen not for proper scientific reasons but because the area's residents were predominantly poor and Hispanic.
"Look, you and I both know this," Mr. Frederick said. "These people are low income, minority populations. They do not have a strong spokesperson in state government. It's obvious that this area was selected because it did not have the financial or political strength to pose serious opposition."
Project leaders say that the Sierra Blanca site was the best one available and that its selection had nothing to do with the town's makeup.
The project has also drawn vehement opposition from politicians in Mexico, particularly officials in the nearby states of Coahuila and Chihuahua and in the Mexican Legislature. A City Councilman from Ciudad Juarez and several supporters staged a hunger strike on one of the international bridges in El Paso. A delegation of Mexican officials flew to Austin to protest the project, but were rebuffed in efforts to meet with Governor Bush. Mexico's ruling party accused the United States of "economic racism."
Proponents of the site point to the improvements that have already come from tax money turned over to Hudspeth County for its decision to take the waste: a new football field, a library, a medical clinic, a new fire truck.
And after the dump site is built and operating, the money will continue to flow, proponents say. And there will be an estimated three dozen jobs at the site and maybe a few more at businesses catering to these new workers.
Mr. Mathews said that if the state license was granted later this year, as he expects it will be, the authority will still need to appeal to the Texas Legislature early next year for construction money.
Even if all goes well, Mr. Mathews said, the first shipment of waste would not arrive in Sierra Blanca until late 2000 or early 2001.
Sierra Blanca, some 90 miles southeast of El Paso, was once a ranching and railroad center. Now it is little more than a stretch of commercial buildings along a feeder road between two exits on Interstate 10, separated from the Rio Grande by the boulder-strewn Quitman Mountains, which create a sawtoothed silhouette in the desert haze.
There are three gas stations, three restaurants, a couple of RV parks, two motels, a general store, a grocery, a post office and a former rail depot that is now a county museum commemorating the moment in 1881 when the Southern Pacific's tracks met the Texas Pacific's right here in Sierra Blanca. The museum is open from 1 to 5 P.M., Wednesdays only.
Maria Mendez, a retired school aide from Allamoore, was part of the delegation that went to Washington this week to protest the compact.
"I don't know," Ms. Mendez said today. "I think Sierra Blanca was chosen for all of this dumping because we don't have any political clout. I think it's a racism thing; I really do. Here we are, the hugest dump in the whole world. First sludge, now nuclear waste. Our home has been taken over as the nation's dumping ground."

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: FINANCE;
5 Big Lenders Report Losses From Russia

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Ripples from Russia's economic crisis are rapidly spreading through other financial markets, as Citicorp, Bankers Trust, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Barclays and Nomura Securities yesterday joined the growing list of companies reporting heavy losses on their Russian business.
Citicorp's chairman, John S. Reed, and its president, Victor J. Menezes, said in a statement to employees that they expected earnings for the three months ending on Sept. 30 to be cut by about $200 million because of losses related to Russia. 
 A significant part of Citicorp's loss can be traced to its backing of hedge funds managed by Dana McGinnis, a financier based in San Antonio, who made big bets on Russian securities and recently sought bankruptcy protection for three funds he oversees. The details of this investment are in dispute.
Mr. McGinnis declined yesterday to comment on his dispute with Citibank but said that "in general any creditor, such as Citibank, would be prudent to take a provision against what's happening in Russia." But, he added, "The situation is fluid and it is not yet certain that the country will walk away from its obligations."
Citicorp, the nation's No. 2 bank, also said that its plans to merge with the Travelers Group are "absolutely on track" and that it was confident of Federal Reserve approval, which it hopes will come before month's end. Earlier this week, Salomon Smith Barney, the Travelers investment banking subsidiary, estimated it had lost $360 million after taxes in the last two months from its arbitrage and Russian businesses, with $60 million of that directly attributable to Russian-related credit.
Bankers Trust, the seventh-largest American bank, said yesterday that to date, it had a $350 million pretax trading loss for the quarter ending on Sept. 30 that is "primarily attributable to charges to reduce the carrying amount of Bankers Trust's exposure to Russian Federation securities to 15 percent of face value."
As of Monday, Bankers Trust had about $350 million of remaining Russian loans and related assets, the company said, adding that half that amount had been financed with revenue generated in Western Europe. That includes loans to companies in Russia that have corporate parents in Western Europe, and assets that are covered by European government guarantees, said Doug Kidd, a Bankers Trust spokesman.
A Morgan Stanley spokesman, Jon Diat, read a statement yesterday saying that the firm "has been affected by the difficult conditions in global capital markets." As a result, "certain credit-sensitive trading activities, and a loss in connection with an institutional leveraged emerging-markets portfolio," will cause an estimated $110 million cut in net income for the quarter just ended.
In London, Barclays said it expected to take a charge of 250 million this year to cover potential losses on its 340 million of Russian lending and securities trading -- now equivalent to nearly $570 million. The big British bank also said its Barclays Capital investment banking subsidiary had probably lost as much as 75 million before taxes in the last two months because of the Russian crisis, or $125 million.
Nomura Securities, the largest Japanese brokerage firm, reported yesterday it had lost as much as $350 million on Russian bonds in the last year. Two big Swiss banks, UBS and Credit Suisse, have also disclosed hundreds of millions of Swiss francs of losses on their Russian businesses.
And the litany of losses is not over. New York analysts said they expected Chase Manhattan to make a statement about its losses on Russia, perhaps as early as today. A Chase spokesman declined to comment on the company's Russian business.
Western leaders are trying to press Russia into taking more responsibility for its financial obligations. In Moscow yesterday, President Clinton, on a trip to meet with President Boris N. Yeltsin and other leaders, urged the nation "to play by the rules" and "to treat investors fairly," or risk alienating badly needed sources of capital.
Discussing Bankers Trust's losses, Ronald I. Mandle, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company in New York, said the loss was bigger than he had expected. "A lot of investors looked at Russia as being too big to fail, and it turned out not to be," he said, adding that "it's extremely unusual to see a country default on its local-currency bonds."
Most of the bad news is out for big American banks, Mr. Mandle said, except for one or two larger institutions -- particularly Chase. Mr. Mandle said he had knocked his earnings estimates down a little for both Citicorp and Chase because of the Russian crisis.
Some analysts criticized the financial-services industry for this latest round of losses.
"This all shows us that banks and financial companies have not properly assessed the risks of their Russian businesses," said John Keefe, president of Keefe Worldwide, a New York financial-services consulting firm. "Banks go through this type of event every few years," he added, citing past problems with real estate investment trusts, Latin American loans, commercial real estate and holdings of junk bonds. "The latest problem is Russia."
Indeed, these new losses often are a result of lending to risk-taking speculators thousands of miles from Moscow in Western financial centers who are making bets on Russian securities.
Nevertheless, as Mr. Mandle and other analysts pointed out yesterday, United States and other big Western banks are now relatively well capitalized and should easily be able to absorb the kinds of losses caused by their loans to Russia.

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: HAPPY BEARS;
It'sa Nightmare for Most Shareholders, but a Dream Come True for Short-Sellers

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
Not everyone is lamenting the stock market's steep selloff. While many investors are still licking their wounds, even after yesterday's rally, some are celebrating. They may have stayed on the sidelines with cash, for example, immune to the damage in the last few weeks, or made astute bets in the Treasury market and racked up some gains.
Some of those with the widest grins are most likely those people who bet on a market downturn, selling stocks short by borrowing shares that they sell and hope to replace with cheaper shares as stock prices decline. The short-sellers are the ultimate bears, cheering any decline. 
 "We're making money in quite a few places," said David W. Tice, the manager of the Prudent Bear Fund, a mutual fund that specializes in shorting stocks. Prudent Bear posted a gain of about 30 percent in August. Among the areas that Mr. Tice has found most profitable for short sales are technology and banking stocks.
Most short-sellers seem to be making out handsomely. According to Michael R. Long, the principal of Rockbridge Research, a Charlotte, N.C., firm that specializes in analyzing short-selling trends, the short- sellers he follows are up about 25 to 30 percent so far this year.
These investors "have done phenomenally well, based on the current they are swimming in," said Mr. Long, who estimates short-sellers as a group had an average return of about 12 percent last year, even though the market was surging.
Even if their victory is short-lived and stocks resume their climb, short-sellers say the drop demonstrates that their strategy offers some protection to investors.
The short-sellers have had no trouble finding opportunities in recent weeks. And Mr. Tice says the market could drop much further because global deflationary forces will severely depress the earnings of American companies.
On the other hand, James S. Chanos, a longtime short-seller and president of Kynikos Associates, a money management firm, is agnostic on the outlook for the market. While the United States seems to be enjoying a strong economy, which would be positive for stocks, investors could refuse to come to the stock market's rescue and the country could slide into a recession. If that happens, "all bets are off," he said. "The downside is enormous."
