HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: POLICY -- Reading the Fed's Tea Leaves;
Some Doubt Lower Rates Will Follow Market Plunge

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1

 BODY:
When faced with a Latin America that could no longer pay its debts during the summer of 1982, the Federal Reserve cast aside its tight-money policy and cut interest rates. When faced with a stomach-churning stock market drop in October 1987, the Fed acted quickly to pump more money into the system.
Does that mean the nation's central bank will now feel compelled to bring rates down to help stem the spread of global financial turmoil and restore some confidence to battered investors on Wall Street and around the world? 
 Don't count on it.
Sure, lots of people on Wall Street and some industry executives have stepped up their calls for the Fed to cut rates. Other countries, including Japan, have been floating proposals for the Fed to lead a move among the most powerful economies to bring rates down around the globe. And with long-term market interest rates already well below the official short-term rates controlled by the Fed, investors appear to have concluded that it is only a matter of time before the central bank begins easing.
Fed officials themselves have encouraged the speculation by making clear that they are less worried now than a few months ago about the combination of strong growth and low unemployment setting off a spiral of rising wages and prices that would demand an interest rate increase.
But unless the stock market drops precipitously over the next few weeks or the still-strong domestic economy shows sudden signs of stalling, many economists think there is little chance that the central bank will ease monetary policy anytime soon.
"It's quite unrealistic to expect a Fed easing at this point," said Bill Cheney, the chief economist at John Hancock Financial Services in Boston.
"Obviously if you get a real market meltdown in the style of 1987 with lots of players on Wall Street and elsewhere going broke from losses or liquidity problems, then the Fed will pump liquidity into the system," Mr. Cheney said. "But I don't think we're at that point."
If a nearly 20 percent decline in the stock market from its peak in mid-July to its sharp drop on Monday failed to force the Fed into action, neither did the collapse of Russia. Analysts said that rather than assuming the mantle of central bank to the world, the Fed and its chairman, Alan Greenspan, remained focused on tracking the domestic economy and on the core mission of maintaining price stability. Today's rebound only reinforces that tendency.
"Whenever people perceive a crisis, they say the Fed has to help out," said Mickey D. Levy, an economist at NationsBanc Montgomery Securities. "But historically, whenever the Fed takes its eye off the fundamentals and tries to tinker with the dollar or some other foreign activity, that's when it makes mistakes."
Mr. Greenspan may even be silently cheering the stock market's correction. Since the end of 1996, when he raised the question of "irrational exuberance," Mr. Greenspan has been warning in increasingly direct terms that investors had adopted an overly rosy view of the prospects for corporate earnings, leading to an overvalued stock market.
"He doesn't want risk to be undervalued in financial markets," Mr. Cheney said.
Mr. Greenspan has also been careful to point out that the Asian financial crisis has benefits as well as drawbacks for the American economy. With investors wary of putting their money into emerging markets, cash has been flooding into American Treasury securities, driving down long-term interest rates. The strength of the dollar has held down the price of imports, and the decline in demand for oil and other commodities throughout Asia has further helped damp inflation. Lower inflation has given consumers more purchasing power.
So while there are considerable risks from the spread of Asia's crisis and from the market's fall, for the moment the economy appears to be doing what Fed officials have hoped all along: slowing on its own to a growth rate that will neither ignite inflation nor raise unemployment.
Some economists think labor markets are still so tight, with unemployment at 4.5 percent, that wages will begin rising, perhaps squeezing profits and spurring companies to try to raise prices. As a result, Mr. Greenspan and the Fed will continue to look closely for signs of incipient inflation, and are already dissecting the recent decline in corporate earnings growth to see if it portends higher labor costs.
But the market's tumble will also force Mr. Greenspan to look for evidence of whether consumers are starting to rein in their spending or if the long boom in housing is beginning to peter out. Although economists argue about the magnitude, they agree that some portion of robust consumer spending over the last several years has derived from the feeling of affluence conferred by the rising stock market. The speed and magnitude with which the same phenomenon might go into reverse remains unclear.
A sharp enough decline could stall the economy or even tilt it into recession, forcing the Fed to cut rates to stimulate demand.
"They're going to want to see a sustained downward move in consumer confidence and then in spending itself before they move," said M. Carey Leahy, an economist at High Frequency Economics.
Economic indicators in recent days have done little to clarify the outlook. The National Association of Purchasing Management reported today that its survey of business conditions in August found a slight increase in activity. But the survey's new-orders component declined for the fourth time in six months.
"The new-orders series is probably very high on Mr. Greenspan's radar screen at the present," said David Orr, an economist at First Union Capital Markets Group. "It is moving toward an ease, but based on past evidence is not there yet."
The Conference Board, a business research organization, said today that its index of indicators intended to predict the future strength of the economy rose four-tenths of 1 percent in July, reversing a two-month decline and appearing to reinforce the view of a gradual slowing of economic growth.
"In general, the economy seems healthy, but growth prospects are not as strong as in the early part of 1998," said Michael Boldin, the board's director of business cycle research.
The Fed will also keep a close eye on the health and stability of the banking system and the securities industry. But unlike 1987, when banks were already suffering from a real estate bust and heavy losses on loans to developing nations, or 1982, when the failure of a small bank in Oklahoma was rocking major financial institutions like Continental Illinois in Chicago, the American financial system today is very healthy.
Short of a calamitous meltdown in the markets, the financial system appears unlikely to need any action by the Fed to provide cash to keep payments and settlements proceeding on an orderly basis.
Even if the domestic economy holds up reasonably well and the market decline does not turn into a crash, Mr. Greenspan will still have to be sensitive to any further erosion in the global economy, since the United States will ultimately be affected to some degree by what happens among its trading partners.
Fed officials have been tracking Latin America particularly closely in recent days. They worry that the region may become infected by the global credit squeeze that followed Russia's debt default and devaluation. Mexico and the big nations of South America receive almost 20 percent of American exports.
Mexico's financial crisis in 1994 led to a bailout by the Clinton Administration over objections from Congress. The 1982 crisis across Latin America was a key factor in the decision by the Fed under Paul Volcker, then the central bank's chairman, to shift its sights from squelching inflation to stimulating the economy at home and abroad by cutting rates. But at that time, said Lyle Gramley, a Fed governor from 1980 to 1985, the American economy was also mired in recession.
"The international considerations affected the decision, but there wasn't at that point any conflict at all between the international and domestic considerations," Mr. Gramley said. "Today the situation is very different. If we ask whether we're really sure that developments in the world economy have had an effect on economic growth in the United States, the answer is we can't be sure."
Mr. Levy said that a rate cut by the Fed could even have negative effects on the global crisis. Reducing rates in the United States, he said, might ease the pressure on other countries, especially Japan, to take the painful steps needed to shore up their economies.
"Domestic demand is strong," Mr. Levy said, ticking off reasons the Fed should not ease immediately. "Labor markets are tight. The U.S. banking system has more than enough liquidity and is well capitalized. And easing would not help Russia and would undermine U.S. efforts to lead Japan to reform."

GRAPHIC: Photo/Chart: "Which Way Will He Turn?"
With his control over interest rates, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, must ponder a multitude of economic issues.
 
To Cut Rates . . .
The decline on Wall Street is not at the top of the list of Fed worries. But if a further precipitous market drop over the next few weeks seems to point toward serious weakness in the American economy or if events elsewhere suggest that the global financial system is on the verge of collapse, the Fed could move quickly to pump more money into the banking system.
 
. . . or Stand Pat
As long as growth remains on a moderate path and consumers continue to spend, the Fed is not likely to want to stimulate the economy in the United States by cutting interest rates. If anything, Fed officials may view the stock market fall as a healthy move that will prevent a runaway Wall Street boom from becoming a bust.
 
(Paul Hosefros/The New York Times, Ann Grillo for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Manufacturing In 3-MonthFall

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1

 BODY:
Manufacturing activity contracted for the third consecutive month in August, suggesting that the economic turmoil in emerging markets was taking a toll on factory orders.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said today that its index of manufacturing activity rose to 49.4 in August from 49.1 in July. Despite the increase, the index remained below 50, meaning that most of the manufacturers surveyed said business was deteriorating. The index had been above 50, signaling growth, for 22 consecutive months before June. 
 "The manufacturing sector is in a serious retrenchment and will be for a number of months to come," said Chris Low, an economist at First Tennessee Capital Markets in New York.
So far, though, consumer spending and housing have provided a buffer against the crises in emerging markets and the slowdown in manufacturing. That might continue, according to two other economic reports issued today. The Conference Board said its index of leading economic indicators rose four-tenths of 1 percent in July, rebounding from two months of declines and reflecting an abundance of jobs. And the Government said that construction spending climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in July to a record level.

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: STOCKS;
Bargain-Hunters Drive Stocks Back Up as Volume Sets Record

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
The stock market yesterday regained more than half of the value it lost on Monday as trading volume set a record.
Traders and stock market analysts said that big institutions, like pension funds and insurance companies, took the lead in buying yesterday, picking through stocks that had been leveled by Monday's selloff. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 288.36 points, or 3.8 percent, to 7,827.43, essentially retracing the 250-point plunge that came in the frantic last half-hour of trading on Monday. That selloff, which market participants traced to an unusual confluence of events, pushed the bellwether stock gauge down 6.4 percent for the day. After yesterday's rebound, the Dow remains 16.2 percent below its high, reached in July, and about 1 percent below where it started the year.
The gain in the Dow yesterday was the second largest in points, after a 337-point jump on Oct. 28 of last year. In percentage terms, however, it ranked far down the list. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange set a record, with 1.21 billion shares changing hands. Nearly two stocks rose for every one that declined.
In jumping into the market yesterday, investors sought companies in which the recent declines seemed to ignore what are still good prospects for earnings growth for the rest of the year. The buying came after a turbulent opening during which the Dow rose sharply, then fell as much as 139 points below Monday's close, all in the first hour of trading. Then stocks started a climb of more than 400 points as measured by the Dow and closed near their highest point of the day.
But several market participants warned that economic uncertainties continued to plague overseas markets and could keep pressure on the United States stock market through autumn.
"On Monday, there were three sellers for every buyer," said Michael Clark, a managing director at Credit Suisse First Boston who oversees the company's United States equity trading. Such an order imbalance is only remedied when prices fall enough to reduce the number of sellers or attract more buyers. "Today, people were willing to look for values."
They did so, however, with some caution. "I think most people have one foot back in the water now, but not two," Mr. Clark said.
Several of Wall Street's top investment strategists voiced their beliefs that the American economy remained strong and that Monday's stock market decline went too far too fast, echoing their sentiments after previous sharp declines, including the 7.2 percent drop in the Dow last Oct. 27.
And some even told investors to increase their bets. Abby Joseph Cohen, the steadfastly bullish strategist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, told investors that they should increase their holdings of equities to 72 percent of assets from her previous recommendation of 65 percent and that cash holdings should be reduced to zero from a previous level of 5 percent. The remainder of investors' portfolio should consist of 25 percent in fixed-income securities and 3 percent in commodities, down from 5 percent.
Many of the biggest gains yesterday came in stocks that were hit the hardest on Monday, including shares of technology companies like Dell Computer, Cisco Systems and Microsoft. The Nasdaq composite index, which is heavily weighted with technology shares, rose nearly 76 points, or 5.1 percent, to 1,575.09. On Monday, the index fell 8.6 percent. Nasdaq volume was a heavy 1.25 billion shares yesterday, second only to last Oct. 28, when it was 1.35 billion.
Also gaining yesterday was the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which rose almost 37 points, or 3.9 percent, to 994.26. Despite a decline of 6.8 percent on Monday, yesterday's gain put the S.& P. 500 nearly 2.5 percent above where it started the year. And the Russell 2000 index, a measure of small-company stocks that has been the hardest hit this year, rose 3 percent yesterday.
With their heavy buying yesterday, investors seemed to be saying that Monday's late-afternoon selloff overstated the possible negative effects faced by American companies. Market participants said that several factors contributed to the selloff, which lopped 250 points off the Dow from 3:30 to 4 P.M.
That last half-hour of trading appeared to be driven in part by sophisticated trading strategies, including index arbitrage, a technique that involves trading futures contracts based on the the S.& P. 500 as well as the 500 stocks that make up the index.
The futures contract and the cumulative value of the stocks in the index are usually worth roughly the same amount. But in volatile markets a gap sometimes opens up between their prices, and traders can try to lock in the difference as profit by selling the more expensive item and buying the cheaper one.
Late Monday, the futures prices, driven by an overwhelmingly negative market psychology throughout the day, fell far more sharply than the stock prices did. Seeing that, some traders bought the futures and then sold the stocks.
As they did so, several other types of sellers were also lining up at the door. Mutual funds were trying to complete sell orders that they had placed earlier in the day, equity traders said. The funds appeared to be seeking to lighten their holdings of stocks in part to pay off shareholder redemptions but also simply to raise cash in their portfolios, which would help them to avoid further market declines.
In addition, Monday was the last day of August. In a note to clients, Ms. Cohen of Goldman, Sachs noted that month-end pressures to meet margin requirements might have played a role in Monday's decline.
The combined effect of that selling caused any possible buyers to step away, traders said. "Buyers simply took a holiday," said Robert Fagenson, a specialist at the New York Stock Exchange firm of Fagenson Frankel & Streicher, who also serves as a vice chairman of the exchange. "They looked around and said whatever they wanted to buy, they would tomorrow at a lower price."
After realizing that some of the reasons for Monday's decline were fleeting rather than permanent, investors and traders returned to the stock market yesterday determined to look for bargains, resulting in the big rally.
All of the stock market's signs were not positive, however, and many of those who breathed a sigh of relief after yesterday's rally acknowledged that more turbulence could lie ahead.
Edward Collins, head of trading at Daiwa Securities America, noted that the stocks of many banks and financial-service companies did not participate in yesterday's rally, perhaps because investors are worried about further losses from the recent downturn in global financial markets.
Indeed, shares of some financial companies have been battered recently. Bankers Trust, which announced yesterday that it expected to report a third-quarter loss because of trading losses, saw its stock fall $1.1875, to $73.125 yesterday, about half the price it traded for in April.
Shares of Citicorp and Travelers Group, which are scheduled to merge later this year, also fell yesterday. After the close of trading, Citicorp announced that losses from holdings of Russian securities would reduce its third-quarter net income by $200 million.
Investors might be warranted in expressing some continued caution as September begins, if only because this is traditionally the stock market's worst month.
Part of the reason, market analysts say, is because corporate executives and boards turn their attention in the fall to budgets for the coming year, reassess the business outlook and are thus more prone to warn investors of earnings shortfalls.
That certainly could be the case this fall, especially when companies already appear to be thinking twice about new spending programs, said Albert Wojnilower, a New York economist. "So many decisions companies make these days are premised by what effect it will have on their stock price," Mr. Wojnilower said. "When boards come back and meet after Labor Day, I think they will take a more cautious view on things."

HEADLINE: S.A.T. Scores Decline Even as Grades Rise

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Calling it evidence of persistent grade inflation in American high schools, College Board officials said yesterday that more college-bound students had A averages than a decade ago but that they scored lower on their S.A.T. exams.
The College Board, which sponsors the S.A.T., said that test takers with A averages grew from 28 percent of the total to 38 percent in the last 10 years, but the S.A.T. scores of those students fell an average of 12 points on the verbal portion and 3 points on the math portion. 
 The disparity between grades and the S.A.T., the nation's leading standardized college entrance test, is sufficiently troubling that the president of the College Board, Donald M. Stewart, said the organization has commissioned a study of the issue by Rand. the research institution.
"We don't know why grades are rising," Mr. Stewart said. "The trend may reflect positive changes in education, but it may also reflect greater focus on personal qualities instead of academic achievement."
Over all, S.A.T. scores remained about the same this year as last: 512 on the math portion, a point above last year and the highest in 27 years, and 505 on the verbal portion, the same as last year. The figures were released yesterday in the College Board's annual report on the 1.2 million students who took the S.A.T. before they graduated from high school last spring.
The board also reported that substantially greater numbers of high school students were taking the test and that more were enrolled in advanced placement courses, making them eligible for college credit before enrollment.
Mr. Stewart said the scores revealed two troubling trends. One is that suburban students are improving their S.A.T. scores, while urban and rural students are falling further behind, with a 30-point gap between urban and suburban students.
"This growing disparity is particularly troublesome," Mr. Stewart said, "because 40 to 50 percent of African-American and Latino students who take the S.A.T. live in large cities."
Also, the S.A.T. scores of the children of parents with less education are falling further below the national average, the report said.
These conclusions were based on the College Board's analysis of the 1.2 million seniors who took the SAT1: Reasoning Test, and the 321,000 who took college-level Advanced Placement Examinations before they graduated from high school last June.
The evidence of continuing grade inflation comes at a time when many states are requiring schools to adopt higher standards, though sometimes grading the students on the basis of portfolios of their work.
"More subjectivity is going into assessments," Mr. Stewart said. "This also could be the result of the increased emphasis on accountability by teachers. That is, since teachers are supposed to be teaching better they are giving out phony grades in an unconscious effort to show themselves well -- something that is exploded by the S.A.T. tests."
Bob Schaeffer, a spokesman for Fairtest, a longtime critic of testing services, warned that the prevalence of grade inflation should not be taken as an argument that the S.A.T. "keeps the process honest." He said that proponents of the S.A.T. "admit that high school performance is a better predictor of how someone will do at college than is the S.A.T."
Bob Chase, president of the National Education Association, the nation's largest union with 2.4 million members, cautioned against blaming teachers for grade inflation. "If it's happening," he said, "no one could be supportive of that, but it may result from pressures from both parents and the schools. We just don't know."
Seppy Basili, a spokesman for Kaplan Educational Centers, the largest test preparation company in the nation, said "grade inflation is here to stay," and may be explained in part by the popularity of advanced-placement courses. "Students who do well in A.P. courses may receive a weighted grade which is higher than an A," he said.
Howard Everson, the College Board's chief research scientist, said that the increased number of students taking the test is "good news for the nation."
"It shows that there is a growing cohort of those who aspire to attend a competitive college," he said.
Mr. Basili attributed the rise in math scores over the last four years to a rule change that permitted students to bring along their calculators when taking the test.
"Having their calculators made them feel comfortable, and helped them to avoid making sloppy mistakes," Mr. Basili said.
Mr. Stewart also said that even though there were growing gaps in the scores of urban and suburban students, there was relatively good news for minorities. "Despite the recent backlash against affirmative action, racial and ethnic minorities continue to see college as the route to a better life," he said. "This year, minority students are a record one-third of the S.A.T. population and 28 percent of AP graduates, and more of them aspire to master's and Ph.D. degrees."
Ward Connerly, a black trustee of the University of California who has long opposed affirmative action, said he sees the increased number of racial and ethnic minorities who take the test as a welcome indication of their growing confidence.
"What this really represents is that with the demise of preferences in California and Texas, and soon the entire nation, blacks and Latinos are beginning to realize that they can make it without preferences," Mr. Connerly said.
Mr. Stewart faulted Mr. Connerly for failing to seek an alternative to affirmative action to equalize opportunity. Mr. Stewart said he, too, would oppose preferences, "but only if we can find a way to create equal educational opportunity."
In another trend reflected in this year's tests, many students' career aspirations seemed out of step with the prospect for jobs in the years ahead. Student test takers were asked to check off on questionnaires the careers they hope to pursue. Labor Department projections indicate that the top three occupations expected to grow most rapidly between now and 2006 are computer-related. Yet relatively few students (5 percent) checked off computing and information sciences.
Students' first career choice was health and allied services (18 percent), followed by business and commerce (14 percent) and social sciences and history (11 percent).
The S.A.T. was taken by 43 percent of all high school graduates, or about 1.2 million students.
The College Board is the nonprofit educational association that sponsors the S.A.T., which is developed and administered by the Educational Testing Service. The S.A.T. is the dominant test on the Atlantic and Pacific coasts. The A.C.T. is more popular in the central United States.

Clinton's Tough Words On Russia's Future

HEADLINE: U.S. to Send Russia Alerts About Missiles

 BODY:
Now that the nuclear standoff with the Soviet Union is over, the United States has found a new use for its warning systems -- alerting the Russians about missile launchings around the world. President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin plan to sign an accord to share data about the launching of ballistic missiles and space payloads. 
 With Russia's economy deteriorating by the day and its Government in political crisis, arms control no longer holds center stage. And the United States has become increasingly worried that the warning system in Russia is so frayed that it might misinterpret the data and conclude mistakenly that it was under attack.
Article, page A9.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 4; Sports Desk

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
The Price of Cleveland's Heart

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
Bart Wolstein has built country clubs, strip malls, Kmarts and offices. They made him fabulously rich, but the thrills are past. Now when Wolstein, the son of a Minsk cloth cutter, thinks of what he must do, one thing remains: buying the Cleveland Browns.
"There is no more excitement in the world than owning a team on game day," Wolstein, who once owned the Cleveland Force of the Major Indoor Soccer League, said during an interview in his suburban Cleveland office. Feeling left out of Cleveland's business elite, he seeks entree to a club more exclusive than the United States Senate. "An N.F.L. guy is an entrepreneur," he said. "I'm their kind of guy." 
 Wolstein is leading one of the four groups still competing in a unique bazaar: the National Football League's auction of the revived Browns for what is almost certain to be the highest price ever for a sports team, one that could double the $311 million paid this year for the Los Angeles Dodgers.
The price tag apparently grew too steep for three of the seven original bidders: they dropped out yesterday before second bids were due at noon. Next Tuesday, N.F.L. owners will meet in Chicago to award the franchise to one of the remaining four groups.
The new Browns will succeed the old ones, a beloved team that helped define this city's sports psyche but was moved in 1996 by the debt-ridden owner, Art Modell, to the comfort of a revenue-rich new stadium in Baltimore. Modell, who gave up the Browns' name, logo and colors as part of the agreement that allowed him to move, will not get a share of the Browns franchise fee.
The scale of the financial competition for the Browns -- featuring millionaire, billionaire and celebrity partners, including Bill Cosby and Don Shula, and bidding rationales like civic duty and a pained conscience -- captures the bacchanalian nature of modern sports business.
The sale of the Browns occurs at a time when television networks gladly overspend to secure the long-term rights to pro football; players sign contracts that exceed what the owner paid for the team; teams sell for ever-higher prices, and cities help pay for sports palaces despite urgent municipal needs.
In Cleveland, for example, the public school system is in receivership, and Mayor Michael White will take control of it -- one day after the Browns' auction. City taxes will pay 58 percent of the cost of a new $280 million, 72,800-seat stadium.
"The income streams for the stadium couldn't be used for schools, so we're not robbing children to pay for football," White said. "Far more important is keeping a community mosaic; just as the Browns are important, so are universities, art museums and public education."
And so the race to acquire the Browns raises again the question of how to measure what a team means to a city -- in this case, a city left furious at Modell's perceived carpetbagging.
And what does owning the Browns mean to the bidders who acknowledge that instant profits are hardly likely? "Each bidder has his own motivations and objectives for their investment," said Roger Goodell, an N.F.L. senior vice president. "Some see it for return on their investment, some for asset appreciation."
How slim the profits may be is well understood.
"Do you think," the billionaire credit card executive Alfred Lerner asked facetiously, "that I can get all the way up to a little return?"
The extent to which this week's stock market correction may influence bidding is unknown. Two of the remaining bidders, Charles F. Dolan, chairman of Cablevision Systems, and Lerner, chairman of MBNA Corp., run public companies, while a third, Wolstein, is chairman emeritus of the publicly traded Developers Diversified Realty, which his son runs.
 
The Numbers Scare Some Off
 For months, there were seven candidates; second bids were due at noon yesterday and were to form the basis of talks between the groups and Goldman, Sachs & Company, the N.F.L.'s financial adviser, which will seek to negotiate still higher bids. The first round of bids last month created an informal floor estimated at $350 million. The highest bidder will not necessarily win; the league will present at least two finalists to the 30 owners next Tuesday, and a winner will have to be approved by at least 23 of them.
But three groups declined to make second bids: Thomas G. Murdough Jr., president of Step2, a toymaker, and Richard E. Jacobs, the Cleveland Indians' majority owner, who had merged their efforts last week, and Jeremy Jacobs, chairman of the food concessionaire Delaware North and owner of the Boston Bruins.
"The numbers didn't work," Murdough said, citing cost overruns at the stadium that have already reached $33 million, and other financial unknowns. "After $450 million, it didn't make sense, and I got a good indication that some people would go over $500 million. I think common sense prevailed."
He added: "You hope the people you're competing with are sane enough and have enough business acumen. But I think a couple of groups are going to go nutty."
Now, four remain: Lerner, Dolan, Wolstein and Howard Milstein, the New York-based real estate mogul.
The league inaugurated the financial hullabaloo in March when it chose to revive the Browns as an expansion team and not as one relocated from another city.
It awakened Richard Jacobs to a new challenge. "I'm like the Dalmatian in the firehouse," he said last month. "I hear the bell and I'm off."
But he added: "There's a limit to anything. It depends on what they want -- money or a good operator."
The league also decided not to set a minimum bid or a flat expansion fee, letting the bidders set the market. In 1993, the league charged Jacksonville and Carolina expansion fees of $140 million.
"We let them evaluate the asset and the outstanding, unique opportunity," Goodell said of the Browns' bidders. "They are all sophisticated investors who will submit the bid they feel will be worth it."
Their evaluation is based on:
*A stadium lease that will put every dollar of revenue in the owner's pocket, requiring him to pay only annual rent of $250,000 and the cost of operations. Everything else is his: gate receipts (visiting teams get 40 percent), club seat payments, rentals of 116 luxury suites, stadium naming rights that are expected to sell for $3 million a year, concessions and signage.
*New N.F.L. television contracts that guarantee each team $70 million annually.
*Fans who will fill the stadium 10 times a year. Already, 52,400 season tickets have been sold and 94 of the 116 luxury boxes have been leased.
What if one bidder shucks financial sense with a pre-emptive strike? "If someone is that stupid, to bid more than it's worth, that's a choice you have to make," Wolstein said. "If a guy bids too high, why would you want him as a partner?"
 
Making a Pitch Beyond Money
 Each of the bidders has done what he felt was necessary to boost his bid. Some have hired public relations firms or have flown around the country to schmooze with owners. Cosby made a tape for Charles Dolan, who is putting together the financing for a group whose general partner is his brother, Lawrence, a Cleveland lawyer.
Some have hired renowned football names. Dolan added Don Shula as his prospective chief of football operations. Milstein is bankrolling a group with the former Browns Paul Warfield and Calvin Hill. Wolstein brought in Brown and said Mike McCormack, former president of the expansion Carolina Panthers and an offensive tackle for the Browns in the 1950's, will run the Browns if he wins. After being persuaded to bid by Carmen Policy, the former president of the San Francisco 49ers, Lerner had to defend the decision he made, as a limited partner of the old Browns, to advise Modell to move to Baltimore.
"Did I help him? Yes," Lerner said. "Would he have moved without me? Yes."
Still, he described his urge to own the new Browns as "an act of conscience" toward his adopted city. The Brooklyn-born Lerner added, "I feel I should make this happen."
Meanwhile, the Dolans live with backing from Modell, who is expected to lobby against Lerner, a former friend, next Tuesday. "Art Modell has adopted us," Lawrence Dolan said. "We can't help it."
Shortly after the N.F.L. approved Modell's move in 1996 and promised to put a team back in Cleveland, it created the Cleveland Browns Trust, with a $15 million budget, to restore the team's business to viability. There were no players, no coaches, no advertisers and no games to play, yet a staff set to work in the old team's training facility in Berea, Ohio.
"We had no blueprint," said Bill Futterer, the trust's president. "People ask, 'How do you operate a team without any players?' "
 
A Team Spirit Waiting for a Team
 Futterer said he had marketable stars the fans already loved. They happen to be retired.
"I've got Brian Sipe at quarterback, Jim Brown running and Paul Warfield at receiver," he said.
Futterer traveled through Ohio and other states to meet with fans, ethnic groups, civic associations and fraternal organizations -- 289 personal appearances and 47,000 people. Initially, the goal was to assuage anger felt toward Modell, then to assure them of the Browns' return.
"At the outset, it was hard to separate us from Modell," he said. "They were angry. Not at the Browns. But at the N.F.L. At pro football."
Television and radio programs were produced. Alumni flag football games and charitable fund-raisers were staged. A Web site was created. The rabid network of Browns Backers clubs was resuscitated.
Ultimately, Futterer's goal was to sell. First came the personal seat licenses, fees for the right to buy season tickets, with the revenues to be used to repay the N.F.L.'s $63 million loan to help build the stadium. "We wanted them to feel that the people using the stadium most would pay more than the taxpayers did," Futterer said. Then came the season tickets, luxury suites and club seats. The trust hired scouts and player personnel executives, led by Joe Mack, a former Carolina Panthers assistant general manager.
Mack's group is faced with developing a team in less than one year, half the time the Carolina and Jacksonville expansion teams had before taking the field for the 1995 season. Like everyone at Berea, he knows he could be gone pretty soon.
"The worst-case scenario is you're starting the building blocks of a great franchise," he said. "That's not so bad."
Now a third season starts in Cleveland without the Browns. The "Dawg Pound" of rabid, barking fans has dispersed. Sundays have been empty, but life has gone on. The Indians' success has provided partial solace, at least into October.
"I watched Ohio State football on Saturday," said John Kristofeld of Columbus, "and spent quality time with my family on Sunday."
Dawn and Gary Brochetti of Euclid were die-hard Dawg Pounders. For two years, they kept a box full of Browns T-shirts, caps and other goods sealed. Across it, she wrote, "Don't Open Until '99."
"We survived," said Dawn Brochetti, a part-time probation officer, "but only because we knew the Browns were coming back."
Whether money that was not spent on tickets and beer at Municipal Stadium or munchies for TV-watching faithful was spent in significant numbers on other pursuits in the region is not known.
"There's probably been a loss because of the absence of transactions at the stadium and spending by high-salaried athletes," said Chris Warren, the city's economic development director. "But that's been more than offset by the huge success of the baseball team."
Although the old Browns contributed an estimated $77 million to the local economy annually, Warren admitted that the team's presence is important mainly as an asset to help civic image and psyche.
"Economically, football isn't a big deal," Wolstein said. "It's only 10 days a year. One factory with 250 people has more impact."
The psychic value of the Browns was displayed vigorously on Aug. 21, when the team staged a rally in a downtown mall to mark the 365th day before the new Browns' first preseason game. Fans lined up to buy Browns caps, watches and tote bags. Children lined up for autographs from John Thompson, a local superfan dubbed Big Dawg, who wielded an oversized dog bone and barked from behind a hound dog mask.
The 40 former Browns -- from Marion Motley to Bob Golic to Lou Groza -- who were introduced were greeted with whoops and cheers. They descended a staircase, some limping, some wearing jerseys stretched tautly over their paunches.
"Give it up for Ot-to Graham!" the announcer roared for the 76-year-old quarterback. "Now give it up for Gluefingers!" he said, and down the steps came receiver Dante Lavelli, now 75.
The fans were celebrating the past, but on the podium sat four former Browns seeking a piece of the future: Brown, Hill, Warfield and McCormack.
"We're getting ready, right?" bellowed Brown, wearing a Browns home jersey with his familiar No. 32 and a kufi cap atop his shaved head.
"Do you believe?" Warfield said. "Do you believe?"

SECTION: Section B; Page 3; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 761 words

HEADLINE: Old Wage Plan for Cabbies Gets Another Look

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
Taxi executives, worried that the city wants to modify or eliminate the cab-leasing system that has become an economic linchpin of the industry, proposed a pilot program yesterday under which 100 cabbies would work on commission, as most did until the 1980's.
Industry leaders say that leasing -- a policy that transformed cabbies from fleet employees into independent contractors who pay up to $110 per shift for use of a car -- brought the taxi business back from the brink of disaster. But many drivers have complained that the policy, which was legalized in 1979, has led drivers to work longer hours for lower wages. The system has also been cited frequently in recent months as contributing to reckless driving and an increase in accidents during the 1990's. 
 The taxi executives said that their pilot program, suggested at a Taxi and Limousine Commission hearing on the leasing system, would be an attempt to make sure that if changes were made, they were done on the basis of objective research.
"Back in '79, when we ran a commission garage, we were going out of business," said Ron Sherman, the president of the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade, which represents big fleet owners. "We need current statistical data to see if the system could work today. If it will work, we're not opposed to it."
The chairwoman of the agency, Diane McGrath-McKechnie, has refused to say what changes, if any, she is seeking. She said she called the hearing simply to learn more about how leasing was working and whether it was the best way to keep good drivers in the industry. But most of her questions at the hearing focused on the relative merits of the leasing and commission systems.
Mr. Sherman's organization and the New York City Committee on Taxi Safety, a group of medallion brokers, proposed operating a garage on the commission system for two years in cooperation with the Taxi and Limousine Commission and comparing the drivers' income and safety records with those of drivers working under the leasing system.
Members of the taxi agency were surprised by the proposal and some seemed eager to hear more about it. But Ms. McGrath-McKechnie was skeptical.
"My immediate response would be, why are you doing that and what do you hope to accomplish, and why now?" she said after the hearing. But she added that the agency would consider all suggestions carefully before taking any action.
Under the pre-1979 system based on commissions, most drivers who did not own medallions split their fares with fleet owners almost 50-50 and received health insurance and other benefits. But during the 1970's, fleets began to run into financial trouble, in part, they said, because cabbies often stole from them by doing business off the meter and pocketing the entire fare.
Regulators legalized leasing in 1979 as an alternative to granting a fare increase. Owners embraced it because it gave them a guaranteed income from the lease payments and cut administrative costs.
Since then, most major cities have adopted the leasing system. But critics have maintained for years that it unfairly shifts the financial risk of operating a cab to the driver and has enriched fleet owners and medallion brokers at their expense.
In a 1996 study, two former New York City taxi regulators reported that in 1981, when most fleet drivers still worked on commission, the average fleet driver worked a nine-hour shift and earned $55 in cash and $21 in benefits. By 1986, when most drivers leased their cabs, the average driver worked a 12-hour shift and made $64 in cash and $3 in benefits -- a 23 percent drop in total compensation per hour, the study found.
In contrast, the authors found, the average cab owner's profit per shift rose to $57 for 12 hours in 1986, from $33 for 9 hours in 1981, a 30 percent increase in profit per hour.
The debate over leasing is hardly open-and-shut. Some fleet owners say that drivers earn more by leasing than under the commission system, and that a driver with a leased car is more productive.
Most of the dozen or so drivers who testified yesterday, in fact, said that they had worked under both systems and preferred leasing because it gave them greater flexibility with their schedules and rewarded them for working harder.
Ms. McGrath-McKechnie, though, was hesitant to take their words at face value.
"Many of the drivers we heard from," she said, "their bosses were sitting in this room. I'm not sure how independently and freely they thought that they could speak. We'll have to speak to them on their own."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
HITACHI PLANS TO CUT 650 JOBS IN TEXAS AND CALIFORNIA

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Hitachi America Ltd. will eliminate 650 jobs in Texas and California because of the worldwide slump in the memory chip business and a merger of two subsidiaries. Hitachi, a subsidiary of Hitachi Ltd. of Japan, said yesterday that all manufacturing at its Irving plant, including wafer fabrication and final assembly operations, would be stopped immediately. It also said it planned to merge two semiconductor subsidiaries: Hitachi Semiconductor (America) Inc. of Brisbane, Calif., and Hitachi Micro Systems Inc. of San Jose, Calif. The new organization will be called Hitachi Semiconductor (America) Inc., and be based in San Jose. Five hundred of the jobs cut will be in Texas and 150 in California.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
DELUXE CORP. ANNOUNCES PLANS TO CUT 1,000 MORE JOBS

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
The Deluxe Corporation, based in Shoreview, Minn., plans to cut about 1,000 additional jobs from its core check-printing business to pare its overhead. The cuts would be in addition to 2,500 already planned from a worldwide work force of 19,000. Deluxe is trying to reduce as much as $100 million from its selling, general and administrative costs. A Deluxe spokesman, Stuart Alexander, said the goal was to bring expenses in line with those of the company's rivals.

HEADLINE: West Isn't to Blame For Russia's Mess

 BODY:

To the Editor:
It is counterproductive to look for someone in the West to blame for Russia's political and economic collapse (Week in Review, Aug. 30). Yes, there were mistakes and problems, but the blame lies with the Russians themselves. 
 President Boris N. Yeltsin has repeatedly wavered between supporting market reforms and supporting the status quo. As recently as January, Mr. Yeltsin diminished the roles of reformers and left his Prime Minister at the time, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, who is not an ardent reformer, in control of economic policy.
Some of the blame also lies with the so-called reformers. In the parliamentary elections of 1993 and 1995 they were unable to leave egos aside and backed several pro-reform candidates, thus diluting their strength. As a result, the Communists gained control of Parliament. Reformers also allowed the controversial loans-for-shares program to go forward, which only enriched the oligarchs, and ultimately emboldened them to demand Prime Minister Sergei V. Kiriyenko's dismissal.
President Clinton is right to go to Moscow, but the message he delivers there must be unequivocal: Mr. Yeltsin must push reform forward or there will be no more aid from the West. Moreover, all factions must cooperate or Russia may well collapse.
 
CAROL R. SAIVETZ
Cambridge, Mass., Aug. 31, 1998
 
The writer is a research associate at the Davis Center for Russian Studies, Harvard University.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW: THE OVERVIEW;
Clinton Tells Moscow Crowd That Future Won't Be Easy

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 1

 BODY:
President Clinton delivered a sober lecture to Russian leaders and the Russian people today about the hard realities of capitalism and the price of international support for relief from Russia's current financial crisis.
In meetings with President Boris N. Yeltsin and the temporary caretakers of Russia's paralyzed political and economic institutions, and in a speech to students at a Moscow university, Mr. Clinton warned that there is no easy escape from the financial catastrophe that has closed banks, left millions of workers unpaid and caused the collapse of the Government. 
 "The stakes are enormous," Mr. Clinton told a group of students and young business leaders at the Moscow State University for International Relations this afternoon. "Every choice Russia makes today may have consequences for years and years to come. Given the facts before you, I have to tell you that I do not believe there are any painless solutions. And indeed, an attempt to avoid difficult solutions may only prolong and worsen the present challenges." Excerpts, page A10.
The first day of Mr. Clinton's two-day visit to Moscow was markedly muted, fitting for a summit meeting whose purpose was far from clear, given Russia's turmoil and its lack of a functioning Government. Mr. Yeltsin's precarious political position and Mr. Clinton's unresolved legal problems at home added to the sense of gloom enveloping his trip.
Mr. Clinton's meetings with Mr. Yeltsin were businesslike and lacking in the back-slapping bonhomie that has characterized several of their earlier meetings, officials said. The state dinner tonight broke up at 9:15 P.M. after barely an hour; in past years such affairs have lasted well past midnight.
The only concrete accords to be announced at the meeting are agreements to reduce both nations' plutonium stockpiles and to share data on ballistic missile launchings. Both were were negotiated in the weeks leading up to the summit meeting, but even after the accords are signed, the details of both remain to be fleshed out.
American officials considered canceling the long-planned summit meeting because the prospects for meaningful progress were nil, but decided late last week to proceed because they concluded that abandoning the meeting would heap insult on Russia's multiple internal injuries.
The day was drab and rainy, unseasonably cold even for late summer in Moscow. Mr. Clinton's solemn speech at the university -- the only extended public remarks he will deliver on the visit -- matched the mood of this sullen city. While he offered words of encouragement and vows of friendship, the message was blunt and bleak. Russia's creditors and its international partners, the President said, will not tolerate a return to state control of important industries, efforts to escape financial hardship by printing rubles or special favors for cronies of powerful figures in the Kremlin.
"The challenge is to create a new Russia that benefits all responsible citizens of this country," Mr. Clinton said in a 35-minute address that was not once interrupted by applause. "How do you get there? I do not believe it is by reverting to the failed policies of the past."
Mr. Clinton then spelled out what he called "the rules of the road" that Russia must follow if it wishes to become a modern state in the global economy. They included a fair and consistent tax collection system, anti-inflationary Government monetary policy, legal protections for property owners and investors, steps to halt accelerating capital flight and an end to sweetheart deals for the tycoons who dominate an increasing share of Russia's legitimate and black-market economies.
"These are not radical theories," Mr. Clinton said. "They are simply facts proven by experience. How Russia reacts to them will fundamentally affect your future."
The hand-picked audience in the hall already agreed with most of what Mr. Clinton had to say, said Yekaterina Drozdova, a recent graduate of the university now working for the United States Agency for International Development in Moscow.
"All these people present are already for all of that," she said. "He might better try to impose his influence on the powerful structures."
She also mildly criticized Mr. Clinton for not speaking more forthrightly about politics in Russia. "The international community should express an opinion on what is going on in our country," she said.
Boris Chernyshev, a physiologist in his late 20's, also agreed with most of Mr. Clinton's views. "What would you expect him to say?" Mr. Chernyshev said. "It was all kind of predictable. I think it's just true."
Mr. Clinton's message to Mr. Yeltsin and to Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, the Acting Prime Minister, echoed that of his speech, according to Strobe Talbott, the deputy secretary of state who attended the morning and luncheon sessions.
Mr. Talbott said the United States would refrain from comment on Mr. Yeltsin's effort to piece together a Government from the battling powers of the lower house of Parliament or Duma, regional leaders and business interests.
"We have assiduously maintained our respect for the sovereignty of the Russian democratic political system," he said. "We're not going to pick and choose among Russian individual political figures, Russia's parties, factions in the current Duma, not least, to be very honest with you, because I'm not sure it would be helpful to those we wanted to help for us to create a hierarchy of whose policies we think most promising."
Nonetheless, he added, a return to control by Communist or other reactionary forces would not be greeted kindly by the United States and other Western nations. "The President said very clearly today in his speech at the institute that he hoped and believed that Russia would keep moving forward and not go back and try policies that have so clearly and dramatically and disastrously failed in the past," Mr. Talbott said.
Mr. Clinton's day in Moscow began with a brief arrival ceremony at Vnukovo II airport, where he was met by Mr. Chernomyrdin. Mr. Clinton and Mr. Chernomyrdin held preliminary discussions in the President's car on the way into Moscow, where they talked chiefly about Russia's current economic challenges, Mr. Talbott said.
Mr. Clinton placed a wreath at the tomb of the unknown soldier along the Kremlin wall, and then proceeded to a 90-minute private meeting with Mr. Yeltsin in the Russian President's ornate oval-shaped study.
Mr. Yeltsin greeted the American delegation, which included Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright; Bill Richardson, the Secretary of Energy; Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser; Gene Sperling, director of the National Economic Council, and Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Secretary of the Treasury. Mr. Yeltsin presented his visitors with a replica of an American flag given by an American delegation to Russia in 1866.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin met privately, then held a working lunch attended by about a half-dozen senior officials on each side. Apart from the economic and political crises gripping the country, the leaders discussed the ethnic bloodshed in Kosovo, Iraqi noncompliance with international arms monitoring and American concerns about Russian missile technology sales to Iran, according to Mr. Talbott.
After lunch, Mr. Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton, the First Lady, visited Elementary School No. 19, on the eastern bank of the Moscow River, to mark the official opening of Russian schools.
A group of well-scrubbed youngsters warmly applauded the Clintons and presented them with a doll and a plaque. Igor Dyomin, 7, wearing a sailor suit, performed a version of the high-kicking Cossack dance, to the delight of the Clintons.
In brief remarks, Mr. Clinton referred to Russia's current troubles and praised the courage and patience the Russian people have shown in earlier crises. He encouraged the students to explore the Internet, work to repair the environment and expand the frontiers of knowledge.
And he said: "I know that Russian students love to read and are proud of your country's great writers. A teacher here in Moscow asked her first grade class why they thought reading was important. One girl stood up and answered, 'You can read any book. You can read Pushkin.' No one in the first grade in my country is reading Pushkin."
The children laughed.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Straddling a Line Between Political Worlds

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
WHATEVER this weekend's rally for black youths turns out to be -- a peaceable protest, a thunderhead of rage and malevolence, a forgettable fizzle -- it will take place on David A. Paterson's doorstep.
In its pride and its anger, most of Harlem eventually passes by his family's apartment near 132d Street and Malcolm X Boulevard, and as the area's State Senator and scion of one of its most prominent families, Mr. Paterson has viewed the rally foremost as a neighborhood tumult, almost a personal responsibility. 
 While others focus on the virulence of the rally's organizer, Khallid Abdul Muhammad, Mr. Paterson has been more concerned about the neighbors and constituents whose children will be drawn to the event, whose sidewalks will be overrun, whose images will be broadcast for the delectation of the outside world.
And so he has tried to be a broker amid the publicity churn, dispensing with Mr. Muhammad as a destructive hater while urging City Hall to recognize the concerns of those who plan to attend the rally and tone down the condemnations in the interest of public safety. For this, he has earned the disdain of Mr. Muhammad and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, both of whom have accused him and other elected leaders of equivocating instead of taking a strong stand for or against a rally that organizers are billing as a Million Youth March. But he gently rejects the idea that one must take such doctrinaire positions, preferring a nuanced approach born not just of political necessity but also of singular experience.
"In spite of some of the problems I've had in my life, I think it's given me a unique perspective, a different way of looking at the world than other people," he said. "I think that's why I can condemn the hate language associated with the rally, but understand the anger and the disenfranchised feeling that makes African-Americans unable to denounce a person who's doing that."
His personal prism, he says, is the result of being the son of Basil A. Paterson, the former State Senator and Deputy Mayor, while feeling inadequate to enter his father's elite political world because he was born with no sight in his left eye and severely limited vision in his right. Even as he struggled to overcome those feelings, he found himself repelled by the racism he saw among some advocates for the disabled, and by the bias among black leaders against people with disabilities.
And so he moves between worlds, understanding but not subscribing to anyone's orthodoxy, freely taking positions unthinkable to his father's generation but never fully straying from the insider's political path.
THOUGH a political product of the city's mainline Democratic organization, Mr. Paterson, who is 44, says his party's inflexibility and lack of creativity have driven away vast constituencies. He is starting to see the merit in such ideas as charter schools and voucher systems. And as much as he criticizes Mr. Giuliani for raising the temperature of the rally and failing to address the longstanding concerns of black residents, he praises the Mayor for his law enforcement achievements and for the city's economic rebound.
"When you criticize everything somebody does, and find a way to diminish any achievement of another person or mayor, you marginalize yourself," he said. "The public believes you're just reacting, that you've succumbed to anger or hostility based on previous events. Whether I like the outcome of the mayoral election in 1993, I was elected by my constituents to bring back the greatest resources to my community. I will work with anybody, because my community is under siege."
His flexibility and his thoughtful explanations of his political positions have made him an important black leader, with influence far beyond his essentially powerless position as a Democrat in the Republican-controlled State Senate.
"David is very much a bridge between young people and his father's generation, and that's something important that's been missing in this city," said Bill Lynch, the former Deputy Mayor and strategist, who was Mayor David N. Dinkins's longtime adviser. "He has the credibility among both groups to say things that other people can't say, like challenging the messenger on this march without looking like he's doing it under somebody's guidance."
Mr. Paterson can see enough to play a decent game of basketball, raise two children with his wife, Michelle, and make his way without a cane. He entered politics after Hofstra Law School at the urging of his father's friends, believing he had to pretend that being legally blind was not an impediment, and until a few years ago he could barely talk about his eyesight. But he finally decided he was more comfortable admitting there were certain things he could not do, joining the community of the disabled and even making jokes on the subject.
Though he seems more comfortable within himself now, proud of his role mediating various racially tinged disputes over the last several years, he has yet to make the move that would propel him into the first rank of the city's political leadership. He has twice tried to escape the deadening frustration of the Senate, but for transitional jobs that he did not win: Public Advocate in 1993, and Manhattan Borough President last year. His friends have urged him to go for something more substantive the next time, and to begin organizing soon. He's thinking about it.
"One thing you learn in my position," he said. "You don't evolve unless you take a chance."

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1398 words

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW: ECONOMIC MEMO;
3 Options for Russia: Populist Path Seems Most Likely but Dangerous

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
Plan A, a $23.6 billion program courtesy of the International Monetary Fund, failed in less than four weeks. Plan B, a devaluation and debt moratorium cobbled together by young Russian reformers, collapsed within days. Neither prevented investors from fleeing or citizens from turning every ruble they have into dollars.
Now, Russia's central bank is nearly out of dollars, its banks are out of cash, and its Government is not just in de facto default on its loans, but for most practical purposes, defunct. And those who have ridden to Russia's rescue before -- the I.M.F., the United States, the Group of Seven industrialized democracies -- are ruling out a bailout. 
 So what options are left for restoring financial stability?
Even as Russia struggles to form a new coalition Government, some prominent Western economists are considering measures that would have been dismissed as extremist a few weeks ago.
Economists outline three possible courses of action for Moscow: Take the populist path of tightening direct control over the economy, including foreign-exchange controls that would make it difficult to convert the ruble into dollars or German marks. Or strike a deal with the I.M.F., paying at least lip service to tight money, budget balancing and orderly debt-restructuring. Or, most radically, link the nation's finances to a strong foreign currency like the dollar.
The last two proposals, both intended to preserve Russian access to foreign capital, could be pursued at the same time.
The trouble is that the choice Russia seems to be leaning toward -- the populist package -- seems the most likely to lead to hyperinflation, social unrest and a lurch toward nationalism -- or worse. Even the usually circumspect I.M.F. managing director, Michel Camdessus, warned that the populist scenario "would lead to disaster."
Consider that option first. Communists in Parliament are talking about a full retreat from a market economy, including nationalizing banks to protect depositors, renationalizing major industries to raise output and Government revenue and instituting price controls to protect the ruble and dampen inflation -- all to bring a sense of order to daily living.
The linchpin of their plan involves foreign-exchange controls that would ban dollar-denominated bank accounts abroad and force exporters to sell their foreign currency to the central bank at a fixed rate. The hope is that by making it impossible to buy dollars, the Russians could stem capital flight and stabilize the ruble.
Although most Western economists deplore exchange controls as authoritarian and prone to abuse, some believe that they may be the lesser of evils right now. "The foreign exchange must be closed," said Padma Desai, a professor of Russian studies at Columbia University and a proponent of gradual economic reform in Russia.
Others disagree. Paul R. Krugman, an international economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who recently wrote an article for Fortune magazine advocating exchange controls in several Asian nations, thinks that they would fail in Russia. In his view, Russia's oligarchs -- the tycoons who control the biggest banks and businesses -- would easily circumvent them. "If having dollars is criminal, only criminals will have dollars," he said.
There are other problems. Foreign-exchange controls risk triggering inflation by giving Russia's central bank a free hand to print more rubles. At best, the Government could keep inflation at bay with Soviet-style shortages and rationing.
Moreover, a heavy dose of state intervention would fuel capital flight and scare off foreign investors. And it would certainly cost Russia the rest of the $22.6 billion I.M.F. loan package announced in July. Exchange controls violate the I.M.F. charter.
A second alternative would be a modified version of the fund's program. That would please Washington, which contends that if Russia would just push ahead with the tax, banking and other economic reforms stipulated by the I.M.F. to restore confidence in the ruble, the West would be willing to lend more money. This is essentially the message that President Clinton is bringing to his meeting with President Boris N. Yeltsin in Moscow this week.
There is just one problem. This hope-for-the-best approach flies in the face of political reality as it has unfolded since Mr. Yeltsin changed his Prime Minister, replacing Sergei V. Kiriyenko, an advocate of economic reform, with the more conservative Viktor S. Chernomyrdin.
"The only way the Russians can get international financing is if they cut their budget deficit," said Anders Aslund, an economist at the Carnegie Endowment for Peace and an adviser to the Russian Government in the early 1990's. The only way to balance the Russian budget quickly is to transfer revenue from the regional governments, which spend huge sums to prop up money-losing banks and industries, to the central Government, Mr. Aslund said. But, he said, "Chernomyrdin was brought in to make sure that the banks were bailed out, that regional governments weren't put under pressure and that barter can survive."
What really stands in the way of fiscal reform is Russia's failure to develop a separate Government budget, central bank and private sector. "There's one common pot, one budget, one credit card which is more or less used for all transactions," said Alvin Rabushka, an economist at Stanford University's Hoover Institution, a public-policy research group. "In Russia, all losses and debts are passed back to the federal budget and the central bank."
That is why money from abroad is probably not the answer. Any cash the I.M.F. pumps into Russia has been lent by the central bank to banks that promptly exchange rubles for dollars. Such assistance just increases the pressure on the ruble and capital flight.
A third option for Russia, admittedly a desperate one, would be to give up all pretense of trying to control the value of its currency by linking the ruble tightly to a hard currency like the dollar and in effect replacing its central bank with a currency board. Under such an arrangement, the supply of rubles in circulation would have to be fully backed by dollars and convertible, on demand, at a fixed rate of exchange. In effect, Russia would be handing over control of its money supply -- which would fluctuate with the amount of dollars available -- to the Federal Reserve Chairman, Alan Greenspan.
Until recently considered an appropriate strategy only for small economies that rely heavily on international trade, the currency-board proposal is gaining supporters among prominent Western experts ranging from Mr. Camdessus to Mr. Aslund and Domingo Cavallo, a former Economics Minister of Argentina.
Rudiger Dornbusch, an international economist at M.I.T., is a recent convert. "What might have been a good idea for Indonesia is a far better one in Russia, where the economy has already been dollarized, just as Argentina's was in 1992," he said. "It's the right cure for a crazy Duma and a lunatic President."
But even Steven Hanke, a professor of applied economics at Johns Hopkins University and a long-time advocate of a currency board for Russia and other "emerging" economies like Argentina and Indonesia, says Russia is in too much turmoil to create a currency board immediately. As an interim measure, he suggests that Russia make the dollar legal tender -- as it was de facto until 1997 -- alongside the ruble.
After all, legally or not, Russians already hold more dollars than rubles, or $40 billion versus just $8.6 billion of their own depreciated currency.
"Russia needs a quick fix," Mr. Hanke said.
Temporarily making the dollar Russia's main currency might produce an injection of fresh financing, without the inflation that excessive money creation would set off. Right now, most Russians' dollars are squirreled away in foreign bank accounts or under mattresses and are not recirculated by domestic banks for use by cash-starved enterprises that need to pay workers or buy raw material.
No short-term measures can address Russia's bedrock problems -- the lack of a functional banking system, of truly private enterprises and of the rule of law. But Mr. Hanke said: "The ship is sinking, and they're trying to save passengers. They're not worrying right now about getting them to shore."

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Rural Life Has Room For Angst

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
Beneath the picture-postcard scenes of pastoral America, writers, at least since Sherwood Anderson and Edgar Lee Masters, have discerned a depressing reality: Things are not as they seem amid the foliage. Tomorrow night, a television documentary maker confirms that civilization's discontents do not spare an upstate New York community despite the beauties of a snowy winter and the childhood frolickings of summer.
In "Cayutaville," Diana Crone Frank trains her camera mainly on two families, the Chapmans and the Soules, and finds plenty of angst. Theirs is a Christian community, centered around faith and church, but these prove frail defenses against early death, heroin addiction, economic buffetings and family breakups. Shunning narration, she lets parents and children tell their own, mostly melancholy stories. 
 Particular attention is given to the most dire cases: Robert Chapman, father of three, who is unable to shake off his grief over a daughter's death years ago at the age of 10, and one of the Soule sons, Robert, who passed much of his life cut off from his parents and in a heroin haze. (Robert has since died.)
Cayutaville is not prospering, and neither family is awash in money. Mr. Chapman has resigned his teaching job for reasons not made clear; the beautiful old Chapman home has been mortgaged. Robert Chapman's attention to tending his daughter's grave seems obsessive and plays into the breakup of his marriage. A daughter says her mother has finally "gotten out from under his thumb," but it is he who seems liberated.
Mr. Soule, retired from his job as a guard at a youth camp, apparently carried his authoritarian style into his home and may have contributed to his addict son's sense of failure. But his other children seem content to raise their own families not far from home in jobs that are guaranteed not to make them rich.
Despite intimations of guilt, blame, responsibility, Ms. Frank sensibly stays clear of judgments of what went wrong. Instead she returns to church meetings where some of the family members find consolation for their disappointments in the warmth of community and the security, despite everything, of small-town living.
 
CAYUTAVILLE

(Channel 13, New York, at 10)

HEADLINE: Orders to Factories Climbed 1.2% in July

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
New orders flowed into United States factories at the strongest clip in eight months in July, the Government said today, emphasizing the industrial sector's vigor in the face of the July strikes at General Motors.
Despite recessions in Asia, which are steadily pinching export sales. as well as the idled plants at G.M., the largest auto maker, and its suppliers, orders grew 1.2 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $335.2 billion in July. 
 That was the biggest monthly rise since a 2.3 percent surge last November and much stronger than June's slight gain of three-tenths of 1 percent. Excluding transportation goods like new cars, orders were up even more strongly -- by 1.4 percent in June and also in July.
Maureen Maitland, an economist for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities in New York, noted that the July factory orders report showed a 1.8 percent drop in orders for capital goods, excluding military items and aircraft. The category is a barometer of businesses' plans for expanding plant and equipment.
"Over all, the data suggest that Asia is impacting the manufacturing sector very gradually," Ms. Maitland said.
Shipments of finished manufactured products fell in July -- the third decline in four months -- by a tenth of a percent, to $334.9 billion. There was a big drop in shipments of primary metals from June and of transportation products, and no change at all in July for electrical equipment or industrial machinery.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Treasury Prices Mostly Dip as Financial Turmoil Eases

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of most Treasury securities slipped slightly yesterday, as stock markets worldwide stabilized and the dollar weakened in currency trading, lessening the flight into Government securities that has been an almost daily occurrence lately.
Late in the day, however, the 30-year Treasury bond rose 3/32, to a price of 102 17/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped to 5.33 percent, from 5.34 percent the day before. 
 With yields at a 30-year low, the lure for some investors is not as strong as it was a few months ago.
Stephanie M. Davis, senior technical analyst at Thomson Global Markets in Boston, said, "Essentially, the markets are all due for some corrective activity," which, she added, could come on Friday, when the Labor Department reports the nonfarm payroll number for August.
"An aggressive 350,000 gain or more will probably knock bonds for a loop, sending prices lower and yields higher," she said, particularly if the dollar continues to weaken. "The next bond trade is apt to be down," she said, adding that the "price has come too far too fast."
The range of economists' forecasts goes from 205,000 new jobs to 430,000. Thomson Global Markets is looking for a rise of 325,000, which is slightly lower than the consensus, but still on the high side.
Hugh Whelan, vice president and portfolio manager at Aeltus Investment Management, is also cautious on bond prices. He urged investors not to try to rationalize current low yields on economic grounds. While Treasuries may have become a symbol of safety for speculators and day traders, he said, "long-term investors must be able to square bond prices with economic reality."
Despite investors' many worries about the effects of weaker foreign economies on this country, factory orders in July rose by a strong 1.2 percent, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.
Mr. Whelan cautioned that Treasury securities, having priced in a 50-basis-point drop in rates, already reflected a lot of the good news. "In fact, with the admission that economic data lag, there is no proof yet of a dramatic slowing in the U.S. economy," he said. "Current data suggest that third-quarter G.D.P. growth is likely to be 2.5 percent to 3 percent, not 1 percent."
