HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Market Frailty Isn't Mexican, Official Says

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Finance Minister Jose Angel Gurria runs an economy that is growing vigorously, with most exports surging and thousands of new jobs opening every day. But ask him whether the Mexican stock market will rise or plunge tomorrow and he shakes his head in bewilderment.
"Ask the Duma; ask Mr. Chernomyrdin," Mr. Gurria said in an interview today, referring to President Boris N. Yeltsin's embattled choice for Prime Minister and the house of the Russian Parliament that has so far refused to approve him. 
 "It has nothing to do with Mexico," he said. "That is what is very dramatic. Sometimes there is this feeling that there's not very much you can do. Basically, you are in the presence of forces you can't control."
Mr. Gurria vented frustration felt by leaders of several Latin American countries -- including Brazil, Chile and Argentina -- that took tough, often unpopular measures in recent years to stabilize their economies but have been dragged into the global market turmoil nonetheless.
"There is a lack of differentiation," Mr. Gurria said, lamenting that international investors had sold Latin securities in response to worries generated by Russia and Japan, without bothering to examine conditions in individual nations of the region.
Today, Latin American markets again showed that they are tied to trading in the United States as several of them rose or held steady, a day after Tuesday's rebound in the Dow Jones industrial average. (The Dow fell 45 points today after rising 288 on Tuesday.)
In Mexico, where there was no trading on Tuesday because of President Ernesto Zedillo's State of the Union address, the stock market rose today by 186.63 points, or 6.24 percent. Mexican stocks had dropped 5.14 percent Monday.
The Latin market performance came in spite of a controlled devaluation overnight Tuesday in Colombia. The authorities there widened the daily exchange rate band for the Colombian peso by 9 percent, saying they would allow it to depreciate 23 percent annually against the United States dollar, compared with 14 percent before.
Colombia had spent about $1 billion of its foreign reserves this year to shore up its currency, which was weakened by a budget deficit equivalent to about 6 percent of the gross domestic product. A new President, Andres Pastrana, took office there on Aug. 7.
Analysts said Colombia devalued anticipating a similar move in neighboring Venezuela, where economists say the bolivar is overvalued by as much as 40 percent. But Venezuela weathered the storm today, with its stock market closing up 3.82 percent. The bolivar was barely lower.
Mr. Gurria, who spoke in English, said that beneath wavering Mexican markets lay a sound economy that expanded 5.4 percent in the first half of this year. Despite a big drop in petroleum prices, the Mexican Government, which relies on oil for a third of its revenue, posted a small surplus for the first half of the year.
Mexico's foreign debt, the Finance Minister said, would remain well under control even if international markets were unsteady into next year. Mexico easily refinanced $4.5 billion in capital payments it owed this year, and those due in 1999 are smaller, at $1.4 billion.
Mr. Gurria said he was concerned that prolonged high interest rates could deal new blows to the Mexican banking system. Earlier this week, annual rates on overnight Treasury bills went to 38 percent. But so far, no bank collapses are looming, he said.
And he declared that threats to financial stability from outside the country were giving fractious lawmakers reasons to settle their differences over a proposed multibillion-dollar bank bailout.
"There is a growing awareness by all parties that we can't play games here, that if you stretch the rubber band a bit too far, it could snap," Mr. Gurria said. The bank bailout debate, in which the opposition has accused the Government of rescuing wealthy friends and colleagues at the expense of Mexican taxpayers, has dragged on since March.
Returning to the global economy and finances, Mr. Gurria said: "What worries me is who is running this show. There is an enormous vacuum of leadership worldwide. Where are the consensus-building and decision-making mechanisms to face situations like Russia and Japan? And how do you reward countries that perform well, like ours?"
He defended the $50 billion international rescue effort that saved Mexico from financial collapse in 1995. At a meeting of Latin finance ministers called for Friday by the International Monetary Fund, he plans to urge the I.M.F. and the advanced economies to once again come to the aid of Russia.
"There is a problem of contagion to the rest of the world's economy," Mr. Gurria said. "You're talking about a country which may qualify as too big to fail."

HEADLINE: American-Style Pay Moves Abroad;
Importance of Stock Options Expands in a Global Economy

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Rose Gerrit Huy was a fast-rising executive at Daimler-Benz A.G., the German industrial giant that makes Mercedes-Benz automobiles. A Harvard-educated economist, she was in charge of developing cars like the SLK roadster before she was promoted to head the company's finance and telecommunications subsidiary.
But last year, Ms. Huy, 43, quit Daimler after 11 years to become the Compaq Computer Corporation's managing director in Germany. Not that her Daimler salary was skimpy, but the Texas computer maker offered something that could catapult her into vastly greater riches: stock options.
Ms. Huy would not disclose the size of the options package that lured her away, but these numbers surely provide a clue: While the chairman of Daimler holds a form of options worth less than $1 million, the options of the Compaq chairman are worth more than $188 million at last count. 
 For the last two decades, even as the global economy has demolished national barriers to trade and investment, the executive pay gap between America and the rest of the world has widened dramatically. While American executives were loading up with stock options, restricted stock and other compensation intended to align their interests with those of shareholders, their counterparts overseas continued to collect only salary and modest bonuses.
That is largely because the political cultures of many European and Asian countries recoiled at the idea of lavishing vast riches on capitalist chieftains for a single year's work. Pay packages like the $49.9 million that Sanford I. Weill, the chairman of Travelers Group Inc., collected in 1997, or the more than $556 million that Michael D. Eisner, the chairman of the Walt Disney Company, made in 1997 by exercising fewer than half of his stock options left many people in Europe aghast.
Now, though, that attitude is changing, albeit slowly. To stem a drain of executive talent to their American rivals, big European and Asian corporations have begun pressing their governments to modify securities laws and accounting practices that discourage jumbo pay packages.
"The rest of the world is moving to our pay model," said Kevin J. Murphy, a University of Southern California finance professor and a leading expert on worldwide executive pay. "Maybe that movement is out of efficiency, maybe it is out of greed -- we don't know which yet -- but the trend is clear."
Last year, for example, Japan revised its commercial code to allow stock options. Already, 160 companies, including Sony, the entertainment and electronics concern, have adopted option plans, according to Bob Buford, a compensation specialist with the consulting firm Towers-Perrin in New York, who has worked with many Japanese companies.
The invasion of American-style pay plans, including stock options, is uneven in Europe, specialists say: faster in high technology, like telecommunications and software, and slower in manufacturing and heavy industry. But it is having a big impact wherever it is found, and the recent turmoil in global stock markets, although it may have cut the value of some compensation packages, is unlikely to have any long-term effect on equity-based pay.
In France, the Netherlands and Australia, a few companies have started adding options and other forms of equity to executive compensation packages, a practice that the British began widely adopting in the early 1980's.
In Germany, a court upheld a form of stock options last month that Daimler offered two years ago to 170 executives, a pool it has since expanded tenfold, while also increasing the size of its still-modest option packages.
Wolfgang Doell, a partner in Frankfurt with the executive-search firm Heidrick & Struggles, said that two years ago the Ford Motor Company extended its American pay levels to its operations in Europe, and immediately lured two top executives from Volkswagen. Ford is now fishing for lower-level managers using the same bait -- stock options -- and this has increased the pressure on the German auto industry, one of the slowest areas of German business to adjust, he said.
"The world is now moving to the U.S. model because it works very well for shareholders," Steven N. Kaplan, a finance professor at the University of Chicago, said.
Stock options give the holder the right to buy shares at a given price over a specified period, usually 10 years. If the stock surges, the holder can exercise the option, sell the stock at a much higher price and pocket the difference.
Even in America, where it is the most widespread, the practice is controversial, especially when poor-performing executives walk away with multimillion-dollar payoffs either because their stock has been held aloft by the bull market or because the exercise price has been reset downward.
Despite all the criticism, other countries are embracing the practice. In London, Paul Hodgson, an editor at Income Data Services, which tracks executive compensation at British companies, said that the "only difference is in the size of pay, not the components, which are going toward the U.S. style."
While options in Britain have tended to be modest, Unilever P.L.C., the British-Dutch household-products maker, and Marks & Spencer P.L.C., Britain's largest retailer, are moving toward American-style mega-grants.
Some companies, including SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., the drug concern with major operations in London and Philadelphia, and Four Seasons Hotels and Hilton International, a unit of Ladbroke Group P.L.C., the multinational lodging companies, have made all or parts of their compensation packages identical regardless of where an executive is stationed.
Compensation experts call such plans "global pay." Translation: pay on an American scale.
These experts say global pay eliminates internal tensions that arise when, say, the home office executives in Brussels or Osaka make less than their subordinates in Chicago or Los Angeles.
The disparity in pay between American companies and the rest of the world came into sharp focus in May, when Daimler agreed to acquire the Chrysler Corporation, whose No. 2 executive made more last year from salary, bonus and cashing-in options than the top 10 Daimler executives combined.
Both Daimler and Chrysler have told shareholders that the new DaimlerChrysler will have separate pay plans for executives in Stuttgart and in Detroit, an indication that it does not plan to quickly equalize pay.
Robert Eaton, the Chrysler chief executive, predicted that the highest German and American executives at DaimlerChrysler would someday be paid similarly. "We have to be competitive, and over some extended period of time, I would see for that group the compensation coming together," Mr. Eaton said.
Ira T. Kay, a partner in New York with Watson Wyatt Worldwide, said that in recent years, foreign owners have begun to adopt long-term incentive pay, including small grants of options, which he saw as signs of how foreign-owned companies were moving closer to American-style pay. By paying executives with equity, American companies have performed better than those overseas, Mr. Kay argues in his book "CEO Pay and Shareholder Value: Helping the U.S. Win the Global Economic War" (St. Lucie Press, 1998).
Gareth R. Williams, an international pay expert in the Chicago office of William M. Mercer, the consulting firm, said that in five years or so there would be many "global executives who will not be hamstrung by their location" and who would earn global pay that is heavily dependent on stock options and other forms of equity-based rewards.
The trend to raising the compensation of executives at multinational companies to the levels in the United States has encountered all sorts of opposition -- even from the very executives who stand to benefit from it. Alan Johnson, a compensation consultant in New York, said many European and Asian executives he has worked with showed an obvious distaste for huge options payouts. "I have been surprised that it is not just a legal, wake-up-and-smell-the-money issue," Mr. Johnson said, "but it is deeply rooted in their culture and views that you just don't seek unlimited money."
On a trip to the United States, the chief executive of Commerzbank, Martin Kohlhaussen, stunned an American banker recently when he said he owned no Commerzbank stocks. "What makes you tick?" was the American banker's response. Ulrich Ramm, Commerzbank's chief economist, said Europe was moving toward American-style pay, but added: "It's done here with more sensitivity than in the United States, with all the exaggerations there. Here you try to spread it a little more broadly."
Mr. Johnson predicted that like Daimler "most companies will change in baby steps." He added, "It will take a decade or so to get like the U.S."
One reason for the slow pace, in the view of John England, a Towers Perrin executive-compensation specialist in Brussels, is the greater responsiveness of European companies to stockholder concerns. When Daimler's original options plan for its executives came under attack from an investor, for example, Mr. England said that Daimler modified its option grants. "You never see a U.S. company do that," he said.
Europe's high income-tax rates can make perks like cars, chauffeurs, gardeners and lifelong health benefits as big a draw as options. And European tax laws discourage companies from making bountiful options awards by treating them as a cost on the corporate balance sheet rather than as a deduction on their taxes. As a result, European stock-incentive plans are often watered-down versions of their American counterparts. What Daimler calls "options," for example, are more like what Americans call convertible debentures.
Under the Daimler plan, executives use after-tax money to buy securities that pay about 4.4 percent interest for 10 years and give the right to convert to stock at a fixed price once the shares have risen 15 percent. The plan limits the 170 top executives to a $120,000 investment a year, pocket change for American chief executives, while senior managers can invest only $30,000 annually.
Brian Foley, an executive compensation lawyer in White Plains, said that requiring executives to buy into their equity, what he called "putting some skin in the game," might lower resistance to American-style pay plans in Europe and Japan.
"Buy one, get two sounds a lot better than giving something" away free, as most American stock-option plans do, he said.
Graef Crystal, the editor of an executive-compensation newsletter who once designed executive pay plans, took a more jaundiced view.
"The virus," he said, "is now spreading around the world."

SECTION: Section C; Page 5; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: RUSSIA'S IMPACT;
Quick Action by U.S. Banks Limits Damage

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Although the Chase Manhattan Corporation and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette joined the chorus of financial services companies announcing losses on their business in Russia yesterday, investors may soon be able to breathe more easily about the Russian impact.
The extent of American banks' exposure to Russia, analysts say, pales in comparison with the hits taken as a result of the Latin American debt crisis in the 1980's. And quick action by several American financial institutions in recent days to mark down their possible losses by as much as 85 percent should limit the damage to their bottom line, analysts said. 
 "It's a bad quarter," said Carla D'Arista, a managing director and banking analyst at Friedman, Billings, Ramsey & Company in Arlington, Va. But, she added, "It's in no way meaningfully derailed the fundamentals of the largest U.S. banks."
Chase Manhattan said yesterday that it expected to take a $200 million charge in the third quarter, primarily for losses in Russia and Asia. Its direct Russian exposure was about $250 million, with the bulk of that, about $140 million, related to commercial banking activities, it said.
Exposure to institutional investors and investment funds collateralized by ruble-denominated Russian Treasury securities was about $210 million, Chase said, with the majority of this exposure backed by "significant" non-Russian assets.
The bank also reported trading revenues for July and August of approximately $160 million. Analysts said that was a significant drop from average monthly trading revenues of about $200 million.
"We believe we have captured most of what can be the impact of Russia," said Dina Dublon, Chase's executive vice president and treasurer.
Chase, which has an inventory of about $50 million of Russian securities remaining, still expects to post "substantial" earnings in the third quarter, Ms. Dublon said.
Yesterday, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette said that it earned about $40 million before taxes during the first two months of the third quarter, after taking into account losses in Russia. A spokeswoman declined to be more specific.
Dresdner Bank A.G., Germany's third-largest bank, said yesterday that its unsecured credit exposure to Russia totaled 1 billion marks, ($571 million), bringing the total for the big four German banks to less than 4 billion marks of unsecured lending. Dresdner Bank has already made provisions to cover about 60 percent of its Russian loan exposure. Recently, Commerzbank A.G. has reported 1 billion marks in exposure; Deutsche Bank A.G. said it had 1.35 billion marks, and Bayerische Hypo-und Vereinsbank A.G. 500 million.
Earlier this week, Citicorp, Bankers Trust, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Barclays and Nomura Securities also reported heavy losses on Russian business. Among the largest were those of Salomon Smith Barney and Bankers Trust. Salomon, a unit of the Travelers Group, said it had lost an estimated $360 million after taxes in its arbitrage and Russian-related credits businesses, while Bankers Trust put its pretax trading loss at $350 million.
But the State Street Bank Corporation in Boston said yesterday that recent events in Russia, Asia and Latin America had had no significant impact on its revenue and earnings.
Last week the BankBoston Corporation said that it lost $30 million this quarter in United States and international trading, including $10 million in Russia. BankAmerica, and J. P. Morgan also reported trading losses.
Despite their Russian exposure, most banks, with the exception of Bankers Trust, should report positive earnings for the third quarter and see minimal impact in 1999, said Thomas H. Hanley, a managing director at Warburg Dillon Read.
"The banks have thrown in the kitchen sink in the third quarter," he said. "They faced up to the problem this time immediately."
In the first quarter of 1998, foreign bank lending to Russia totaled about $61.4 billion, according to the Bank for International Settlements.
German bank exposure equals about one-half of that, Mr. Hanley said.
Over all, major American money center banks have about $1.6 billion of pretax losses from Russia, Mr. Hanley estimates. Prior to the Russian crisis, the banks' total exposure was about $6.4 billion. Pretax losses and withdrawn lines of credit have reduced their net exposure to about $3.3 billion, he said, a modest percentage of the banks' total capital of about $92 billion and their total reserves of $15.9 billion.
In comparison, at the height of the Latin American debt crisis in 1984, loans from money center banks totaled about $58.5 billion, outpacing the banks' total capital of $26.7 billion and reserves of $4.1 billion, according to a Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation report.
Banks needed several years to recover from the losses, Mr. Hanley said.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW;
Excerpts From Clinton and Yeltsin Remarks: 'Peace and Stability'

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the joint news conference of President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia in Moscow yesterday, as provided by the White House:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
By President Yeltsin
Distinguished ladies and gentlemen, the official visit of the President of the United States Bill Clinton to Russia is coming to an end. We have had intensive, productive negotiations. We have managed to discuss a wide range of topical issues. I would like to emphasize the exchanges were sincere and keen. The dialogue was marked by the spirit of mutual understanding. 
 Responsibility of our two countries for maintaining and strengthening peace and stability is obvious. That is why we have paid special attention to the discussion of the entire spectrum of security issues in the world.
The discussion has included the implementation of international and bilateral treaties and agreements concerning the weapons of mass destruction, as well as the elaboration of common approaches to dealing with the threat of nuclear weapons proliferation and their delivery means.
Unfortunately, this is not the only major task that humanity struggles to resolve. That is why President Clinton and I have discussed global threats and challenges. Our positions on this issue have coincided and this closeness of approaches is reflected in the joint statement on common security changes on the threshold of the 21st century. I consider this document to be a significant step toward strengthening strategic partnership between Russia and the United States.
We have also had substantial talks on the most topical international issues. And there are quite a few such issues. I'll put it frankly; here our approaches have not always completely coincided. Russia rejects the use of power methods as a matter of principle. Conflicts of today have no military solutions, be it in Kosovo or around Iraq or Afghanistan or others. Also we do not accept the NATO centrism idea for the new European security architecture. Nevertheless, our talks have been conducive to greater mutual understanding on these issues.
Of course, we could not do without discussing economy problems. Current dimensions of our economic relations should be brought up to a qualitatively new level. We shall have to suffer through much blood, sweat and tears before new forms of business cooperation worthy of our two great powers are found, reforms that would be able to withstand volatile circumstances. There exist quite a few opportunities for this. These are mentioned in our joint statement on economic issues.
In conclusion, I would like to say -- and I hope Bill will agree with me -- the summit was a success. . . .
 
OPENING STATEMENT
By President Clinton
Thank you very much, Mr. President, for your hospitality and for giving Hillary and me and our team the chance to come to Moscow again.
Over the past five years, I have been in this great, historic city in times of bright hope and times of uncertainty. But throughout I have witnessed the remarkable transformation of this nation to democracy, to a more open economy. We all know that this meeting comes at a challenging time for the Russian people. But I don't believe anyone could ever have doubted that there would be obstacles on Russia's road to a vibrant economy and a strong democracy. I don't -- also believe that anyone can seriously doubt the determination of the Russian people to build a brighter, better, stronger future.
Russia is important to America. Our economies are connected; we share values, interests and friendship. We share security interests and heavy security responsibilities. In our discussions, President Yeltsin and I spoke about Russia's options for stabilizing its economy and restoring confidence. I reaffirmed America's strong view that Russia can move beyond today's crisis and create growth and good jobs, but only if it carries forward with its transformation, with a strong and fair tax system, greater rule of law, dealing forthrightly with financial institutions, having regulations that protect against abuses; and yes, developing an appropriate safety net for people who are hurt during times of change.
President Yeltsin reaffirmed his commitment to reform. And I believe that is the right commitment. The answer to the present difficulties is to finish the job that has been begun, not to stop it in midstream or to reverse course. This is a view I will reaffirm when I meet today with leaders of the Duma and the Federation Council. America and the international community are, I am convinced, ready to offer assistance if Russia stays with the path of reform.
We discussed also at length common security concerns. . . .
 
Arms Export Controls
In recent months Russia has taken important steps to tighten its export controls on weapons of mass destruction and the missiles to deliver them, and to penalize offenders.
This week, Russia barred three companies from transactions with Iran. Today, we agreed to intensify our cooperation by creating seven working groups on export controls to further strengthen Russia's ability to halt the spread of dangerous weapons. Also, we renewed our commitment to persuade India and Pakistan to reverse their arms race. And we pledged to accelerate international negotiation to establish a tough inspection regime of the Biological Weapons Convention. I don't believe it's possible to overstate the importance of this initiative for the next 20 years. . . .
Russia and the United States share a commitment to combat terrorism. We agree that there is no possible justification for terrorism; it is murder plain and simple. . . .
Finally, we discussed our common foreign policy agenda, including, first and foremost, the need to continue to strengthen the peace in Bosnia and to look for a peaceful solution in Kosovo, where the humanitarian situation is now quite grave. We agreed that the Serbian government must stop all repressive actions against civilian populations, allow the relief organizations immediate and full access to those in need, and pursue an interim settlement.
 
Sanctions on Iraq
President Yeltsin and I also agree that Iraq must comply fully with all relevant U.N. Security Council resolutions imposed after the gulf war, and in particular, must agree to allow the international weapons inspectors to again pursue their mission without obstruction or delay. Far from advancing the day sanctions are lifted, Iraq's most recent efforts to undermine the inspectors will perpetuate sanctions, prevent Iraq from acquiring the resources it needs to rebuild its military and keep Iraq's economy under tight international control. . . .
This has been a full agenda, a productive summit. . . .
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
Q. My first question is, before you met, a lot of politicians, a lot of the public believed your meeting would not be needed . . .So what was the psychological atmosphere during your talks? . . . And second, are Russia and the U.S., partners right now, or still contenders? And today, bidding farewell, Boris Yeltsin and Bill Clinton, are they still friends?
MR. YELTSIN: I will start with your last question. Yes, we stay friends and the atmosphere since the beginning of the talks until the end was a friendly one. I would say it was very considerate and there were no discontents during the talks that we had.
And this brings my conclusion that since we did not have any differences, in my opinion, there will be no differences also in our activities, in what we do bilaterally. Of course, that goes without saying. This is very logical.
Now, in response to those skeptical observers who alleged, and continue to do so, that they don't believe, I've been always saying, no, on the contrary -- we need to repeat it -- we do believe we do that in order to remove the tension, and each time, having those meetings, we've been able to do something to alleviate the tension. This is what really matters. We've been doing that, removing the tension. And this time again we have removed part of the tension one more time.
MR. CLINTON: Well, first of all, I think it's important to answer your question of what happened from the point of view of the Russian people and then from the point of view of the American people.
You ask if we're still friends. The answer to that is yes. You ask if Russia and the United States have a partnership. I think the plain answer to that is, yes, even though we don't always agree on every issue. I can tell you from my point of view, this was a successful meeting on the national security issues, because I think establishing this early warning information sharing is important and I know that the destruction of this huge volume of plutonium is important. And it also might be important to the Russian economy. It can be a plus as well as a national security plus.
Now, on the domestic economic issues, from the point of view of America, it was important for me to come here just to say to the President and to his team and to the Duma leaders I will see later and the Federation Council leaders that I know this is a difficult time, but there is no shortcut to developing a system that will have the confidence of investors around the world. These are not American rules or anybody else's rules. These are -- in a global economy, you have to be able to get money in from outside your country and keep the money in your country invested in your country.
And if the reform process can be completed, then I for one would be strongly supportive of greater assistance to Russia from the United States and the other big economic powers, because I think we have a very strong vested interest in seeing this economically successful Russia and that is a full partner across the whole range of issues in the world. I also think it's good for preserving Russia's democracy and freedom. . .
MR. YELTSIN: I would like to add just a moment, just two words here. We have put it on paper. We have decided to set up on the territory of Russia a joint center of control over the missile launches. For the first time this has been done. This is exceptionally important.
 
Economic Perils
Q. President Yeltsin, yesterday President Clinton spoke of the painful steps that Russia will have to take and the need to play by the rules of international economics. What difficult steps are you prepared to take?
. . . And to President Clinton, the world stock markets seem very fragile right now. How can the United States withstand all these outside pressures?
MR. CLINTON: I think the answer to your question about what we can do that's best for our economy is really twofold. The first thing we have to do is to do our very best to make the right decisions at home. You know, we have to stay with the path of discipline that has brought us this far in the last 5 1/2 years, and we have to make the investments and decisions that we know will produce growth over the long-run for the American economy. Whether it's in education, or science and technology, we have to do the things that send a signal that we understand how the world economy works and we intend to do well in it. But the most important thing is sticking with sound economic policy.
Now, in addition to that, it is important that more and more Americans, without regard to party, understand that we are in a global economy and it's been very good to the United States over the last 5 1/2 years -- about 30 percent of our growth has come from exports -- but that we at this particular moment in history, because of our relative economic strength, have an extra obligation to try to build a system for the 21st century where every person in every country who is willing to work hard has a chance to get a just reward for it.
And that means that we have to -- in my opinion, that means that we have to continue to contribute our fair share to the International Monetary Fund. It means we have to do everything we can to support our friends in Russia who believe that we should continue to reform. It means that Secretary Rubin's upcoming meeting with the Finance Minister of Japan, former Prime Minister Miyazawa, is profoundly important. Unless Japan begins to grow again, it's going to be difficult for Russia and other countries to do what they need to do. It means, in short, that America must maintain a leadership role of active involvement in trying to build an economic system that rewards people who do the right thing. And that's in our best interest.
So I think this is a terribly important thing. The volatility in the world markets, including in our stock market, I think is to be expected under these circumstances. The right thing to do is to try to restore growth in the economies of the world where there isn't enough growth now, and to continually examine whether the institutions we have for dealing with problems are adequate to meet the challenges of today and tomorrow. And we are aggressively involved in both those activities.
MR. YELTSIN: Naturally, we face problems basically of our own. We have not been able to do many things over the past time when we started our reforms. And still we need to conclude our reforms, to bring them to completion, and consequently, to get results.
We are not saying that we count solely on the support from outside -- no. One more time I will reiterate this no. So let your mass media not spread the word to the effect that allegedly we would count solely on the support from the West. And to this end, we have gathered together here by no means. What we need from the United States is political support to the effect that the United States is in favor of reforms in Russia. This is what we really need, and then all the investors who would like to come to the Russian reformed market will do so, will come with their investments. And this is what we really need now. This is what is lacking -- investments. This is first and foremost.
Certainly, we ought to fight our expenditures pattern and mismanagement. This is the second issue which, to us, is one of the most important issues. And we have been adopting accordingly the measures which need to be taken -- like we have adopted the program of stabilization measures; in other words, those measures which will result in stabilization of our reforms. Stabilization -- I believe that such measures and such a program will work, promptly, over the coming two years it will produce results.
 
U.S.-Russia Links
Q. Mr. Clinton . . . what is the basis of your belief that our country will get back to its feet and that Russian-U.S. relations have promising prospects?
MR. CLINTON: Well, my belief that Russian-U.S. relations have promising prospects has been supported by the agreements we have made in the security and foreign policy areas. My belief that Russia will get back on its feet is based on my observation that in Russian history every time outsiders counted the Russian people out, they turned out to be wrong. And this is a very big challenge, but, I mean, a country that rebuffed Napoleon and Hitler can surely adjust to the realities of the global marketplace.
Now, what's to be done? The reason I wanted to come here and -- to be fair, let me back up and say, I don't think there are many people in America who are afraid of Russia anymore. I think there are some people in America who questioned whether I should come at this moment of great economic and political tension for the country. But I don't think it's because they want something bad to happen to Russia. I think, by and large, the American people wish Russia well and want things to go well for Russia, and like the fact that we are partners in Bosnia and that we've reduced our nuclear arsenals so much and that we've reduced our deficit establishment and that we've found other ways to cooperate in space, for example. I think most Americans like this very, very much.
So let me go back to the economic question. I believe whether you succeed and how long it takes you to succeed in restoring real growth to the Russian economy depends upon President Yeltsin's ability to persuade the Duma to support his formation of a government which will pursue a path of reform with a genuine sensitivity to the personal dislocation of the people who have been hurt. And here's where I think the World Bank and other institutions can come in and perhaps help deal with some of the fallout, if you will, of the reform process.
But I think if other political forces in Russia try to force the President to abandon reform in midstream or even reverse it, what I think will happen is even less money will come into Russia, and even more economic hardship will result. I believe that because that is, it seems to me, the unwavering experience of every other country.
That does not mean you should not have a social safety net. It does not mean you have to make the same domestic decisions that the United States or Great Britain or France or Sweden or any other country has made. You have to form your own relationship with this new economic reality. But I still believe that, unless there is a manifest commitment to reform, the economy will not get better.
So I support President Yeltsin's commitment in that regard. And I think those -- my conviction that it will get better is based on my reading of your history. How long it will take to get better depends a lot more on you and what happens here than anything else we outsiders can do, although if there is a clear movement toward reform, I'll do everything I can to accelerate outside support of all kinds.
 
Lewinsky Situation
Q. Has the reaction since your admission of a relationship with Ms. Lewinsky given you any cause for concern that you may not be as effective as you should be in leading the country?
MR. CLINTON: No, I've actually been quite heartened by the reaction of the American people and leaders throughout the world about it. I have acknowledged that I made a mistake, said that I regretted it, asked to be forgiven, spent a lot of very valuable time with my family in the last couple of weeks and said I was going back to work. I believe that's what the American people want me to do, and based on my conversations with leaders around the world, I think that's what they want me to do, and that is what I intend to do.
As you can see from what we're discussing here, there are very large issues that will affect the future of the American people in the short run and over the long run. There are large issues that have to be dealt with now in the world and at home. And so I have been quite encouraged by what I think the message from the American people has been and what I know the message from leaders around the world has been. And I'm going to do my best to continue to go through this personal process in an appropriate way, but to do my job, to do the job I was hired to do, and I think that very much needs to be done right now.
 
Russia and NATO
Q. The question has to do with the relationship between Russia and NATO . . . How do you think this relation should evolve in the future?
MR. YELTSIN: Yes, we have discussed with President Clinton the question concerning the relationship between Russia and NATO. We're not running away from the position which has been that we are against NATO expanding eastward. We believe this is a blunder, a big mistake, and one day this will be a historic error.
Therefore, at this point in time, what we necessarily would like to do is to improve relations so that there be no confrontation. Therefore, we have signed an agreement between Russia and NATO. And in accordance with that agreement we want to do our job. However, no way shall we allow anybody to transgress that agreement, bypass that agreement, or, generally speaking, put aside it. No, this will not happen. . . .
MR. CLINTON: I would like to say one word about that. We obviously, President Yeltsin and I, have a disagreement about whether it was appropriate for NATO to take on new members or not. But I think there is a larger reality here where we are in agreement, and I would like to emphasize it.
Russia has made historic commitments in the last few years to essentially redefine its greatness, not in terms of the territorial dominance of its neighbors, but instead, of constructive leadership in the region and in the world. The expansion of NATO, therefore, should be seen primarily as nations interested in working together to deal with common security problems, not to be ready to repel expected invasions. . . .
 
Chernomyrdin's Fate
Q. President Yeltsin, do you see any circumstance in which you could accept someone other than Mr. Chernomyrdin to be your Prime Minister? And, Mr. President, another Lewinsky question. You know, there have been some who have expressed disappointment that you didn't offer a formal apology the other night when you spoke to the American people. Are you -- do you feel you need to offer an apology?
MR. YELTSIN: Well, I must say, we will witness quite a few events for us to be able to achieve all those results. That's all.
MR. CLINTON: That's my answer, too. That was pretty good. . . .

GRAPHIC: Photos: Presidents Yeltsin and Clinton ended their summit talks with declarations of mutual support and cooperation on security and arms control, then took questions yesterday. SECTION: Section A; Page 11; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1099 words

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW: NEWS ANALYSIS;
The Firewall: Doubts About a Tactic to Contain Chaos

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Inside the Treasury Department, some of the strategists desperately seeking to contain spreading outbreaks of financial chaos once called their approach the "firewall strategy."
The idea was straightforward and born of Washington's success in containing the Mexican peso crisis in 1995. As foreign currencies plummeted and investors fled -- first from Thailand, then Indonesia, then Korea and now Russia -- the Treasury and the International Monetary Fund would stitch together a bailout that insisted on far-reaching reforms, which would rebuild national economies in America's image. 
 The hope was that the emergency support from the I.M.F. would buy some time, and the promise of change -- cleaning up failing banks, imposing austerity and ending corruption and crony capitalism -- would lure back investors and protect the United States and other countries from economic contagion.
But now firewall strategy is coming undone. It has collided, some Administration officials concede, with the inability -- or unwillingness -- of weak or inexperienced foreign governments to give stock and currency markets what they want.
"The political price of complying with the markets' demands are finally hitting home," said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, which was an investor in Asia and has been deeply involved in the bailouts of South Korea and Russia. "And they simply seem too high."
In Russia, firewall strategy has never amounted to more than a few haphazardly placed bricks. The Parliament has refused to enact many of the I.M.F.'s conditions; the central bank has virtually run out of dollars to defend the ruble, and the Western aid that was sent in late July -- $4.8 billion -- has seemed to vanish. .
Speaker Newt Gingrich drove the point home today in demanding that the Clinton Administration explain why Congress should give $18 billion more to the I.M.F. "Where has all this money gone?" he asked Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin in a letter. "How much of this money has left Russia? How much of this money is in the hands of corrupt officials or their corrupt business associates?"
In Indonesia, the firewall was built of straw and was immediately ignited. Now, with a Government barely hanging on, rioters targeting the Chinese minority, which brought much foreign investment into the country, and the Army reeling, the Fund's program is at a virtual standstill.
And this week, Malaysia became the first country to reject the I.M.F.'s advice -- and Mr. Rubin's -- in explicit terms, deciding to turn its back on the free market and virtually halt currency trading.
Investors have been told that the country's currency cannot be traded outside the country -- all of it must be returned to Malaysia by Oct. 1 or it will be declared worthless. Today Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad dismissed his presumed successor, Finance Minister Anwar Ibrahim, who has been an advocate of free-market strategies and a champion of financial modernization in Asia. Mr. Anwar's house has been cordoned off by police, and there is widespread speculation that he may soon be arrested for sedition.
One senior Administration official today called the turn of events in Malaysia -- a country where firms like Intel, Motorola and Matsushita have built huge factories -- "a tragedy." Others said it was the inevitable clash between the power of government and the power of markets, and they predicted that Mr. Mahathir's effort to wall himself off from financial markets would be a spectacular failure.
Mr. Mahathir saw it differently. "Malaysia is facing terrible problems because of the Western capitalist system, which has gone wild," he said on Saturday. "Financial instruments have become as good as gunboats for colonizing."
Mr. Mahathir has always ranked among the most vocal critics of what he views as Western efforts to dominate Asia, and in brighter times he was a leading advocate of promoting "Asian values." But the Asian values debate was largely about cultural and legal issues -- the American emphasis on individual rights, for example, versus an Asian insistence on the importance of stability and the good of the community.
The current argument, while couched in terms of I.M.F. plans and currency conversions, is an offshoot of that debate. In Russia, Malaysia and even Japan, the United States is insisting on reforms that would essentially give power to investors to move their money across borders at will, instead of to governments seeking to control their destinies.
Mr. Rubin, a man trained on the trading room floor, has cast this choice in stark terms: countries that try to interfere with the freedom of markets will be cut off by international investors and starved for lack of international capital. His speeches and President Clinton's stiffly worded speech in Moscow on Tuesday make it clear that the United States and the I.M.F. will only aid countries that adopt reforms along the lines the I.M.F. has prescribed.
"This is the first time Rubin has had to face a series of political revolts to his plans," a White House official observed this week.
Mr. Rubin's team insists that the country-by-country approach -- getting the fundamental economics right, forcing the disclosure of more financial information -- still works. Thailand and Korea, his aides say, recently managed to lower interest rates, and there is hope that this will help spur their economies in 1999. In Latin America, they argue, countries like Brazil have taken preventive measures, which have helped ward off the kinds of disasters that struck Asia and Russia.
But Mr. Rubin's deputy, Lawrence H. Summers, has said many times in recent months, "We can't want reform in any country more than its government and its people do."
And that is essentially what is beginning to happen now. The United States is virtually screaming at Japan to end seven years of economic paralysis, and it will repeat the message on Friday night when Mr. Rubin and Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, meet in San Francisco with Kiichi Miyazawa, Japan's finance minister and a 40-year veteran of United States-Japan relations.
But dragging Japan, which has the world's second-largest economy, toward politically painful reforms has been almost as difficult as dragging Russia and Indonesia in that direction. And, increasingly, there is a sense inside the Treasury that, in the words of a top official, "We don't have much time." Japan could touch off another, far more serious round of financial crises if it fails to deal with its problems.

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: ASIA;
Hong Kong Restricts Short Sales of Some Stocks

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Sept. 2

 BODY:
The Hong Kong government bolstered the stock market again today by suspending short-selling of shares in a number of companies.
The crackdown forced the short-sellers -- who sell borrowed stock in the hope that the price of the stock will subsequently fall -- to cover their bets today by repurchasing shares. 
 The government has been buying stocks, and lifting the overall market, since mid-August to thwart short-sellers, and today's action had a similar effect. The Hang Seng index of 33 leading issues jumped 6.2 percent.
Stock exchange officials suspended short-selling of shares in the banking giant HSBC Holdings, Hong Kong Telecommunications, and China Telecom (Hong Kong) Ltd. until they could clear a backlog of trades. Those companies had been the three most popular issues to sell short as they ranked among the most heavily traded shares on the Hong Kong market.
The exchange also reinstated a rule that requires people selling a borrowed stock to do so at a price that is at least equal to the last asking price quoted on the exchange for that stock. That regulation is known as the "tick rule."
The crackdown on short-selling kept many traders out of the market. Shares with a total value of $5.8 billion (Hong Kong), or $748 million (United States), changed hands, a small fraction of last Friday's record volume of $79 billion (Hong Kong). Short sales amounted to $31.4 billion (Hong Kong), compared with $9.1 trillion (Hong Kong) on Friday.
In short sales, the lenders of shares -- typically pension funds, insurance companies and mutual funds that arrange the sales through a stockbroker -- earn money from the interest rates they charge the borrowers.
As the supply of stock has dried up, rates to borrow such shares have surged. Annual interest rates to borrow stocks that are components of the Hang Seng index now stand around 15 percent, more than a tenfold increase from before the government intervention.
Last Friday, investors rushed to borrow stocks so that they could sell them to the government as it embarked on its buying spree.
Many of those who had lent the stocks called in those shares so that they could take advantage of what they perceived to be the last day of the government purchases. Today, they hurried to buy back those shares to cover the short sales.

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: ECONOMIC SCENE;
Relax. Stocks Rarely Steer the Economy.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
Are plunging stock prices a harbinger of economic crisis? Paul Samuelson, the Nobel laureate in economics, once quipped that stock market declines had anticipated nine of the previous five recessions.
That impish caution from decades ago has been updated by Peter Temin, a colleague of Mr. Samuelson at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. After examining every recession this century, he concludes that only a minor downturn, in 1903, was caused by falling stock prices. Some recessions were caused by anti-inflationary policies of the Federal Reserve Board. Others were caused by external events, like the oil price shocks in the 1970's. Even the Great Depression of the 1930's did not stem from plummeting stock prices. Chalk that horror up to persistent policy blunders here and abroad. 
 History does not necessarily repeat itself. But the nearly unblemished record is a sobering counterpoint to breezy speculation this week about recession, rising unemployment and other economic woes that could follow the recent plunge on Wall Street. On Monday, the broad market gauge lost more than 7 percent of its value, leaving it down nearly 20 percent from its peak in July.
Though no forerunner of recession, stock market plunges can nevertheless slow an economy. Consumers react to their shrunken wealth by cutting purchases. Companies, fearful of uncertainty and forced to issue a larger number of (lower-priced) shares to raise any given amount of money, react by cutting investment outlays. It is possible, then, that a stock market crash could tip an economy into recession.
But that leap would occur only after a sharp decline and then only under certain conditions. A back-of-the-envelope calculation shows why a stock drop the size of the one in the last couple of weeks is unlikely to do serious harm.
American stocks are worth about $10 trillion; in recent weeks, their value has fallen about $1 trillion. Economists estimate that consumers cut back spending by about 4 cents for every dollar of wealth they lose. So a trillion-dollar stock market plunge would cause about a $40 billion drop in annual consumer spending, about one-half percent of total spending. Prof. Benjamin Friedman of Harvard University points out that it ordinarily takes a spending cut four times that size to bring on a recession.
A $40 billion cut in consumer spending could produce a downturn in an already-stagnant economy. But this economy is strong, with consumer spending and business investment growing briskly in the first half of the year. Besides, consumers may not cut back spending even as much as these estimates suggest because many might not react to a drop in paper wealth from recent sky-high levels they never regarded as secure. Consumers did not rush out the minute the Dow hit 9,300 to order a new yacht, nor are they likely to cancel the family vacation because of a possibly temporary fall below 8,000.
If the argument sounds Pollyannaish, consider what was wrought by October 1987, when the market plunged by more than 20 percent in one day. Main Street -- national output and jobs -- barely noticed, though some regions, like New York City, were hit hard. The economy is more resilient today than it was 11 years ago. Inflation, interest rates and unemployment are low. Bank reserves are high. The Federal Reserve could readily fight off recession by pumping up the money supply without fear of igniting inflation or making other smoldering problems worse.
That is what the Fed, under its chairman, Alan Greenspan, did in 1987.
Yet there is one problem today that Mr. Greenspan did not face in 1987. Asia is mired in recession, and financial crises plague Russia and threaten Latin America.
Indeed, some economists and market watchers called this week for the Fed to set domestic monetary policy with an eye toward the plight of the country's trading partners, perhaps nudging rates down even if the American economy needs no such help.
Lower domestic interest rates would ease the debt burden of foreigners who have borrowed in dollars. Lower rates in the United States would also drag down interest rates in countries that tie their currencies to the dollar. That too will help these countries recover. And, the argument goes, if a Fed easing helps Asia and other beleaguered regions recover, then the United States will eventually reap the benefit of trading with prosperous partners.
But while it's easy to call on the Fed to take global factors into account, Federal law and good sense dictate that Fed policy follow home-grown events. Professor Friedman cautions against having the Fed tailor its policies to foreign borrowing practices or exchange rate policies. Prof. Alan Blinder of Princeton, a former vice chairman of the Fed, says the impact of Fed policy on foreign economies is neither huge nor certain.
Counting on Fed easing to help the domestic economy by bolstering foreign economies is to rely on a speculative chain of events that provides no sure guide to policy. Economists agree that the Fed needs to factor foreign demand for exports into its projections about the domestic economy. Mr. Blinder can imagine times when the Fed would decide to ease because of weakness abroad even though it was otherwise wavering between cutting rates and standing pat. But almost always, the Fed's focus must be domestic needs alone.
The important point, on which monetary experts agree, is that the Fed's monetary weapons are powerful enough to keep the American economy in line, short of financial catastrophe abroad. The Fed can pump up domestic spending by making it easier to borrow. Any shortfall in foreign demand for American products can be offset by additional American purchases.
Doomsayers point out that plummeting stock prices could spook the international currency and capital markets, leading to a self-fulfilling pessimism among consumers and investors. From there the story turns to worldwide downturn and even deflation reminiscent of the 1930's. But few economists find that story compelling. They point out that a lot of stock investments are tied up in retirement and pension accounts and will not be dumped the minute the markets turn sour. Besides, investors who lived through the carnage in 1987 are secure they can ride out the next nose dive.
It is tempting to exaggerate the impact of dramatic events like this week's stock market volatility. But consider that even at this week's low, stock prices were about where they were in January -- and well above the levels at the end of 1996 that caused Mr. Greenspan to warn that the market was irrationally high. Suppose, rather than soaring beyond 9,000 in July and swooning below 7,600 in August, the Dow had merely moseyed its way on an even track for eight months at what were widely perceived to be high levels. Would anyone now be wringing hands over a recessionary blow to the American economy that could reverberate across international borders?
Stock prices rise and fall and, as Mr. Samuelson taught us 30 years ago, that's that.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW: THE OVERVIEW;
PRESIDENT SAYS AID WILL RISE IF RUSSIA PRESSES REFORMS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 2

 BODY:
President Clinton signaled today that the West would step up its aid to Russia if the Kremlin pressed ahead with tough economic reforms.
His message, intended to encourage the Government of President Boris N. Yeltsin to stick with its pro-capitalist course despite the nation's deepening economic crisis, was the most striking development as a two-day summit meeting ended. It was dominated by a collapsing ruble and a Government paralyzed by its battles with a Communist opposition. 
 "If the reform process can be completed, then I for one would be strongly supportive of greater assistance to Russia from the United States and the other big economic powers," Mr. Clinton said during a joint news conference with Mr. Yeltsin. Excerpts, page A10.
Russia recently negotiated a $17 billion bailout with the International Monetary Fund, $4.8 billion of which has been delivered.
But the financial turmoil that has rocked the Yeltsin Government has led the United States to think about further steps to speed and expand Western assistance.
American officials do not have a detailed plan of just how much additional aid might be provided and where the funds would come from.
But Mr. Clinton has told his aides that the United States should be prepared to lead a new international aid effort, which could draw on the Group of Seven industrialized nations and international organizations like the World Bank.
"If there is a clear movement toward reform, I'll do everything I can to accelerate outside support of all kinds," Mr. Clinton said, echoing assurances that were also provided in private meetings with Mr. Yeltsin, according to Mr. Clinton's aides.
Providing further assistance to Russia is far from a popular idea with Congress. The United States also appears to be out in front of many of its allies on the issue, although Tony Blair, the British Prime Minister and current chairman of the Group of Seven, telephoned Mr. Yeltsin on Monday to indicate general support for Russia if economic reforms continued.
Clinton aides said billions in aid would be a small price for keeping Russia's young democracy on a reform course and preventing the rise of an anti-Western regime. They stressed, however, that Russia bears the primary responsibility and that fresh assistance would be provided only if the Kremlin demonstrates that it has the political will not just to talk about reforms, but also to carry them out.
"It is absolutely critical for the well-being of the United States for decades to come that Russia not lurch backwards," a senior American official said. "But we have also made it clear that Russia needs to take steps to insure that the money that is here stays here and does not leave."
Whether Russia can summon the determination to put its economy in order, however, is far from clear.
Mr. Yeltsin vowed today to proceed with economic reforms and said: "What we need from the United States is political support, support for Russian reforms. Then all investors who want to come to the reformed Russia will come."
He also reappointed Boris G. Fyodorov, an aide who backs a strong free-market policy, as Deputy Prime Minister. No sooner was Mr. Fyodorov officially restored than he began talking about tough measures to stabilize Russia's battered currency.
There are few, however, who believe that gestures alone will do the trick.
Russia still lacks a Prime Minister, leaving in doubt the Kremlin's overall commitment to economic reform and its ability to garner support for its policies. Mr. Yeltsin's current choice, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, was decisively rejected by the Communist-led Parliament on Monday.
Another vote is scheduled for Friday, but his opponents say he sure to lose again. And a third defeat would result in the disbanding of the legislature and new elections.
That would represent a major escalation in the Kremlin's tug of war with the Communists. It is far from clear, however, whether the politically and physically weakened Mr. Yeltsin has the stomach for the fight. The Russian President dodged a question today on his commitment to Mr. Chernomyrdin.
American officials say Mr. Yeltsin appears to be pondering dumping Mr. Chernomyrdin for a new candidate like Konstantin A. Titov, the reform-minded Governor of the Samara region; Yegor S. Stroyev, the head of the upper house of Parliament and a Yeltsin ally, or Mayor Yuri M. Luzkhov of Moscow.
The delays in forming a new government have also put off the economic decisions that are needed to extract the nation from its crisis and regain credibility with the West.
The I.M.F., for instance, was scheduled to decide whether to distribute the next $4.3 billion installment of its loan by mid-September.
Stanley Fischer, the fund's No. 2 official, said the I.M.F. would be unlikely to take up the matter before October.
"Given what we know now about the changes in the exchange rate, of course difficulties in the banking system, possible difficulties in the budget, it's clear that the Russians will have to do quite a lot before that money could be released," Mr. Fischer told the CNN program "Moneyline."
Mr. Fischer's timetable clashed with the Clinton Administration's promise to try to accelerate aid, pointing to the confusion in Western ranks about how to help Russia.
But without a new government in place, even Mr. Yeltsin's biggest boosters found it difficult to make the case for speedy help.
Despite the addled Russian political scene, today's summit sessions proved to be more substantive than many observers had predicted.
The Clinton Administration scheduled the summit meeting hoping to promote Russian ratification of strategic arms treaty known as Start-2. It soon found the issue issue overtaken by the rush of economic events.
Still, the two leaders signed an arms accord to share missile-warning data and agreed to begin disposing of bomb-grade plutonium.
Mr. Clinton used his sessions with Mr. Yeltsin to encourage him to stay the economic course.
And in a meeting with opposition politicians today, Mr. Clinton sought to persuade Gennadi A. Zyuganov, the Communist leader, of the need to play by the rules of the free market.
There was no sign that Mr. Clinton made any headway on that score -- or in persuading the Communists to cooperate with Mr. Yeltsin. Some opposition leaders said, however, that Mr. Clinton did the right thing by coming.
Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the leader of the liberal Yabloko party, said many Russians appreciated that Mr. Clinton had gone through with the summit, despite the nation's latest crisis.
"It was the right idea to come," he said. "Clinton was a brave man to come to Russia in the conditions we are in now."

HEADLINE: Main Street Investors Take the Bear by the Horns

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa, Sept. 2

 BODY:
During these pogo stick days on Wall Street, Stanley Walker, a retired mechanic with a good chunk of his life savings in the stock market, has thought once or twice about his boyhood in the Depression years.
And he has no desire to have pockets so empty, as his father did, that Sunday dinner means pig tails and sauerkraut. 
 "Is it time to pull the rip cord?" Mr. Walker, 77, nervously asked his broker on Monday, when the market dived more than 500 points. "I like to be able to sleep at night."
His broker told him to relax. And Mr. Walker, who did not sell a single stock, is trying to do just that.
Despite some jitters, there is little apparent panic on Main Street this week.
"People are becoming old veterans at this," said Doug Reese, a broker here for Edward Jones. "They've been through all of this before."
As in most of America, the stock market has become everybody's game in this pleasant Iowa courthouse town. Inside the Muddy Waters coffee shop, small investors who endured the plunge of Monday and rode a strong rebound on Tuesday echo all the financial-analyst cliches: the economy's "strong fundamentals," "great buying opportunities" and, of course, the importance of "staying in for the long haul."
Some people have even become a bit blase about the market's gyrations.
One is Mark Engle, a 44-year-oldteacher of high school Russian, who kicked his boots up on a chair and rattled this morning's issue of The Des Moines Register.
On the front page, there was a cartoon about Wall Street that showed a bunch of little chickens screaming about a falling sky, along with a frightened-looking bull. But Mr. Engle skipped right past the articles about the market, turning instead to the sports section to read about Mark McGwire, the home run king, who, to paraphrase Babe Ruth's line, is having a much better year than Wall Street.
"He's amazing," Mr. Engle said.
In recent years, though, it is the market that has hit the home runs for people in this town of 26,000 about 40 miles northeast of Des Moines.
Market gains allowed Barb Collins to retire from a factory job at the age of 57, vacation in France, England and Italy, and cruise to Crete. She even has a vacation home in Minnesota. To people like Mrs. Collins, now 63, who was pushing her 1-year-old grandson, Ariaus, in a stroller on this sunny day, there is little point in complaining about a bumpy stretch of road along an otherwise magnificent run.
DyAnne Henry, 49, who owns an embroidery shop, In Stitches, said the stock market was a lot like life.
"You have some highs and you have some lows," she said between bites of pancakes at Monica's coffee shop. "But if you have patience and keep the faith, everything mellows out in the end."
Despite the general buoyancy, however, Mr. Reese, the broker, noted that some nettlesome developments had given investors a number of uneasy moments. Besides the specter of a weakened President Clinton, tarnished after acknowledging that he misled the public about his relationship with a White House intern, there are the financial and political crises in Russia and the economic turmoil in Asia.
In a place like Iowa, which exports plenty of grain and agriculture-related machinery, among other goods, a crisis halfway around the globe can come home to roost in a hurry.
"When it comes to economics, Iowa is by no means isolated," said Mr. Engle, the Russian teacher. "How we do depends a great deal on how people in other countries are doing."
Tom Mueller, a 47-year-old insurance salesman, expressed few worries about the strength of the American economy, although he did have doubts about the President's effectiveness.
"You can't help but think he's not the same leader that he was four or five weeks ago," said Mr. Mueller, who got up early today to watch Mr. Clinton and the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, on television in Moscow. "He doesn't come across as being so confident anymore. Is that going to hurt our standing around the world?"
In general, though, people did not seem to think that Mr. Clinton's problems would hurt the stock market. Making a connection between the Washington soap opera and the earnings of Fortune 500 companies is "a bit of a stretch," Shirley Duffy said.
Mrs. Duffy, 69, who operates tours for Iowans to places like Nova Scotia, Alaska and New York, said she was not going to take a penny out of the market. She and her husband, Wallace, became alarmed at a sudden downturn two years ago and shifted much of their holdings to fixed-income accounts. That proved a mistake.
"We learned our lesson," Mrs. Duffy said, "so we're going to sit tight."
Mr. Reese and other brokers have been talking to customers about a downturn's silver lining. For much of the last few years, he had to tamp down expectations of investors, many of whom were looking for whopping gains in a matter of weeks. Now, with prices on many stocks down 15 to 20 percent in only a few months, he has been encouraging investors to think about adding to their holdings.
Not that everyone is prepared to jump on board.
John Kraft, a 38-year-old painter, said that he would like to get into the market but would stay out, in deference to his wife.
"She doesn't like the idea," he explained, "that you can end the day with less money than you had yesterday."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Clinton Hints at Offer To Russia of Financial Aid
President Clinton suggested that the West would increase its aid to Russia if that country continues its tough economic reforms. His message was intended to encourage the Yeltsin Government to stick with its pro-capitalist course despite the nation's deepening economic crisis.
Mr. Clinton has told his aides that the United States should be prepared to lead a new international aid effort, which could draw on the Group of Seven industrialized nations and international organizations, such as the World Bank. Page A1. 

Chase Manhattan Bank and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette announced losses on their business in Russia. Chase said it expects to take a $200 million charge in the third quarter, primarily for losses in Russia and Asia. C5.
 
F.D.A. Panel Backs Tamoxifen
An advisory committee to the F.D.A. voted unanimously to approve the use of the drug tamoxifen to reduce women's risk of developing breast cancer. A1.
 
Shares of Zeneca, which makes the drug tamoxifen, and Barr Laboratories, which sells its generic form, rose sharply. Also increasing were shares of Genentech, which received approval from an F.D.A. panel for Herceptin, the brand name for a biological drug to treat metastatic breast cancer. C7.
 
More Northwest Workers Laid Off
Northwest Airlines laid off 27,500 workers, including mechanics, flight attendants and customer service representatives, and canceled all its 1,700 daily flights through the Labor Day weekend, a move that could extend the disruption caused by the five-day old pilots' strike for weeks. A18.
 
Malaysian Finance Minister Ousted
Anwar Ibrahim was dismissed as Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister of Malaysia. His dismissal came one day after the Prime Minister imposed controls on the sale of the currency, the ringgit, and fixed its exchange rate. These steps followed a July stimulus package that overturned Mr. Anwar's tight fiscal policies. A3.
 
Hong Kong Suspends Short Sales
The Hong Kong government bolstered the stock market again by suspending short-selling of shares many companies. C5.
 
Shares of Brokerage Firms Down
Shares of brokerage firms have been battered in recent weeks, in some cases falling more than 40 percent. Analysts say that if the market stabilizes and builds on its fledgling recovery, these stocks might increase, but then again, if the market's slide continues, they might decline. Market Place. C6.
 
Livent Names Artistic Director
Livent hired Todd Haimes, the artistic director of the Roundabout Theater Company, as artistic director, effectively supplanting Garth H. Drabinsky, Livent's co-founder and the producer of "Ragtime." C6.
 
Long Bond's Yield Edges Down
Prices of most Treasury securities slipped slightly, with investors feeling less need to seek a haven, as stock markets worldwide stabilized and the dollar weakened. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 5.33 percent, from 5.34 percent on Tuesday. With yields at a 30-year low, the lure for some investors is not as strong as it was a few months ago. C7.
 
U.S. Seeks More Microsoft Papers
The Government has asked a judge to order Microsoft to hand over documents that the Government contends show a pattern of illegal behavior by the software giant toward industry rivals. C19.
