HEADLINE: In Gubernatorial Debate, Democrats Sound Like Allies

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: TROY, N.Y., Sept. 2

 BODY:
With remarkable unanimity, the Democratic candidates for governor attacked Gov. George E. Pataki on the state budget, job growth, education and campaign finance in a debate here tonight, treating one another more like chums than like adversaries.
In a hint of the shifting fortunes of the campaign, none of the other candidates overtly attacked Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross or asked her any questions, as they did in previous debates when she was clearly considered the front-runner. In forums held last month, they demanded that she explain positions she had taken just a few years ago as a Republican, often leaving her struggling for a response. 
 What went unmentioned in tonight's hourlong event, however, was the recent talk of the campaign: the apparent disarray in Ms. McCaughey Ross's camp. She spent much of the day denying reports that her campaign manager, Michael Nussbaum, had been ousted, and refusing to answer questions about whether she intended to launch a long-awaited television advertising campaign.
"I'm going to be making a statement about my campaign finances tomorrow," she told a crush of reporters after the debate at Hudson Valley Community College.
Tonight's was the sort of exchange candidates claim to want: a polite, serious discussion of issues. The other contenders were Peter F. Vallone, the New York City Council Speaker; Charles J. Hynes, Brooklyn District Attorney, and James Larocca, a businessman and former state transportation commissioner.
But the debate failed to inject any fire into a race that so far has not received much voter attention. The event, sponsored by the League of Women Voters and public television, will be broadcast statewide Thursday night on public television.
The most enthusiastic attacks on the Governor came about his handling of state spending and borrowing, which have increased sharply, with all four Democrats claiming that they would be more fiscally responsible than Mr. Pataki, an avowed conservative. They also charged that the Governor had done little for the anemic upstate economy.
"We are looking at the possibility of significant budget cuts as early as next spring," Mr. Larocca said. "Today in New York, there is no economic development plan. There isn't even a plan to make a plan."
Mr. Vallone, whose standing in some polls has risen at Ms. McCaughey Ross's expense, referred to the fact that the state had begun this fiscal year with a $2.4 billion surplus but now projects large deficits in two years. "When you take that surplus and turn it into an admitted $5.5 billion deficit in a few years," he said, "that is the height of irresponsibility."
He repeated his call for a state law giving preference to New York businesses in government contracting, similar to a measure Mr. Pataki vetoed this year. That idea has been called into question by some economists, and none of the other Democrats have advocated it.
The only real note of disagreement came in the area of campaign finance reform. Mr. Vallone, Mr. Hynes and Mr. Larocca advocated measures like strict contribution limits, public financing of campaigns and a ban on "soft money," the unlimited contributions to parties, ostensibly for organizational needs.
But Mr. Larocca took Mr. Vallone to task for taking contributions from people who do business New York City, saying that the practice should be banned.
But Ms. McCaughey Ross, whose own campaign treasury is provided almost entirely by her husband, the investment banker Wilbur L. Ross Jr., would only say that she favored banning contributions by anyone with a business interest before the state. She refused to say whether she supported tighter contribution limits, a ban on soft money, public financing of campaigns, or any other measure.
All four candidates lauded the higher high school graduation standards adopted recently by the Board of Regents. But they agreed that the schools were not ready to meet those standards, and advocated an expansion of school programs for the youngest children, and after-school programs for older students.
The candidates agreed that patients should have the right to sue their health insurers, something now denied by state law. And all said that many drug offenders should be sent to rehabilitation programs, not prison. The only attack on the lieutenant governor came from Mr. Larocca, in discussing health care. He said that patients would be better off "if the conservative right wing hadn't trashed the national health care program" proposed by President Clinton.
That was a reference to Ms. McCaughey Ross, who first gained fame critiquing the Clinton plan. But Mr. Larocca did not mention the lieutenant governor by name.
Even as Ms. McCaughey Ross was trying to focus on the debate, she and her aides were besieged with questions about the status of her campaign. Several people close to the campaign said Mr. Nussbaum, a top adviser to the campaign, had not spoken to Ms. McCaughey Ross or spent time at her campaign headquarters since last week.
Kevin Davitt, a spokesman for Ms. McCaughey Ross, said that Mr. Nussbaum had left only for a few days to take his son to school in Boston, and that he was still "giving us tremendous advice."
But others close to the campaign said that Mr. Nussbaum's absence was provoked by the disagreement between Ms. McCaughey Ross and her husband over financing for the campaign. They point out that Mr. Nussbaum is closer to Mr. Ross than he is to Ms. McCaughey Ross.
Mr. Nussbaum is an executive at News Communications, a company owned by Mr. Ross, and is not paid for his work on the campaign, Mr. Davitt said.
Mr. Ross has provided more than $3 million to his wife's campaign, but hardly any of it has been spent. People close to the campaign said that Ms. McCaughey Ross had been trying to persuade her husband in recent days to spend the money on advertising, but that he was reluctant. With the Sept. 15 primary less than two weeks away, Ms. McCaughey Ross has begun talking privately about spending her personal savings on advertising, they said.

HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: IN MOSCOW;
CLINTON DEFENDS HIS TV ADMISSION ON LEWINSKY CASE

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Directly questioned for the first time in public about the Monica Lewinsky matter since his televised admission two weeks ago, President Clinton said at a Kremlin news conference today that he believed he had expressed "profound regret" to those who had been hurt by his relationship with Ms. Lewinsky.
While his remarks today amplified his previous statements, the President again stopped short of issuing an outright apology for the illicit relationship or for lying about it to his family, his staff and the nation. And Mr. Clinton repeated that the investigation by the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, that brought him to this pass was "disproportionate" to his alleged offenses. 
 "I have acknowledged that I made a mistake, said that I regretted it, asked to be forgiven, spent a lot of very valuable time with my family in the last couple of weeks and said I was going back to work," Mr. Clinton said, speaking at a joint news conference here with President Boris N. Yeltsin.
"I believe that's what the American people want me to do, and based on my conversations with leaders around the world, I think that's what they want me to do, and that is what I intend to do."
Mr. Clinton also said he was "heartened" by the reaction of the American people and world leaders to his public admission on Aug. 17, the same day that he testified to the grand jury about accusations that he had lied about the relationship and tried to cover it up.
But within the walls of the Kremlin, as Russia is seething with political intrigue and economic privation, the President looked anything but heartened by having to deal with the Lewinsky matter when he would prefer to be conducting high-level diplomacy. Mr. Clinton's demeanor during the news conference, which lasted 43 minutes -- indeed, throughout the two-day summit meeting here -- was subdued, almost mournful.
In the last two weeks, Mr. Clinton has come under heavy criticism, much of it from members of his own party and political allies, who said he was insufficiently contrite and overly defensive in his public statements two weeks ago.
Aides said he had been prepared for questions about the Lewinsky matter at the news conference and decided on his own to address them rather than rebuffing them as inappropriate in a foreign country.
Yet Mr. Clinton's response today to the first question left many in the White House press corps dissatisfied. At the next opportunity, he was asked whether he regretted the bitter tone of his statement and felt that he owed an apology to his family, his supporters and the American people.
Mr. Clinton tried to avoid the question by jokingly echoing a curt response by Mr. Yeltsin to a separate question about his prospects for forming a Government out of the current political chaos in Moscow. But President Clinton then gave a fuller answer.
"I think the question of the tone of the speech, and people's reaction to it, is really a function of ----. I can't comment on that," Mr. Clinton said as Mr. Yeltsin looked on alternately bemused and bewildered by the spectacle in the beautifully restored Catherine's Hall in the Kremlin.
Mr. Clinton continued, "I read it the other day again, and I thought it was clear that I was expressing my profound regret to all who were hurt and to all who were involved, and my desire not to see any more people hurt by this process and caught up in it."
Then, elaborating on his combative words toward Mr. Starr, the President added: "And I was commenting that it seemed to be something that most reasonable people would think had consumed a disproportionate amount of America's time, money and resources and attention, and now continued to involve more and more people. And that's what I tried to say."
White House aides offered no elaboration on the President's remarks.
"On this matter," said Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, "the President obviously wants to speak from the heart, and he did. He said what he wanted to say, and I don't think it's the role of staff to try to amplify or comment further on his remarks."
Nor would Mr. McCurry or other aides provide the names of the "leaders around the world" who Mr. Clinton said had offered him support and encouragement after his admission of an inappropriate relationship with Ms. Lewinsky and his misleading public statements on it. Officials would not say whether Mr. Clinton's comments today would be his last on the matter.
He has spent some of the rare unscheduled time on this trip making calls to the United States to gauge the impact of his admission, a senior White House aide said. Other officials on the trip have also been in contact with Congressional Democrats to try to judge their mood as they return to Washington.
One senior Administration official who has worked closely with Mr. Clinton at the summit meeting said he had seen no evidence the President was dejected over the Lewinsky revelations and the critical reaction to his televised speech last month.
The official said Mr. Clinton's somber mood over the last two days reflected the turmoil in Moscow.
"This is a serious situation which does not lend itself to laughter," the official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity.
The official said Mr. Clinton's mental state had not affected his ability to do his job. "Not on this trip," the official added.
Mr. Yeltsin did not comment on the questions about Ms. Lewinsky, either in the news conference or in private meetings with Mr. Clinton, American officials said.
But Grigory A. Yavlinsky, leader of a liberal political party here, said that many Russians sympathized with Mr. Clinton for the legal problems he faced arising from the Lewinsky matter.
"We look at it in a more personal way," Mr. Yavlinsky said. "We don't take this juridical view."

HEADLINE: Northwest Lays Off 27,000, Increasing Pressure on Strike

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Northwest Airlines laid off more than half of its 51,000 workers yesterday, spreading the economic disruption created by a five-day-old strike of its pilots.
The move signals that the airline is preparing for a protracted battle while at the same time increasing pressure on President Clinton to order the pilots back to work, an intervention that the company has been quietly seeking. 
 Northwest said that with its 1,700 daily flights grounded since Saturday by the walkout, it had no need for a full work force. The 27,500 employees being laid off, including mechanics, flight attendants and customer service representatives, are also in contract negotiations with the company. Unions representing these workers remained firm in their support of the pilots.
Also yesterday, as Northwest canceled all its flights through the Labor Day weekend, the Department of Transportation said that two commuter airlines affiliated with Northwest had violated Federal law by suspending service to 17 small cities in 11 states. The department ordered the airlines, Mesaba Airlines and Express Airlines I, which connect the cities with Northwest's hub airports in Detroit, Minneapolis and Memphis, to resume flying today. The commuter airlines' pilots are not on strike.
The large layoff means that Northwest, which is the country's fourth-largest carrier and dominates much of the Midwest, will not be flying again anytime soon, even if it reaches a settlement with the pilots. The carrier estimated that it would take 8 to 10 days to get all its planes back in the air once the pilots returned to the cockpit.
The major issues in the strike are pay and job security. Before negotiations broke off on Friday, the union was seeking a 14 percent raise over three years. Northwest's last offer was a 9 percent raise over four years. The union says the pilots' yearly average salary is $120,000; the company says it is $133,000.
Magdalena G. Jacobsen, the chairwoman of the National Mediation Board, who is supervising the negotiations, invited the two sides to meet with her in Chicago on Saturday.
Jim Armshaw, a spokesman for the board, which is an independent Federal agency, said the meeting was not a resumption of negotiations but an effort to see whether there was enough movement on either side for new talks to be productive.
"It is an exploratory meeting," Mr. Armshaw said. "If it can go beyond that, it will."
The meeting was announced a day after Rodney E. Slater, the Secretary of Transportation, met with the chief executive of Northwest, John H. Dasburg, and the president of the Air Line Pilots' Association, J. Randolph Babbitt, separately and together for nearly five hours in his Washington office.
Donald J. Foley, Northwest's vice president for communications, said: "Dasburg made it very clear that ALPA's position on pay is unachievable. They gave no indication that they will move on that. Until they do, we can't do anything."
The pilots restated their position that they were waiting for Northwest to return to the negotiating table.
The Northwest pilots say they helped save the airline from bankruptcy in 1993 when they accepted a 15.5 percent wage cut in exchange for stock along with the other unions.
Since then, Northwest has registered four years of record profits and the airline's executives have cashed in stock options worth tens of millions of dollars, while the pilots' salaries have merely returned to the pay levels before their concessions. After two years of negotiations, the pilots say they are seeking an "industry-leading" contract that would vault them over their counterparts at American Airlines, United Airlines and Delta Air Lines.
The company has said it cannot afford to pay the pilots more than its three larger competitors pay theirs.
In addition to the 14 percent raise, the pilots are seeking a lump sum of $86 million, an end to a two-tier wage scale in which newly hired pilots are paid less than those who have been at the airline for more than five years, and limits on the number of small, regional jets Northwest can add to its fleet.
In addition to the 9 percent wage increase, Northwest has offered a lump sum of $57 million, a reduction of the two-tier wages scale to three years from five, profit sharing and improved pension benefits.
The pilots say the differences between the two offers amount to $70 million a year; the company estimates the difference at $170 million.
But Northwest is also in the midst of negotiating contracts with its five other unions. The airline has said that if it meets the pilots' demands, it will be forced to be equally generous with its other workers, saddling it with high costs at a time when a weakening global economy threatens to end the boom in the airline industry.
The strike has caused fewer problems than many had predicted. Because of the 30-day cooling off period required under the Railway Labor Act before the pilots could walk out, businesses and consumers had more than a month to prepare for life without Northwest.
But if the strike drags on beyond the busy Labor Day holiday, it promises to cause increasing disruption as business people resume heavier travel schedules.
Northwest has repeatedly warned of the disastrous effects of a strike in the hope of convincing President Clinton to intervene. The White House has the power to compel the pilots to return to work for 60 days while an emergency board tries to negotiate a compromise. But Mr. Clinton, who ended a pilots strike at American Airlines last year, has declined to step in.
Northwest said yesterday that it regretted having to lay off its workers. "This is a sad day for Northwest Airlines," Said Dwayne Tucker, Northwest vice president for human resources. "We hoped never to have to exercise this option."
But the pilots accused the company of exaggerating the impact of the strike. The union has also said that there was no reason for Mesaba and Express to stop flying just because Northwest was grounded.
The Transportation Department said that under a Federal program that subsidizes flights to underserved areas, Mesaba and Express are prohibited from suspending service below a minimum level without giving 90 days notice.
Warren R. Wilkinson, a spokesman for Mesaba, which is effectively controlled by Northwest, said that it made no economic sense for the airline to fly without being able to connect passengers to Northwest.
Facing their own negotiations with the company, Northwest's other unions supported the pilots.
"We do stand behind them," said Kathy Jo Smith, a business agent for Local 2000 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which represents Northwest's 11,000 flight attendants. "They're sort of paving the way for us. We want them to stand hard and firm."
But with thousands of workers losing their jobs, the pressure on both sides to reach a settlement is sure to increase.

HEADLINE: Poughkeepsie Man Linked to Slayings Of Eight Women

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

 BODY:
Police investigators wearing face masks and white jump suits found the bodies of two women and the decaying remains of others yesterday in a ramshackle green house a block from Vassar College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.
They charged Kendall Francois, a 27-year-old unemployed school aide who lived in the house, with strangling one of the women to death and said they thought he was responsible for killing seven others, most of them prostitutes, who have been missing for as long as two years. 
 "We have reason to believe that ultimately eight bodies will be recovered from our search of the house based on our conversations with him," said William V. Grady, the District Attorney of Dutchess County.
The house, where Mr. Francois lived with his parents and sister, is on a quiet tree-shaded block of gracious Victorians and doctors' offices one block from Vassar. But it is also two blocks in the opposite direction from a stretch of Poughkeepsie's Main Street used by prostitutes, including some who are drug users, to solicit customers. Mr. Francois's parents and sister continued to live in the house at 99 Fulton Avenue, where the bodies and the remains of the women were found, yet law enforcement officials said the family was surprised when told of the murders. Neighbors and a mail carrier said the stench coming from the filthy house -- the paint was peeling, the shrubbery was overgrown and the electricity meter was broken -- had long been unbearable.
Late into the evening, investigators continued to search the Francois house for remains of the other women. Mr. Grady said at least one body was found in the basement, but he would not disclose other locations in the house that he said Mr. Francois had mentioned when interrogated about the missing women on Tuesday night and yesterday.
Mr. Grady said there was no indication that the women had been dismembered.
"He had something to say about all of the missing women," Mr. Grady said of the suspect. Mr. Grady would not say what led the police to Mr. Francois, although other law enforcement officials said Mr. Francois was jailed for 15 days last winter on charges of assaulting a prostitute.
The case is the latest in a sequence of serial murders of street prostitutes during the last two decades. It bore strong similarities to the case of Joel Rifkin, who confessed to killing 17 women he said were prostitutes on Long Island, and to the so-called Green River case, in which 49 women, most of them prostitutes, were slain or vanished in the Seattle area.
The string of missing women has unsettled both the city of Poughkeepsie, a Hudson River manufacturing center with 28,844 residents, and the surrounding township, also named Poughkeepsie, which has a population of 40,143.
The economic vitality of the area has been battered by the closing of a nearby IBM plant and the flight of business from the city's downtown.
Some relatives of the victims complained that until last week, when a task force focusing on the disappearances was formed, the police were not paying enough attention because the victims were prostitutes and drug users.
"If there had been this much press before, I don't think it would have gone this far," said James J. DeSalvo, the brother of Kathleen Hurley, who vanished in January of 1997.
The only body identified yesterday was that of Catina L. Newmaster, 25, who friends said used drugs. She was last seen on Aug. 25 by a boyfriend in nearby Pleasant Valley, who found out that she had traveled to Poughkeepsie.
The first woman reported missing was Wendy Meyers, 30, who was last seen on Oct. 24, 1996, at a motel in nearby Highland. Her disappearance was followed by that of Gina Barone, 29, on Dec. 9, 1996; Catherine A. Marsh, 29, who was pregnant, on Nov. 12, 1996; Ms. Hurley on Jan. 12, 1997; Michelle Eason, 27, on Oct. 9, 1997; Mary Healey Giaccone, 29, on Nov. 13, 1997; Sandra Jean French, 51, on June 11, 1998, and Ms. Newmaster.
Although some lived in the rural towns outside urban Poughkeepsie, four of the women were last seen in the meaner stretches of the city. All except Ms. Hurley had been arrested on prostitution charges.
Mr. Francois, who is 6 feet 4 inches tall and weighs more than 300 pounds, was arraigned yesterday morning before Judge Ira Pergament of the Town of Poughkeepsie court and charged with one count of second-degree murder.
He pleaded not guilty and was assigned a lawyer from the state's Capital Defender Office, which handles cases that might result in a death penalty.
Mr. Francois was born in Poughkeepsie, graduated from high school in the Arlington School District, made up of the town of Poughkeepsie and seven other towns, and served in the United States Army. He may have been on the high school's wrestling team because, when he worked as an aide, he showed students wrestling holds he claimed to have learned in high school competition, said Judy Olmstead Clark, a teaching assistant who worked with him at Arlington Middle School.
He began working at the Arlington Middle School in 1994 as an occasional custodial worker and then from April 1996 to January 1997, he worked full time as a hall monitor at Arlington, making sure that students were not unruly in the halls and the cafeteria. He earned $6 an hour, or roughly $42 for a school day.
When he left Arlington, he told the school administrators that he was going to work for the Anderson School, a school for mentally retarded and other developmentally disabled children in Staatsburg, a 20-minute ride from the city of Poughkeepsie. Officials of that school would not confirm or deny that he had worked there.
Don Rothman, Superintendent of the Arlington School district, said Mr. Francois's years of employment were uneventful.
But Mrs. Clark said many teachers complained that Mr. Francois behaved improperly with some girls, hugging them, playing with their hair, following them in the hall or making off-color jokes.
"I thought he was kind of inappropriate in his appearance, in his demeanor," she said.
There was some relief on the Vassar campus that a suspect had been arrested. Susan DeKrey, director of college relations for Vassar, said that students and faculty members have been aware of the vanishing women, but because the pattern of victims indicated they were drug-using prostitutes, "it did not grip the campus in a panic in that sense."
"But it's very shocking that this has happened in a safe college neighborhood," she said.

HEADLINE: National News Briefs;
Report Says Navy Suffers From Shortage of Sailors

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 2

 BODY:
A shortage of thousands of sailors has forced the United States to send several warships to the Persian Gulf without full crews, hurting the ships' preparedness, a newspaper report said today.
Some members of Congress and military analysts said the numbers showed that the Navy was suffering from poor recruiting and retention as a result of low civilian unemployment and a widening pay gap, The San Diego Union-Tribune reported. 
 Pacific units, which included ships and personnel based in San Diego, had 10,716 unfilled jobs because there were not enough sailors, said Adm. Archie Clemins, commander of the Pacific Fleet.
In the Persian Gulf, the aircraft carrier Lincoln had 500 fewer sailors than it had in its last deployment in 1995, the newspaper said.
Officials said most of the Navy's 18,022 unfilled positions were aboard warships, forcing it to deploy most warships at only the second-highest level of readiness.

HEADLINE: NEWS WATCH;
Finding Something Nice to Say About Microsoft's Operations

BYLINE: By Matt Richtel 

 BODY:
Richard McKenzie and William Shughart don't believe that there should be the Microsoft logo under the word "monopoly" in the dictionary.
The two economists, writing in the fall issue of Independent Review: A Journal of Political Economy, contend that Microsoft's activities have not hindered software competition. In fact, they conclude that it is the Justice Department that is "squelching competition." 
 The review is published by the Independent Institute, a nonprofit research organization in Oakland, Calif., that advocates free markets and less economic control by governments. The institute says Microsoft has a subscription to the Independent Review but does not contribute money to the organization.
Professor McKenzie, of the University of California at Irvine, and Professor Shughart, of the University of Mississippi, wrote that Microsoft could not afford to restrict output and raise prices, as a monopoly would be expected to do. If it did, they argue, competition would immediately jump in to take away the business.
"Its market pricing and product development do not square with those of a monopolist," they said. Their article can be found on the Independent Institute's Web site (www.independent.org).

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW: THE SCENE;
And Still No Government: Ruble Sags and So Do Spirits

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Russia struggled through another day without a Government; the ruble's value fell again; people had less money than ever, and spirits and fortunes sagged.
"The situation is worse than in 1917," the year that the Bolsheviks seized power in a country depleted by war and government indecision, Aleksandr I. Lebed, the regional governor with presidential ambitions, said he told President Clinton today. 
 "I told him that the situation in Russia is catastrophic," said Mr. Lebed, a former general, who joined other Russian political leaders this afternoon for a meeting with Mr. Clinton at the residence of the United States ambassador.
Bleak predictions were common in Moscow today, as newspapers and commentators discussed various possibilities -- from dictatorship to armed insurrection -- that could result from the standoff between President Boris N. Yeltsin and his opposition in the lower house of the Russian Parliament.
The lower house is set to meet on Friday afternoon for a second round of voting on the nomination of Viktor S. Chernomyrdin as Prime Minister, five days after his candidacy was rejected the first time. If no political breakthrough occurs before then, and the Parliament rejects Mr. Chernomyrdin a third time, then Mr. Yeltsin is constitutionally bound to disband it and call for new elections.
Moving into the breach today with a presidential decree, Mr. Yeltsin named six acting Cabinet members, including Boris Fyodorov, Russia's tough-talking top tax collector, and the only clear and authoritative voice advocating Western-style remedies for Russia's worsening economic and financial crisis.
At a news conference today, Mr. Fyodorov drew the line at any mass printing of rubles, an option Mr. Yeltsin's opposition pushed in its economic program. Such a course, he said, would only lead to hyperinflation.
"Nobody intends to go down the road to inflation," he said.
Such talk would be reassuring to Mr. Clinton and Russia's other Western allies, who all week have been pressing Moscow to stay the course on economic reform, and not slide back into Soviet-era practices like price controls and excessive state spending.
Blasting the Central Bank for policies that set the stage for the ruble's collapse, Mr. Fyodorov also floated the idea of a currency board, which would impose strict controls on the money supply and which has been used successfully in Argentina, Bulgaria and other countries to steady inflation and restore investor confidence.
Mr. Fyodorov said he would continue to pursue the idea at a meeting on Thursday with Domingo Cavallo, Argentina's former economy minister who presided over a currency board that halted inflation by requiring the central bank to hold one United States dollar for every Argentinian peso in circulation.
But without a Government to carry them out, Mr. Fyodorov's pledges and proposals had a ring of prematurity. "Who can tell me who is going to be Russia's prime minister in a week?" asked a Western official. "That is the question."
Mr. Yeltsin has insisted he will not back off Mr. Chernomyrdin's nomination, although he prevaricated today when the question was put to him at a news conference. Most analysts thought it unlikely that Mr. Yeltsin would be the first to blink in the standoff because any concessions would further embolden his opposition to press for more.
In a radio interview today, Boris Berezovsky, the financier who helped engineer Mr. Chernomyrdin's nomination, suggested that Mr. Yeltsin might ultimately have to resign to allow a strong political figure to emerge in his place. An alternative, he said, would be to create room for a strong political figure who would rule with Mr. Yeltsin, "quietly putting up with the fact that the president cannot, to the necessary degree, take part in the swiftly developing events."
Mr. Berezovsky, in a television interview later, said that he thought Parliament might still be outmaneuvered by the Kremlin, and that Mr. Chernomyrdin's chances of becoming prime minister were not lost.
"Chernomyrdin had a chance," Mr. Berezovsky said. "It's another question how he will use it now. He had a real chance. I still think far from everything has been lost."
Mr. Chernomyrdin picked up support from a group of regional governors, who urged the lower house to act swiftly so that a Government can start putting a program in place. He is due to meet on Thursday with the Parliament's upper house, made up of regional leaders, which has influence, but no power over the formation of governments.
The political paralysis continued to take an economic toll today, as the value of the ruble fell again in electronic interbank trading. Continuing uncertainty about the value of the currency caused major stores to halt credit card transactions, even as their shelves were being emptied of essential goods.
The central bank said today that it was preparing to transfer savings accounts from six major banks to the Government-controlled Sberbank, although in an interview on television tonight, a top bank official said depositors could leave their accounts untouched "if they have faith in their bank."
Another central bank official said in a radio interview that Russia had spent $9 billion in the last two months defending the ruble, and had had no choice now but to let its value float.
"We were hoping that if events took a normal course, the rate could be held without any intervention," said Denis Kiselyov, the deputy bank chairman. "What is happening now in economics and politics can in no way be called a normal course of events."
 

CORRECTION-DATE: September 4, 1998, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the political standoff in Moscow used a word erroneously in a description of President Boris N. Yeltsin's news conference comment on the nomination of Viktor S. Chernomyrdin as Prime Minster. The article should have said Mr. Yeltsin equivocated (not prevaricated) when asked about the possibility of a compromise.

HEADLINE: Empire State's Strength

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Elizabeth Kolbert (Metro Matters, Aug. 28) questions the progress New York State's economy has made in the four years since state policies started becoming more friendly to employers. But economic trends in the Empire State are among the strongest in the country. 
 In 1997, for the first time in more than a decade, the state gained manufacturing jobs. Private-sector growth in New York is starting to catch up to that in other states, after years of lagging far behind. In one key industry, construction, we surpassed the national growth rate for the year ending in June. New Census Bureau data show that in 1995 and 1996, manufacturing investment in the state grew 33 percent, to more than $10 billion.
 
DANIEL B. WALSH
President
Business Council of New York State
Albany, Sept. 2, 1998

HEADLINE: Don't Expect Russia To Fend for Itself

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "Let Russia Fend for Itself" (Op-Ed, Aug. 29), Richard Pipes suggests a "hands off" policy toward Russia because for too long, Russians have been relying on external aid to delay putting their house in order. Mr. Pipes's judgment and prescription are excessively harsh. The Russian economy has already experienced substantial reforms. Prices have been freed, foreign trade has been opened up, defense spending has been slashed to around 3 percent of gross domestic product and much industry has been privatized. It is hard to imagine this progress in an atmosphere of a "hands off" policy by the West. 
 The residual but considerable difficulty with reforms has been the inability of successive leaders in the government to persuade the democratically elected but unfortunately Communist-dominated lower house of parliament to go along with building up Russia's fiscal infrastructure by cutting back expenditures and enacting a simplified tax code. But, as students of foreign aid have long known, denial of aid will often imperil rather than induce the adoption of policies we consider desirable. Russia fits that mold.
 
PADMA DESAI
New York, Aug. 30, 1998
 
The writer is a professor of economics at Columbia University.

HEADLINE: Retailers' Sales Strong in August; Analysts Still Wary

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
American retailers reported relatively strong sales for August yesterday, but analysts warned that continued unease in the stock market and in the global economy could slow down retail sales for the rest of the year.
"It is obviously premature to make a call," said Jeffrey Feiner, a retail analyst at Lehman Brothers. "But certainly the volatility in the market and in the economic outlook is likely to cause some slowing in consumer spending. Some companies have been talking about gradually scaling back orders for Christmas." 
 Retailers enjoyed strong sales increases over the summer, and August was no exception. Same-store sales, or sales in stores open at least a year, rose 3.5 percent in August compared with the month a year earlier, according to the Goldman, Sachs retail composite index.
Leading the way were discount stores, which have enjoyed two years of exceptional sales. Wal-Mart Stores Inc. reported a 7.6 percent gain, while Target, a unit of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, said sales rose 4.9 percent. Sales at Dollar General rose 7.1 percent.
Off-price apparel retailers, which have also been strong performers for several quarters, saw sales slow a bit last month, perhaps because they had lofty numbers with which to compare. Ross Stores, for example, said sales rose only 2 percent, while Value City saw sales fall 1.8 percent. The TJX Company reported a sales gain of 1 percent.
Among all retailers, department stores continued to be the real laggards. Sales at Sears, Roebuck & Company fell three-tenths of 1 percent, and sales at Federated Department Stores Inc. fell 1.3 percent.
The May Department Stores Company said sales dropped seven-tenths of 1 percent in August, and Dillard Department Stores reported a 1 percent decrease. Neiman Marcus, a unit of Harcourt General Inc., said sales fell 1.7 percent. Only Saks Fifth Avenue reported a respectable sales increase -- 7.1 percent.
"Department stores have been weak all year," said Richard N. Baum, a retail analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "They are losing share to specialty apparel retailers, who are executing better this year than last year. And then you've got the discount department stores moving their offerings more upscale, like Target, which is siphoning off business as well."
Indeed, among specialty apparel merchants, Ann Taylor Stores said sales rose 15.5 percent, and Gap Inc.'s sales rose 9 percent. The Limited Inc.'s sales blossomed 7 percent, thanks in large part to improvements at its Express and Limited women's chains.
Retailers may also have given some of August's sales to September because of the late Labor Day. "There was some pretty strong evidence that business in the Northwest and Southeast, where back to school is earlier, was better for the month than in the Northeast," Mr. Baum said. "So we don't yet have the full picture of back to school. We think September will be a strong month, and we'll have to look at the two together."

HEADLINE: Small Gain Seen In Productivity

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Growth in American workers' productivity, the key to rising living standards, slowed in the last quarter, which ended in June, and posted the smallest gain in nearly two years.
The productivity of nonfarm, nonsupervisory workers, measured as output per hour of work, rose at a one-tenth of 1 percent annual rate, the Labor Department said today. 
 That was better than expected from preliminary figures, released last month, which indicated that productivity had fallen two-tenths of 1 percent.
The weakness this April through June followed a healthy 3.5 percent increase in productivity for the first three months of this year.
Fast productivity growth allows employers to raise wages and earn increased profits without raising product prices.
In a separate report today, the Labor Department said that first-time applications for unemployment benefits rose only slightly last week, by 1,000, to a seasonally adjusted 302,000. A four-week moving average of claims, which economists consider even more telling, fell to 302,250, its lowest level in a year.

HEADLINE: In Wake of Strikes, G.M. Posts August Sales Drop

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

 BODY:
Still struggling with the aftermath of two strikes, the General Motors Corporation reported yesterday that car and light-truck sales fell 36.4 percent in August. At the same time, the Ford Motor Company reported a stronger-than-expected 8.1 percent increase in sales.
G.M.'s lower sales pushed the industry down even though nearly all auto companies selling vehicles in the United States reported higher sales. Vehicle sales for the month totaled 1,229,989 cars and light trucks, a decrease of 6.6 percent compared with sales in the month a year earlier. 
 A total of 675,173 cars were sold, down 8.8 percent, and truck sales were off 3.8 percent at 554,816. The seasonally adjusted selling rate dipped to 14.6 million cars and light trucks after running at a rate of more than 16 million for the last three months.
"Considering the G.M. strike and the expiration of the loyalty coupons," incentives that ran from April to July, "these are very strong numbers," said David Healy, an auto analyst for Burnham Securities in New York.
G.M. sold 271,177 cars and light trucks during the month, a 36.4 percent decline compared with sales in August 1997. Car sales were 156,876, down 37.4 percent, and light-truck sales totaled 112,362, down 35 percent. Sales of nearly every model in G.M.'s line dropped 30 percent to 40 percent. The largest sales declines were in vehicles with the lowest inventories, such as full-size sport utility vehicles.
Nearly all of G.M.'s North American assembly operations were closed for 54 days in June and July because of strikes by the United Automobile Workers at two parts plants in Flint, Mich. G.M.'s plants are now operating on overtime to push inventory levels back to normal in October.
More than 60 percent of G.M.'s August sales came in the last 10 days of the month. The level of sales in those 10 days were close to the level of sales in the last 10 days of August 1997. For the year so far, G.M.'s vehicle sales trail 1997 sales by 5 percent.
At Ford, sales were stronger than analysts expected. Ford reported that its Ford, Mercury, Lincoln and Jaguar divisions sold 323,599 cars and light trucks in August, an 8.1 percent increase compared with figures from August 1997. Ford sold 129,527 cars, up 1.3 percent from a year earlier, and 189,809 light trucks, up 13.2 percent, a new industry record for monthly truck sales.
Nearly every major vehicle manufacturer reporting sales this week experienced higher sales in August compared with those in the month a year earlier; some set records.
Sales for the Chrysler Corporation were up 3.5 percent. Toyota reported its best August ever for its Toyota and Lexus brands, up 10.9 percent. Sales of Mercedes-Benz, a unit of Daimler-Benz, rose 75.8 percent, and BMW sales increased by 5.2 percent. Volkswagen A.G. had its best August in 17 years, with a 71.3 percent increase in sales, passing full-year sales for 1997. Its Audi brand enjoyed its best August since 1986, with sales up 37.7 percent. Volvo sales increased 8.5 percent, and Porsche A.G. sales jumped 134.7 percent.
Subaru of America had its best August since 1989, with a 9.3 percent increase in sales. Mazda had its best month since March 1995, with sales up 37.8 percent. Kia Motors America reported sales up 26.8 percent, and Nissan sales rose 2.9 percent. Isuzu sales rose 5.7 percent.
Most automotive executives and automotive analysts predict the industry will close the year on a high note despite the roller-coaster behavior of the stock market and the Asian financial crisis. Forecasts generally indicate 1998 car and light-truck sales will be about 15.5 million units, which would be the fifth consecutive year of more than 15 million units sold.

HEADLINE: Latin America Tells I.M.F. Economies Are Sound

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Fearful of being swept up in the financial turmoil that has devastated Asia and Russia, officials from nine Latin American nations said today that their economies were basically sound and should not be penalized indiscriminately by panicky investors.
Arriving for the start of a two-day meeting with the International Monetary Fund, the officials said that they were not seeking any international financial help, and that they were taking the difficult steps needed to weather a storm that is threatening to batter much of the world. 
 "Latin America is doing its homework," the Finance Minister of Mexico, Jose Angel Gurria, said. "Markets are certainly overreacting and not discriminating at all. Everyone is thrown in the same basket."
The Clinton Administration praised the progress of many Latin American countries. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, arriving for the meeting, said that what transpires in the region was profoundly important to the United States and that many Latin governments had "accomplished a great deal."
Investors paid little heed to those messages. Financial markets across Latin America fell sharply today, one day after Colombia devalued its currency. Moody's Investors Service, the credit-rating agency, downgraded its rating of Brazil's foreign-currency debt, setting off an 8.6 percent decline in the main stock-market index there.
The worries about Latin America are growing as Mr. Rubin prepared to meet on Friday in San Francisco with Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan. Mr. Rubin is expected to keep the pressure on Japan to strengthen its banking system and do more to pull its economy out of the doldrums and help the rest of Asia.
To the degree that the global financial unrest spreads through Latin America, it will only increase the risks to the American economy and to investors on Wall Street, where there is wide concern that corporate earnings will suffer as growth slows or evaporates in Brazil, Mexico, Argentina and other big markets.
Analysts said the combination of Latin America's checkered economic history and the current turmoil in global markets all but assured that the region was in for a bumpy ride at a time when investors are looking for the safest places to put their money.
"This is a region with high external debt numbers and a history of default in a world that's currently experiencing a flight to quality," Phil Suttle, an international economist at J. P. Morgan in New York, said. "In that situation it's a tough world for Latin America."
Officials from Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, Uruguay and Venezuela attended the meeting, along with Mr. Rubin and Finance Minister Paul Martin of Canada.
Some analysts said the fund's unstated agenda might have been to warn the Latin nations not to expect much help if they ran into trouble, because the I.M.F. has been warning for months that it is running short of money to finance further bailouts.
But I.M.F. officials said they would make clear to the Latin nations that money would be there to support countries that took the necessary difficult steps to whip their economies and financial systems into shape.

HEADLINE: Chief U.N. Inspector Reports More Interference by Iraq

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 3

 BODY:
The chief United Nations weapons inspector for Iraq said today that the Government of Saddam Hussein had gone beyond its decision to block surprise inspections and is now interfering with routine monitoring operations.
The inspector, Richard Butler, told the Security Council about the deteriorating situation in Iraq as the United States and Britain moved to keep comprehensive sanctions on the Iraqis until they resume cooperation. 
 The two nations introduced a resolution today condemning Iraq and putting future sanctions reviews on hold. The measure is expected to be voted on next week, probably after more negotiations with Iraq's supporters, the Russians and Chinese. Security Council members will study the draft resolution over the next few days.
Mr. Butler, chairman of the United Nations Special Commission, said today that he had been able to carry out only the increasingly circumscribed activities that Iraq permitted.
"It is less than the whole monitoring program," he told reporters. "We are doing no disarmament work."
Mr. Butler told the Council that Iraq had blocked the commission on three occasions since Aug. 5, when the Iraqis stopped allowing new on-site inspections and said they would allow only long-term surveillance and monitoring of previously designated sites.
In the second week of August, Mr. Butler said, the Iraqis refused information about and access to equipment used for test-launching their Samoud missile, saying it was outside the mandate of the commission, known as Unscom.
On Aug. 16, inspectors were told that they could not return to a previously visited site because it was a military area. The Iraqis had threatened in the past to exclude all military sites, which would in effect gut large parts of the inspection program.
On Sept. 1, Iraqis barred inspectors from a place where missile parts had been tagged and stored by Unscom for further observation. Iraq said the area was not a "declared site," a distinction that appears to have been turned into a new reason for denying access.
In all such cases, refusals of access raise suspicions that the material sought may have been removed and possibly returned to use in prohibited weapons programs. Iraq must abolish all chemical, biological, nuclear and certain missile systems as well as the means of producing them for sanctions to end. With no support for military action to enforce Baghdad's compliance, however, Iraq and the Security Council appear to be settling in for a long standoff, or another mediation effort by the Secretary General.
British and American diplomats are banking on the growth of what one envoy called "a rising tide" against the Iraqis, who have been confident for a year that sanctions will be gone by the end of 1998. The Russians and Chinese, however, have continued to argue for including encouraging overtures to Iraq, hoping that rewards for cooperation will budge Baghdad in ways that threats will not.
The British and American resolution introduced today makes a gesture in that direction, saying the Council will "respond favorably to future progress made in the disarmament process."
But some diplomats say that this does not go far enough, and that if the Council had rewarded Iraq in July by closing the nuclear inspection file and switching to long-term monitoring, Iraq might not have become so obstructive a month later.
Some Chinese, Russian and other diplomats also favor a review of relations with Iraq and possibly a restructuring of Unscom, following Iraqi accusations that Mr. Butler and his inspectors have overstepped their authority.
The criticisms of Unscom and Mr. Butler were resurrected after an American inspector, William Scott Ritter Jr., resigned from the commission, accusing the Security Council and Secretary General Kofi Annan of giving ground to the Iraqis.
Bill Richardson, the United States representative, said in an interview on Monday before accompanying President Clinton to Moscow, where Iraq was discussed among aides from both sides, that he saw no likelihood of changes in Unscom, especially at the top.
"Butler is safe because of his strong relationship with the Secretary General," Mr. Richardson said. "It's in the best interests of the Security Council and the U.N. to keep such a credible independent force like Butler doing his job. I think that despite this latest scuffle, Butler has improved his standing with other Security Council members besides Britain and the United States."
Mr. Richardson said Mr. Annan has been much more supportive of Mr. Butler behind the scenes than many believe to be the case.
The shift in American policy from threatening Iraq militarily to building a diplomatic front against Baghdad in the Security Council has been welcomed by some pivotal members.
"I think it was a blessing," said Antonio Monteiro, Portugal's representative and the chairman of the Council's Iraq sanctions committee. "Unilateral actions are very dangerous. We have enough anger in the world. Why do we want to provoke more gaps between us in the Western world and the Arabs? If we can contain Iraq in a reasonable way, and I believe we can, is that not better than using force?"
Mr. Monteiro and several other envoys said there is no nation that wants to tolerate Iraqi defiance or allow Iraq to escape sanctions unilaterally, despite all its grievances.
"First they comply," Mr. Monteiro said of the Iraqis. "Then we see what we can do to take them on board."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
The 30-Year Treasury Price Moves Higher

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bonds continued to benefit from the turbulence in stocks yesterday, managing a modest gain.
Investor demand for United States Government securities recently, especially for the shorter maturities, has been tied to the rise and fall of the nation's and overseas stock markets. With stocks down yesterday, still in reaction to the unresolved economic crisis in Russia and turbulence in the global financial markets, bonds were up. 
 The 30-year bond rose 15/32 , to 103. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction, was down to 5.30 percent, from 5.33 percent on Wednesday.
The bond market was poised for the release of the August jobless report today. Analysts forecast a gain of 370,000 new jobs last month. One estimate was even higher, calling for a gain of as many as 500,000 new jobs.
The Department of Labor released its weekly report on first-time applications for jobless benefits yesterday for the week ended last Saturday. The data rose only slightly, indicating that the labor market was still tight. Claims were up 1,000, to 302,000. The four-week average of claims -- which economists consider more reliable -- fell to 302,250, its lowest level in a year.
Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of fixed income at J. W. Charles Securities Inc. in Boca Raton, Fla., said: "The long and the short of it today is that bonds are trading inversely to the Dow.
"As for the August employment data being released on Friday, I have no apprehension about the number. I think that all of the positive factors have been factored in at these market price levels."
Keeping in mind what happened to stocks, he is being cautious about bonds: "I get a little apprehensive when I hear analysts say bonds are going to go up in price. It makes me a little nervous. That's why I think any surprise in the employment numbers tomorrow could just as easily be a negative for Treasuries. The only reason the bond market traded higher today is because of the turmoil in the equity markets."
Bonds were further bolstered in the afternoon by late buying linked to the Moody's Investors Service downgrading of Brazil's foreign currency debt rating to B-2 from B-1.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Staten Island Co-op Project Is Priced for Moderate Incomes

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Construction will start this month on 74 town house-style co-ops on Staten Island that are part of a new city program to provide housing that is affordable to people who earn as little as $30,000 a year.
The program makes the two- and three-bedroom apartments affordable by using city subsidies, a project-wide mortgage with a low interest rate and an abatement on property taxes. 
 The shares in the residences, with 1,000 to 1,700 square feet of space, will sell for $5,695 to $6,845, and the apartments will also have monthly carrying charges -- including mortgage payments, insurance and taxes -- of $885 to $1,054. The town houses will be offered to people with annual incomes that do not exceed $70,000.
Groundbreaking on the co-op project will be on Sept. 15, and the 74 town houses will be built over the next 15 months on the north shore of Staten Island in Fox Hills, near the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. Sales will begin in October.
The town houses are the latest phase of a 23-acre development along Osgood Avenue called Celebration at Rainbow Hill that eventually will have 600 residences. So far 380 units have been built and sold, all of them fee-simple town houses, meaning the buyers own the town houses and the land underneath them.
The new units, like the earlier ones, are being developed by R. Randy Lee, president of the Leewood Real Estate Group of Bulls Head, with Ralph Zurlo, Michael Boccieri and Eugene Boccieri. They are all builders on Staten Island.
Mr. Lee said the partners switched to the cooperative form of ownership to be eligible for the city's Middle-Income Housing Loan Program, which provides financing only to rentals and to what are known as limited equity co-ops, meaning there are limits on how the co-ops can be resold. Both the rental and the co-op components of the program have income eligibility requirements. The co-op component limits the profits that buyers can make when they sell their units. A portion of the profit on each unit must be used to repay the city for its subsidies.
The earlier units at Celebration at Rainbow Hill, also intended to be affordable to middle-income buyers, were subsidized with money from the New York State Affordable Housing Corporation. But much of the money from this program is now going to city-sponsored projects. Mr. Lee said the city's new loan program "became the most viable alternative."
Under the program, the New York City Housing Development Corporation issues taxable bonds to provide construction loans with interest rates that are below the market rates and permanent financing to builders, or both. The builders are also eligible for a 25-year tax abatement from the city. The corporation, using its own reserves, also offers a subsidy of up to $20,000 per unit in the form of a second mortgage at an interest rate of 1 percent to 3 percent for 30 years.
"We saw a real need for additional support for middle-income housing," said Richard T. Roberts, who is chairman of the board of the housing corporation and commissioner of the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development.
The Staten Island project shows how the financing works. Celebration at Rainbow Hill received $8 million in bond financing at an interest rate of 7.5 percent and a loan of $15,000 per unit, or $1.1 million, at an interest rate of 1 percent. Combining the two interest rates produced a 30-year project-wide mortgage at an interest rate of less than 6.5 percent, Mr. Lee said. As a result the units are affordable to people making as little as $30,000 a year, he said.
Since the program began last October, eight projects, totaling 850 units, have been approved, and six projects, with 230 units, have been proposed, Mr. Roberts said. Among the projects are a 132-unit rental complex being built on Austin Street in Rego Park, Queens, and a 90-unit rental complex to begin this month on Degraw Street in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn.
Discussions are under way for a second round of the program, Mr. Roberts said, and a decision is expected in the next two to three months.
The Staten Island project is distinctive because even though it offers the cooperative form of ownership, it is structured as a condominium, Mr. Lee said. The 74 units will be owned by a cooperative apartment corporation in which residents will buy shares, and those shares will entitle them to a proprietary lease to occupy their units. In condominiums, a purchaser buys an apartment and an interest in the common area.
But the bylaws will be like those of a condominium: Owners will be able to buy and sell their units without the approval of the board of directors they elect. (Under the program, the units must be occupied by owners who meet the income requirements.) Buyers will also join the homeowners' association and pay a $59 monthly fee to take care of common areas.
In addition, Mr. Lee said, the units will be the same sizes as the other 380 town houses and have the same brick and stucco facades and vinyl siding. Each will also have small yards in front and back that buyers will maintain, and some will have one-car garages.
On Staten Island, housing prices have risen an average of 10 percent over the last year, but are beginning to level off, said Thomas Maira, who runs Maira Real Estate in Huguenot. Depending on the location, prices range from $179,000 to $219,000 for semiattached, single-family houses, and from $279,000 to $359,000 for one- and two-family houses that stand alone, which are the most popular types of houses, he said.
There are few cooperatives, Mr. Maira noted, adding, "You never know how Staten Islanders will take to them." But in Fox Hills, the 74 co-ops "fill a need for affordable housing and extend to the public another form of ownership," he said.
Mr. Lee conceded that marketing the units will be a challenge because of their co-op form of ownership. "But it is one we can meet because of the affordability of the units and the desirability of the development," he said.

HEADLINE: U.N. Arms Inspector Who Quit Is Told He Can't Make Policy

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Senate Democrats mounted a careful counterattack today against the American who resigned in protest last month from the weapons inspection team in Iraq.
The senior inspector, William Scott Ritter Jr., repeated his charges today that the Clinton Administration had blocked efforts by United Nations inspectors to ferret out Iraq's clandestine biological, chemical, nuclear and missile programs, even as Washington publicly supported the inspections. 
 At a rare joint Senate hearing, Democrats praised Mr. Ritter's dedication and candor, and even agreed with his frustration over the Administration decision to seek a diplomatic resolution rather than confront Iraq when Baghdad stymied inspectors.
But Democrats also said using military force to compel Iraq to allow the inspections was a complicated political and diplomatic decision that was not up to Mr. Ritter.
"That responsibility to take the nation to war is above your pay grade," said Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, ranking Democrat on the Foreign Relations Committee.
Senator Charles S. Robb, Democrat of Virginia, told Mr. Ritter, "I admire your singlemindedness, even though I may disagree with you on the big picture."
Partisan politics infused the hearing of the Armed Services and Foreign Relations committees. Democrats temporarily blocked the hearing even before it started, arguing that senior Administration witnesses who could rebut Mr. Ritter were out of the country, traveling with Mr. Clinton.
To allow the hearing to proceed, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, put the Senate in recess and took the unusual step of escorting Mr. Ritter to the witness table in the packed hearing room.
"I wanted to show my support for a man of courage," Mr. Lott said in an interview later.
The hearing was held as the Republican-controlled Congress is growing increasingly critical of the Administration's handling of foreign policy crises like Iraq, North Korea and the International Monetary Fund.
"We are again at a serious crisis point with Iraq," Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, said. "No one appears to be quarterbacking a game plan in which intrusive inspections continue and produce results."
Mr. Ritter, 37, a former Marine intelligence officer, has said that from last November to August, the Administration made at least seven efforts to stymie an investigation by the United Nations Special Commission, known as Unscom, which is charged with destroying Iraq's weapons of mass destruction.
"The United States has undermined Unscom's efforts through interference and manipulation, usually coming from the highest levels of the Administration's national security team," Mr. Ritter said, citing Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, in particular.
Mr. Ritter said the United States; the United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, and the Security Council were complicit in the decision to avoid a confrontation with Iraq, to maintain the embattled international sanctions against Baghdad.
"Iraq provokes a confrontation, knowing there will be no consensus in the Security Council and knowing they'll get a concession," Mr. Ritter said.
He added that two separate inspections, one in July and another in August, were canceled, despite "hard intelligence" about the locations of ballistic-missile components and information about how Iraq was concealing other forbidden weapons.
Without an aggressive inspections program, Mr. Ritter testified, Iraq could rebuild its nuclear, chemical and biological arsenals in six months. Iraq, he added, possessed the components for three nuclear weapons and lacked only the necessary fissionable material to complete the bombs.
Administration officials insisted today that they still supported the United Nations inspections, but reserved the right to weigh the projected gains from any inspections against the political and diplomatic downside.
"We respect this guy," an Administration official said of Mr. Ritter. "But the U.S. is given a fair amount of information. And the moments are rare when an inspection goes for something like this and is successful."
Republicans and Democrats voiced agreement that Mr. Ritter had forced Congress and the Administration to review policies on Iraq and to examine whether they had the stomach to use force, even unilaterally, to back up the inspections.
"We're going to have to make some fundamental decisions about whether to follow a policy of containment or deprive Iraq of its weapons of mass destruction," said Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts.

HEADLINE: Development Claims a Harlem Sculpture

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
To some, the enormous skeletal structure along the Hudson River in Harlem was an eyesore that took up valuable space. To others, it was the perfect mix of art and utility, a sculpture that had been adopted by children who used it as a jungle gym.
Whatever it was -- scaffolding or sculpture -- it is now history. This week workers dismantled the 75-foot-high pipe-and-concrete structure that for a decade stretched from 125th Street three blocks north along the Harlem waterfront -- puzzling many people who could not determine its purpose. 
 The New York City Economic Development Corporation, which owns the property the steel skeleton sat on, had planned months ago to remove it to prepare the site for renovation by a private developer, said Steve Jacobs, a project manager. The agency, which began soliciting proposals in June for the renovation of the West Harlem waterfront site, will select a plan after Sept. 30, he said.
Yesterday morning, the concrete disks and rusty pipes of the structure were scattered beside the rotting piers along the river. To people familiar with the structure, including commuters who could see its pointed arches from the West Side Highway, its destruction was either the act of art-blind boors or long overdue.
Erected 10 years ago, it was originally draped with silver streamers, pink and fuchsia banners and twinkling lights.
"People came and sat and fished and there were jazz concerts," said Maritta Dunn, the chairwoman of Community Board 9. Commissioned by the Harlem Urban Development Corporation, now defunct, the structure, Ms. Dunn said, was intended to offer Harlem residents an instant, inexpensive substitute for a long-planned but ill-fated $400 million waterfront renovation project.
Rod Knox, the Cooper Union architecture professor who designed and oversaw the building of the structure, said the metal frame was constructed in six weeks for $225,000. He kept the cost down by using discarded sewer pipes and old railroad ties and hiring unemployed local residents to build it.
"It was a wonderful experiment in architecture," he said.
But to Ken Sutherland, 51, a retired police officer who regularly fishes from the piers, calling it art is taking things a bit too far. "That was just a rusted old thing," he said.
In recent years, the structure was primarily used by children, who climbed and swung on it.
The reason for its hasty removal was "concern for the safety of the children," said Janel Patterson, an agency spokeswoman.
Ms. Dunn said she would like the city to provide temporary play equipment to replace the structure. But she said she was pleased that it was finally being removed, heralding the renovation of the property.
She envisions a park, restaurants and clubs. "A fantastic oasis," she said. Removing the structure was the first step, she said.
"It was never art," she added. "It was scaffolding."
But for a few people, the sight of the looming, airy structure was an aesthetic thrill, an oasis in itself, and its destruction something to mourn. "It was a marvelous, magical piece," said John Hejdek, dean of Cooper Union's architecture department. "It added to the landscape and mystery of the city."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Workers this week dismantled a 75-foot-high structure that for a decade stretched from 125th Street three blocks north along the Harlem waterfront. Rod Knox, a Cooper Union architecture professor, had designed it. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Stocks Take Broad Plunge; Dow Off 100

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Stock prices headed broadly lower yesterday as investors continued to show nervousness about the effects of a possible global economic slowdown on the profits of American companies.
Shares of financial and transportation companies, which would be among those hurt worst by a decline in global business activity, fell most sharply in a volatile day of trading. Also posting declines were companies like Coca-Cola, Procter & Gamble and Gillette, which get large percentages of their revenue from overseas. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 100.15 points, or 1.3 percent, to 7,682.22. It was the sixth loss in seven days for the Dow, and other market indexes followed it lower. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 8.21 points, or slightly less than 1 percent, to 982.26, while the Nasdaq composite index declined 20.99, or 1.3 percent, to 1,571.86.
The decline in American stocks followed further losses in European markets, where the fallout from the financial instability in Russia, including further drops in the value of the ruble, dragged down share prices. Germany's most-watched stock market index fell more than 3 percent, while the Financial Times Stock Exchange 100 index in London fell 2.2 percent, closing below the level at which it started the year.
The weakness in the economies of Asia and, more recently, Russia, have led many American analysts to cut their estimates of corporate earnings here. Chuck Hill, director of research for First Call, which tracks earnings estimates, said yesterday that analysts' projections of growth in 1998 operating earnings for the companies in the S.& P. 500 index had declined to 5.3 percent in recent days, from a previous level of 5.7 percent.
In the last two months, estimates of third-quarter profit growth have plunged to 2.1 percent from 10 percent. In addition, Mr. Hill said, many analysts are still predicting that fourth-quarter profits will rise more than 10 percent. He expects those forecasts to be revised downward, causing overall profit estimates to fall as well.
Yesterday, the last half-hour of trading again proved to be the most volatile part of the day. But whereas stock prices had been falling sharply in the final minutes of trading in several previous sessions, the Dow moved higher yesterday as the blue chips cut their losses in half in the last 30 minutes of trading.
While some of those sharp swings have come from the implementation of sophisticated trading strategies, traders attributed the late-day gain yesterday to positive comments about the strength of the United States economy by the Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin. Mr. Rubin was scheduled to meet today with the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and the Japanese Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, in California.
Also today, traders will be watching the August employment data, which they hope will give some hint whether the domestic economy has begun to feel any effects from the year-old Asian malaise.
"You can see the worries in the price of cyclical stocks, the transportation stocks and shares of plain old-fashioned industrial companies," said Jonathan Olesky, head of block trading at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company. "People are concerned about a possible downturn in the U.S. that would have been Asian-induced. I think people are going to be very concerned if they see a jump in unemployment." Analysts generally expect the unemployment rate to remain steady at 4.5 percent.
As such, investors are likely to see continued volatility in the stock market, "as long as everybody is focused on daily economic numbers," said Robert Freedman, chief investment officer for the John Hancock Funds.
Shares of bank and financial-service companies continued to take a pounding yesterday as investors reacted to disclosures of losses by many of the big banks. Citicorp fell 10 1/4, to 98 1/2; Chase Manhattan slumped 5 5/8, to 49 1/4; American Express lost 6 1/2, to 77 1/4, and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter fell 5 3/8, to 53 5/8.
Also losing ground yesterday were the economically sensitive transportation stocks, which include airline and trucking companies. Ryder Systems fell 215/16 , to 20, while Roadway Express dropped 17/16 , to 12 3/4. Shares of airline companies fell across the board, with Delta Air Lines dropping 2 3/8, to 957/16 , and UAL, the parent of United Airlines, slipping 3 1/8, to 58 3/4.
One difference between this year's stock market turmoil and past periods of volatility, like those in 1987 or 1990, stock traders say, is that they now have a far harder time gauging the mood of the market from day to day and minute to minute.
Michael Molnar, a managing director in the retail sales and trading operations of Salomon Smith Barney, said that as his firm's trading operations had become more computerized, the volume of background noise in the trading room had become far less reliable as an indicator of market swings.
Where a decade ago traders spent much of their day shouting orders across the floor, today they spend more time punching buttons on computer terminals. "If you want to measure the psychology of the market, you have to watch an individual stock," Mr. Molnar said.
Mr. Molnar, who in 1987 worked at Lehman Brothers, says that in times like this, sentiment can be as crucial as some fundamental measures of value. Referring to the famed proponents of the objective method of investing based on a company's underlying value, he said: "If the market is going to snap back 100 points, that's not Graham and Dodd. That's sentiment."
