HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: A Tiger in a Sea of Pussy Cats;
Trinidad and Tobago Bids Goodbye to Oil, Hello to Gas

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad and Tobago

 BODY:
The flights coming in from the United States are so jam-packed with oil and chemical company executives hungry for a piece of the action here that reservations are hard to come by. Almost weekly, it seems, the Government has some natural gas find or new factory project at the booming Point Lisas Industrial Estate to announce.
While much of the rest of the English-speaking Caribbean worries about making ends meet, this twin-island nation, almost evenly divided between citizens of African and Indian descent, is experiencing a burst of investment and growth. Thanks to the belated realization that its substantial natural gas reserves may prove to be even more valuable than its oil, Trinidad is rapidly emerging as the region's foremost economic success story. 
 Since the beginning of the boom less than five years ago, the 50 American companies now operating here have invested more than $4 billion, a remarkable figure in a country with only 1.3 million people. Seeking to take advantage of cheap and abundant energy supplies, petroleum, chemical and steel companies from Britain, Canada, Germany, India, Norway and Spain are also flocking here.
In the process, "this country is becoming industrialized" and turning into a Caribbean tiger, said Krishna Persad, a leading Trinidadian oil and gas industry consultant. "If only 50 percent of what is being talked about actually comes to pass, you're going to be seeing a Singapore in the Western Hemisphere," he predicted.
But as Government officials here acknowledge, they must also resist the temptation to spend too much too soon and risk overheating the economy. Administering a bonanza, while more pleasant than coping with scarcity, offers hazards of its own. For confirmation of that, Trinidad need only look at its own recent past, or neighboring Venezuela, where billions of dollars in oil profits are said to have been squandered or pilfered.
At the moment, though, "This country is booming, going gangbusters, and the boom is nowhere near peaking," a diplomat here exulted. "With all the recent finds and the plants coming on line, you're going to see a substantial level of activity for the next several years."
In 1997, Trinidad's economy grew by 4 percent, compared with a 1.5 percent contraction in 1993; over the same period, inflation has dropped to 3.8 percent from 13 percent. Income per capita, adjusted for inflation, has risen to $4,290 from $3,920.
Fueling the boom are Trinidad's proven natural gas reserves of more than 21 trillion cubic feet, up from 8.9 trillion just five years ago. David Wight, president of the Amoco Energy Company of Trinidad and Tobago, the local subsidiary of the American oil and gas giant, said that figure was likely to double yet again, while Mr. Persad predicted reserves could eventually reach 75 trillion cubic feet.
"Whatever the numbers turn out to be, they are big, comparable to anywhere in the world," Mr. Wight said. "Trinidad has already become a very big and active player, both in terms of natural gas resources and the downstream side, offering development opportunities here in-country and also significant export opportunities."
The natural gas discoveries have coincided with a downturn in oil production as Trinidad's proven crude reserves dwindle. Output has dropped from a peak of 225,000 barrels a day in the late 1970's, when oil accounted for 80 percent of the country's export income, to 130,000 barrels; at current rates of production, existing reserves will be exhausted in little more than a decade.
But with oil prices in decline and now "at their lowest level in a dozen years," explained Finbar Gangar, Minister of Energy and Energy Industries, "we have consciously diversified our economy away from oil." The basic strategy of the Government of Prime Minister Basdeo Panday, which took power late in 1995, has been "to widen and deepen our industrialization thrust," Mr. Gangar said.
As a result, this Delaware-sized nation at the southeastern tip of the Caribbean, just seven miles off the coast of Venezuela, is already the second-largest exporter of ammonia and methanol in the world. By the end of next year, when the last of five plants built here during the last five years comes on stream, it is expected to become the largest exporter of both those key industrial products.
"If you stand back and look at the broad picture, you can identify four major industrial thrusts," Mr. Persad said. "Gas is being used as raw material for petrochemicals, as fuel for steel plants, as fuel for aluminum projects, and is being liquefied and exported."
In addition to the methanol and ammonia complexes, plants that will produce urea, ethylene, fertilizers and other industrial chemicals are completed or under construction, many of them at the Point Lisas Industrial Estate on the coast south of here. The Indian steel company Ispat already has one plant here and has committed to another, Government officials said. Negotiations are under way with Brazilian interests to refine iron ore mined in the Amazon and with other foreign investors interested in building an aluminum smelter here.
"Brazil, Guyana, Jamaica and Suriname have no shortage of supply of the raw materials required" for such plants, Mr. Gangar said. "It's a welcome bit of synergy when countries in the immediate geographic region have vast supplies of raw materials and Trinidad and Tobago can supply the energy."
The country's showcase project is the $1 billion Atlantic L.N.G. Company of Trinidad and Tobago complex in southern Trinidad, which officials here say is the largest single industrial investment ever made in the Caribbean. Amoco has taken a one-third interest in the project, joined as partners by British Gas, a unit of Centrica; Repsol of Spain; Cabot L.N.G. Ltd., and the state-run National Gas Company of Trinidad and Tobago Ltd., and is already talking of expansion early in the next century.
Production of three million tons a year of liquefied natural gas is scheduled to begin in the second quarter of next year, with the bulk of production initially scheduled to go to Spain. But some output is also intended for New England, where, as Amoco's Mr. Wight noted, "the wintertime demand for energy far exceeds the pipeline capacity." Trinidad would be the closest supplier of L.N.G.
Since Trinidad and Tobago achieved independence from Britain in 1962, Amoco has traditionally been the dominant player here. But the Panday Government, in what one diplomat described as an effort to increase its leverage, has adopted "a conscious policy of avoiding overdependence on any one company." That has led the Government to award several recent offshore drilling contracts to Amoco's main rivals.
Amoco's share of total production here has dropped to 60 percent from 80 percent, according to Government estimates, and is likely to continue to fall. But Mr. Wight said his company was more than satisfied with its situation, in part because "we've had a high degree of exploratory success."
That track record, he explained, has "elicited a huge amount of competition. Everyone is here now," including ARCO; Conoco, a unit of Du Pont; Exxon; Royal Dutch/Shell, and Texaco.
The uncertainties of international politics have also lent a hand. For European energy companies like Repsol of Spain, countries like Algeria and Nigeria may be closer, but domestic turmoil and widespread corruption in those energy-rich countries have made Trinidad a more attractive place to invest.
"Ours is not the cheapest gas on the market," acknowledged Frank Look Kin, president of the National Gas Company of Trinidad and Tobago. "But we believe we have the advantage of a legal system based on British law and a high degree of honesty and transparency."
Mr. Wight agreed. "We're still working from contracts and concessions that date from independence," he said, which have not been tinkered with or renegotiated despite several changes of government. "That is rare and really important to a businessman."
There are also huge reserves of natural gas, seven times larger than Trinidad's, in nearby Venezuela. But the leading candidate in the presidential election there later this year, Hugo Chavez, has threatened to review contracts with foreign oil companies, leading to suggestions by many executives that Trinidad would be the best place to process not just local gas reserves, but also those of Venezuela, which are concentrated in the east.
"We need to develop a fair amount of Trinidad's reserves first, but we believe there is an opportunity there," Mr. Look Kin said when asked about the issue, adding that he and other Government officials have talked with their counterparts in Caracas about the matter. "There is recognition on both sides that because of pure geography, Trinidad would seem to be the appropriate place to process some Venezuelan gas."
The high regard in which Trinidad is held by foreign investors contrasts sharply with the image it had two decades ago, when the local oil boom was at its peak and profligate spending was the order of the day. This time around, chastened Government officials say they are determined to maintain fiscal discipline and funnel the country's riches into much-needed infrastructure projects.
"We know it's rare to get a second chance, and we are trying very hard not to make the same mistakes as in the past," Vishnu Ramlogan, president of the Government's economic promotion agency, the Tourism and Industrial Development Company of Trinidad and Tobago, said. "We're not going to let inflation and conspicuous consumption run away and overheat the economy. This time there is a consensus our new-found wealth must be prudently managed."

HEADLINE: In Something Like a Debate, Kohl Defends While a Relaxed Schroder Taunts Him

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Sept. 3

 BODY:
In the closest thing to a televised presidential debate before elections this month, Chancellor Helmut Kohl gave a rambling defense today of his role as a statesman and the architect of German reunification.
Looking avuncular and almost unaware that he is in danger of losing his bid for re-election in just a few weeks, Mr. Kohl, 68, squared off in Parliament against the man who now leads him in popularity polls: Gerhard Schroder, 54, the Social Democratic Party's candidate. 
 Mr. Schroder, appearing confident and relaxed in his speech, accused Mr. Kohl of having fallen completely out of touch with the needs of the country and the demands of the job.
"The job of a chancellor is to bring the country together," Mr. Schroder taunted. "There was a time you understood that. But in the meantime you seem to have totally forgotten it."
The face-off had been built up in German media as a climactic rhetorical duel, the only direct confrontation between Mr. Kohl and Mr. Schroder before the elections on Sept. 27. It was not a debate, but rather a pair of speeches.
Under the rules today, the two candidates merely delivered rival statements to Parliament on the ostensible issue of debating the latest government budget. There was little opportunity for spontaneous repartee, clever riposts or other displays of quick thinking.
Mr. Kohl, who has been Chancellor for 16 years, is in the toughest fight of his career. With nationwide unemployment at 10.7 percent -- and nearly twice that high in the formerly Communist eastern half of the country -- Mr. Kohl is lagging behind Mr. Schroder in most polls by three to six percentage points.
Mr. Kohl has adamantly refused Mr. Schroder's demands to take part in any sort of American-style debate on prime-time television, probably because the Chancellor cannot begin to compete with his challenger in performing before the cameras.
Mr. Kohl often exudes a homey warmth and an endearing lack of pretentiousness, but he is also an obese man who wanders into long reminiscences and speaks indistinctly.
Mr. Schroder, by contrast, has mastered the art of being at ease before cameras and projecting a wide range of emotions from humor to righteous passion.
In his speech today, Mr. Kohl talked for nearly an hour about his historical accomplishments as a statesman. He dwelt proudly on his role in uniting East and West Germany, blasting Mr. Schroder and the Social Democrats for fretting about the costs. He talked at length about his role in creating a single European currency, though that is a change that most Germans are skeptical about.
Mr. Schroder, wearing a charcoal-colored suit and striped silk tie, hammered away at the idea that Mr. Kohl has been in power too long and allowed Germany to sink into record levels of unemployment while raising taxes ever higher.
Mr. Schroder also taunted the Chancellor about not entering a true debate. "I read all the time I can't be pinned down," he said, alluding to criticisms that he has not given enough detail about his positions on issues. "Well, come on then, pin me down."
Today's performances reinforced the sense that the election campaign is less about deep policy differences than it is about images and personalities. Mr. Kohl is campaigning on the image of stability and security, as well as his status as Europe's most influential leader. His campaign slogan is "World Class for Germany."
Mr. Schroder is campaigning on the promise of dynamism and personal abilities. A pragmatist who has tried to blur his party's Socialist traditions, he is running on an ambiguous idea of forging a "new middle" that defends Germany's generous social programs while promoting a vaguely pro-business agenda.
Both candidates today pledged their allegiance to roughly similar concepts for broad tax reform as well as to a continuation of Germany's social-market economy. Both endorsed continued heavy financial support for eastern Germany, mired in depression and unemployment.
Mr. Kohl accused Mr. Schroder and the Social Democrats of being ambivalent supporters of reunifying with East Germany, a charge that Mr. Schroder denied. Mr. Kohl also accused the Social Democrats of blocking tax reform for the last several years, only to support their own plan now.
"It's like one of Pavlov's experiments with dogs," Mr. Kohl said. "You just look at me, and you're already against it."
Mr. Schroder focused on the argument that Mr. Kohl has fallen completely out of touch. "At the beginning of our campaign, we Social Democrats said 'Thank you Helmut, but enough is enough,' " he said. But now, he continued, "your people don't even say thank you."

HEADLINE: State Trying to Coax 2 Exchanges From New York

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Sept. 3

 BODY:
State officials are involved in talks intended to woo the nation's second- and third-largest stock exchanges out of New York City and into a new home in New Jersey, an economic development official said today.
The official, Lisa Kruse, who is the vice president for marketing and development for the New Jersey Commerce and Economic Growth Commission, confirmed unattributed reports in The Star-Ledger of Newark today that the state was talking to the computerized Nasdaq Exchange and the American Stock Exchange about a possible move to New Jersey. She would not disclose the locations involved, but the published reports said that Jersey City and Hoboken had been mentioned as possibilities. 
 Spokesmen for both exchanges, which are working out the final details of the merger that their members approved three months ago, would not comment on whether they were involved in any talks.
The 27-year-old Nasdaq has 3,100 employees in New York City, Washington and its suburbs and Trumbull, Conn.
The 77-year-old American Stock Exchange, which has 600 employees and 1,500 traders, is spread over three lower Manhattan locations.
Walter M. Smith Jr., executive vice president of Hartz Mountain Industries, a developer of office space along the Hudson River and elsewhere in the state, said he had no knowledge of such talks, but he added that he was not surprised at the reports. All the exchanges have expressed a need for new and larger sites, and now New Jersey seems to have an edge over New York when it comes to the cost and availability of office space, he said.
"Ten years ago the savings of New Jersey over New York were substantial, and it appears that we may be approaching that kind of era again," Mr. Smith said. "Every businessman, it seems to me, has to periodically address the cost of doing business."
The news of the talks comes on the heels of reports in May that New Jersey was trying to interest the New York Stock Exchange in moving. Over the years, New Jersey has been a perennial option, but it has lost out more than it has won; in many cases it appears that companies used the threat of moving to New Jersey to wring more incentives out of New York officials.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Big Board Votes to Abandon Mandatory Job-Bias Arbitration

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
The board of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday to no longer require industry arbitration of job-discrimination claims, deciding that it will hear such claims only when they are submitted and after a dispute has arisen, according to executives at the exchange.
The decision, which affects the whole brokerage industry as it covers stockbrokers and other members of the exchange, will be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in the next few days, and after a period for public comment, it is expected to lead to a change in the exchange's rules, said James E. Buck, senior vice president and corporate secretary of the exchange. 
 The brokerage industry's practice of mandatorily referring employment disputes to industry arbitration -- as many brokerage employees agree to do when they sign their work contracts -- has gradually been eroded. Critics of mandatory arbitration have maintained that it gives unfair advantage to brokerage firms, and denies employees their civil rights by preventing them from getting access to courts. The proponents of mandatory arbitration say it is quicker, cheaper and more efficient than resorting to the courts.
The change by the Big Board follows Federal court decisions in Massachusetts and California, which held that brokerage firm employees could take discrimination claims to court and did not have to submit to industry arbitration. It also follows a recent decision by the National Association of Securities Dealers, which oversees the Nasdaq market. That body recently ruled that the matter of mandatory arbitration in these cases was one for individual securities firms to decide for themselves.
George Nicolau, a past president of the National Academy of Arbitrators and now a spokesmen on such issues, called the decision "a progressive step toward fairness."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Latin America Tells I.M.F. That Economies Are Sound
Officials from nine Latin American nations, who are in Washington for a two-day meeting with the International Monetary Fund, said their economies were basically sound and should not be penalized by investors because of the financial turmoil in Asia and Russia. 
 Latin America markets did not heed the comments, however. They fell sharply one day after Colombia devalued its currency. Moody's Investors Service also downgraded its rating of Brazil's foreign currency debt yesterday, sending Brazil's main stock market index down 8.6 percent. Page A9.
 
Russia's Crisis Is Deepening
As the crisis in Russia seems to be worsening and the ruble continues to decline, many of that country's food markets and hard-goods stores are running out of supplies. A4.
 
Russian Woes Cut Lehman Profits
Lehman Brothers became the latest brokerage firm to say that the financial turmoil in Russia and other developing countries would reduce its net income. Lehman had expected net income for the quarter to be about $211, but now estimates that it will be $151 million. C4.
 
Plea for an End to Northwest Strike
The Governor of Minnesota, Arne Carlson, called on President Clinton to order the pilots of Northwest Airlines back to work, but the White House reiterated its belief that the two sides should return to the bargaining table. The move by the Minnesota Governor, which follows the same request from other governors, came on the sixth day of the strike and a day after Northwest laid off more than half its 51,000 workers. A13.
 
Retail Sales Increase 3.5%
American retailers reported sales in stores open at least a year rose 3.5 percent in August, but analysts warned that continued unease about the economy could slow retail sales for the rest of the year. C4.

Microsoft Ordered to Provide Files
A Federal judge ordered Microsoft to give the Justice Department reams of new evidence that Government lawyers say will bolster their antitrust case. Microsoft's lawyers had argued that the evidence should not be a part of the case because it was not specifically mentioned in the original lawsuits. C4.

Shell and Texaco in European Match
Royal Dutch/Shell and Texaco plan to combine their refining and marketing businesses in Europe, a step that could further speed a trend toward cutting costs and capacity as the oil industry struggles with declining profit. C2.
 
Crude oil prices surged, after Nigerian and Russian shipments were delayed. Crude oil for October delivery rose $1, to $14.67 a barrel. C8.
 
Japan May Nationalize Some Banks
Japan's Government is wrestling with what to do with one of its deeply troubled large banks, Long-Term Credit Bank, which has $180 billion in assets. One of the possibilities frequently mentioned is nationalization. C2.
 
2 Former Stratton Heads Indicted
Two former principals of Stratton Oakmont, the defunct brokerage firm, have been indicted in an international securities fraud and money-laundering scheme that Federal prosecutors say was intended to manipulate the stocks of two small companies. C8.

Delay in Banking Overhaul Bill
The Senate Banking Committee postponed consideration of a bill that would overhaul the nation's banking laws. C4.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN ULSTER;
Excerpts From Clinton's Remarks: 'We Are Through With Hate'

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's address yesterday to the people of Armagh, Northern Ireland, as transcribed by Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription company:
I am especially proud to be here with my wife at this important time. Yesterday, she spoke to the Vital Voices conference, hundreds of women from Northern Ireland, working across all the lines that divide you for a better future. 
 Tonight, we are proud to be in a place that is a spiritual home to Irish people of both religious traditions and to millions of Irish-Americans as well.
Armagh is a city on a hill in every sense. Your faith and tolerance are making a new era of peace possible.
For yourselves and all the world, in every act of genuine reconciliation, you renew confidence that decency can triumph over hatred. You have inspired the rest of us to aim a little higher. I thank you and America thanks you for the precious gift you give us all -- a gift of hope redeemed and faith restored. . . .
Here, a Briton, St. Patrick, devoted himself to the cause of Ireland and left a legacy of faith and compassion. Here the Book of Armagh preserved his gentle message and the power of the Gospels.
Today the two cathedrals that dominate the landscape stand for the idea that communion is better than destructive competition. Two proud traditions can exist side by side, bringing people closer to God and closer to each other.
I salute the leadership of Dr. Sean Brady and Dr. Robert Eames, the Archbishops of the Catholic and the Church of Ireland diocese, respectively. For years they have walked together when it counted.
I salute the Presbyterians and the Methodists who have worked hard for peace, indeed the men and women of all denominations.
Here there have been difficulties, as elsewhere, but the historic streets of this old town remind us of a fundamental fact about your community: Armagh literally encircles its many traditions in a single community.
That is what Northern Ireland must do if you want the future of peace and prosperity that belongs to the children in this crowd tonight.
As you look ahead, to be sure, in this peace process, there will be false steps and disappointments. The question is not if the peace will be challenged. You know it will. The question is how will you respond when it is challenged. . . .
The Prime Minister and Mrs. Blair and Hillary and I just came from Omagh. We met with the families whose innocent were slaughtered. We met with those who were terribly wounded. We saw children scarred, some of them for life, because of the madness -- that if someone could just set off a big enough bomb; and kill enough Protestants and Catholics; kill enough men, women and children, including two pregnant women; kill enough people from Northern Ireland, Ireland and foreign countries -- that maybe everybody would walk away from peace. But it backfired.
Out of the unimaginably horrible agony of Omagh, the people said it is high time somebody told these people that we are through with hate, through with war, through with destruction. It will not work anymore. . . .
We wanted to come here in person to thank you -- to thank you for the peace, to thank you for strengthening the hand of everyone, everyone anywhere who is working to make the world a little better.
When I go now to other troubled places, I point to you as proof that peace is not an idle daydream, for your peace is real and it resonates around the world.
It echoes in the ears of people hungry for the end of strife in their own country.
Now when I meet Palestinians and Israelis, I can say: Don't tell me impossible; look at Northern Ireland.
When I meet Albanians and Serbs in Kosovo, I can say: Don't tell me it's impossible; look at Northern Ireland.
When I hear what the Indians and Pakistanis say about each other over their religious differences, I say: Don't tell me you can't work this out; look at Northern Ireland.
Centuries were put to bed and a new day has dawned.
Thank you for that gift to the world.
And never underestimate the impact you can have on the world. The great English poet and clergyman John Donne wrote those famous lines: "No man is an island. We are all a piece of the continent, a part of the main."
Tonight, we might even say in this interconnected world not even an island, not even a very unique island -- not even Ireland -- is fully an island.
On this island, Northern Ireland, obviously, is connected in ways to the republic as well as to England, Scotland and Wales. And in ways, the Republic of Ireland is connected to them also.
All of you on this island increasingly are connected to Europe and to the rest of the world as ideas and information and people fly across the globe at record speeds.
We are tied ever closer together. And we have obligations now that we not -- that we cannot shirk: to stand for the cause of human dignity everywhere.
To continue John Donne's beautiful metaphor -- when the bells of Armagh toll, they ring out not just to the Irish or Protestant and Catholic traditions. They ring out to people everywhere in the world who long for peace and freedom and dignity. That is your gift.
We Americans will do what we can to support the peace, to support economic projects, to support education projects. . . .
Three years ago, I pledged that if you chose peace, America would walk with you. You made the choice, and America will honor its pledge.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: THE CHALLENGER: A special report.;
A German Socialist Veers Toward the Center

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: BONN

 BODY:
Gerhard Schroder has changed with the times.
He first made his name in German politics in the 1970's as leader of the Jusos, the radical, stridently anti-American, anti-nuclear youth group of the Social Democratic Party. In 1981, in his maiden speech in Parliament, he became the first man ever to speak there without wearing a necktie. Late one beer-fueled night, according to an often-told story, he stopped by to rattle the gates of the Chancellery, and to shout, "I want in there!" 
 But the higher he rose and the older he got, the less rambunctious he became. He grew to admire the United States, he says. As premier of Germany's second largest and third most populous state for the last eight years, he as been the consummate pragmatist, cooperating with or disregarding the left-wing party hierarchy according to his purposes. He not only started wearing neckties, he took to smoking fine Havana cigars and sporting clothes designed by Armani.
He got so chummy with business executives that trade unionists and other ideological stalwarts in his party started mocking him as "der Genosse von Bossen" -- the comrade of the bosses.
Now the Social Democrats, who have failed three times to oust Chancellor Helmut Kohl, have turned to Gerhard Schroder to do the job in a national election on Sept. 27. Handsome, telegenic, a ferocious worker, Mr. Schroder, 54, is almost a generation younger than Mr. Kohl, who is 68. Not by accident, he is running a media-savvy campaign as ambiguous and devoid of specifics as those that brought Tony Blair and Bill Clinton to power in Britain and the United States.
Mr. Schroder must grapple with the problem that has confronted left-wing politicians throughout Europe as well as the Democrats in the United States: big government has become too costly.
Partly because of the huge expenditures in eastern Germany after reunification, partly because of the competition with countries that have learned to live with less, Germany can no longer afford the restrictive labor laws, ample pensions and generous health care system with which Mr. Schroder's party has been identified. "There is no more West German island," said a Western diplomat here. "Germany has to live by the same rules as the rest of us, which means cutting back. That's the real dilemma for Schroder and his party."
A victory would make Mr. Schroder one of Europe's most powerful men, standing at the helm of the continent's dominant economic and political power. It would also constitute an unprecedented accomplishment in modern German history; no sitting Chancellor has been defeated by a candidate of another party since the federal republic was established in 1949.
The polls put him ahead, but only by a slender margin, with a sizable undecided vote. Germany is accustomed to a more carnivorous, less image-oriented politics, with plenty of ideological meat to chew on, and people are starting to grumble.
"You can't quite get hold of him," said Josef Joffe, editorial page editor of the Suddeutsche Zeitung of Munich, one of the country's major newspapers. "He was given the nod very grudgingly by the party bosses, who stand well to his left, because they were convinced he was the only one with a chance to win. So he tries to placate the left wing of his party and to win over the swing voters at the same time."
"He obfuscates, prevaricates and says as little as possible."
Michael Naumann, the German-born New York publisher whom Mr. Schroder has recruited as a potential culture minister, takes a different view. He sees Mr. Schroder as a man who has the capacity to answer a national craving, "to fill this big psychological hole at the center of German life, the need to define what we live for in the midst of our amazing material well-being."
Above all, he has a fresh face. Mr. Kohl has been Chancellor for 16 years, as long as Franklin D. Roosevelt would have served as President had he not died in office. Mr. Schroder has apparently concluded that the electorate is tired of Mr. Kohl but resistant to a major deviation from his policies. So he talks, in pure Clintonese, of "a New Middle."

Recognizing Limits To Welfare State
In mid-August, on the day before he announced his party's election program, Mr. Schroder sat down for an interview at the party's striking steel-and-glass headquarters, Willy Brandt Haus, in the heart of the new Berlin.
"The welfare state has reached its limits," he said, sitting at a table covered with the detritus typical of campaigns everywhere -- half-eaten sandwiches and empty coffee cups. "We won't be able to increase payments."
You could almost hear the echo of Bill Clinton's voice proclaiming the era of big government over.
But like generations of liberal politicians eager to sound a note of fiscal responsibility, Mr. Schroder insisted that by closing "a labyrinth of tax loopholes," he could roll back the small welfare cuts made by Mr. Kohl and still cut income taxes. "It's not that much of a riddle," he said.
An engaging man with a large head, a boldly cut jaw and the beefy body of a former linebacker, Mr. Schroder spoke quietly but gestured vigorously with his squarish hands, waving a pair of half-moon spectacles as he talked. His eyes are his most notable feature -- ice blue under fair, bushy brows and unwelcoming until he laughs, which he does often, in private as well as on the stump.
"I've had to give up the old Hegelian idea that when theory and reality clash, reality is wrong," he said, apropos of his move to the middle. "Reality is often right."
Asked whether he feared that Mr. Kohl would try to discredit him by talking about the radicalism of his youth, Mr. Schroder responded, "I don't think so. As you see, the revolution I planned didn't take place, so there's no point in bringing up what I said then."
He added, in a paraphrase of what he said at Georgetown University earlier this year: "Learning is the essence of politics. You should never trust politicians who think they have nothing left to learn any more."
But Mr. Schroder predicted that his opponents might try to discredit him by talking about his private life, although Germans, he said, were less interested in scandal and gossip "than you Americans or even the British."
Mr. Schroder has been married four times. The first marriage lasted 3 years, the second 9 and the third 12, breaking up bitterly two years ago. When he eloped with Doris Kopf, a journalist from Bavaria, the spurned third wife, Hiltrud Hamel, called him "a coward, an opportunist and an egotist."
Although the Christian Democratic leaders have refrained so far from personal criticism, the party's youth group has produced a brochure that tackles the marriage issue. "Schroder is a bad choice," it says. "Three women couldn't be wrong."
In another indirect assault, the owner of a big German car-rental company called Sixt is running a magazine advertisement that shows two pictures of Mr. Schroder, one looking left and the other looking right. "Sixt," the caption declares, "has cars for people who don't know where they want to go."
One of the biggest questions about Mr. Schroder's destination is who would help him get there. It appears highly unlikely that the Social Democrats will gain a clear majority, even if they win, so he would need a coalition partner. There are two possibilities -- an alliance with the Greens or teaming up with the Christian Democrats in the kind of grand coalition Germany had under Kurt Georg Kiesinger from 1966 to 1969.
When his visitor suggested that a coalition with the often erratic Greens would make more sense in the party context, because they are more ideologically compatible, but a grand coalition would make more sense in a governmental context because of greater stability Mr. Schroder agreed. Then he added, with a malicious little grin: "There's an old saying in this country: If you want to be successful, think first of your country, then of your party."
Whose old saying? he was asked.
"Mine," he answered.
But the decision will not be his alone. Parties matter more in German politics than in the United States, and Mr. Schroder does not yet control his party. Oskar Lafontaine, the party leader, is giving stout backing to Mr. Schroder for now, though he looked noticeably jumpy recently as Mr. Schroder announced the party program. Many people wonder what he will do once the ballots have been counted, and the Christian Democrats are trying to play on that, suggesting that it would be the party bosses rather than Mr. Schroder who would call the ideological tune in choosing a partner and framing Government policy.
 
Trying to Emulate Clinton and Blair
Mr. Schroder tries to equate himself to Mr. Clinton and Mr. Blair. But the parallel is inexact. Each of them took office having already won the main ideological arguments within his own party, and Mr. Schroder, if he wins, would become Chancellor with important questions still unresolved.
For example, Mr. Lafontaine, a harsh critic of "billionaire capitalists," wants to cut the top income tax rate from 53 percent to 49, while Mr. Schroder wants to bring it down to 45. Mr. Schroder sometimes emphasizes a "modern" Germany that shines in new technology, as when he named Jost Stillman, a businessman, as an economic adviser; other times he attacks the pension reform and labor flexibility that modernizers consider mandatory.
Nor is it clear, despite tens of thousands of words and endless columns of analysis in the newspapers, exactly what Mr. Schroder would do to attack unemployment, one of Germany's most serious and intractable problems.
The party platform says a Schroder Government would expect labor unions to permit "the more flexible organization of work." Business, it continues, needs to invest more, innovate more and provide more apprenticeships. The Government itself, it says, needs to shrink the bureaucracy and increase public spending on research.
It promises a "crash program" to fight joblessness among the young by bringing 100,000 unemployed young people into training programs.
But the nuts and bolts of the program are still missing. Persuading labor and business to work together, devising practical programs and finding the money to pay for them would be the job of Walter Riester, the highly regarded 54-year-old deputy chairman of the powerful metalworkers' union, who has been designated as the labor-minister-to-be in a Schroder Government.
One thing seems plain: with Mr. Schroder as Chancellor, Germany will remain a firm ally of the United States. Diplomats from both countries seem sure of this, as do officials Mr. Schroder met during his recent trip to Washington.
Sometimes he stretches a point to dramatize his conversion from anti-American views. He tells people that "my daughter was born in New York," when in fact she is his stepdaughter by his fourth marriage, and until 1997, he had not visited the United States in more than 15 years.
But there is no doubt that Mr. Schroder admires Mr. Clinton's political style, especially his success in repositioning himself and his party. Mr. Schroder has embraced issues like crime that the Christian Democrats long dominated. He has even hired Hank Sheinkopf, a Clinton adviser in 1996, to help with instant rebuttal and research on the opposition.
In the conversation at the party headquarters, Mr. Schroder said that despite an all-party agreement that Germany will not commit military forces abroad except on a United Nations mandate, he could not conceive of Germany holding back from intervening in the embattled Serbian province of Kosovo if the United Nations was silent and other European nations wanted to act. That would please the United States, which has long felt that the Europeans have been too slow to police their own turf.
In a long career, Mr. Schroder, who is known as Gerd, has managed to find a way forward when others might well have felt stymied.
He had no more promising a start in life than Bill Clinton. His father, a conscript, was killed during the retreat from Russia when Mr. Schroder was only three days old, and his mother raised him alone while working as a cleaning woman. He dropped out of school at 14, went to night school and ended up studying law at Gottingen University during the turbulence of 1968.
These days, Mr. Schroder handles hecklers, commonplace in German politics, with great aplomb. Asked how he learned, he replied, "By heckling."
 
Climbing the Rungs Of the Political Ladder
After a stint as an member of Parliament in Bonn, he won his party's nomination for premier in the state of Lower Saxony in 1984. He lost that time, but won four years later. Last March, he gained a third term in a landslide, a victory that clinched his nomination for Chancellor.
Except for the good suits and expensive cigars, Mr. Schroder lives unpretentiously in a smallish apartment in Hanover, the state capital. He has no vast entourage, disdaining all but the most basic security protection.
Lower Saxony, covering most of the northwestern corner of the country, is perhaps best known outside Germany for the fact that Hanover's ruling family acceded to the British throne in the person of George I in 1714. The state includes Hamlen, where the Pied Piper played, and Wolfsburg, headquarters of Volkswagen.
A seat on the Volkswagen board goes with the premier's job because the state government is the company's largest shareholder. And that, by all accounts, has had a major impact on Mr. Schroder's life. In a number of ways, he modeled himself on the company's wily chairman, Ferdinand Piech.
For centuries, Hanover has held annual trade fairs, and Mr. Schroder became a regular at them, courting businessmen, inviting them to dinner at a favorite Italian restaurant or to a game of tennis.
But he always kept his fences mended with younger, more proletarian groups as well. Dr. Ludolf von Wertenberg, the head of the Federation of German Industries, who was a Christian Democratic member of Parliament when Mr. Schroder was in Bonn, recalled that Mr. Schroder always asked beforehand who would be in the audience when he was invited to make a speech.
 
Keeping a Close Eye On the Audience
 "Students? He'd show up in a turtleneck," Dr. von Wertenberg said in an interview in his Cologne office. "Entrepreneurs? The whitest shirt you ever saw. He's amazingly good on his feet, never uses texts or notes if he can avoid it, and if he sensed that what he was saying wasn't going over well, he'd change gears within seconds. Nice guy, provacateur, it didn't matter, as long as he wasn't ignored."
He bulled his way to the nomination for Chancellor, taking his case over the heads of the party leaders to the rank-and-file.
"Schroder's will for power is certainly impressive," the former party chairman, Hans-Jochen Vogel, wrote in his memoirs. "But the question increasingly is, What does he want to do with that power?"
But the leaders gave him his shot at the Chancellorship anyway, and he opened his campaign two weeks ago with three rallies in a single day, in Berlin, Munich and Bonn. Relaxed, at times almost professorial in his interviews and news conferences, he let it rip on the stump. His voice hoarse from shouting, his face almost as red as his power necktie, Mr. Schroder greeted the crowds with both arms aloft in a V-for-Victory sign like Richard M. Nixon's.
At Rheinaue Park in Bonn, along the riverfront, there were bratwurst stands and beer vendors, hot-air balloons and rock musicians. Some in the audience wore football jerseys marked "Schroder 10" -- a reference to the candidate's habit of giving people a flyer listing nine reasons to vote for the Social Democrats and telling them, "The 10th is Helmut Kohl."
There was also a lot of talk, from Mr. Schroder and other party figures about building an economy that was both humane and efficient, some complaints about the lot of the lowest-paid people in German society and the inevitable vague allusion to a new alliance linking labor, management and government.
But there was not a single mention of socialism.
Occasionally, Mr. Schroder got into some tried-and-true Social Democratic grooves, lambasting the Government, for example, for allowing disabled workers to collect only 80 per cent of their wages when sick. This, he said, "is not social justice; they can't go to the store and pay 80 per cent of the price of a loaf of bread or get their landlord to give them a 20 percent discount."
That went over well enough with the crowd of 8,000 to 10,000, although they had been soaked by rains. But what they had on their minds most of all, it seemed, was what Mr. Schroder is concentrating on: winning.
Their loudest cheers came when he told them: "We want to win -- we will win -- because we want to do -- we will do -- something for the German people."

Clinton Urges Ulster To Press Quest for Peace
President Clinton, visiting Northern Ireland, urged all parties to press on with their quest for peace, and he pledged continued American support for their efforts. A8
 
Kohl Defends His Record
Chancellor Helmut Kohl gave a rambling defense of his role as a statesman and as the architect of German reunification in a televised face-off in Parliament against Gerhard Schroder, who leads him in popularity polls keyed to the elections later this month. A10 

Chernomyrdin Rallies Forces
Acting Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin rallied new forces to try to stop the Communist-led lower house of Parliament from rejecting his nomination a second time. A4
 
Iraqis Increase Interference
Richard Butler, the chief United Nations weapons inspector for Iraq, said the Government of Saddam Hussein had gone beyond the blocking of surprise inspections and was interfering with routine monitoring. A6
 
 
Senate Democrats launched a careful counterattack against William Scott Ritter Jr., the former American weapons inspector in Iraq who resigned in protest last month and criticized Administration policy. A6
 
Suspect May Get New Lawyer
The lawyer for Mohammed Saddiq Odeh, one of the two defendants charged in the bombings at the United States Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, may be replaced. A6
 
North Korea May Test Again
North Korea may be preparing to test another missile, American and Japanese officials said. North Korean diplomats met in New York to discuss their missile and nuclear programs with American officials. A3
 
Fewer Executions in China
The number of criminals executed in China appears to have dropped sizably in the last year, since the passage of a law that restricts use of the death sentence, human rights monitors say. But they emphasize that China still executes far more people than any other nation. A3
 
Latin America's Economy
Officials of nine Latin American nations said they were not seeking international financial help and were taking difficult steps needed to weather an economic storm threatening much of the world. A9
 
2d Death in Cape Town Bomb
A man wounded in the bombing of a Planet Hollywood restaurant in Cape Town, South Africa, died in the hospital, raising the death toll in last month's attack to two. The latest victim, Brian Duddy, a 55-year-old bank manager, was at a goodbye party for a colleague and was critically injured when the bomb exploded on Aug. 25, the police said. Another bank employee died the night of the bombing. Twenty-six people were injured. The police have made no arrests, but have ruled out international involvement. (Associated Press)
 
NATIONAL A12-20
 
F.E.C. Audit Prompts Reno To Review '96 Campaign
Attorney General Janet Reno has seized on a Federal Election Commission audit to reopen the Justice Department's review of whether an independent prosecutor should examine the issue of spending by the 1996 Clinton-Gore campaign. A summary of the findings of F.E.C. field auditors strongly questions the legality of a multimillion advertising campaign underwritten by the Democratic National Committee in 1996 that indirectly helped the Clinton-Gore campaign, Government officials said. If Ms. Reno decides to proceed with an outside inquiry after a 90-day preliminary review, President Clinton could be a pivotal subject because he was deeply involved in the ad campaign. A1
 
Democrat Assails Clinton
Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, denounced the President's conduct in the Lewinsky matter as "disgraceful" and "immoral" and said in a Senate speech that the issue had deep moral consequences. A1
 
Senate Passes Spending Bill
A Senate Republican agreed to drop an effort to oust Lawrence M. Noble, the general counsel of the Federal Election Commission, and the Senate passed, by a vote of 91 to 5, of a spending bill for the Treasury Department and Post Office, to which the Noble matter was attached. A20
 
Southeastern Storm
A hurricane lashed Florida's Panhandle with winds of 80 miles an hour, crossing the coast in the darkness early yesterday. But the hurricane, named Earl, spared the state major damage before moving into Georgia and the Carolinas as a weaker storm. Three people have been killed. The storm was moving through the Southeast with sustained winds of 45 m.p.h. and was expected to stay inland today. A12
 
Strike Intervention Sought
Gov. Arne Carlson of Minnesota abandoned his neutral stance in the pilots' strike against Northwest Airlines and called on President Clinton to order the pilots back to work, but the White House stood firm against the idea. A13
 
Contact Made With Spacecraft
The disabled Soho solar observatory, which went silent more than a month ago, is responding to commands and slowly recovering from a series of ground control errors that almost caused the loss of the valuable scientific observatory. A16
 
Deportations for D.W.I.
Federal agents have arrested 490 legal immigrants in Texas in an effort to deport immigrants with three or more convictions for drunken driving. Under a 1996 Federal law, agents can arrest and deport immigrants who have been convicted of serious violent crimes like murder, kidnapping, armed robbery and sexual assault. This year, the Board of Immigration Appeals added drunken driving to the list. Most of those arrested are in jail and will face a deportation hearing. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Senator Lieberman's Talk on President's Personal Conduct

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a speech about the Clinton-Lewinsky episode that was delivered on the Senate floor today by Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, as recorded by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription service:
To begin with, I must respectfully disagree with the President's contention that his relationship with Monica Lewinsky and the way in which he misled us about it is nobody's business but his family's and that even Presidents have private lives, as he said. 
 Whether he or we think it fair or not, the reality is in 1998 that a President's private life is public. Contemporary news media standards will have it no other way. And surely this President was given fair notice of that by the amount of time the news media has dedicated to investigating his personal life during the 1992 campaign and in the years since.
But there is more to this than modern media intrusiveness. The President is not just the elected leader of our country. He is, as Presidential scholar Clinton Rossiter observed, and I quote, "the one-man distillation of the American people" and, as President Taft said at another time, the personal embodiment and representative of their dignity and majesty.
So when his personal conduct is embarrassing, it is sadly so not just for him and his family, it is embarrassing for all of us as Americans.
The President is a role model and, because of his prominence and the moral authority that emanates from his office, sets standards of behavior for the people he serves. . . .
So no matter how much the President or others may wish to compartmentalize the different spheres of his life, the inescapable truth is that the President's private conduct can and often does have profound public consequences.
In this case, the President apparently had extramarital relations with an employee half his age and did so in the workplace, in the vicinity of the Oval Office. Such behavior is not just inappropriate, it is immoral. And it is harmful, for it sends a message of what is acceptable behavior to the larger American family -- particularly to our children -- which is as influential as the negative messages communicated by the entertainment culture.
If you doubt that, just ask America's parents about the intimate and frequently unseemly sexual questions their young children have been asking them and discussing since the President's relationship with Ms. Lewinsky became public seven months ago. I have had many of those conversations with parents, particularly in Connecticut, and from them I conclude that parents across our country feel much as I do that something very sad and sordid has happened in American life when I cannot watch the news on television with my 10-year-old daughter anymore.
This, unfortunately, is all-too-familiar territory for America's families in today's anything-goes culture, where sexual promiscuity is too often treated as just another life-style choice with little risk of adverse consequences.
It is this mind-set that has helped to threaten the stability and integrity of the family, which continues to be the most important unit of civilized society, the place where we raise our children and teach them to be responsible citizens, to develop and nurture their personal and moral faculties.
President Clinton, in fact, has shown during the course of his Presidency that he understands this and the broad concern in the public about the threat to the family. He has used the bully pulpit of his Presidency to eloquently and effectively call for the renewal of our common values, particularly the principle of personal responsibility and our common commitment to family. And he has spoken out admirably against sexual promiscuity among teen-agers in clear terms of right and wrong, emphasizing the consequences involved.
Now, all of that makes the President's misconduct so confusing and so damaging. The President's relationship with Ms. Lewinsky not only contradicted the values he has publicly embraced over the last six years, it has, I fear, compromised his moral authority at a time when Americans of every political persuasion agree that the decline of the family is one of the most pressing problems we are facing.
Nevertheless, I believe the President could have lessened the harm his relationship with Ms. Lewinsky has caused if he had acknowledged his mistake and spoken with candor about it to the American people shortly after it became public in January.
But, as we now know, he chose not to do this. This deception is particularly troubling because it was not just a reflexive and in many ways understandable human act of concealment to protect himself and his family from what he called the embarrassment of his own conduct when he was confronted with it in the deposition in the Jones case. But rather, it was the intentional and premeditated decision to do so.
In choosing this path, I fear that the President has undercut the efforts of millions of American parents who are naturally trying to instill in our children the value of honesty. As most any mother and father knows, kids have a singular ability to detect double standards. So we can safely assume that it will be that much more difficult to convince our sons and daughters of the importance of telling the truth when the most powerful man in the nation evades it. Many parents I have spoken with in Connecticut confirm this unfortunate consequence.
The President's intentional and consistent statements, more deeply, may also undercut the trust that the American people have in his word. Under the Constitution, as Presidential scholar Neustadt has noted, the President's ultimate source of authority, particularly his moral authority, is the power to persuade, to mobilize public opinion, to build consensus behind a common agenda. And at this, the President has been extraordinarily effective.
But that power hinges on the President's support among the American people and their faith and confidence in his motivations and agenda, yes, but also in his word.
As Teddy Roosevelt once explained, "My power vanishes into thin air the instant that my fellow citizens, who are straight and honest, cease to believe that I represent them and fight for what is straight and honest."
"That is all the strength that I have," Roosevelt said.
Sadly, with his deception, President Clinton may have weakened the great power and strength that he possesses, of which President Roosevelt spoke.
I know this is a concern that many of my colleagues share, which is to say that the President has hurt his credibility and therefore perhaps his chances of moving his policy agenda forward.
But I believe that the harm the President's actions have caused extends beyond the political arena. I am afraid that the misconduct the President has admitted may be reinforcing one of the worst messages being delivered by our popular culture, which is that values are fungible. And I am concerned that his misconduct may help to blur some of the most important bright lines of right and wrong in our society.
Mr. President, I said at the outset that this was a very difficult statement to write and deliver. That is true, very true. And it is true in large part because it is so personal and yet needs to be public, but also because of my fear that it will appear unnecessarily judgmental. I truly regret this.
I know from the Bible that only God can judge people. The most that we can do is to comment without condemning individuals. And in this case I have tried to comment on the consequences of the President's conduct on our country.
I know that the President is far from alone in the wrongdoing he has admitted. We as humans are all imperfect. We are all sinners. Many have betrayed a loved one, and most have told lies. Members of Congress have certainly been guilty of such behavior, as have some previous Presidents.
We try to understand. We must try to understand the complexity and difficulty of personal relationships, which should give us pause before passing judgment on them. We all fall short of the standards our best values set for us. Certainly I do.
But the President, by virtue of the office he sought and was elected to, has traditionally been held to a higher standard. This is as it should be, because the American President, as I quoted earlier, is not just the one-man distillation of the American people but today the most powerful person in the world. And as such, the consequences of his misbehavior, even private misbehavior, are much greater than that of an average citizen, a C.E.O. or even a senator. . . .
Just as the American people are demanding of their leaders, though, they are also fundamentally fair and forgiving, which is why I was so hopeful the President could begin to repair the damage done with his address to the nation on the 17th. But like so many others, I came away feeling that for reasons that are thoroughly human, he missed a great opportunity that night. He failed to clearly articulate to the American people that he recognized how significant and consequential his wrongdoing was and how badly he felt about it.
He failed to show, I think, that he understood his behavior had diminished the office he holds and the country he serves and that it is inconsistent with the mainstream American values that he has advanced as President. And I regret that he failed to acknowledge that while Mr. Starr and Ms. Lewinsky, Mrs. Tripp and the news media have each in their own way contributed to the crisis we now face, his Presidency would not be imperiled if it had not been for the behavior he himself described as wrong and inappropriate. Because the conduct the President admitted to that night was serious, and his assumption of responsibility inadequate.
The last three weeks have been dominated by a cacophony of media and political voices calling for impeachment or resignation or censure, while a lesser chorus implores us to move on and get this matter behind us.
Appealing as that latter option may be to many people who are understandably weary of this crisis, the transgressions the President has admitted to are too consequential for us to walk away and leave the impression for our children today and for our posterity tomorrow that what he acknowledges he did within the White House is acceptable behavior for our nation's leader. On the contrary, as I have said, it is wrong and unacceptable, and should be followed by some measure of public rebuke and accountability.
We in Congress, elected representatives of all the American people, are surely capable institutionally of expressing such disapproval through a resolution of reprimand or censure of the President for his misconduct. But it is premature to do so, as my colleagues of both parties seem to agree, until we have received the report of the independent counsel and the White House's response to it.
In the same way, it seems to me that talk of impeachment and resignation at this time is unjust and unwise.
It is unjust because we do not know enough, in fact -- and will not until the independent counsel reports and the White House responds -- to conclude whether we have crossed the high threshold our Constitution rightly sets for overturning the results of a popular election in our democracy and bringing on the national trauma of removing an incumbent President from office. For now, in fact, all we know for certain is what the President acknowledged on Aug. 17. As far as I can see, the rest is rumor, speculation or hearsay -- much less then is required by members of the House and Senate in the dispatch of the solemn responsibilities that the Constitution gives us in such circumstances.
And I believe that talk of impeachment and resignation now is unwise because it ignores the reality that while the independent counsel proceeds with his investigation, the President is still our nation's leader, our Commander in Chief. Economic uncertainty and other problems here at home, as well as the fiscal and political crises in Russia and Asia and the growing threats posed by Iraq, North Korea and worldwide terrorism, all demand the President's focused leadership. For that reason, while the legal process moves forward, I believe it is important that we provide the President with the time and space and support he needs to carry out his most important duties and protect our national interest and security.
That time and space may also give the President additional opportunities to accept personal responsibility, to rebuild public trust in his leadership, to really commit himself to the values of opportunity, responsibility and community that brought him to office, and to act to heal the wounds in our national character.
In the meantime, as the debate on this matter proceeds and as the investigation goes forward, we would be advised, I would respectfully suggest, to heed the wisdom of Abraham Lincoln's second annual address to Congress, in 1862. With the nation at war with itself, President Lincoln warned, and I quote: "If there ever could be a time for mere catch arguments, that time is surely not now. In times like the present, men should utter nothing for which they would not willingly be responsible through time and eternity."
I believe that we are at such a time again today. There's so much at stake, we too must resist the impulse toward catch arguments and reflex reactions. Let us proceed in accordance with our nation's traditional moral compass, yes, but in a manner that is fair and at a pace that is deliberate and responsible.
Let us as a nation honestly confront the damage that the President's actions over the last seven months have caused, but not to the exclusion of the good that his leadership has done over the past six years, nor at the expense of our common interest as Americans.
And let us be guided by the conscience of the Constitution, which calls on us to place the common good above any partisan or personal interest, as we now in our time work together to resolve this serious challenge to our democracy.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Considers Nationalizing Some Banks

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Japan is considering a trial step toward nationalizing troubled big banks.
The idea, one that might seem more at home in the old Communist bloc than in the world's second-largest capitalist economy, would be an odd and embarrassing step for Japan's Government to adopt. Yet taking over one or more giant banks could avoid the risk of a large-scale bankruptcy that would rattle the nation's financial system. And while there are doubters, some analysts say that nationalization may be the best way out of a difficult situation. 
 The test is likely to be played out with the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, which has been teetering as political parties here squabble over how to save it. Now there are signs that the parties may put their swords aside and work toward a solution, perhaps involving nationalization.
Thus, as Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa heads on Friday for talks with officials in the United States, he is leaving the financial system in less turmoil than it was a week ago. Though the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 stocks fell 115.38 points, or eight-tenths of a percent today, to 14,261.24, bank stocks in general rose more than 15 percent. Early Friday, the Nikkei was down a further 163.04 points, to 14,098.20 at midday. The yen eased to 134.26 to the dollar.
If Japan can restore financial stability, experts say, it can move toward repairing the broad economy -- something American officials have been prodding the Japanese, less and less politely, to do for years.
Confidence has been shaken by the near-collapse of the Long-Term Credit Bank, whose $180 billion in assets makes it one of the country's largest. The Government wants to inject taxpayers' money, so that the bank can be more readily absorbed in a rescue merger. But the opposition parties demand rigid criteria in exchange for the use of public funds.
The issue of what to do with the nation's biggest and weakest banks has become crucial, and it has helped drag down stock prices in recent weeks. But the idea of the Government's stepping in to nationalize banks has become increasingly accepted, and expected, by investors.
"Many small banks and many major banks can no longer fund themselves in the market because people are too scared," said Alicia Ogawa, a banking analyst with Salomon Smith Barney here. "The Government has to take over that function. But the public will not stand for the Government lending a ton of money unless the Government manages it. Otherwise, they run the risk of current management taking the money and flushing it down the toilet again."
The Government has already taken stakes in the largest banks, but the holdings are relatively tiny ones. Now, after dancing around the concept of nationalization, the ruling Liberal Democratic Party and the opposition parties are expected to address the issue. "Nationalization is one of the major pillars of our proposed bill," said Eisei Ito, who heads the policy research board of the Democratic Party, the largest opposition group. "We do not think that many banks will be nationalized, but we are organizing the bill to accommodate the situation, just in case several banks collapse."
Today, the opposition parties submitted their proposed bills for reviving the financial system to Parliament and will defend them in debate Friday. They have criticized the Government proposals, arguing that they cater to small and regional financial institutions but lack provisions for dealing with the largest and weakest banks.
Japanese officials listen to Americans for advice on tackling bad-debt problems, and they fashioned their plan from methods used in the United States to resolve the savings and loan crisis of the late 1980's and early 90's. But now, some Japanese say that perhaps the proper model is not the Resolution Trust Corporation and the small bridge banks, which Washington used to help close insolvent savings and loans, but a method used to deal with the collapse of Continental Illinois Bank in 1984.
Although no specific deals between the opposing sides have yet been struck, politicians are widely backing a proposal allowing the Long-Term Credit Bank to be the model for nationalizing a big bank. The bank would write off about $5.5 billion in unrecoverable loans, depleting its capital by more than 80 percent. The Government would then step in and buy newly issued shares to bring the capital back to its former level and then restructure the bank, selling what assets it could and trying to collect on the rest.
In the process, the Government would bring in new managers, who would either liquidate the bank or revive it and sell it to another bank.

HEADLINE: Minnesota Governor Asks Clinton to Halt Northwest Pilots' Strike

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Abandoning his neutral stance in the pilots' strike against Northwest Airlines, Gov. Arne Carlson of Minnesota called on President Clinton yesterday to order the pilots back to work, but the White House stood firm against the idea.
Northwest took a tougher stand, too, sending a provocative signal to its unions by naming the head of its strike preparation efforts, Mickey P. Foret, as its new chief financial officer. Mr. Foret was president of Continental Airlines under Frank Lorenzo, whose battles with unions at Eastern Airlines and Continental, drove both into bankruptcy. 
 Mr. Foret replaces James A. Lawrence, who Northwest said would pursue other interests.
The moves came on the sixth day of the pilots' strike and a day after Northwest laid off more than half its 51,000 workers, many of whom live in Minnesota, saying it could not afford to keep paying them if it was not operating.
Several other Midwest governors have already called on the White House to intervene. But Mr. Carlson, a Republican in the state where Northwest has its headquarters and where there is wide sympathy for the pilots, had been reluctant to urge such action, a course that the pilots oppose and Northwest quietly favors.
"It was everyone's hope that the strike could be resolved without the President taking this action," the Governor said. "But now as we enter the sixth full day of this strike with no end in sight, I believe it is time for the President to act."
The White House said that the President appreciated the views of Mr. Carlson and other officials but that Mr. Clinton felt that the best way for the strike to be resolved was for the sides to return to the bargaining table.
Talks broke down last Friday night, hours before the strike deadline set by the pilots and have not resumed. The pilots want a 14 percent wage increase over three years to make up for pay cuts they took to help save the airline from bankruptcy in 1993. They also say they want increased job security. Northwest has offered 9 percent over four years, saying it cannot afford more.
The two sides have agreed to meet on Saturday in Chicago with a Federal mediator to determine whether full-fledged contract negotiations would be productive.
Northwest also said yesterday that it was suspending its advertising campaign critical of the pilots during the Labor Day weekend because of the meeting on Saturday. The two sides have been warring with each other in print and television advertising in Detroit, Minneapolis and other cities. The pilots previously said they had stopped their advertising.
On Wednesday, Rodney E. Slater, the Secretary of Transportation, ordered Mesaba Airlines and Express Airlines I, two Northwest-affiliated commuter carriers that have stopped flying as a result of the strike, to come up with a plan to resume service to 17 cities in 11 states by the end of today. Under a Federal program, Washington subsidizes flights to the cities because airlines say it would impossible to make money serving them.
But both of the carriers said yesterday that complying with the Secretary's order would threaten their viability and therefore their long-term service to the 17 cities.
It is not clear what step the Transportation Department will take next.
Under the Railway Labor Act, the President has the power to force the pilots back to work for 60 days while a special emergency board tries to come up with a solution acceptable to both sides if he believes that the strike is disrupting the economy.
