HEADLINE: Police Are Criticized as Poughkeepsie House Yields Corpses

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER and JANE GROSS 

DATELINE: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 3

 BODY:
A day after an unemployed school aide was arrested in the murder of one woman and was first suspected in the deaths of seven others, new questions arose today over how aggressively the police pursued complaints from at least two prostitutes who contended that they were assaulted by the suspect in the case.
The bodies of four of the women that the school aide, Kendall Francois, 27, is suspected of murdering over two years have been removed from his parents' house here near the campus of Vassar College. But officials said they knew that there still were more bodies to be removed. 
 Georgiana Johnson, hovering at the crime scene, said that her daughter, Debbie Annan, had twice told the police that she barely escaped alive from an encounter with Mr. Francois, who had picked her up on the corner of Academy and Montgomery Streets, took her to his home for paid sex and tried to strangle her.
Mrs. Johnson said that her daughter, then an addict and prostitute who occasionally helped police in undercover drug operations, had given detectives Mr. Francois's name and address as early as November.
"They totally ignored her," said Mrs. Johnson, one of many friends and relatives of the women thought to be victims in the case who stood outside 99 Fulton Avenue. Mrs. Johnson added that her daughter now lives in Ocala, Fla., clean of her crack cocaine addiction and working double shifts as a cashier at a convenience store.
A similar story was told by a second woman, a one-time prostitute who now lives in Dutchess County, outside Poughkeepsie, and was interviewed on tape by Irene Cornell of WCBS radio. The woman said that she told the police that Mr. Francois had tried to strangle her in November 1996, a month after the first disappearance in the case. She remembered that during the assault Mr. Francois suddenly stopped himself from choking her and said: "Oh my God, I almost did it again."
She, too, managed to escape and flagged down a squad car from the Town of Poughkeepsie.
Frank Lanza, afternoon producer for the radio station, declined to identify the woman, but said she told them that after the incident she was interviewed twice more by police, once shortly after the disappearance of the seventh woman missing in the case.
Lieut. William Siegrist, a spokesman for the task force investigating the case made up of detectives from both the City and Town of Poughkeepsie as well as the state police, would not comment on the specific complaints. But he defended the police's handling of the investigation.
"All the complaints that came to us were handled in a proper manner and we have done everything we can to solve this crime," he said.
He also denied that the police were lackadaisical because seven of the eight women missing and presumed dead were prostitutes. "I've tried to maintain that these women were human beings and should be treated with as much respect as any other person," he said.
Outside the ramshackle house where Mr. Francois lived, investigators in white jumpsuits and goggles continued their search for remains and Mrs. Johnson talked about her daughter's inability to get the attention of the police, saying, "They didn't even take a report."
But another parent of a possible victim offered a drastically different account of how the police had pursued the case.
Patricia Barone, whose daughter Gina disappeared on Dec. 9, 1996, said investigators followed every lead and interviewed every person she had suggested.
"They absolutely did their job," Mrs. Barone said. "They picked up on it the day I reported her missing, and took it from there."
Mrs. Barone, accompanied by two nieces, spoke with uncanny calm, even though her daughter, a drug addict since the age of 12, was expected to be among the decomposing bodies inside.
"In my head, I'd come to terms with it," Mrs. Barone said. "I had a feeling she was gone all this time. I always felt when the good Lord thought I was ready to hear it, I'd hear it."
The Dutchess County District Attorney, William V. Grady, declined to give details of the long investigation into the missing prostitutes, all of whom are now presumed dead and inside Mr. Francois's house. But the District Attorney said that many women had come forward with accounts of "rough sex" with Mr. Francois. All of their stories were taken seriously, the District Attorney said, regardless of their background or demeanor.
"But just because incidents took place doesn't mean arrests can happen," he said. "You need probable cause, sufficient evidence."
The police today wheeled out a fourth body on a stretcher from the green clapboard house in which Mr. Francois lived with his parents, McKinley and Paulette Francois, and a teen-age sister, Kirstyn. They also brought in a supply of rakes and shovels, presumably to dig up more remains or evidence.
Mr. Grady said investigators had "spotted" many other bodies that they had not yet reached because of the laborious process of gathering evidence in such squalid conditions.
Mr. Grady speculated that Mr. Francois's parents, who also lived there, had not smelled the corpses because this "is not your average home -- it stinks, it is garbage-ridden."
The District Attorney added that the "bodies were hidden" though he would neither confirm nor deny reports that some were in suitcases.
So far the only body publicly identified is that of Catina L. Newmaster, 25, who disappeared on Aug. 26. Two other bodies taken out of the house have been tentatively identified as well, but their next of kin have not been notified, according to Mr. Grady. Mr. Grady spoke before the fourth body had been taken out of the house.
Besides Ms. Newmaster, the vanished women are: Wendy Meyers, 30; Gina Barone, 29; Kathleen Hurley, 47; Catherine Marsh, 31; Michelle Eason, 27; Mary Healey Giaccone, 29, and Sandra Jean French, 51. Seven of the eight had been arrested for prostitution and most were said to have worked Poughkeepsie's Main Street to support their crack habits.
So far, Mr. Francois has been charged only in the strangling of Ms. Newmaster, but a county grand jury has begun looking into the case and could issue a broader indictment.
Neighbors of the Francois family told the police that they were not aware of the killings, though some longtime neighbors and a postman said they had noticed a stench emanating from the filthy house, whose overgrown shrubbery and neglected appearance make it stand out on a tree-lined block of tidy middle class houses.
Law enforcement authorities still refused to explain publicly why they finally seized Mr. Francois for questioning on Tuesday. But Manjit Singh, a worker at a Sunoco gas station near Mr. Francois's house said that on Tuesday morning a distraught woman with blond hair and clad in sweat pants ran into the station saying she had been attacked. A customer alerted police officers nearby who were handing out fliers with photographs of Ms. Newmaster. A law enforcement official who spoke on condition of anonymity said the gas station incident provided a major break in the case.
The case has cast light on the two worlds that flanked Mr. Francois's house. One block away is the relatively rarefied world of the prestigious college and two blocks in the other direction is Main Street, a strip of fast food restaurants like McDonald's, Wendy's, Taco Bell and Dunkin' Donuts, where prostitutes eager for drugs sold fleeting sex for as little as $5 to men who drove by in cars.
Prostitutes along the Main Street Mall, a dilapidated commercial strip of pawnshops and wig stores, said today that they knew some of the victims and recognized photos of others. One woman, Connie DuVall, said the police were out in force questioning women in the neighborhood last winter, then disappeared and only returned recently.
Ms. Newmaster, for example, was well known at the Dunkin' Donuts, said its manager, John Winkler.
"Everybody knew what she was," said Mr. Winkler. "She tried here, so we ran her off."
Mr. Francois, a burly man 6 feet 4 inches tall who often stopped by the Dunkin' Donuts for a chocolate cruller, would search out women in his white station wagon, said Melissa Goebel, an 18-year-old mother of two who said she was a friend of several of the prostitutes.
People who knew him casually described him as mild-mannered and pleasant, although workers and students at the Arlington Middle School where Mr. Francois patrolled halls and the cafeteria said he often acted improperly with girls, embracing them, stroking their hair or punishing them with lunchtime detention so he could spend time with them.
"He gave out lots of detentions for everything," said Giovanna Vellone, 17.

HEADLINE: North Koreans May Be Preparing Another Missile Test

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3

 BODY:
North Korea may be preparing to test another missile, American and Japanese officials said today, even as North Korean diplomats met in New York to discuss their missile and nuclear programs with American officials.
The United States has detected a flurry of activity at the same military base along North Korea's northeastern coast used to launch a two-stage ballistic missile on Monday, an American Government official said. 
 But, the official added, it appeared that North Korea was making preparations to test one or more of its older missiles, not the advanced missile tested for the first time three days ago by firing it in an arc over Japan.
The preparations suggest that North Korea's reclusive Government, led by Kim Jong Il, was brushing aside international protests over Monday's test, which has inflamed tensions in the region.
Japan and South Korea, responding to North Korea's preparations at the site about 20 miles north of Kimchaek, placed their militaries on higher states of alert today. Their Foreign Ministers, Masahiko Komura and Hong Soon Young, met in Tokyo to discuss how to respond to North Korea's tests.
Japan has withdrawn an offer to begin talks on establishing diplomatic relations with North Korea and suspended a $1 billion payment to the Korean Energy Development Organization, the international agency building reactors in the North in exchange for North Korea's pledge in 1994 to halt construction of nuclear weapons.
In New York, North Korea's Deputy Minister for Foreign Affairs, Kim Gye Gwan, met into the night with an American delegation led by Charles Kartman, the State Department's special envoy for Korea. The talks broke off, and Administration officials said it was possible they would resume on Friday. Officials declined to give details of what they had discussed in today's talks.
While the Clinton Administration has officially voiced concern over North Korea's test, the response has been unusually understated. Some officials have played down the significance of the test, and of the later activity detected at the launch site.
"While there is activity around the launch site, it is not at all certain there is going to be any kind of test," an official said.
But a senior Japanese official said his Government had been specifically warned by the United States that a second missile launch was likely in the next few days.
Even as the launch site buzzed with activity, the European Union today called on North Korea to refrain from further tests. A statement issued by Austria, in its capacity as the union's current president, said the tests inflamed tensions. The statement also deplored the fact that North Korea would devote resources to missile development while its people faced severe hunger.
On Wednesday, the Pentagon announced that it would send six powerful bombers -- three B-52's and three B-2's -- to Guam on a previously unscheduled training exercise, but officials were adamant that the decision to send them to the Pacific over this coming weekend had nothing to do with North Korea.
Monday's test of a two-stage, medium-range missile, called the Taepodong-1, represented a significant advance in North Korea's missile program, according to arms experts. The missile can carry conventional or nuclear weapons and has a range of 900 to 1,200 miles, putting all of Japan within striking distance.
The first stage of the missile soared into the sky and then dropped into the Sea of Japan. The second stage continued over Japan's main island before plunging into the Pacific, 360 miles northeast of the American military base in Misawa.
Until now, North Korea had only tested a single-stage missile, called the Nodong, which has a shorter range and is considered unreliable. North Korea tested the Nodong only once, in 1993. It also has two variants of the Scud missile, originally developed by the Soviet Union.
North Korea could be planning to follow up Monday's test with new tests of those missiles, the American official said. After testing the Nodong in 1993, North Korea fired three Scuds into the Sea of Japan.
In another indication that North Korea might be preparing more tests, the officials said today, North Korea had issued a maritime alert to ships passing through the Sea of Japan, indicating that there could be military activity in the area until Sept. 20.
The United States has 37,000 troops in South Korea and 44,000 in Japan. The Taepodong would bring all of them within striking distance of North Korea.

HEADLINE: New Hollywood Studio Wrangles Over Project

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3

 BODY:
It was the high-tech vision that was supposed to make the dream in Dreamworks come true, the first newly built Hollywood studio in nearly 60 years, nestled in a 1,000-acre tract amid the coastal wetlands where Howard Hughes built his giant seaplane, the Spruce Goose.
But now Dreamworks SKG, the studio partnership of Steven Spielberg, Jeffrey Katzenberg and David Geffen, is threatening to pull out of the proposed Playa Vista development in the Ballona Wetlands just north of Los Angeles International Airport. And city officials here are warning that if Dreamworks goes, the whole residential-office-retail project may be in jeopardy. 
 It is a classic clash of Hollywood egos and New York investors, and it involves not only money but also local power politics and a newly resurgent real estate market in a battle for a piece of the booming movie business that has filled up existing studio space and helped fuel the region's economic recovery. In essence, the developers, led by the investment houses of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company and Goldman, Sachs & Company, want to impose more costs and conditions for building the new studio than Dreamworks is willing to accept.
In recent days, in anonymous sniping in the trade press and leaked letters, each side has accused the other of bad faith and of working to sabotage the deal. The developer's camp has questioned whether Dreamworks, which is still feeling its way nearly four years after its founding, really wants to build its own studio after all, while Dreamworks allies speculate that the developer is trying get higher-paying tenants and a better return on its investment now that the local real estate market is hot again.
"Dreamworks has given all that it can give," Mr. Katzenberg wrote to the developers last month in a letter that also included threats to look elsewhere.
"We are truly at a point where we cannot, and will not, give any more," he added in the letter, a copy of which was sent to Mayor Richard J. Riordan, Gov. Pete Wilson and other officials. The letter has since become public and has led to the latest round of wrangling over a project that has been stalled for three years.
Dreamworks wants enough land to build and operate its own headquarters and studios, up to 15 state-of-the-art sound stages at a cost of about $200 million. But the developer, Playa Capital, which took control of the site last year after the original investors' financing collapsed, now wants to develop at least some studio space on its own, and then lease it back to Dreamworks or other users at rates that Dreamworks officials say are unrealistic and exorbitant.
"In the world of stupid ideas, that's an Olympic winner," said one senior Dreamworks executive, speaking on condition of anonymity and adding that it would be far preferable for the studio to continue renting production space as needed from existing studios.
But in an intense public lobbying campaign this week, Dreamworks has hardly behaved like a player ready to fold its cards. Instead, it has repeatedly flashed them, enlisting the vocal support of state and local officials to reinforce its position that its involvement is crucial to the overall project's success. Mr. Riordan has offered to help mediate, and even the head of the Motion Picture Association, Jack Valenti, has weighed in.
Indeed, the city and state originally agreed to provide more than $70 million in incentives and employment tax credits to the project on the basis of Dreamworks' involvement in it, and local community and environmental groups long wary of development in one of the last remaining stretches of coastal wetlands in greater Los Angeles also lent their support, largely on the basis of Dreamworks' tenancy and a plan to restore much of the wetlands. This week such groups warned the developer against upsetting that balance.
"Recent statements by the new owners of Playa Vista force me to question those commitments," City Councilwoman Ruth Galanter, who represents the area, said this week.
But Peter Denniston, president of Playa Capital, issued a statement on Wednesday noting that the developer cannot deviate from the current city-approved plan without additional review and City Council approval.
"We see this condition not as a constraint but rather as a testament to our conviction to stand by our promises," Mr. Denniston said.
Dreamworks announced its plan with great fanfare three years ago in the old hangar where the Spruce Goose was built in World War II. The new studio, the first one built here since Warner Brothers moved to the San Fernando Valley in the 1930's, was to be the anchor of a special media district that would create nearly 9,000 jobs and 3,000 housing units and generate billions of dollars in revenue for the city.
"When you have a full-fledged studio, the quality of the job is higher, the pay level is higher and there's a sense of endurance and continuity," Mr. Valenti said in a telephone interview from Paris this week. "It's the difference between owning your car and renting one."
But after months of financing problems and public wrangling with Dreamworks, the original local developer, Robert Maguire, lost control of the project last year, and the studio had to begin negotiations over again with the new owners. The project was also held up by litigation by some environmental groups, although a Federal court has so far temporarily barred work on only 16 acres, most of it centered in a freshwater marsh, pending a fuller review by the Army Corps of Engineers.
In the meantime, the local real estate market had sharply rebounded, and the new owners and the moguls spent much of the last year haggling over terms.
In exchange for the tax credits and intangible marquee value that Dreamworks would bring to the project, the developer agreed to give the studio a plot of land -- Dreamworks says it was 35 acres -- at no cost. But the studio contended that it needed 12 more acres, and reluctantly agreed this summer to pay the developer $20 million for it, according to Mr. Katzenberg's letter.
But then, Mr. Katzenberg wrote, the developer increased the price to more than $48 million, an amount Mr. Katzenberg dismissed as "completely unacceptable." And Dreamworks said the developer sent a subsequent proposal offering even less free land, and the idea of divided control of the sound stages, in which Dreamworks would control some and Playa Capital the rest. It was this proposal that appeared to particularly outrage the studio.
"We have a better deal with most of the studios around town today than we would have with Playa Capital," one Dreamworks official said. "They simply do not understand this business at all."
Playa Capital officials declined to comment in any detail on the negotiations, except to say, as the vice president of corporate affairs, David A. Herbst, put it: "The bottom line is we want to make it happen. We want to do whatever we can to make Dreamworks a part of Playa Vista."
But one person close to the negotiations, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that the developer had been renting out the vast old Hughes hangar and surrounding buildings as sound stages since 1994, and that there still seemed room for compromise.
From the beginning, the Dreamworks partners themselves had varying views of the project, with Mr. Spielberg pressing hardest for it while Mr. Geffen, who became a billionaire in the record business and has always liked to operate with low overhead, was reluctant to invest so heavily in real estate.
Mr. Katzenberg, who cut his teeth as a young City Hall aide in the administration of former Mayor John V. Lindsay of New York, has taken the lead in negotiations, and one Dreamworks official said the partners now seemed more united in their determination to proceed, if not at Playa Vista then by expanding their existing operation on the Universal Studios lot or some other site.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Stamford Rents Rise As Firms Move In

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
As more businesses have moved to Stamford, Conn., an increased demand for housing there has led to skyrocketing rents.
The monthly cost of a studio or a one-bedroom apartment has risen to between $750 and $1,800 this year, from $700 to $1,300 a month in 1997, according to William Pitt Relocation Corporate Services. 
 The average price of a home sold in Stamford in the last six months was $371,000, a figure that is also rising, according to Century 21 A & B Realty.
In the last two years, several companies have moved to the city, including UBS A.G., formerly known as Swiss Bank, which moved its North American headquarters and about 2,700 employees from New York City. The Louis Dreyfus Property Group plans to build a 500,000-square-foot office tower in Stamford.

HEADLINE: NYC;
In Berkshires, A Baseball Tip For the Bronx

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
SUMMER vacation in the Berkshires included, by custom, a family pilgrimage to Wahconah Park in Pittsfield, Mass., where the minor-league Pittsfield Mets set up shop from June to September. In case you wonder about the name, they are the New York-Penn League offspring of the better-known Mets of Flushing Meadows, Queens.
Wahconah Park (capacity 4,000) offers baseball the way it was meant to be: in an intimate setting, with splendid seats for the general admission price of $2.50 and with no silly distractions like exploding scoreboards, guys in chicken suits telling you when to clap or luxury skyboxes that make a mockery of the game's egalitarian roots. 
 But for all its pleasures, Wahconah is showing its age. It was built in 1919, four years before Yankee Stadium opened, and the summer has been filled with cries of how Pittsfield sorely needs a new ball field. Sound vaguely familiar?
Some New Yorkers may be interested in the relationship between the ball club and its neighborhood. Pittsfield has fallen on hard times, having endured its share of economic body blows, like General Electric pulling up stakes a few years ago. But you do not hear the local Mets talk trash about the community that has sustained it.
"It's a question of being out in the community and being a part of it," said Richard Murphy, the team's general manager.
"We have to look at what our mission statement is," he added, "and that's affordable family entertainment."
Thoughts turned to Mr. Murphy during a rain delay at Yankee Stadium on Wednesday night (in a so-so seat near the right-field foul pole that cost $20). It was hard not to contrast his remarks with the behavior of the Yankees' owner, George M. Steinbrenner 3d of Tampa, Fla., who has continued to bad-mouth the Bronx gratuitously despite the millions he makes there and despite the season attendance record his team is close to setting.
Mission? Mr. Steinbrenner makes clear that his is not to be part of a community but rather to take New York City for what he can in his quest for a new ball park. It certainly isn't to provide affordable family entertainment, not with his lust for so many luxury boxes that Yankees baseball risks becoming the preserve of the wealthy and the corporately connected.
Only George Steinbrenner can add a sour note to this enchanted season when the Yankees may become the winningest team of the century. Haven't they already provided enough magic to carry this city through the bleakest winter? Not to their bilious owner. "I really don't care about how many victories we get this year, I really don't," he said last month. "What I care about is the playoffs."
In the spring, City Hall politicians allowed this man's ambitions to make a mess of their municipal budget negotiations. Now, because of him, they are set to clutter the November ballot with one dubious referendum or another.
THIS may be as good a time as any to note how generous New York has already been to the Yankees -- and, for that matter, to the Mets. Compare that with the city's contract with the United States Tennis Association, a favorable deal for New York even if its Yankees-adoring Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, does not think so. (No doubt, it is purely a coincidence that this agreement was reached by David N. Dinkins, his tennis-loving predecessor.)
In the last 10 years, the tennis association has paid the city $5.3 million in rent for its United States Open matches in Flushing Meadows, compared with $2.1 million paid by the Yankees and $2 million by the Mets for the use of their stadiums. Bear in mind that the Open, now under way, lasts a mere two weeks while the regular baseball season is six months long.
What makes the tennis deal shine is that the Dinkins administration required the association to pay all maintenance costs. By contrast, the Yankees and Mets get to deduct those expenses from their rent bill. And Mr. Steinbrenner has not been above an occasional chisel. Some years, his accounting had the city owing him money. Once, he tried dunning the city for an engineer who supposedly worked 168 hours a week. Guess how many hours there are in a week.
Anyway, all this is something New Yorkers may wish to ponder in the thickening battle over a new playground for the Yankees owner. How did the Pittsfield man put it? "It's a question of being out in the community and being a part of it."

HEADLINE: Labor and the Left: Getting Cozy Again;
But Common Goals May Not Be Enough to Revive a Potent Alliance

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
For the last three decades, two groups that should be obvious bedfellows -- the labor movement and leftist intellectuals -- have far more often acted as enemies than as allies.
Close partners throughout the first half of this century, these two had an ugly breakup in the 1960's over Vietnam, integration and the vehemence of cold war anti-Communism. 
 But with the end of the cold war and with leadership changes in the house of labor, unions and left-of-center intellectuals have concluded that they might have a lot in common after all. Eager to counter the rise of the right and growing corporate dominance of the economy and culture, labor and the left have attempted a reconciliation over the last two years. To what degree this rapprochement will succeed, however, very much remains an open question.
In candid moments, several intellectuals who have fostered the reconciliation acknowledge that one of their main goals is to end their exile from power and the public policy arena. In the 1960's, liberal-left thinkers like Arthur Schlesinger Jr., John Kenneth Galbraith and Michael Harrington had the White House's ear, but by the 1980's, the right was clearly winning the war of ideas as much of its agenda gained acceptance even with Democrats.
A decade ago the A.F.L.-C.I.O., preoccupied with toppling Communism overseas, added insult to the left's insignificance by allying itself with neoconservative intellectuals -- the nemesis of labor's new-found friends.
"This is a way out of the ghetto, out of marginalization, a way to once again have our ideas taken seriously and to move public policy and the cultural values of the country in what we think is a more progressive direction," said Steven Fraser, who wrote a biography of Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, and was a prime mover in bringing left intellectuals and labor back together.
These labor-friendly academics, writers and artists, often call themselves social democrats and include veterans of Students for a Democratic Society, graduates of the Berkeley Free Speech Movement and disciples of the Socialist leaders, Norman Thomas and Michael Harrington. There is also a smattering of red-diaper babies and of academics who were pulled left by the civil rights movement and legendary labor leaders like Cesar Chavez. This pro-labor group first banded together publicly in January 1996, three months after John J. Sweeney was elected A.F.L.-C.I.O. president, promising to help lift the poorest workers and to expand labor's influence and size after decades of decline. Encouraged by Mr. Sweeney's approach, more than 30 prominent intellectuals signed a letter to The New York Review of Books vowing to support labor's renaissance.
This Who's Who of left-of-center thinkers and writers included Paul Berman, Barbara Ehrenreich, Betty Friedan, Henry Louis Gates Jr., Robert Heilbroner, Jonathan Kozol, Richard Rorty, Cornel West, Alfred Kazin and Mr. Schlesinger.
"We believe the revitalization of the American labor movement can fashion a new politics of social solidarity and economic justice, and reverse the country's descent into the kind of mean-spirited selfishness that so discolors the contemporary political scene," they wrote. "It is the most heartening development in our nation's political life since the heyday of the civil rights movement a third of a century ago."
Leftist intellectuals and labor both want a country with less corporate dominance, with more social protections and with more democratic participation in government and in the workplace. Both want American workers to have more security and a fairer share of the nation's economic wealth, leading both to support universal health insurance and a higher minimum wage.
These writers and university professors have been following a tradition that dates from organized labor's formative years in the late 1800's all the way through its heyday in the 1930's and 1940's. In those years, luminaries like the philosopher John Dewey, the economist Charles Beard and the novelists Upton Sinclair, Theodore Dreiser and John Dos Passos wrote books and essays that furthered labor's cause. These intellectuals are responding to appeals from Dewey and Richard Rorty, widely considered the nation's leading living philosopher and a champion of the labor-left alliance, that intellectuals were too inward looking and should not ignore social problems.
"In 1960, if you were on the left, the left was always asking, 'What is the vehicle, to increase power?' " said Nelson Lichtenstein, a University of Virginia history professor and a biographer of Walter Reuther, the auto workers' leader. "Back then, the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee and the civil rights movement were unquestionably the dynamic movement that one had to orient to. Today, to the extent there's any movement's that has the potential for dynamic possibilities, it's the labor movement."
Hoping to build a social movement, Mr. Sweeney has encouraged the alliance with intellectuals, as well as ones with civil rights groups, women's organizations and religious leaders. "The labor movement needs to win the war of ideas in addition to other wars that are going on," said Robert Welsh, Mr. Sweeney's executive assistant and his liaison with intellectuals. "The whole conversation with progressive scholars, writers and artists is critically important to having a vibrant, outward-looking labor movement as opposed to an inward-looking, moribund one."
Nonetheless, some union leaders quietly share the sentiment of Samuel Gompers, the founder of the American Federation of Labor, who feared that aloof intellectuals, often with a utopian bent, might be more hindrance than help.
And not surprisingly, the neoconservatives who were labor's friends a decade ago ridicule the intellectual left, branding them desperate midgets eager to piggyback on the labor giant so they once again can be seen and heard. "It's not a new strategy," said Norman Podhoretz, one of the fathers of neoconservatism. "What you have is a movement with all of these warm bodies and a big treasury, and if you're a small splinter group somewhere on the left, it's not a bad idea to hook up with a movement like that. I do not believe there is much good that will come of this alliance."
For many intellectuals, however, their new embrace of labor gives them an opportunity to climb down from the ivory tower and ally their yin with a brawny, powerful yang that they have long envied from afar. And while the intellectuals talk repeatedly about how their goal is to help the less fortunate, a few admit to some self-interest in forming the alliance. With universities relying increasingly on low-paid adjuncts to teach classes, many academics say they need to join arms with labor to prevent their own exploitation.
"We as academics are increasingly under attack and are experiencing many of the same problems that workers are, workers who are paid much less than we are," said Daniel Clawson, a sociology professor at the University of Massachusetts. "It's difficult to see how we can solve our problems without alliances and support. If we talk about part-time and contingent workers, it's not only U.P.S. and the teamsters. It's what's happening in the universities."
So far the most tangible fruits of the alliance have been two dozen teach-ins at universities around the country. There, scholars and union leaders have dissected and denounced stagnating wages, growing corporate might, globalization's squeeze on workers and management's offensive against unionization drives. A frequent refrain at these teach-ins is that something is badly awry in this richest of nations when millions of full-time workers remain caught below the poverty line and the percentage of workers without health insurance and pensions is growing.
"The teach-ins make labor issues more salient in the minds of students," said Eric Foner, a Columbia University history professor who was master of ceremonies at the first labor teach-in, a standing-room-only affair at Columbia in October 1996. "Many students here have never met a member of a labor union except the person who cleans up on campus. These are students coming from rather privileged backgrounds, and it's important for them to be exposed to some of the reasons why the labor movement is so vital."
Through the teach-ins, the alliance has helped funnel hundreds of students into the labor movement to work as organizers. These intellectuals have formed an organization, Scholars, Artists and Writers for Social Justice, with 1,500 members and an acronym pronounced "sausage." The group has encouraged members to write pro-labor op-ed pieces and has pulled scores of pro-union academics together at the annual meetings of the nation's sociologists and political scientists.
This alliance has not taken the world by storm, however, as the left (intellectual and otherwise) continues to languish and labor remains far less potent than a half-century ago when John L. Lewis, the thundering president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, was as well known as Bill Gates is today.
Even some of the movers behind the alliance, like Mr. Fraser and Professor Foner, voice disappointment that the partnership has not captured the nation's attention and that labor has still not climbed back onto center stage in politics and social policy. Their goal is to make labor as vocal and powerful as it was a half century ago, but with unions representing 14 percent of all workers, down from 35 percent, that will not be easy.
Labor and its intellectual friends also face an uphill battle because globalization and the Gingrich revolution have repeatedly thrown unions on the defensive. In addition, the teamsters' campaign finance scandal and other eruptions of union corruption have tarred unions badly just as they are trying to win more members and public backing.
Daniel Bell, the Harvard sociologist and longtime student of unions, said he doubted the labor-left alliance would amount to much. "For the intellectuals, it's a lot of wishful thinking; I don't mean that in an invidious way," he said. "The real test will be whether labor has the ability to expand its numbers. Simply becoming more rhetorical and becoming more active politically is not in and of itself enough."

HEADLINE: Falling Prices For Oil Impede Iraq Aid Plan

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 4

 BODY:
Recent sharp drops in the price of oil have undermined a program under which Iraq can sell its oil to raise money for urgent civilian needs like food and medicine, the senior official in charge of the program told the Security Council today.
The official, Benon Sevan, briefing the Security Council on a report on Iraq from the Secretary General, said the reduced earnings from oil sales would mean that the United Nations could not meet a higher nutritional target in food supplied monthly to every Iraqi. 
 Hundreds of millions of dollars worth of food and medicine have been shipped to Iraq since the program began a little over a year ago, a United Nations spokesman in Baghdad, Eric Falt, said on Thursday.
This week, the largest ship to arrive in Iraq under the program, a 52,000-ton Greek freighter, brought a shipment of American red winter wheat. American companies have won nearly $35 million in grain contracts with Iraq under the program.
The "oil for food" program was increased substantially in February, to $5.2 billion from $2.1 billion in oil sales every six months. This followed growing reports of malnutrition and deaths caused by lack of medication and medical supplies. The quantities were fixed in a formula based on the price of oil in February.
After subtracting money set aside for compensation to victims of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990 and other built-in deductions, Iraq should have had several billion dollars for aid expenditures. But lower oil prices have reduced the expected amount available to about $1.79 billion for this six-month period.
To complicate matters, the distribution of supplies, especially medicines, has been delayed. The reasons cited in the report included poor communications with health centers, Iraq's extended quality control testing of imports and the tendency of Iraqi officials to hold back stocks for what they say are emergency needs.
Moreover, Iraq is not able to pump all the oil permitted under the expanded agreement because of the run-down condition of its oil industry.
Hopes of increasing the volume of oil sales to compensate in some part for the lower prices have not been met because of delays in approving contracts for spare parts.
The delays are taking place in the Security Council's sanctions committee on Iraq, where the United States has challenged contracts despite the recommendation of oil experts hired by the United Nations to review Iraqi purchases. Iraq is often suspected of trying to import items beyond what it needs. The country has been under stringent sanctions for eight years.
Bill Richardson, the departing American representative to the United Nations and the new Energy Secretary, said there was no change in the American position.
"The United States is ready to assist the Iraqi people with humanitarian needs," Mr. Richardson said after Mr. Sevan's briefing. "We're ready to approve oil spare-parts contracts provided that they deal with improving the oil delivery efficiency system for the Iraqi people to get humanitarian assistance. For other purposes we will not approve them -- for frivolous purposes."

HEADLINE: Accidental Tourists Need Not Apply Here$ %;
It Takes Methodical Planning to Lure Visitors to Far Corner of Texas

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

DATELINE: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex.

 BODY:
The world surely is wide enough to hold a few more tourist attractions, and this city of 400,000 people has tried mightily to fill the bill.
And why not? After all, other cities in the United States have fashioned successful tourist industries by virtue of natural setting, vision or sometimes good luck.
These include Branson, Mo., a year-round country music capital; Tunica, Miss., a town that is climbing out of rank poverty with glitzy hotels and glitzier gambling casinos, and such shopping meccas as Potomac Mills outlet mall in Dale City, Va., which draws more tourists than Colonial Williamsburg. Then there is Newport, Ore., where the arrival of Keiko the whale (of "Free Willy" fame) has attracted one million more visitors to the Oregon Coast Aquarium and has the town's 9,000 residents pondering what will become of its multimillion-dollar tourist industry after Keiko is returned to a sea pen in its native Iceland on Sept. 9. 
 But Corpus Christi, a socially conservative and heavily Hispanic city, has few spectacular natural assets or claims to fame. Instead, it has pursued tourism methodically, investing millions to try to overcome hard strokes of geographical misfortune. And success is already evident in the rising number of visitors.
"We don't ever expect to become another Orlando or Las Vegas, because we understand what kind of tourist destination we are -- primarily a beach town," said Mike Crouch, director of public affairs for the Greater Corpus Christi Business Alliance. "But we hope to attract lots more tourists and convention delegates and have them stay longer."
Known mostly for its oil industry, which fell on hard times starting in the late 1980's, the city is tucked within a lovely bay behind Padre Island on the Gulf of Mexico, way down in southeast Texas, more than 200 miles from Houston and almost 400 miles from Dallas. As a former tourist official said, "You don't get to Corpus Christi by accident; you have to work at getting here."
Most air service to and from the city is on regional carriers, and nonstops to other states are nonexistent. Even a flight to El Paso, for example, 720 road miles away, typically takes four to six hours, depending on connections and stops.
Though a number of Corpus Christi hotels and attractions are worth bragging about -- one is a life-size statue of Selena Quintanilla Perez, 23, the Queen of Tejano, or Texas-Mexican borderland music, who was shot dead by her fan club president in 1995 -- they are a far cry from the snazzy theme parks or casinos that pack in the crowds elsewhere. Thus, the great bulk of Corpus Christi tourists are still likely to come from within a 150-mile radius.
With its large Hispanic population and proximity to Mexico, Corpus Christi is especially determined to attract a larger share of the three million Mexican tourists and convention delegates who spent almost $900 million in the state last year.
And so it was that city officials set about building a tourist industry that did more than attract penny-pinching college students on spring break or day-trippers to its many beaches.
Dead set against the "build it and they'll come" mentality, Corpus Christi officials have been careful to order economic impact studies before plunking down a dime to buy attractions.
For example, the go-ahead for a $33 million aquarium, which opened in 1990, was given only after studies projected that it would make money -- and after a look at the success of Baltimore's aquarium and Inner Harbor. Averaging about 440,000 visitors a year, the aquarium is now credited with adding $50 million a year to Corpus Christi's economy.
The city also spent $4.1 million for the U.S.S. Lexington, the legendary World War II aircraft carrier, after spirited bidding with Quincy, Mass., and Mobile, Ala. But first the city received reassurance from Debbie Prost, head of what is now Prost Marketing Inc., a San Antonio consulting firm, that the ship would draw far more than the 270,000 visitors a year needed to break even. Even then, officials also studied the success of six other cities that had former Navy ships as tourist sites. Since opening in October 1992, the Lexington has averaged almost 350,000 visitors a year and has contributed $62 million a year.
The ship and the aquarium have also spruced up North Beach, a section of the city that was badly damaged in a hurricane in 1971.
"When I grew up in this city," said Frank Stanford of College Station, Tex., "North Beach was infested with drugs and crime. But as you can see, today it's filled with families." Mr. Stanford was showing Corpus Christi's attractions to a friend, Diane Havalda of Austin. As he spoke, lots of children scampered around the aquarium.
The $20 million Greyhound Race Track, opened in 1990 and owned by a Florida corporation that was able to qualify for certain tax rebates available under a state enterprise zone, continues to attract many out-of-staters who spend the winter months in Texas. But the track has been overshadowed somewhat since the state lottery began in 1992.
The only sizable investment that has not lived up to promise is the $1.1 million paid to Spain for the right to operate and manage replicas of the Nina, Pinta and Santa Maria, the fleet that Columbus sailed to the New World more than 500 years ago. Although the fleet has attracted 650,000 paying customers since opening five years ago, the Pinta and the Santa Maria were damaged in 1994, when a tow cable snapped and a barge crashed into them. Repairs by Spanish shipwrights were completed only this summer.
A small zoo and a botanical garden have recently been added to Corpus Christi's tourism mix, the Asian Cultures Museum moved into a new building, and the Museum of Science and History was extensively remodeled and expanded.
As a result of all these efforts, the number of visitors grew to 5.5 million in 1997, from fewer than 2.3 million in 1986 -- a 139 percent increase during a time when total United States tourism grew about 89 percent. Hotel room revenues doubled, to $100.4 million. Tourism-related jobs also doubled, to 10,200, and the tourism-related payroll almost tripled, to $152 million. The average visitor's stay, which had never been more than a day, grew to 2.5 days.
The Convention Center in Bayfront Plaza booked 151,679 convention delegates in 1996, the last year for those figures available, a 60 percent increase over 1986.
Still, for all the growth, Corpus Christi doesn't approach the number of visitors to Orlando, Fla. (35.6 million in 1996), Las Vegas (30.5 million) or even San Antonio, which recorded 7 million visitors last year.
Moreover, not all the improvements, including the trendy restaurants, sleek office buildings and modern hotels along the two-mile-long white waterfront seawall and walkway, are a result of tourism. The petrochemical industry, for example, pumps more than $1 billion into the local economy, while the city's growing health care services employ about 24,000 people.
It was the collapse of Corpus Christi's decades-long dependence on gas and oil that sent the city reeling when the price of domestic oil plummeted from $40 a barrel in 1980 to $10 in 1986.
"In 1986, unemployment reached a decade high of 12.2 percent, and we lost 5,000 jobs in the oil and gas exploration industry," said Gary E. Bushell, president of the area business alliance. Just between 1986 and 1988, hotel revenues fell from $45.5 million to $38.7 million.
Bill Pruet, a small-business owner, former city councilman and chairman of the business alliance's tourism committee, said: "For almost 100 years oil and gas provided our tax base, funded our schools and created our jobs. Every big oil company was here. But when oil went down the chute, they just abandoned those offices and pulled out. When it was agreed to really go after tourists, we knew we had to go beyond just T-shirts and kids on the beach."
Tourism indeed remains at the forefront of Corpus Christi's effort to make a name for itself while adding jobs and earning money.
While hoping (and lobbying) to attract cruise ships, the city has formed a partnership with San Antonio whereby cruise passengers can also fly to that mission city before or after their cruise, to visit the Alamo or the city's acclaimed River Walk.
It has also established a tourism and trade office in Monterrey, Mexico, together with its Texas neighbor, Laredo, and the Port of Corpus Christi, the nation's sixth-largest port.
A big drawing card for Mexican and Mexican-American tourists is the Selena statue. In the middle of the nine seawall pavilions along Ocean Drive, the bronze statue continues to attract legions of fans, young and old.
"We came mostly for the beach," said Roberto Leal of Monterrey, on his first visit here recently with two related families that together consisted of 10 adults and 12 children. "But we don't want to go home without seeing the aquarium and the memorial to Selena."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries AreA Bit Higher In Short Session

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities traded mostly higher in an abbreviated session yesterday, as a decline in stocks led nervous investors to seek safety in bonds.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 8/32, to 103 8/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, dropped to 5.28 percent, from 5.30 percent on Thursday. The Treasury market closed early yesterday, two hours before the 4 P.M. closing bell of the New York Stock Exchange, which might have prompted some investors to be cautious going into a long holiday weekend. Markets will be closed on Monday in observance of Labor Day.
For the week, the benchmark long-bond yield was down 5 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. 
 The August employment report had little impact on the market. The report showed that the return of workers following two strikes against General Motors helped swell payrolls by 365,000 jobs and kept the unemployment rate at 4.5 percent.
Anthony Chan, managing director and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said that although the credit markets were focusing more heavily on world developments than on domestic economic data, the employment report was fairly market-friendly.
Mr. Chan said that the average nonfarm payroll jobs gain for the months of July and August raced ahead of the first-quarter average but came in well below that of the second-quarter average. "Such evidence suggests that we should not expect too much further firming on the wage front in the months ahead," he said.
He also noted that many traders were looking ahead to a speech last night by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, at the University of California at Berkeley. A number of traders, Mr. Chan said, "refused to rule out the possibility that a more friendly Fed posture would be revealed by the chairman."
"If so, his comments would certainly go a long way in coloring the path of trading" during the next couple of trading sessions, he said.
Bonds were also bolstered by a strong dollar in currency trading.

HEADLINE: Claims Processor Loses Contract With Blue Cross

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, SEPT. 4

 BODY:
Allied Specialty Services, a claims-processing company for four of New Jersey's largest health maintenance organizations, has been dropped by one of these managed care insurers, and its contract with another is being reviewed.
Allied, which is based in Florida, lost its account with H.M.O. Blue, the state's second largest H.M.O., which announced the decision in a letter last Monday. The contract was canceled two days before doctors and some health consumer groups publicly accused Allied of delaying, denying and decreasing claims payments to specialists in a way that threatened the solvency of some medical practices and distorting the decisions of health care providers. Allied has denied that such problems exist. 
 Allied had handled the claims for 553,000 of the state's 2.3 million H.M.O. customers.
In the letter on Monday, H.M.O. Blue notified the doctors in its plan that it was terminating its contract with Allied. Donna Celestini, the vice president for managed care with Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey, which owns H.M.O. Blue, echoed the doctors' complaints about delays in payments in explaining why the company had ended its contract with Allied after just 18 months. Figures were not available for the amount H.M.O. Blue paid Allied during that period. The H.M.O. will process the claims itself, she said.
Ms. Celestini said that the company's cost of monitoring Allied and the many complaints was exceeding any savings Blue Cross had anticipated from the arrangement. She said that Allied appeared to have "expanded too fast, too soon" in the state in an effort to capture a share of the H.M.O. market. Months of negotiations did not succeed in improving Allied's handling of claims, she said.
Elizabeth Schmuck, a spokeswoman for another of Allied's customers, NYLCare Health Plans, which was recently acquired by Aetna, the state's largest H.M.O., said that in light of the complaints made by the group of doctors and consumers on Wednesday, NYLCare was reviewing those complaints and its relationship with Allied.
Kevin Heine, a spokesman for Prudential H.M.O., another Allied client, however, expressed surprise at the complaints, saying that during Prudential's nearly 10-month-old contract with Allied, there had been no serious complaints and that the company had "met or exceeded" the on-time payment goals set for it. Calls to the fourth company, Cigna H.M.O., seeking comment on its relationship with Allied were not returned today.
Allied, in a statement released today from its corporate headquarters, said that H.M.O. Blue's decision to handle claims itself was a function of that company's business needs changing over time. It did not address the specifics of the criticisms in claims processing.
On Wednesday, doctors from the Medical Society of New Jersey and the Physicians Union of New Jersey and consumer health advocates accused the company of delaying payment on bills up to 90 days, losing paperwork and frequently substituting their judgment for the doctors' on necessary treatment by refusing to pay for certain levels of care. The problem was all the more frustrating, they said, because third-party administrators such as Allied were not insurance companies subject to direct regulation by state insurance commissioners.
Health economists say that with the growth of managed care, third-party administrators like Allied Specialty Services have emerged in the last 15 years to sell their services to self-insured companies and union health plans that do not have the ability or expertise to process health care claims.
Dr. Alan Hillman, the director of the Center for Health Policy at the University of Pennsylvania, said that traditional insurers have turned to such companies for claims processing and review help only in the last five years, "when anything is possible in the health care business."
Dr. Hillman said that the introduction of yet another element in the equation involving doctors, patients and insurers has often led to delays, complaints and accusations that these new intermediaries were benefiting financially from such delays.
But James Robinson, a professor of health economics at the University of California at Berkeley, defended such entities as a helpful part of cost control in the changing health care industry. He said much of the criticism of them was "a red herring" put forward by doctors and others who were fighting a rear guard action against the entire managed care movement.
Originally called Allied Health Group, Allied Specialty Services was founded in 1987 in Boca Raton, Fla. Allied developed computer software that evaluated the fees charged by specialists in relation to national and regional norms, and it marketed itself as a company that could cut insurers' costs, root out fraud and catch frequent and costly filing mistakes by health care providers.
It operates in 12 states and processes about four million claims a year from 21 medical specialties. Last December, Allied was acquired by Magellan Health Services, a publicly owned managed care company based in Atlanta with offices in 35 states. Magellan paid $50 million for Allied, and the deal calls for $60 million more to be paid to Allied's founders should Allied meet certain earnings goals over the next three years.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
The Faces of Clinton: Weary to Somber to Vibrant

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: LIMERICK, Ireland, Sept. 4

 BODY:
President Reagan's advisers were fond of saying that people never remember the words of a President, only the pictures.
If that is true, President Clinton this week offered a kaleidoscope of images played out on his face and in his gestures, from the pained confession of his "profound regret" about the Lewinsky matter to his compassion for the victims of the Omagh bombing. He was alternately engaged and distracted, buoyant and mournful. At times his eyes were locked in the thousand-yard stare of the soldier who has seen too much combat. His interactions with Hillary Rodham Clinton lurched from apparent affection to icy distance. 
 But the overwhelming impression was of a man exhausted and in distress who was able, when necessary, to put aside his private pain and reclaim the brave face of the practiced performer.
The week has taken a dizzying trajectory for the President, from the end of a restless 10-day vacation with his family on Martha's Vineyard to a therapeutic round of golf scheduled for Saturday afternoon on the ancient links at Ballybunion in southwest Ireland.
But in between, what a ride.
 
Presidents, Aging and Ashen
A somber President stepped off Air Force One into a cold drizzle in Moscow on Tuesday morning after a 10-hour overnight flight from Washington. He had the red, puffy eyes of the overnight traveler as he walked hand in hand with Mrs. Clinton down the steps of the plane.
He met that morning at the Kremlin with Boris N. Yeltsin, but there was none of the "Bill and Boris" jocularity of past meetings. The aging, ailing Russian leader moved with the awkward gestures of an invalid; Mr. Clinton appeared ashen, almost funereal.
Mr. Clinton was little better that afternoon in a speech in a Moscow university auditorium, a familiar kind of setting for him and one he usually plays to advantage. But his delivery was uncharacteristically flat, perhaps compounded by an impassive audience that did not once interrupt his remarks with applause.
Aides explained that Mr. Clinton was tired. Besides, one said, Russia's political paralysis "does not lend itself to laughter."
 
No Vodka This Time
That night, Mr. Yeltsin was the host at a state dinner in the Kremlin, but this was not the customary vodka-drenched, hours-long Russian affair. Neither Mr. Clinton nor Mr. Yeltsin was in the mood for hilarity.
Although he appeared attentive, Mr. Clinton's mind was on Wall Street, which the day before had suffered a 512-point nose dive.
Gene Sperling, the chief White House economic adviser, whispered in the President's ear that the market was bouncing back. Mr. Clinton grinned and gave him the thumb's-up sign.
 
In Search of a Smile
The American side had signaled to the Russians that the President had had a long day and asked that the dinner be abbreviated. Barely an hour after the party sat down to eat, the dinner broke up, an hour ahead of schedule.
At times, the President's demeanor matched his words. On others, they were strangely out of synch. Twice on this trip Mr. Clinton took questions from reporters. The first occasion was in a joint news conference in the Kremlin with Mr. Yeltsin. Mr. Clinton knew he would face questions about his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky and the fallout from his bitter admission of Aug. 17.
As Mr. Yeltsin spoke, Mr. Clinton scanned the faces of reporters, looking for a sympathetic smile and trying to gauge the level of aggressiveness. Two of the three questions the President took were about the Lewinsky issue. He said he had made a mistake and asked for forgiveness. But he did not look as if he expected to get it. Cameras caught him at one point cradling his chin in his palms, looking like a weary businessman whose flight home had just been canceled.
 
For First Time: 'Sorry'
Mr. Clinton fielded questions about the Lewinsky matter again this morning, at a photo opportunity with Bertie Ahern, the Irish Prime Minister. Reporters clamored for a response to a damaging statement on Thursday from Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, a longtime ally of the President's.
Mr. Clinton said he deserved all the criticism he got and said for the first time that he was "sorry" about the affair. But his manner appeared anything but penitent.
He was oddly relaxed, almost jovial as he again admitted error and called his behavior "indefensible." If one watched the statement on television with the sound off, one might have guessed that Mr. Clinton was discussing Mark McGwire's chase for the home-run record.
The best day of the trip for Mr. Clinton was Wednesday, as he took a victory lap around Northern Ireland, encouraging work on the peace agreement he had helped broker and comforting the families of the victims of the bomb attack in Omagh.
This was the Bill Clinton of the 1992 campaign, with perfect emotional pitch in his remarks and a soothing arm for the bereaved. As he walked down Market Street in Omagh, scene of the deadly blast, he was caught wiping away a tear in a picture that dominated the front pages of several Irish newspapers.
 
Date With Ballybunion
The President's spirits were raised by the closeness throughout the day of Tony Blair, Britain's charismatic Prime Minister, a younger version of Mr. Clinton, without the baggage of scandal.
Mr. Clinton wandered back into the press compartment of Air Force One tonight on his way to Limerick and his date with Ballybunion on Saturday. He was somber but at ease, said the reporters who saw him. He said he had had a "wonderful time" in Ireland, but ducked substantive questions about policy or scandal.
He grew animated in discussing his golf date. He said he has been gathering tips from professionals on how to play the course and had been looking forward for weeks to the challenges of the wind-whipped links on an outcropping above the sea. "I'm going to be glad to get through it," Mr. Clinton said.
But this trip, and the two weeks before it, have taken their toll.
"I'm tired," said the President before returning to his cabin.

GRAPHIC: Photos: In the last week, President Clinton reflected a palette of contrasting moods: Darker, more pensive, while listening to reporters' questions with President Boris N. Yeltsin in the Kremlin and again while waiting to speak in Belfast, Northern Ireland. But lighter, indeed, light-hearted at times: In Moscow, a cheerful President held up an "I Love MGIMO" T-shirt (the acronym stands for Moscow State Institute for International Relations). And in Belfast, with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain at his side, he offered a campaign-style salute after speaking. (Photographs by Reuters (top) and Associated Press (bottom))

HEADLINE: Payrolls Rose By 365,000 Last Month

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
Despite a sagging stock market and a growing trade deficit, America's labor market remains very solid.
The Labor Department reported yesterday that the return of workers idled by the 54-day strike at General Motors helped to keep the unemployment rate at 4.5 percent in August, close to its 30-year low, and helped to swell payrolls by 365,000 jobs. 
 Investors were not surprised by yesterday's report and digested its most obvious implication -- that it reduced the likelihood of an immediate interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve Board -- with apparent equanimity. By the end of the day, stock prices had fallen modestly in volatile trading, while bond prices had rallied.
Disregarding the effects of the G.M. strike, the economy churned out an average of 217,000 new jobs a month in July and August, slower than the 244,000 monthly rate in the year's first half but still a strong pace. Pay is rising at a good clip, too; total hours worked are up and first-time unemployment claims are at a 10-year low.
"In spite of everything that's out there, the general economy is growing at a pretty good pace," said Mitchell S. Fromstein, chief executive of Manpower Inc., the nation's largest supplier of temporary workers.
David Wyss, chief economist of Standard & Poor's DRI, said: "We're where we've been for the last four months. It's still a very tight labor market."
Until recently, the Fed's primary concern has been whether the economy would slow enough to head off the threat of inflation as companies compete for relatively scarce workers. If growth stays too strong or inflation picks up, the Fed could raise rates. Financial troubles abroad, though, have put the Fed in a bind, raising questions whether lower rates might be needed to encourage Americans to keep buying products made here and abroad to head off a downturn.
"There's nothing in this report that says ease," said Robert J. Barbera at Hoenig & Company, an investment consulting firm, in White Plains.
The issue now is how long the American labor market will stay this robust. Job numbers provide a better look at where the economy has been than at where it is headed.
"This is as good as it gets," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist of Deutsche Bank Securities. "All the risks are on the downside. If we're lucky, unemployment will stay this low. If we're not, more of the effects of the global recession will reach us."
The dark spot in the otherwise bright labor picture is a troubling weakness in manufacturing. Asia's economic problems are starting to take a bigger bite. Although total manufacturing hours worked rose sharply in August, suggesting that monthly industrial production may rise for the first time this summer, a total of 100,000 factory jobs disappeared in July and August, even taking into account the effects of the strike at General Motors.
Tom Nardone, an economist at the Labor Department, said that the pace of job losses had doubled from the two previous months. The biggest losses occurred among makers of clothing and electronic equipment and in food processing.
"Manufacturing is in a pricing recession," Mr. Yardeni said. "Not only can't they raise prices, but they're under a lot of pressure to cut prices because of the collapse of exports to Asia. As a result, profits are under pressure, and companies are starting to cut back on hiring."
The danger, he added, is that the weakness in manufacturing could spread to services.
"Services don't operate in a vacuum," Mr. Yardeni said. "Many of their customers are manufacturers." Manufacturers employ less than 15 percent of the work force, he points out, but account for 30 percent of all business activity.
Just about everywhere else in the labor market, however, jobs were sprouting last month.
Services -- from day care to management consulting -- added 135,000 jobs. Temporary-help companies accounted for 42,000 of that number, reversing a loss of a similar magnitude in July. Computer and data processing added 11,000 jobs. Transportation and public utilities added 24,000 jobs.
Finance, insurance and real estate added 13,000, substantially less than the pace of the last year or so. Mortgage lenders probably account for much of that gain, as low rates keep the home loan business humming.
A gain of 16,000 construction jobs reflects the continued boom in the building and buying of homes. Since last fall, construction has added 261,000 workers.
Government jobs rose by a strong 57,000, although that figure was probably exaggerated as early school starting dates in some parts of the country complicated attempts to make seasonal adjustments.
One-fifth of small businesses say their most pressing problem is an inability to find enough skilled help, according to the latest survey of the National Federation of Independent Business. Nonetheless, hiring in August was extremely strong.
The wage picture is positive. The increase in workers' average hourly earnings was half a percent, or 7 cents, in August, after a gain of two-tenths of a percent in July. The year-to-year increases, however, have flattened out at just over 4 percent in the last few months. Still, even though wage inflation does not seem to be accelerating, pay is rising fast enough to grant workers some of the best gains in real income in years.
Some of the biggest gains are going to workers at the bottom of the pay scale, said Mr. Fromstein of Manpower. He sees a tremendous amount of job hopping as low-wage hotel, fast-food and service workers take advantage of the extremely tight labor market to obtain better pay. "There just aren't enough people to fill these jobs," he said. "In an economy like this, when people making $7 an hour can get a job for a dollar more, they're getting a 15 percent raise."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Greenspan Hints at Cut In Rates Amid Global Crisis
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said that the central bankers were growing more concerned about the effect of the global financial crisis on the United States economy, and he seemed to open the door to consideration of a rate cut if the global situation continues to deteriorate.
In the spring and early summer, Federal Reserve policy makers were more concerned about the threat of renewed inflation, Mr. Greenspan said, and they adopted a policy stance signaling they stood ready to raise rates at the first sign of any significant inflation. But he said policy makers decided last month that the global turmoil posed a growing threat to prosperity. Page A1. 

Chernomyrdin Details Financial Plan
Russia's Acting Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, detailed a series of economic remedies that would shore up the nation's banking system and ease the country into an "econonomic dictatorship" where the money supply would be rigidly controlled and failing factories could face bankruptcy for the first time. The Parliament put off a vote on the new Government until Monday, buying more time for political negotiations. A6.
 
G.M. and Union Reach Saturn Pact
General Motors and the United Automobile Workers reached an accord at the auto maker's Saturn assembly plant in Spring Hill, Tenn., averting another strike. Details of the agreement were not disclosed, but both sides said it affirmed the plant's partnership between management and labor. C2.
 
Two Carriers Ordered Back in Air
The Secretary of Transportation, Rodney E. Slater, ordered Mesaba Aviation and Express Airlines I, commuter carriers that suspended service last week because of the pilots' strike at Northwest Airlines, to resume flights to 17 small cities no later than Tuesday. A12.
 
Dow Rallies Late but Loses Ground
The Dow Jones industrial average fell as much as 186 points before it and other market measures recovered, cutting their losses by two-thirds and more. The Dow closed down 41.97 points, or five-tenths of 1 percent, at 7,640,25. It is now down 3.4 percent for the year. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 8.37 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 973.89, and the Nasdaq composite index dropped 5.34 points, or three-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,566.52. C3.
 
Treasury securities traded mostly higher. The yield of the 30-year bond dropped to 5.28 percent from 5.30 percent. C3.
 
Futures Exchange Wins Approval
Cantor Fitzgerald won approval from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission for the first computerized futures exchange in the United States, the latest in a global shift to electronic networks. The system will compete with the Chicago Board of Trade, the nation's largest futures market. C3.
 
Moody's May Lower Ratings in Asia
Moody's Investors Service said it might lower its debt ratings for China and Hong Kong. Moody's pointed to slowing exports and investment in China and Hong Kong's deteriorating economy and decision to spend currency reserves to buy stocks. C2.
 
Moody's said it might lower its rating on Nomura Securities, Japan's largest brokerage firm, because of concerns about its profitability. C2.
 
Labor and the Left Reacquainted
Organized labor and the intellectual left had an ugly breakup in the 1960's over Vietnam, integration and anti-Communism. But with the end of the cold war and with changes in union leadership, labor and left-of-center intellectuals have concluded they might have a lot in common after all. B9.
 
Cooper in Deal for British Company
Cooper Industries of Houston said that it had acquired the British company TLG, formerly known as Thorn Lighting Group, for $535 million in cash. Thorn is a major European maker of lighting equipment. C3.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Fed Chairman'sSpeech

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a speech last night by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, at the Walter A. Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley.
It is just not credible that the United States can remain an oasis of prosperity unaffected by a world that is experiencing greatly increased stress. Developments overseas have contributed to holding down prices and aggregate demand in the United States in the face of strong domestic spending. As dislocations abroad mount, feeding back on our financial markets, restraint is likely to intensify. In the spring and early summer, the Federal Open Market Committee was concerned that a rise in inflation was the primary threat to the continued expansion of the economy. By the time of the committee's August meeting, the risks had become balanced, and the committee will need to consider carefully the potential ramifications of ongoing developments since that meeting. . . . 
 When costs rise, the attention of management presumably becomes focused more sharply on investments to limit the effects of rising costs.
But if cost-cutting at will is, in fact, currently available, it suggests that a backlog of unexploited capital projects has been built up in recent years, which, if true, implies the potential for continued gains in productivity close to the elevated rates of the last couple of years. Even if this is indeed the case, and only anecdotal evidence supports it, security analysts' recent projected per share earnings growth of more than 13 percent annually over the next three to five years is unlikely to materialize. It would imply an ever-increasing share of profit in the national income from a level that is already high by historic standards. Such conditions have led in the past to labor market pressures that thwarted further profit growth. . . .
Clearly, the history of large swings in investor confidence and equity premiums for rational and other reasons counsels caution in the current context. We have relearned in recent weeks that just as a bull stock market feels unending and secure as an economy and stock market move forward, so it can feel when markets contract that recovery is inconceivable. Both, of course, are wrong. But because of the difficulty imagining a turnabout when such emotions take hold, periods of euphoria or distress tend to feed on themselves. Indeed, if this were not the case, the types of psychologically driven ebbs and flows of economic activity we have observed would be unlikely to exist. . . .
