HEADLINE: BELIEFS

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
Peter L. Berger is a contrarian, no doubt about it. A pre-eminent sociologist of religion, he has been undercutting conventional assumptions since "The Noise of Solemn Assemblies," his 1961 book, cast a cold eye on the postwar religious revival still in full bloom.
His latest salvo is in the current issue of The Christian Century, the journal of liberal Protestantism. Professor Berger, director of the Institute for the Study of Economic Culture at Boston University, began by confessing one big error in his early thinking: that modernity necessarily leads to a decline in religion. 
 Except for a few locales like Western Europe and few highly visible groups, like the humanistically educated intelligentsia, most of the world, he said, is as religious as ever. But he remains convinced that modern pluralism undermined the "taken for grantedness" that has bolstered traditional religious beliefs and moral values.
Pluralism, in sum, may not keep people from believing but it influences how they believe -- namely, with a good deal less certainty. There are, of course, individuals who thrive on this lack of certainty. But most people find it disconcerting, especially when it touches on life's most basic questions. That is why they are drawn to various contemporary "offers of certainty."
He identifies three of long standing within the Christian orbit. One can seek certainty in the institution of the church, in an absolute understanding of the biblical text or in one's own direct religious experience. Catholicism has tended toward the first, fundamentalist Protestantism toward the second, revivalism and Pentecostalism toward the third.
Professor Berger argues that the modern human sciences have weakened all three possibilities. Historical scholarship creates uncertainties about the institution's trustworthiness. Biblical criticism raises doubts about any certain interpretation of the texts. Psychology and the sociology of knowledge undermine confidence in inner experiences.
But is the person who rejects these offers of certainty thrown into the alternative of a relativism that verges on nihilism?
"If one rejects the stark alternatives of an open-ended relativism or some variant of absolutist retrenchment," the professor wrote, "one is faced with a simple but far-reaching question: How is one to have religious beliefs and to lead a religious life in a state of uncertainty?"
His answer draws on classical Protestantism and its core formula: "By faith alone -- sola fide."
Faith is capable of providing what cannot be provided by direct experience, pure logic or the "taken for granted" knowledge that pluralism undermines. But Protestantism does not have a monopoly on this religious posture. "It is a mellow synthesis of skepticism and faith that, in principle, can be found in any religious tradition," Professor Berger wrote.
Of course, words like "faith," "relativism" and "absolutism" are red meat for voracious theologians and philosophers, and many will be tempted to have a tasty meal at Professor Berger's expense. But that may be nothing like the free-for-all his article could provoke among scholars of American religion.
The new reigning wisdom in those circles has been that only "strong religion" is likely to prosper in contemporary America, only religious groups, in other words, that demand substantial commitments of time and resources from their adherents and firm allegiance to beliefs and practices that differentiate the faithful from the surrounding culture.
This view gains support from the growth of conservative Christian groups and from the decline or stagnation of "weak" liberal denominations that more readily tolerate modern uncertainties.
Professor Berger's article is both a sociological and theological challenge to that view, and he even supplies a text from Paul's First Letter to the Corinthians: "God chose what is weak in the world to shame the strong." He cites some recent evidence that "weak" religious institutions can be remarkably vital.
But what gives his article force is less the evidence it cites than the changed attitude toward mainline Protestantism that it expresses.
A conservative, Professor Berger has made many biting observations over the years on the political and economic liberalism marking the leadership of mainline Protestant bodies (and of American Catholicism as well), reflective, he said, of a deeper accommodation to the assumptions of modern culture.
"I tended to look on mainline Protestantism as a community very much gone astray," he said yesterday in a telephone conversation, "one terribly vulnerable to fashionable ideas." That view is "still correct," he said. "But it has struck me increasingly that there is a kind of blessing in this."
"This has been a pretty demoralized community," he added. "I'm telling them, Don't be that demoralized." The "era of uncertainty" created by modern pluralism has created believers of a new sort "who may be a majority of the population," he said, "and need ministering."
Jesus may not be found in "the self-assured, triumphalist institutions that merit the appellation of "strong churches,' Professor Berger wrote in his article, but "in those 'weak' places -- where people are unsure of themselves, groping for a few glimpses of truth to hold on to."

HEADLINE: GREENSPAN HINTS THAT A RATE CUT ISN'T UNTHINKABLE

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER with RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, signaled today that the central bank was now less concerned about inflation as a threat to the American economy and was increasingly wary that the spreading global financial crisis could harm the United States.
Mr. Greenspan's comments seemed to open the door to consideration of an interest rate cut if the global financial situation continued to deteriorate or if the American economy showed signs of stalling. Excerpts, page C2. 
 His comments at the University of California at Berkeley came just minutes before Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin met here with Japan's new Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, to hammer home the message that the best hope of halting the crisis lay in quick action by Tokyo to stimulate its economy and shore up its financial system.
But with market volatility having spread to Latin America and with Russia veering toward economic collapse, American officials said they feared that it would be increasingly difficult to contain the turmoil.
At the end of a week in which Wall Street experienced a sharp selloff, Mr. Greenspan said that even the United States was increasingly vulnerable. "It is just not credible that the United States can remain an oasis of prosperity unaffected by a world that is experiencing greatly increased stress," he said. The current state of the economy was reflected in today's August employment report, which showed that payrolls grew by 365,000 jobs. Page C1.
Mr. Greenspan stopped well short of saying that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates, a step being urged on him by a growing chorus of economists and officials in other countries. An interest rate reduction in the United States would help reduce borrowing costs around the world and could be a powerful psychological boost to embattled investors at home and abroad.
But Mr. Greenspan's comments were a marked departure from his last major policy statement, in July, when he told Congress that the risks of inflation outweighed the possibility that the global financial turmoil could push the otherwise strong American economy into recession.
The global turmoil that has robbed countries of prosperity and growth has benefited the United States so far by helping to dampen inflation and slow down an economy that was at risk of overheating, Mr. Greenspan said in his speech tonight. The downward pressure on inflation is likely to intensify as the turmoil in other nations mounts, a development that he said led Federal Reserve policy makers to rethink their strategy at their last meeting, on Aug. 18.
"In the spring and early summer, the Federal Open Market Committee was concerned that a rise in inflation was the primary threat to the continued expansion of the economy," he said. "By the time of the committee's August meeting, the risks had become balanced, and the committee will need to consider carefully the potential ramifications of ongoing developments since that meeting."
Mr. Greenspan's wording indicated that the committee had abandoned its formal policy of leaning toward an interest rate increase in favor of a neutral stance that favors neither a rate increase nor a cut. The Fed's next policy meeting is Sept. 29.
Mr. Greenspan went on to suggest that the Fed would not rush into a decision about reducing rates just because of this week's slide in stocks.
"We have relearned in recent weeks that just as a bull stock market feels unending and secure as an economy and stock market move forward, so it can feel when markets contract that recovery is inconceivable," he said. "Both, of course, are wrong. But because of the difficulty imagining a turnabout when such emotions take hold, periods of euphoria or distress tend to feed on themselves."
Mr. Greenspan, who has been warning investors for nearly two years that stock prices were higher than reasonable expectations of earnings growth would justify, did not say whether he thought stocks were now more fairly valued after this week's tumble on Wall Street.
But he said the 13 percent annual growth in earnings projected by analysts "is unlikely to materialize."
Mr. Greenspan joined with Mr. Rubin after his speech in meeting with Mr. Miyazawa. Just two days ago in Moscow, President Clinton termed the meeting with Mr. Miyazawa, who served as Prime Minister for two years until a fracturing of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party in 1993, as "profoundly important." That statement reflected a growing view in the Administration that the best hope of choking off the 14-month-old Asian crisis was to bring about a turnaround in Japan.
But Treasury officials winced at Mr. Clinton's characterization because they feared that Japan was still weeks or months away from decisive action, at a time that markets were fraying around the world.
All the early indications from Tokyo were that Mr. Miyazawa was arriving with few new ideas, no new plans and only vague promises. "This meeting was never designed or intended to address the question of a plan," Mr. Rubin said on a flight to San Francisco today.
The main reason Mr. Rubin and his aides were seeking to play down expectations was their fear that the world's markets could react badly to news of little progress from the meeting. But it is also in part because Mr. Rubin and Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers have relatively little leverage: Their explicit criticisms of Japan in recent months have created a backlash in Tokyo, and the Japanese Parliament is spinning its wheels as the ruling and opposition parties argue over what to do about the insolvency of some of the world's largest banks.
"I don't think we will propose anything new," a senior Japanese official said before the meeting. "It is just that for the first time we have a Finance Minister who can explain what our Government is doing."
The official was referring to Mr. Miyazawa's greatest attribute as an international diplomat: He speaks fluent English, learned during travels in the United States before World War II, and for half a century he has been cast into crises and negotiations with the United States.
But in this case, he has relatively little to work with. Japan's Parliament has been talking for months about passing legislation that would address the country's deepening banking crisis. But the debate has just begun, and it has been bogged down by the question of whether billions of dollars in public funds should be used to bail out banks that now have upward of a trillion dollars in bad loans on their books.

Russian Parliament Delays

The Russian Parliament put off until Monday a critical vote on a new Government, buying more time for political negotiations as the country's economic crisis worsened. The decision came hours after Russia's Acting Prime Minister laid out his program to pull the country out of crisis. A1 

Clinton's Subdued Ireland Visit
President Clinton returned to a rainy Dublin for a low-key visit, the first trip since his warm reception there in 1995, when prospects were taking root for a lasting peace. He attended only indoor events with Irish politicians and met with workers at an American-owned computer plant. A3
 
Sentence for Rwanda Genocide
A United Nations tribunal sentenced a former Prime Minister of Rwanda, Jean Kambanda, to life in prison for his part in the 1994 genocide in Rwanda, notwithstanding his agreement last spring to plead guilty and to testify against other high-ranking officials. A4
 
Pakistan Accused of Coercion
The former lawyer for a defendant charged in the bombing of the United States Embassy in Kenya said that his client was told, while under interrogation in Pakistan, that the Government there wanted his confession in order to improve relations with the United States, which had been damaged by Pakistan's test of nuclear weapons in May. A4
 
Oil Prices Hurt Aid Program
Recent sharp drops in the price of oil have undermined a program under which Iraq can sell its oil to raise money for urgent civilian needs like food and medicine, the senior official in charge of the program told the Security Council. The official said the reduced earnings from oil sales would mean that the United Nations could not meet a higher nutritional target in food supplied to Iraqis. A5
 
North Korea Defends Launching
North Korea said the purpose of its launching of a multistage rocket on Monday was to carry a satellite into orbit, not to test a missile. It denounced Japan and other countries for concluding that it was launching a new class of missile. A5
 
Hurricane Strikes Mexico
Hurricane Isis killed at least eight people and caused devastation in two Mexican states, officials said. The Governor of the state of Sinaloa said the storm that hit the city of Los Mochis on Wednesday and Thursday had killed seven people and destroyed the houses of about 300 people. Seemingly harder hit, but with a lower death toll, was the Los Cabos region at the tip of the Baja California peninsula. (Associated Press)
 
Sierra Leone Rebel Indicted
The rebel leader who sparked Sierra Leone's civil war and whose soldiers continue to brutalize the West African nation was charged with treason and with assisting the enemy to invade Sierra Leone. If convicted, he could face the death penalty. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Analysts Warn of Dangers to Brazil's Economy

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 4

 BODY:
With Brazil's stock market in a nose dive and the Central Bank spending $1 billion a day to defend the currency, economists warned that despite the strengths of Brazil's economy, investor panic could plunge the region into decline.
Brazil's market fell by 5.8 percent today, following a decline of 8.61 percent on Thursday, its second worst in history, touched off, in part, by a downgrading of Brazilian bonds and notes by Moody's Investor Service. The markets were not soothed by an televised appeal by President Fernando Henrique Cardoso on Thursday night for a "national pact for fiscal adjustment" or by criticism of the Moody's assessment by Brazilian officials. 
 To the contrary, stocks plunged further today as a low-ranking United States Treasury official called the Brazilian currency "unarguably overvalued." The Treasury later disavowed the comments as a personal opinion not reflecting the department's policy.
Investors worldwide have been fleeing emerging markets, and Brazil has been caught in the crosscurrents. In the month of August alone, Brazilian equities fell 40 percent, with similar losses in stock exchanges around the continent.
Brazil's current account deficit hovers at nearly 4 percent of gross domestic product. The country's failure to cut Government operating expenses, particularly Civil Service costs, has put the country in a difficult position as credit tightens for emerging markets around the globe.
Citing these structural weaknesses, Moody's downgraded its rating of Brazilian bonds and notes to B2 from B1 and the ceiling for foreign currency bank deposits to Caa1. It also downgraded three Brazilian banks to C from C+.
The Brazilian Finance Minister, Pedro Malan, in Washington for a meeting of Latin finance ministers with the International Monetary Fund that ended today, lashed out at Moody's analysts, saying they were compensating for earlier optimistic ratings in Asia by turning more cautious toward Latin America.
Michel Camdessus, managing director of the fund, said that many of the problems faced by Brazil and Latin countries derived from panic elsewhere in the world rather than lack of will to take tough economic measures.
But with markets throughout the region plummeting, Mr. Camdessus acknowledged that the situation for Latin America was "dangerous." He said that "a degree of panic" among investors had led to "an excessive and unfortunate pressure" on many countries in Latin America. "It's true that if this persists, a number of countries will have to tighten their policies," Mr. Camdessus said, hurting their growth prospects.
In his speech Thursday night, Mr. Cardoso, who is favored to win re-election Oct. 4, did not announce any new initiatives. His talk restated his Government's commitment to Civil Service, social security and tax reforms that stalled during his first term. "We have to continue a program of fiscal adjustment," he said.
With roughly $58 billion in foreign reserves, Brazil has substantial resources to stabilize its currency. Under Mr. Cardoso, it has made headway toward market-oriented reforms, privatizing state industries and slaying chronic hyperinflation.
Analysts say the Central Bank has been spending an average of $1.3 billion a day since Sept. 1 to protect the Brazilian currency, the real, while today's O Globo newspaper reported international reserves had fallen $15.8 billion since Aug. 1. A spokesman for the Central Bank, usually forthcoming with information, would not confirm the figures or provide others.
Mr. Malan has ruled out a devaluation, but Brazilians are buying dollars to cover themselves. The difference between the official and informal rates of exchange has been widening, with exchange houses offering 1.27 reais against the dollar, compared with an official rate of 1.17 reais.
Under Mercosur, the southern cone customs union joining Brazil with Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay, Argentina's exports to Brazil quadrupled, and now represent more than 25 percent of its export business. With Argentina's peso pegged to dollar reserves, a devaluation in Brazil would send instant tremors through Buenos Aires. "Safely and securely, they would be in a deep crisis," said Alexandre Barros, a Brasilia-based political consultant.
Paulo Leme, economic research director of emerging markets at Goldman, Sachs, argues that industrial nations must come up with solutions, such as a lowering of United States interest rates, replenishing the International Monetary Fund's bailout capacity and restoring stability to Japan, to help emerging markets. "These are not isolated viral cases, but an epidemic," he said.
Brazilian companies are carrying a foreign debt of $108.5 billion, up from $37.3 billion three years ago. Some $11 billion will come due before next July, and if international lenders decline to renew the loans, the companies will turn to the Central Bank.
One emerging-markets specialist, who requested anonymity, said that while investment analysts picked over the differences between developing markets, investors these days acted on the similarities. Underpinning the rage for emerging markets were assumptions -- that currencies do not devalue, that countries do not default -- that have been shattered with Russia's collapse.
"The real contagion is not something I'm worried about, it's the financial contagion," the analyst said. "Everybody agrees that if the Hong Kong peg were to go, the attack on Brazil would be relentless, until there were no international reserves left."
"It's not because there's a real connection between the economies," he added. "It has everything to do with perceptions, and the psychosis of the market."
Perhaps for that reason, a letter to the editor of The Wall Street Journal from the lower-level Treasury Department official was quickly disavowed. The official, Britta Hillstrom, wrote that while "Brazil's real is unarguably overvalued, a destructive devaluation is not the only solution," and said the country could move the exchange rate band. A spokeswoman for the Treasury Department said those "were absolutely not the views of the Treasury Department."

HEADLINE: 6 Children Found Strangled After Mother Confesses to 911

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, Sept. 4

 BODY:
A mother of six, living in poverty and estranged from her husband, called 911 on Thursday night, the police said, and made a shocking statement: she had killed her children.
Police officers and paramedics rushed to her apartment and found the bodies of three girls and three boys, ages 5 to 11. The woman, Khoua Her, 24, was lying inside the doorway wearing a fancy red dress. The body of one of the children was behind her. 
 The woman was in custody at Region's Hospital here. The medical examiner's office said the children had been strangled.
In the call to 911, the woman had spoken about suicide. But it was unclear whether she had harmed herself.
As a 13-year-old girl, Khoua Her was paired with her husband in an arranged marriage in her native Laos, neighbors said. When her babies started to arrive, they came almost every year, six of them altogether.
Minnesota is a center for the Hmong, refugees from Laos who have long struggled economically. But the police and civic officials were careful to play down any notion that such a horrific event had any cultural underpinnings.
The police had been called to the apartment at least 15 times in the last 18 months for domestic turbulence.
Calling the deaths "very, very tragic," Chief William Finney of the St. Paul Police said: "We see this across cultures. It doesn't matter what culture you're from, American or otherwise."
The family lived in a two-story housing project, which is racially and ethnically mixed.
This afternoon, there was a hush and a somberness among adults and children who could not quite believe what had happened.
Not long after the deaths, more than 150 people gathered outside Thursday night. A voice called out for respect, pleading, "Can we get a moment of silence for these six angels that's gone?" The Star Tribune reported.
In recent months the woman's husband, Tou Hang, had left the apartment, and she had been dating another man, neighbors said. One neighbor said she saw Ms. Her "scoop up the kids" and chase them inside when he came to call recently.
Chief Finney acknowledged the many police visits to the apartment for domestic violence, but said, "There was never any indication the children were in this kind of danger." Police records show at least eight calls to the apartment since January.
Mai Xiong, a friend of the woman's new boyfriend, told reporters that the mother loved her children, but that she had regretted marrying to young.
The friend she Ms. Her was "depressed over the amount of responsibility she had."
She told The Star Tribune: "She basically missed out on all her teen-age years. She wanted to have fun." She added, "I always thought of her as kind of odd, but I didn't think this would ever happen."
A neighbor, Christopher Yang, said the parents had taken turns taking care of the children. He described the mother as "someone who was not really taking care of her kids," saying that she would sometimes leave the apartment without taking them.
The children were scheduled to return to school next week.
Minnesota has long been a center of resettlement for refugees, largely because of the work of Lutheran Social Services and other religious organizations. Thousands of refugees from Somalia have settled in Minneapolis in recent years.
The Hmong have had a difficult time in America. Most are poor and illiterate, and street gangs have been growing among their young people. Arranged marriages are common in the Hmong culture. In general, the Hmong people do not mix very much among other cultures.
Neighbors said the family had lived in St. Paul for several years.
Mayor Norm Coleman of St. Paul described the deaths as "a tragedy of overwhelming proportion," adding, "We're all shaken, the community is shaken."
The police identified the dead children as Kouaeai Hang, 11; Samson Hang, 9; Nali Hang, 9; Tang Lung Hang, 7; Aee Hang, 6; and Tang Ke Hang, 5.
The apartment building was roped off with yellow police tape today, and few of the children played in the playgrounds.
"There's usually a lot of kids playing," said Sade Kelly, 12. "Now it's kind of empty."

HEADLINE: Clinton Says He Is 'Very Sorry' After Senator's Harsh Criticism

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: DUBLIN, Sept. 4

 BODY:
Forced again on this five-day foreign trip to confront questions about the Lewinsky scandal, President Clinton said today that he "basically" agreed with Senator Joseph I. Lieberman who on Thursday criticized the President's conduct as "immoral" and "disgraceful."
And for the first time, Mr. Clinton said he was "very sorry about" his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, describing it as "indefensible." 
 In a picture-taking session this morning with the Prime Minister of Ireland, Bertie Ahern, Mr. Clinton was asked about Mr. Lieberman's remarks on the floor of the Senate.
"I've been briefed on them and basically I agree with what he said," Mr. Clinton said.
He was clearly prepared for the questions and his manner displayed no suggestion of unease or defensiveness, standing casually with his hands clasped behind his back as Prime Minister Ahern looked on.
"I've already said that I made a bad mistake, it was indefensible and I'm sorry about it. So I have nothing else to say except that I can't disagree with anyone else who wants to be critical of what I have already acknowledged was indefensible."
Pressed by reporters, Mr. Clinton added, "There's nothing that he or anyone else could say in a personally critical way that I -- that I don't imagine that I would disagree with, since I have already said it myself, to myself. And I'm very sorry about it. There's nothing else I could say."
In Washington today, Senator Lieberman, a Connecticut Democrat, said he appreciated Mr. Clinton's apology, but added that the President would have to say more. "It doesn't end with a single statement," Mr. Lieberman said. Page A8
Aides said after the President spoke that his remarks were part of a deliberate effort to convey remorse and to placate critics who say that Mr. Clinton has not sufficiently apologized for his actions. The critics, many of them in the President's own party, have said Mr. Clinton has inflamed the crisis by continuing to attack Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel whose investigation exposed the Lewinsky relationship and Mr. Clinton's lies about it. Mr. Clinton made no reference today to the investigation that threatens his Presidency.
Mr. Lieberman suggested on Thursday that Mr. Clinton's transgressions were so severe that the Senate might feel compelled to formally condemn them in a vote of censure or other official action.
Mr. Clinton responded, "I just don't want to comment on that. I shouldn't be commenting on that while I'm on this trip, and I don't think that, my understanding is that was not a decision that was made or advocated clearly yesterday."
He added, "If that's not an issue, I don't want to make it one, one way or the other. I don't think that's appropriate right now."
For the second time on this trip to Russia and Ireland, Mr. Clinton's comments on the Lewinsky matter overshadowed the scripted message of the day, which today was supposed to be on progress toward peace in Northern Ireland and prospects for economic growth in the Republic of Ireland.
On Wednesday, Mr. Clinton faced questions on the affair in a Kremlin news conference with Boris N. Yeltsin, the besieged President of Russia. On that occasion, Mr. Clinton said he believed he had already expressed his "profound regret to all who were hurt" by the Lewinsky scandal.
Aides said Mr. Clinton knew he would confront the issue again today after Mr. Lieberman's statement. Erskine B. Bowles, the White House chief of staff, tried to persuade Mr. Lieberman to delay his remarks until after Mr. Clinton returned to Washington on Saturday night, but Mr. Lieberman declined, said Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary.
Mr. Clinton spoke to Mr. Lieberman about the Senator's concerns before he left Washington, but he, too, failed to persuade Mr. Lieberman to withhold public judgment, Mr. McCurry said. Mr. Clinton, the aides said, chose his words carefully today as part of a strategy to apologize for his actions, without offering any fuller explanation for them.
Mr. Clinton went to bed on Thursday night unaware of Mr. Lieberman's comments, Mr. McCurry said. The President was informed of the statement this morning, and he discussed possible responses with Mr. Bowles and other senior advisers.
"He made very clear how he wanted to respond, and that's what he did," Mr. McCurry said. He added that there was no special significance to the President's saying he was "sorry" twice in his responses this morning.
"He believes that that's what he's been saying all along," Mr. McCurry said. "Saying you're sorry means you're sorry."
But the President knows that his further statement of regret will not put the matter to rest, Mr. McCurry added. "He's got a very realistic outlook" on Mr. Starr's investigation, the continuing debate in Congress and among the public about the Lewinsky relationship, and the certainty that he will continue to face media questions about this issue at every turn.
Mr. McCurry said the President had been calling Democratic leaders and other supporters in hopes of preventing further desertions like Mr. Lieberman's. But the job of repairing the breach with members of his party, and the public, will not be easy and will not be accomplished quickly, Mr. McCurry acknowledged.
"I think the President clearly does not believe that one conversation, one statement, one speech, is going to be sufficient in addressing this matter the way he wants to, and he intends to keep addressing it both personally and, to the degree he needs to, publicly, as he sees fit," Mr. McCurry said.
But there is, for now, no firm plan for how the President intends to try to put the Lewinsky matter to rest. The President is trying to find an escape from the credibility crisis he generated by his own actions and false statements, Mr. McCurry said.
"This is such an intensely personal thing, and the President is deciding for himself how to address these matters," Mr. McCurry said. "And so there can't be any concrete plan that I'm aware of because the President is taking it one day at a time."
Mr. McCurry said there had been no discussion "whatsoever" among Mr. Clinton and his advisers about the President's resignation.
The President said in April that he would "never" resign. Asked if Mr. Clinton had reconsidered in light of recent revelations, Mr. McCurry replied, "I am confident his attitude has not changed on that."

HEADLINE: A Tradition Remade in Brooklyn;
West Indians Prepare a Lavish, and Popular, Pageant

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA and GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
A Brooklyn block lined with auto repair shops becomes an open-air rehearsal studio for three competing orchestras. As dusk falls on Parkside Avenue, quick, trained hands strike rows upon rows of carefully tuned oil barrels, mallets are beat on rusty tire irons, and the warm summer nights fill up with the syncopated sounds of calypso.
In the one corner of a shop where the roof has not yet collapsed from rain, a man who makes his living as a security guard constructs tall, baroque costumes out of cardboard and peacock feathers. Nearby, teen-agers brought up on basketball and Biggie Smalls spend the evening mastering the steel-band songs of their Caribbean parents. 
 A New World tradition is being remade once more in New York: the Caribbean heart of Brooklyn is getting ready for its annual late-summer Carnival, the city's biggest, most extravagant parade.
On Monday morning, in the 31st annual West Indian American Day Carnival along Eastern Parkway from Utica Avenue to Grand Army Plaza, schoolteachers and nannies will shed their workday clothes for skimpy thongs and dreamy costumes. The grandchildren of migrants from the American South will play steel drum with the children of Trinidadian immigrants. In a distinctly Brooklyn mix, Haitian rara bands with their goatskin drums will file among the tassa drummers, and mammoth trucks will roll down the Parkway, blasting soca and reggae.
What began as a small, homespun celebration in Harlem in the 1930's has grown into a pageant surpassing older, better-known processions like the St. Patrick's Day or the Puerto Rican Day parades -- a reflection of the surging immigration from the islands. Today, New York City is home to an estimated 600,000 Caribbean-Americans, the bulk of them in Brooklyn.
But the growth of the parade, and its dozens of attendant parties, concerts and competitions, is more than a testament to rising Caribbean immigration. It is also a reflection of how many Caribbean immigrants who ignored, even snubbed, the rites of Carnival in Trinidad or Grenada have embraced it here, both as a way to recall the home they left behind and to keep their children in the Caribbean fold.
Brooklyn's West Indian parade draws an estimated two million people, in comparison with the million or so who come out for the Thanksgiving Day Parade in Manhattan. The city's Convention and Visitors Bureau now includes it on its list of Labor Day weekend attractions, and New Yorkers with no ties to the islands come to watch and, increasingly, to don costumes in the masquerade bands, to play "mas" as it is called.
In a nod to the political power of Caribbean New Yorkers, the parade has become a mandatory campaign stop. Banners pitching beer and long-distance telephone service now stretch along the parade route. And for the last three years, the parade has been broadcast live on local television, this year on WNBC, with a kind of cultural play-by-play by one of Trinidad's most prominent masquerade designers, Peter Minshall.
The evolution of the parade also speaks volumes for how old-country rituals are reinvented, Brooklyn-style.
Yvonne Barnes, 60, a transplanted Trinidadian whose children and grandchildren now join her on Eastern Parkway, likened the Brooklyn parade to a tasty fruit-flavored drink. "With the grapyness," was how she put it, "but not the grape."
Indeed, carnival scholars and revelers say, the Brooklyn parade is in many ways a different kind of concoction altogether. For one thing, it is an American-style march, not a series of free-floating processions as in Port of Spain, the capital of Trinidad and Tobago, where this Carnival was born. To accommodate television, the parade here must stick to a schedule, and marshals must keep dancers from veering off the route.
"Oh, they used to be extremely careless about scheduling," recalled Major R. Owens, the United States Representative from Crown Heights who made his first appearance at the parade 18 years ago. "It was supposed to start at 11 o'clock, and it wouldn't start till 1."
Since then, considerable effort has been made to bring the parade in line with a tighter schedule, install portable toilets and police barricades, and garner corporate donations.
But the growth of the parade has also sown dissension between the organizers and some of the band leaders, particularly over how to pay for this phenomenally expensive affair. The West Indian Day Carnival Association, the organizer, says the weekend-long bacchanal now costs nearly a half-million dollars; for some of the bigger masquerade bands, like the 1,000-member Hawks International, the costumes and sound equipment necessary for a few hours on the Parkway cost $50,0O0. This year, organizers expect 30 such bands.
While the city does not estimate the parade's economic impact, there are a few budding efforts to use the Carnival as an engine of economic development. Una Clarke, the City Councilwoman from Crown Heights, for instance, has proposed a program to generate year-round jobs for the Carnival costume-makers. Mr. Owens is seeking to build a Caribbean-American cultural museum with an office for parade organizers.
Corporations with an interest in the Caribbean-American market have begun to capitalize on the parade, with companies like Western Union, AT&T and Mobil sponsoring some of the larger masquerade bands as well as the parade itself. "It's relevant to our target audience, and we want to be part of it," said Anthony Smith, the Mobil Corporation's manager for diversity marketing and community relations.
The parade has also fueled the resurgence of another Trinidadian rite. For the last several years, Trinidadians hankering for less structure and more steel bands have turned to a free-spirited predawn pageant called J'ouvert, which since slavery times has been a venue for drums, dance and social commentary.
In Brooklyn, J'ouvert -- a French-derived term pronounced joo-VAY and loosely translated as "I open," as in the opening of Carnival -- has grown by leaps and bounds in the last few years. It now draws about 50,000 people to a parking lot behind the Brooklyn Museum, but so far, no politicians. Amplified music is barred, leaving only the peals of the steel pan to break the cool silence of the night.
For J'ouvert this year, Tricia Mayhew and her friends will slather themselves from head to toe with red paint and dance under the stars. Ms. Mayhew, a 27-year-old high school science teacher, has joined the parade on the Parkway ever since she left Trinidad, 11 years ago. But she has not played J'ouvert like this since she was a child.
"Catching all those faces and listening to the steel bands, you get that original feeling," she said. "We've gotten so commercialized now. But to watch these musicians play these notes, you just marvel. You feel a sense of more freedom."
If the growth of Carnival is a function of a conventional immigrant narrative -- doing in this country what one did at home -- the opposite is also true. Many have delved into the rites of Carnival only after leaving home.
As a Catholic school student in Trinidad, Kathy Clarke was allowed only a glimpse of the masquerading revelers at Carnival time. She never covered herself in paint on J'ouvert morning. And she would never have been caught in the neighborhood pan yard, whiling away her evenings with the pan men -- and it once was only men -- who were considered "hooligans," she said.
Now, both her college-age son and daughter play steel drum. And Ms. Clarke, a middle school teacher from East Flatbush who moved to New York in 1979, serves as sort of a den mother for their band, the Invaders. She joins her children as they play pan on J'ouvert morning and then rushes home to change into costume for the parade.
"People tell me this -- you're lucky you can keep kids in the culture," she said the other day, as her daughter, Dominique, 20, practiced on a six-headed bass drum in the backyard of an East Flatbush preschool.
If parents look to steel band as a way to keep their children "in the culture," the music now also fills a void in neighborhoods where sports, arts and other recreational programs for young people have all but dried up.
On a recent Sunday evening, the pan yard of the Sesame Flyers steel band in Flatbush was bustling. Bass drums were spray-painted gold. The chrome tenor drums were rubbed until they shone. Later in the evening, they would play on Church Avenue, and people would pour out of their hot apartments to stroll and listen.
Teen-agers now form the core of many bands in Brooklyn. Roots-seeking may be important to their parents, but the young people are drawn to the pan yard by other things. They come so they can stay out with friends long past their curfew. They come because they feel safe, because the pan yard, they say, is like family. Mostly, they come for the music.
Anthony (Mike) Patten, the captain of the Sesame Flyers, remembered when the steel pan first pulled him in. Even though his father played pan as a young man in Belize, Mr. Patten discovered it only serendipitously. He was a sophomore in high school back then, and he was giving rides to a neighbor who played pan at a youth center on Flatbush Avenue. "The energy was amazing," he said, his eyes lighting up at the memory. "It was kind of infectious."
It was infectious enough to bring Mr. Patten, now 25, back to Brooklyn after college in Connecticut. It is also apparently infectious enough to draw teen-agers to the pan yard every night of the week, until well past midnight, all summer long -- and to give up every Friday and Saturday night during the school year as well.
Kelvin Browne, 16, has been playing for nearly seven years, often riding the bus for a half-hour each way to get his hands on a tenor drum.
"Something got stuck on me," he said. "Having something to play, having fun, hanging out. In the end, it's worth it."

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
ACHESON: The Secretary of State Who Created the American World, by James Chace. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) An engrossing biography of a public servant whose vision, self-confidence and personal integrity are still enshrined in international institutions and American attitudes.
 
AND BOTH SHALL ROW: A Novella and Stories, by Beth Lordan. (Picador USA, $21.) A collection, in an assured and distinctive voice, about relentlessly unglamorous characters whose experiences go beyond words and cannot be named, though Lordan is able to describe them.
 
ECOLOGY OF FEAR: Los Angeles and the Imagination of Disaster, by Mike Davis. (Metropolitan/Holt, $27.50.) When the current, historically anomalous habitability of Los Angeles departs, Davis predicts, ways will be found to blame the poor for the natural disasters and the consequences that ensue.
 
KAATERSKILL FALLS, by Allegra Goodman. (Dial, $23.95.) Little actually happens in this first novel, but the author discovers form and sensibility in the small excitements and grand rhythms of life in an Orthodox Jewish community.
 
THE MOURNERS' BENCH, by Susan Dodd. (Morrow, $24.) A novel in which two working-class sisters in the South and a male teacher from Yankeeland assume tragic configurations, from which the survivors are able to escape by humor, irony and real interest in what's happening.
 
THE MURDER OF HELEN JEWETT: The Life and Death of a Prostitute in Nineteenth-Century New York, by Patricia Cline Cohen. (Knopf, $27.50.) A meticulous investigation of an 1836 crime, once notorious because its probable perpetrator was acquitted through what looked like male privilege.
 
SLOW MOTION: A True Story, by Dani Shapiro. (Random House, $23.95.) The cautionary confessions of a former spoiled, self-destructive rich kid who discovered that life is earnest when her parents were involved in a catastrophe.
 
SUMMER OF DELIVERANCE: A Memoir of Father and Son, by Christopher Dickey. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) An angry, affectionate, hypnotic account of conflict and reconciliation between a son and his father, the brilliant literary celebrity and impassioned, inveterate liar James Dickey.
 
THE TENNIS PARTNER: A Doctor's Story of Friendship and Loss, by Abraham Verghese. (HarperCollins, $25.) A wise, lyrical, controlled narrative about tennis, medicine and friendship and their spiritual costs and benefits.
 
VAST EMOTIONS AND IMPERFECT THOUGHTS, by Rubem Fonseca. (Ecco, $24.) An engaging Brazilian novel whose hero, a movie director, is uncomfortably close to a murder and ungovernably obsessed with Isaac Babel's fiction.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 5; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 2005 words

HEADLINE: The Rape of the West

BYLINE: By Timothy Foote; Timothy Foote is a senior editor and writer at Smithsonian magazine.

 BODY:

LASSO THE WIND
Away to the New West.
 By Timothy Egan.
 266 pp. New York:
 Alfred A. Knopf. $25. 
 "In my book a pioneer is a man who turned all the grass upside down, strung bob-wire over the dust that was left, poisoned the water, cut down the trees, killed the Indian who owned the land and called it progress." Timothy Egan is quoting a surprising source, the celebrated cowboy artist Charles Russell. But he could as easily be quoting himself. In "Lasso the Wind," Egan, a national correspondent for The New York Times, alternately comes on as a Jeremiah with notebook and running shoes, and the Peck's Bad Boy of the New West. "I'm in Big Timber, breakfasting at the Road Kill Cafe," he writes, after pridefully describing the "nosebleed" section of the high Rockies as "one of the few places left in the world where bears still eat people, semiregularly."
Egan grew up in Washington State. In an earlier book, "The Good Rain," he wrote eloquently about what has been done to salmon, Indians and the environment in the Pacific Northwest. Now, on a larger canvas, he rages against big ranchers, mine owners, dam builders, real estate moguls, timbermen and, of course, the dead-hand grip still exerted by the Legend of the Old West, which he sees as a "pitiful excuse for a history," a brief, shameful period (1846-90) driven by greed, lawlessness and attempted genocide.
Environmentalists and revisionist historians have been making similar points for quite a while; often, it seems, because however ghastly the past may have been, the historians wanted us to know that women, blacks and Indians played their part. Initially, "Lasso the Wind" promises more: a kind of reflective reportorial tour of the 11 states "on the sunset side of the 100th meridian," in which Egan manages to come to tentative conclusions about the elusive New West. He makes 14 stops, two each in Arizona, Montana, New Mexico and Utah, one in Nevada, Colorado, Idaho, Oregon, Washington and (last) California, a place where, he writes in Delphic mode, "it is a quick ride from the Geography of Hope to the cliff of fear."
Effete Easterners will possibly want to fly out West, rent a car and follow in Egan's footsteps as he describes zinging around in the wide open spaces. Drop in, as he does, on a local hero of the Sagebrush Rebellion in Catron County, N.M. (Catron is one of several places where ranchers claim that the Government has no right to charge them for grazing cattle on public land, even though the fees they pay are so low as to amount to what Egan, with much company, regards as a Federal subsidy of a dying industry). Move north to Lake Havasu City, Ariz., where London Bridge, transported stone by stone, was reassembled in the midst of an ersatz English village. Head on up to that water-guzzling urban monstrosity, Las Vegas, as the Sands Hotel (the iniquitous landmark of many a Sinatra-struck youth) is blown sky high by ambitious developers. Hike with him in the burning rock country of southern Utah as he looks for petroglyphs. Egan is a connoisseur of rock drawings, and a man wild about wilderness. When he finds a splendid glyph covered by wire mesh to protect it from possible vandalism, he is deeply cast down. "No longer wild," he writes, "it was as if it had been put in a zoo."
Any reader of "The Good Rain" will recognize here Egan's nimble skipping between past and present, his high-powered invocations of natural scenery, his easy grip on the geography of hills and rivers, as well as a talent for writing in provocative sound bites. It is soon clear that a good deal of the book will be less a journal of inquiry than a didactic tour. He wants us to understand that the upstart West does too have an ancient history. A section somewhat brassily labeled "Plymouth Rock West" gets into Coronado's armed incursion into New Mexico in the 1540's, then Don Juan de Onate's savage assault in 1598 on the ancient Indian hill town of Acoma, which Egan describes as the "first battle over religious freedom in what is now the United States."
Soon he is off to fast-growing Douglas County, outside Denver, where the optimistic Ken Turnbull hopes to turn ostrich steak into America's preferred protein. The creatures weigh 340 pounds, run 40 miles an hour, are cheap to feed and can kick a coyote to death. Egan lightens up a bit, imagining a past in which John Wayne et al. try to herd these unherdable birds. But comic relief is not in sight. For, in addition to low-life cowboys, 19th-century railroad barons, merciless copper-mining kings and powerful cattlemen then and now, Egan has it in for the cow itself. An alien creature that was imported from England after the longhorn cattle died out, the cow, he insists, has ruined the rivers, overgrazed and stomped bare the once-green ranges of the West.
Egan does not make the argument of the reformist author Jeremy Rifkin. In "Beyond Beef: The Rise and Fall of Cattle Culture," Rifkin insisted that raising cattle to eat not only bids fair to destroy the South American rain forest but is also bringing starvation to many parts of the world because it is a much less efficient use of land (in terms of feeding people) than growing grain. Egan's grudge against cows seems more personal, and deeper, than such standard environmentalist complaints. He apparently wants them banished -- to be replaced not by ostrich but by bison (read: buffaloburgers), once wantonly destroyed and now making a mild comeback with help from Ted Turner and a few Indian tribes. "Unlike cattle," Egan writes, "bison know how to drink from a stream without destroying it; their hooves are thin, and they don't lie around in . . . mudflats, aswarm with flies, waiting to be herded off to the next meal."
Worse than cattle, as he sees it, is the West's continued misuse of water. Instead of "following the plow," as the creators of various Homestead Acts officially hoped it would, water mostly "flows uphill to money." The result is dams on every Western river except the Yellowstone. Seven states have water rights in the mighty Colorado. The United States, in fact, has more than 75,000 dams. When it comes to curtailing the flow of Western rivers, Egan works in the shadow of Edward Abbey, who in his novel "The Monkey Wrench Gang" created a lively crew bent on blowing up the 710-foot-high Glen Canyon Dam. In Egan's view dams deform nature's rivers, drown great scenery, destroy ancient Indian relics and play hob with wilderness, wildlife -- especially migrating salmon -- and the ecosystem in general. And for what? Often, Egan insists, not to make the desert bloom for the deserving small homesteaders but to further line the pockets of the undeserving rich, among them land speculators who create unsustainably huge, air-conditioned cities -- Phoenix in particular -- in unlivably dry and hot places.
Western water is still allocated to a remarkable degree by what Egan memorably calls the "hydro-extension of gold-fever grubstaking," or the doctrine of "first in time, first in line," meaning that if, historically, you had first crack at a river's water you always have considerable say in its use. Distribution rights have been modified, but not enough, and in the past have set states at virtual war with one another. As Egan notes, quoting Mark Twain, "Whisky is for drinking, water is for fighting over." He predicts that unsustainable Las Vegas, which squanders millions of gallons from great artesian wells that belong to the Paiute Indians and siphons more and more from Lake Mead, will end up having to be protected by the National Guard. In 100 years it will be gone, he says. In 500 years "archeologists will be puzzling over the site of the Sands."
About the misuse, unfairness and chicanery involved in distribution of Western water rights past and present, few will disagree. How to fix the problem will involve more than ironic cries of outrage. Water involves a struggle for a crucial, limited resource, as well as a quasi-religious war between those who hold the earth holy and those who don't -- at present the vast majority of a huge population whose very existence is a greater threat to the environment than the bad guys in black hats Egan constantly blames. Implicitly, he seems to be an old-fashioned populist who can hardly imagine that once freed from the evil grip of greedy special interests "the people" might side against him.
Egan takes a measure of cheer from the fact that just in the last several years a few dams have been scheduled for demolition, while others are under (often acrimonious) discussion. His book would have profited, I think, from examining a few more dam cases and looking closely at who actually uses the power America's dams generate -- an estimated 10 percent of the country's total electricity, and 90 percent of our renewable energy.
"Lasso the Wind" is at its most attractive, and least polemical, toward the end, when Egan gets back on his home turf. In the Northwest, he really knows the people, and shows affection for them -- even when they disagree with him. In Joseph, Ore. (named for the remarkable Nez Perce chief), he finds an angry crowd: frustrated ranchers and timber men, along with large numbers of the local unemployed, are protesting the Endangered Species Act and a plan to make Hells Canyon into a national park. Everyday people "know the New West is inevitable," Egan writes. "They just don't know what their role will be in it." What they don't want is "to become bit players in a new economy, flipping buffaloburgers for mountain bikers from the city." Still, his advice is essentially to forget the old and, as he sees it, doomed economy of cattle, timber and mining, and go along with the New West flow, forsaking angry caricatures like "yuppie scum."
Moving even closer to home, he finds his vision of a peaceable and prosperous future. Sunnyside, Wash., he says, is a place where "much of the West" is headed. Sunnyside is awash in Hispanic immigrants, new and old, already almost 65 percent of the population. In the West "entire valleys, counties, cities have, almost overnight, become majority Latino," with more to come. What Egan has in mind is nothing less than a regional multicultural melting pot, with Latinos enriching the customs and language of the United States but becoming old-fashioned Americans at the same time, as they are now doing locally in many parts of the country. Indians at last will be somewhat integrated into local society, and everyone will do O.K. with espresso bars, heritage tourist centers, rodeos, art and music shops, microbrew and jazz festivals and stores that sell both snakeskin cowboy boots and Mexican guitars.
It is a warmhearted vision, though not entirely compelling, even if you factor in, as he rarely seems to, all sorts of high-tech projects now sprouting in the New West. This is, after all, an age in which we are constantly reminded that the melting pot no longer works. Many minority groups come equipped with lawyers dedicated to divisive self-interest. And since Egan himself invokes the centuries-long presence of Latinos in the West, it may be fair to note that, for whatever reason, most Hispanic countries of the New World have yet to show a real gift for stable parliamentary democracy.
The one convincingly upbeat moment in this heartfelt jeremiad of a book comes, appropriately enough, not from the works of man but from the resilience of nature. In his final chapter, Egan is floating down a stretch of California's American River, where gold was found in 1848, setting off what he sees as the plundering of the West in the name of greed and commerce. Reckless mining and sluicing totally ruined the river. After looking at late-19th-century pictures of it, Egan writes, "Kuwait after it was torched and bombed in the gulf war may have looked better." But the river refused to die, and now it is beautiful and tranquil, clean and full of wildlife. Why? Because it has been left entirely alone.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 3; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 858 words

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
In Chinatown, Preserving The Past or the Present?

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
MOST visitors to this city's teeming, colorful Chinatown would probably never notice Hang Ah Alley. A concrete corridor between a restaurant and a playground, it looks like nothing more than a broad, tidy sidewalk, spruced up with a few adolescent trees and several new wooden benches.
But those trees and benches, along with several informational legends carved into the immaculately polished pavement, signal the recently completed renovation of the passageway, the first of 31 alleys in Chinatown scheduled to get face lifts over the next few years with $2.9 million of city money. 
 The campaign to make over the alleys reflects the constant efforts, marked by enduring angst, to keep Chinatown, San Francisco's second most popular tourist destination, at once authentic and accessible, historic and modern, redolent of tradition without being petrified in the past.
Over the last two decades, Chinatown has changed slowly but surely, in small increments that have yielded big results. Its architecture and adornments have in many ways grown less flamboyantly distinctive -- the golden, curled eaves on the corners of buildings less prominent, the individualized woodwork and tile patterns on the facades of many stores less common.
Plastic, glass, economy and efficiency have challenged, if not quite usurped, showmanship. And relentless tourism has wrought the same effect on Chinatown that it has on Fisherman's Wharf, San Francisco's most popular destination for visitors, which lies just a few miles away.
In both places, what began as a working neighborhood devoted to a particular enterprise or ethnicity has been homogenized, at least in part, into an all-purpose visitors' bazaar, rife with T-shirts and trinkets.
"It's just all mumble-jumbled," said Enid Lim, a longtime resident. "The food markets have moved to the fringes, and the merchandise that the shops in the center are selling is schlocky."
Ms. Lim belongs to the Chinatown Community Development Center, a group trying to steer the future of Chinatown in a direction that respects its past. The alleys are one of the group's projects, and they represent the nexis of historic preservation and contemporary adaptation.
On the one hand, the alley project is designed to restore to use a network of commercial passageways, lined by tiny shops with doors but no display windows, that were traditionally as vital to many Chinatown residents as the major avenues.
On the other hand, the project gives a nod to the interests of tourists, festooning the alleys with historical lessons.
"Hang Ah means fragrant in Chinese," explains the carved letters on one of a series of legends that a person walks over while traversing Hang Ah Alley. The alley got this name, the legend explains, "when a German chemist opened a perfumery."
But while the alley renovation has been greeted with almost unanimous approval, other bids at historic preservation have not always been so popular. For example, attempts over the last two decades to have Chinatown declared a historic district failed, in large part because many merchants, property owners and developers worried about building restrictions and other rules that would impede profitability.
That opposition shone a light on an ongoing tension in Chinatown: Is it best servedby letting it adapt to market forces, the way other neighborhoods do -- or by conserving its more individual characteristics?
Philip Choy, another longtime Chinatown resident, said that too much conservation was an impediment, an insult of sorts.
"It's like saying we're people in this little artificial zoo for visitors to see," Mr. Choy said. He added that he used the word artificial because what is commonly perceived as traditionally Chinese about Chinatown's architecture is, in fact, an invention to please outsiders. "It was never really Chinese in the first place," he said. "It was pseudo-Chinese."
Indeed, Mr. Choy and other historians of Chinatown noted that most of the brightly lighted pagodas and fancifully detailed buildings were constructed after the 1906 earthquake, in a calculated attempt by Chinese residents to stave off city officials' plans to move them out of the city center. The idea was to create a neighborhood so appealing and idiosyncratic that no one would want to dismantle it.
But time, tourism and soaring real estate values around San Francisco's Financial District, which threatens to encroach on Chinatown, have done some of what city officials at the turn of the century could not. In a few cases, small stores have ceded their lots to office towers; in other cases, the Chinese stationery store with its ornate bronze door, or the Chinese grocer with his pungent, savory offerings, has been replaced by the glass-walled electronics shop.
Those changes sit uneasily with many of the estimated 15,000 residents of Chinatown, about 85 percent of whom are Chinese. "Chinatown is not just for tourists," said Rose Pak, a consultant to the Chinese Chamber of Commerce. "It's still for living. The question is how can we maintain the character and integrity of Chinatown while keeping it functional?"

SECTION: Section 5; Page 5; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2681 words

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
In Minnesota, Due North

BYLINE: By DAISANN McLANE; DAISANN McLANE writes about music and culture.

 BODY:
THE urge to strap on 10 pounds of gear and walk boldly through thickets of pine trees and mosquitoes is not something that often overcomes this suburban- and city-bred traveler. But in late summer the New York air coagulated into a steamy soup, and a wilder landscape began insisting its way into my daydreams: a steep trail marked by carefully stacked stones, an icy lake dotted with aluminum canoes, the rustle of leaves and invisible critters. Ruefully, I realized where my imagination was taking me -- to my Girl Scout sleepaway camp in New Jersey, circa 1966.
I knew there was no way back (the condo developers had seen to that), yet I still craved those deep, idyllic childhood woods where I'd learned to build a fire, pilot a canoe and sing "Kumbaya." Where to find them? And, most important, because I am no longer inclined to rough it in pup tents and cook over a Coleman stove, where could I find a bargain wilderness with a double bed and private bath or shower? 
 Early one morning, the answer came as I leafed through the newspaper at breakfast. "Northwest Airlines Fare Sale," read an ad that listed cut-rate deals to that airline's home cities in Minnesota.
Minnesota! Coffee speeded up the free associations -- lakes . . . Lake Superior . . . the North Woods -- and I reached for the phone.
Three weeks later, in mid-August, I was in a Chevrolet Cavalier driving northeast toward the Canadian border on Highway 61 out of Duluth -- where Northwest flew me for $302 round trip from La Guardia. Thick stands of pine and aspen rose to my left, and to my right, Lake Superior's waves lapped a pebbled shore. The day was hot, but the air was crisp and tingly, and clouds feathered the sky. On the car radio, Bob Dylan, Minnesota's favorite musical son, was crooning "Tangled Up in Blue." The wail of his harmonica seemed the perfect soundtrack for my trip into Minnesota's Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness, a network of hundreds of interconnected lakes, and the Superior Hiking Trail, a 226-mile wilderness track only a few miles above Highway 61's lifeline of small towns, hotels and restaurants. It was also music to a city slicker's ears, more reassuring than my dusty, little-used Swiss mountaineering boots rattling around in the trunk every time I hit a bump on the two-lane highway.
Although I'd had no trouble finding a cheap ticket to Minnesota, negotiating my way into the North Woods -- via the Lake Superior port town of Grand Marais, 120 miles north of Duluth -- was another story. To get the discounted fare, I had to fly into Duluth around midnight Wednesday, and return at 7 A.M. the following Monday. But Duluth's major auto rental chains weren't open for business when I needed to get and return a car. There was no public transportation. Just when I'd about given up on the whole plan, a chance call to the Duluth Chamber of Commerce tipped me to a local car rental agency, U-Save. Byron Kleimola, U-Save's manager, said he'd be glad to bring the car to my hotel the morning after my arrival (he even faxed me the numbers of some inexpensive hotels near the airport, from which I chose an Econo Lodge that cost $44 a night). Best of all, he'd arrange for me to return the car at the crack of dawn the following Monday morning.
"You can just leave it in the short-term airport parking lot unlocked with the keys under the visor," Mr. Kleimola said.
(Sharp intake of breath from aghast native New Yorker). "Er . . . unlocked?"
"Yep. Sure. Never had any problems before," he said, sounding a bit puzzled.
When he offered me the low rate of $24.99 a day for the four-day rental, I began to wonder what other surprises Minnesota would hold.
"Busy up here today isn't it, always is in summer," said the fellow strolling the main street of Two Harbors, the first stop on the three-hour drive to that night's destination, the Rockwood Lodge on Gunflint Trail. Two Harbors, with its two traffic lights and nearly deserted harbor seemed almost abandoned.
Outside Buddy's Wild Rice -- a store that sells rice, jams, honey and large wooden statues of bears and moose called "chainsaw art" -- a line of kitschy-looking homemade windmills whirred in the brisk breeze. I had to yell for someone. In what I was coming to understand as North Woods etiquette, the shop was left wide open, unlocked and unattended. I paid the clerk for a jar of creamy honey made from blueberry blossoms ($3.99), and hit the road again.
The traffic got sparser and the towns smaller as I continued north through a landscape that reminded me of the rural mid-Atlantic of 30 years ago -- the only things missing were the Burma-Shave signs. Along the road, brightly painted cottages converted for commercial use sold bait and tackle, or wood carvings, or homemade blueberry pie and locally smoked fish. Although I meandered, few cars sped to overtake me. The drive up Highway 61 is known for its spectacular scenery, and no drivers seemed inclined to rush it. Every few miles a marker and a turnoff signaled a parking area, and yet another gorgeous view of trees, rocks, lake and water's edge foam. I couldn't help but wish that I was traveling a few weeks later, for although what I saw was beautiful, during foliage season (mid-September) I knew it would be breathtaking.
I'd selected the Rockwood Lodge and Outfitters on a list that the Ranger Station of the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness faxed to me in New York. Rockwood is on the shore of Poplar Lake, about 35 miles up Gunflint Trail, a narrow paved road that runs uphill and inland from the Lake Superior harbor town of Grand Marais. I pulled in, and instantly was transported back to my camp days; the tiny wooden cabins tucked among the pines beside the dark lake recaptured my childhood memories.
Poplar Lake isn't part of the Boundary Waters, but it's a popular entry point to dozens of smaller lakes in the Government-protected preserve.
No motorboats are allowed on these waters, where canoers portage their gear and boats from lake to lake, as they've done since the pre-Colonial days when Ojibway Indians and voyageurs hunted beaver in these woods. Rockwood's clients are mainly fishing enthusiasts and wilderness buffs from Minnesota who come up for overnight trips, which require a permit.
I didn't have the time for that -- and I feared I didn't have the skill either. So I arranged to stay overnight in Rockwood's plain but comfortable bunkhouse with private bath ($40), and spend a day exploring Poplar Lake with its 27 islands by canoe (rental $25).
The details of my first hour alone on Poplar Lake in a two-man, 57-pound We-noh-nah canoe are best left untold (let's just say that if the lake had been the "Wheel of Fortune," my canoe would have been the spinner). But gradually, slowly, my Girl Scout chops kicked in -- and, fortunately, Mark, the outfitting assistant, figured out that putting a heavy rock in the bow would help counteract the stiff headwind.
With the ballast in place, I flew across the lake, rounded a series of wooded islands, and steered through a channel into a narrow arm of water. It was silent, except for the wind and an occasional loon, and once I pulled out of sight of the lodge, I was utterly, completely alone.
Thanks to Mark's careful directions, I found the entry for the portage to Meads Lake, dragged my canoe ashore over rocks, and sat down to rest for a moment -- until a squadron of hungry Minnesota black mosquitoes decided it was lunchtime. I put on those dusty boots and outran them, making swift tracks along the portage trail, sans canoe -- for I couldn't even imagine carrying such a heavy load more than 20 feet. The path continued for a mile across boggy lowlands, then opened, dramatically -- and there was Meads Lake, silent, dark and empty.
You could go right through to Canada like this, from lake to lake, and the idea appealed to me, at least in theory. In practice, Rockwood's big wood-burning sauna seemed like a better idea than Canada, so I headed back to my canoe.
I paddled around for a few more lovely, quiet hours until late afternoon, then called it a day. At night I drove three miles down Gunflint to the Trail Center Black Bear Bar and Restaurant (Rockwood serves no food), a bustling roadhouse popular with local residents that has stuffed bears and moose antlers hanging from the rafters. All the tables were full, so I elbowed up to the bar and ordered the thing I most craved: a jalapeno cheeseburger ($6.50).
I'd only planned a single day of canoeing at Rockwood -- a mistake, as it turned out, because I woke up the next morning longing to feel the steady rhythms of paddling through water again. But I had booked a Friday and Saturday night stay with my credit card ($80 a night at the time of my stay) at the popular Pincushion Bed-and-Breakfast just outside of Grand Marais. The Pincushion sits alongside paths that feed into the Superior Hiking Trail, so it looked like the perfect location for the hiking segment of my expedition.
EXPLORING the town of Grand Marais (population 1,170), on my way to Pincushion, I began to regret my reservation plans. I stumbled onto the sweetest little motel nestled in a grove of birch trees off Highway 61. The white cottages at Trailside Cabins and Motel seemed to have been frozen in the 1950's. The cottage closest to the road had a big red sign that said "Tiny Tim" over an old-style screen door and red metal garden chairs on a front porch. I peeked inside another, larger cottage and yearned to stay in the clean, pine-paneled cabin with its own kitchenette. To make matters worse, when I inquired I found that the cabin rented for just $55 a night. The only news that made me feel better was that it was already taken -- as were all five other cabins at Trailside, and at the half-dozen similar old-fashioned mom-and-pop motel camps that dot Grand Marais. Warning: Reservations are essential for summer weekends in the North Woods.
Compared with the rustic cabins, Pincushion initially disappointed me. It was a modern, suburban-style, three-story house with four guest rooms and two wooden decks. Its proprietors, Scott and Mary Beattie, however, more than compensated for any architectural letdown. In the common room, around the big dining table, Scott, a lanky cross-country ski instructor, pored over trail guides with me, while recounting local tales. He steered me to a city-caliber restaurant facing Lake Superior called the Angry Trout Cafe and the Gunflint Tavern, where the TV is permanently tuned to the Weather Channel (Grand Marais gets more than 100 inches of snow every year). My comfy bedroom had a double bed, sink and a private bathroom with a shower across the hall.
With Scott's help, I chose a remote, five-mile section of the Superior Hiking Trail, about 20 miles north of Pincushion, that followed a ridge to a point enticingly called "Hellacious Overlook." Toting a rucksack containing two bottles of water ($2), a takeout cheese sandwich from the Loafer Cafe ($3.75) and a rain parka, and wearing those heavy boots, I set out. Once again in this "busy" season I passed not a single soul for five hours, and saw not a trace of humans, not even a boot track. But I did see four beavers playing in a beaver pond on the trail (I fell into the muck with my camera trying to take their picture). As I climbed along the rocky ridge, pine, aspen and fir groves parted to reveal glimpses of Lake Superior shining far below.
On my last day in the North Country, at Scott's suggestion, I drove another 35 miles north to Grand Portage, just three miles from Canada, where the local Ojibway Indian nation was acting as host for its annual powwow. It was open to the public, and it was free. I had never been to a powwow and didn't know what to expect. Part marketplace, part fair, part ceremony, it was wonderful.
I watched as a solemn file of elders marched out onto the field carrying eagle feathers on staffs, accompanied by a uniformed honor guard. At a signal, the warriors began to dance in honor of the many Ojibway veterans of the armed forces, many of whom were present. The best drummers and singers from Ojibway nations in several states were there, and they gathered in circles to urge the dancers on. I drew close to one circle, so close I could feel the pounding of their large skin drum in my bones. I imagined I was putting my ear to the ground and listening to the North Country's heartbeat. It felt good, and soothing, like the rocking of a canoe, like memories of childhood.
 
The bottom line: by land or lake
I spent about $80 a day for accommodations, meals and activities during my five-night stay in Minnesota's Northeast.
I bought my round-trip ticket in July from New York to Duluth on Northwest Airlines for $302.
A Chevrolet Cavalier from U-Save Auto Rental, (218) 733-0200, cost me $24.99 a day, not including a 12.7 percent state tax. The rate included 600 free miles. I drove 470 and filled the tank once for $17.
 
Lodging
The Duluth Airport Econo Lodge, 4197 Haines Road, Duluth, Minn. 55811, (800)922-0569, was a bit better than I expected. My clean, no-smoking single room with king-sized bed was bigger than usual for a budget hotel, about 20 by 12 feet. I asked for, and got, a corporate discount on the $49 rate, which brought my cost to $44.
I arranged to stay in the bunk room at Rockwood Lodge and Outfitters, 50 Rockwood Road, Gunflint Trail, Grand Marais, Minn. 55604, (800) 942-2922, the night before my canoe jaunt. It had seven Spartan bunk beds and reminded me a bit of an army camp, but it was clean and comfortable and the bathroom even had a tub. At $40 (which rents the entire bunk room) the price was right. Rockwood also has seven cabins with kitchens, from $110 to $160 a day.
I fell in love with the 50's-style cabins at Trailside Cabins and Motel, Box 155, Grand Marais, Minn. 55604, (218) 387-1550, and plan to go back someday and rent No. 5, a tiny cottage with queen bed, kitchenette and private bath. Five other cabins and eight motel rooms rented at prices ranging from $40 to $70.
Pincushion Bed-and-Breakfast, 968 Gunflint Trail, Grand Marais, Minn. 55604, (800) 542-1226, was a wise choice for a first venture into the area, because my hosts, Scott and Mary Beattie, are a wellspring of information about hiking, canoeing -- and even where to spot a moose. The modern, two-story house has four guest rooms.
I stayed in "Maple," which had a queen bed and a separate but private bath across the hall. The price of $80 for a single ($90, double) included a hearty breakfast (prices are now $90 and $99).
 
Places to Eat
Trail Center Black Bear Bar and Restaurant, 7611 Gunflint Trail, (218) 388-2214, is the hottest, and just about the only, eatery on the Gunflint Trail, open for breakfast, lunch and dinner. The average dinner bill for one runs about $10 to $12. Their "Up North" omelet, with eggs, wild rice and Cheddar cheese, is a house specialty.
While the entrees on the menu at the Angry Trout Cafe, on Highway 61, (218) 387-1265, seemed pricey at about $15 a plate, they ended up being a great deal, because the price included not only fresh locally caught fish, but a huge salad course and a side of pesto fettucine. The bonus is that you can eat outside, facing Lake Superior.
The Gunflint Tavern, 111 Wisconsin Street, Grand Marais, (218) 387-1563, serves simple sandwiches and unusual bar munchies like a smoked trout pate with crackers, all for about $6.50 an item.
 
Activities
Rockwood Lodge and Outfitters (see above) will equip your entire canoeing expedition, or simply rent you a canoe for the day: my two-person We-noh-nah cost $25 and included a map, the use of oars and life jacket, and an itinerary consultation.
The Superior Hiking Trail Association, 731 Seventh Avenue, Two Harbors, (218) 834-2700, is the volunteer organization that maintains and promotes the 226-mile-long trail that eventually will run from the Canadian border all the way to Duluth. It sells trail maps and an excellent trail guide.
