PUB-DATE: September 6, 1998

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 3; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1505 words

HEADLINE: Q&A/Joy G. Dryfoos;
Charting a Safe Course for Adolescence

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
AT 72, Joy G. Dryfoos, a longtime resident of Hastings-on-Hudson, still remembers her own crisis of identity as an adolescent. Years later, she watched her son as a teen-ager and wondered how he -- and the family -- would survive it. But they did.
Not every teen-ager and the family are so fortunate -- and Ms. Dryfoos, a self-taught sociologist, has spent more than 17 years trying to change that. She was director of research for the Alan Guttmacher Institute, a nonprofit research and educational organization in Manhattan, until 1981. An independent researcher for the Carnegie Corporation foundation, she is the author of four books and about 100 articles dealing with those issues. Her most recent book is "Safe Passages: Making It Through Adolescence in a Risky Society" (Oxford University Press). 
 Ms. Dryfoos's work has drawn the attention of the Westchester Children's Association and the Westchester Council on Crime and Delinquency, which have collaborated with her to form the Westchester Center for School/Community Partnership, which is trying to establish full-service community schools where children and adults can go not only for school but also a myriad of social and health needs. Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with Ms. Dryfoos:
 
Q. Is it harder to be an adolescent today than when you were one?
A. I thought it was pretty hard to be one when I was one, and that was a long time ago. But probably for different reasons. I remember very well and have written about my own sort of identify crisis, knowing who I was and what I wanted to be. I don't think that has changed very much.
But there are a couple of big differences now. One of them is if you have sex without protection you can die. The other is guns. That was certainly not true when I was growing up. And a lot of the drugs have become much more sophisticated and much more available. So there is more risk, but that doesn't mean there wasn't any when I was growing up.
If you talk to people my age, everyone has a story about terrible parents, terrible problems. Things like sexual abuse have been going on for a long time. So I think you can overstate it if you say these are terrible times for kids and before it was so easy. It was never easy, and particularly it was never easy to be poor. And it was never easy to be black.
And now we have new kinds of challenges -- an increasing Hispanic population with a language barrier. The population is changing quite rapidly.
 
Q. Is there a need to teach parenting skills more?
A. Oh, yes, and I think they have to be taught earlier, and I think there is a pretty good body of research on how to do that. There are many successful programs. That's why I wrote the book "Safe Passages" -- to make the point that we know what to do. There are wonderful parenting programs in some of the schools, for example. There are parent resource rooms and parent educators, and parents themselves become outreach workers. But a busy parent is not going to be able to get to that very easily. But we know, for example, home visiting for young parents and people with young babies is terribly important.
 
Q. So with unlimited resources we could solve the problem?
A. No. We have more resources than any place else in the world. We just don't use them very wisely. And we tend to proliferate programs. Every time anyone sneezes there is a new program instead of stepping back and putting it all together in some way so you have a comprehensive approach to the children and their families.
I start with one premise -- and that may be true of rich kids as well as poor kids -- and that is, Every child must be attached to a responsible adult. If it's not the parent, it has to be someone else.
 
Q. So if a parent is not doing it, find someone else?
A. Yes. Now, once you think of that, you start thinking of the program implications and then you also bring together the school, the community people, the other parents, everybody. And there are a lot of different ways to do that and it is being done in some places, and it's probably the most successful program intervention there it is. Sometime it's a teacher; it can be anyone, a grandfather, an older sister.
 
Q. Describe that ideal school-based community collaboration you are advocating.
A. In the book I call it a "safe passage school" that is open. It was very much based on the Children's Aid Society model in Washington Heights in Manhattan and another in Philadelphia. They're jointly run by a school and a community agency, and in many cases the United Way is involved. So the principal of the school and the coordinator of the community school jointly run the program. It is open from early morning till late at night. There is a parent resource center, and it has a health clinic. All those pieces get put together by different agencies in the community. And it has an innovative curriculum. There would be community services provided, and parents would be encouraged to act as volunteers.
 
Q. Why are we looking to schools to do this?
A. We're not looking for schools to do it all; quite the contrary. What we're looking for are new kinds of institutions, school-community partnerships, where the work is shared between the school and the community agencies. What this does is open up the schools so the community agencies that are out there can come into the schools and have direct contact with the children and their families.
 
Q. So the schools are contributing a physical entity?
A. Yes, that's where the kids are. And the schools need this because they really can't deal with the kinds of problems kids have today. Schools can't educate children who lack human resources, and people who provide human resources are not going to be successful if the children aren't going to get a good education.
 
Q. Are we talking mainly about economically disadvantaged children or all children?
A. My interest is in economically disadvantaged children, and there are plenty of them here in Westchester. But what I find is, People all over are concerned about their kids. So the idea of having schools open after school, for example, is very attractive to everybody because almost everyone works and they don't know what to do with their kids, especially their middle-school kids. But there are the famous latch-key children who are just getting into more and more trouble, and they really need someplace to hang out in the afternoon. So it makes sense for a boys' club or a girls' club to locate right in the school.
A lot of that is happening. Very interesting things are happening all over the country that bring together the community resources that are out there in the schools. You can link together what happens after school and what happens in school. The teachers have to be involved, but then they are very happy to have people from the outside come in -- some of them are volunteers and others professionals -- to really work with the kids so they can catch up.
 
Q. On the other end of the spectrum, we hear of economically advantaged children who get into trouble.
A. I think that is particularly true because of the lack of availability of parents. Some people are working very hard -- the double-income family -- but that means mom is away working long hours, and everyone is working pretty hard to keep up that high standard of living. There is a cost to all of that, and that's why I say I think suburban schools, more privileged areas, are very interested in these ideas as well because parents need to have their children engaged 24 hours a day with somebody -- some responsible adult.
 
Q. You are talking about institutional changes. The book "Reviving Ophelia" suggests that all adolescent girls are potentially at risk of eating disorders and other problems. What do you think?
A. It's almost a different subject. I hesitate to say to parents, Do this, do that. I'm much more comfortable in the policy arena. But my editor at Oxford Press insisted I write a chapter for parents, and I guess one of my resistances was that I felt I wasn't a very good parent when my son was an adolescent. He's now 47, but he definitely was an adolescent and it was definitely difficult. My husband and I had very little confidence that what we were doing was correct. Somehow we lived through it and he grew up and turned into this magnificent human being.
I think when I write about being a good parent and all of that, I trivialize. I don't feel comfortable with it because it's not my natural metier. But the whole thing about communications is really true and keeping the door open, and the same principles that apply to programs -- the need for attachments.
If parents feel they're not being successful with their kids, they should find some other adult who can be. That's not as hard as it sounds. Kids really like adults. They just don't necessarily like their own parents at the moment when the parent is telling them they can't do what they really want.

HEADLINE: Racing Rebounds at Bridgeport Dog Track

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIZEL 

 BODY:
WHEN the Shoreline Star Greyhound Park and Simulcast Complex closes down for the season next week, dog betting enthusiasts say they will miss it, but know their favorite greyhounds will be back at the starting gates next March.
That's something they didn't know the last time the Bridgeport track closed down, in in November 1996. Bankruptcy proceedings had followed dismal turnouts and revenues, and a criminal investigation into allegations of gaming improprieties by the owner, A. Robert Zeff. At the time, few would have bet on the track's chances of ever holding a live race again. 
 But with fewer kennels and races, a half-year season instead of year-round racing, and a far smaller staff and budget, the track's first season back has been successful enough to look to the future, according to Steve Alford, the general manager.
Mr. Alford said both attendance and revenue were up only slightly from 1996 during the period March 20 through June 30 (the latest date for which figures are available), but expenses have been slashed, from nearly $3.5 million two years ago, to less than $1.9 million.
"When we re-opened in March we said if would could break even we would consider the first season back a success, and that's basically what we've done," said Mr. Alford. "We're getting more people than before with a much tighter overall operation and budget, and we want to begin thinking about turning a profit next year."
The future looks promising enough, he said, to begin planning for next year's season, and to formulating a marketing and advertising strategy for several more years. Mr. Alford said the track is not likely to ever reach the lofty expectations of $120 million -- some predicted more than $200 million -- when it opened nearly three years ago.
At the time, with 600 employees and some of the best kennels in the country, it was hailed as one of the best new dog tracks. It could help save both a dying industry and Connecticut's largest city, some said.
But when the first year's revenues barely went over $14 million -- just a tenth of projections -- more than half of the kennels pulled out bitterly, saying they had suffered severe losses, and accused the track of mismanagement, poor planning and a lack of advertising and promotions.
Mr. Alford agrees the track operators were both naive and arrogant, and did not anticipate how difficult it would be to both draw people -- and get them to wager.
"We made every mistake," he said. "But this time we were devoted to learning from those mistakes, such as opening at the worst time of year -- in the winter -- and expecting people would just come. We had this arrogant attitude that because we were in this tristate market just 50 miles from New York that all we had to do was open the doors and people would flock here."
When live racing resumed in March, expectations were considerably more modest. There were about 1,000 in attendance, and there was much less fanfare than at the original opening when many city and state dignitaries, business leaders and politicians turned out.
But to Mr. Alford it was just as exciting -- in some ways even more so. "Just seeing the dogs back out there on the track is pretty close to a miracle, we've done what everybody told us we never would," Mr. Alford said.
What local and state officials had been counting on the first time around was approval of a nearby waterfront casino, which together with the dog track would create a dynamic gambling duo that would spark the local economy.
But the state legislature rejected the casino proposal, and the dog track was a big disappointment right from the beginning. Live racing was suspended in November, 1995, and the track's owners filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in July, 1996. The $30 million track, transformed from a jai alai fronton, was on its way out.
Then, with the onset of a criminal investigation into the relationship between the track's owner, Mr. Zeff, and the former chairman of the State Gaming Board, Francis Muska, stemming from a trip they took together around the time the track was seeking a gaming license, even the most ardent track supporters believed it had been dealt a final, irreparable blow. Mr. Zeff was later fined as a result of the investigation.
But a bankruptcy court judge earlier this year accepted a reorganization plan that allowed live racing to resume from March 20 to Sept. 13. (Under Chapter 11 the operation has been allowed to remain open for dog and horse-racing simulcasts from around the country.)
But can Shoreline make it the second time around?
Greyhound racing has experienced dramatic declines -- both at the state's other track in Plainfield and across the country -- leading to considerable skepticism.
"They can do it, but it's going to be very tough, they're going to have to work hard and do things a lot differently," said George Wandrak, acting executive director of the state's Division of Special Revenue, which oversees gaming operations.
Mr. Wandrak noted that while the state's two Indian casinos in Ledyard and Montville are doing extremely well, wagering at jai alai frontons and dog tracks has steadily and dramatically declined. During the past decade annual revenue at the Plainfield track has fallen from $120 million to about $24 million.
"Generally, what we have found is that whenever any kind of casino opens within 250 miles of a dog track, the track is in trouble, big trouble," said Stanley Flint, coordinator of the American Greyhound Track Operator's Association in Birmingham, Ala.
Because Shoreline is located less than 75 miles from both Foxwoods in Ledyard -- now the world's largest casino -- and the Mohegan Sun, which opened in Montville in 1996, it is facing a double whammy.
But gaming officials said Shoreline can make it if officials keep things, as they have so far, on a smaller scale, and build up slowly.
"I think they probably learned a lot about what they did wrong the first time, and they could have a modest success under the right conditions this time around," said Mr. Wandrak.
Mr. Flint agrees, citing the basic statistics again. "They are within just 50 miles of New York City, and just a few hundred miles from Boston -- right between two of the East Coast's major markets," he said.
Shoreline officials, meanwhile, cite their need to work for their market.
"We know that while we have a potential market of 15 million people within a 50-mile radius," said Mr. Alford, "we have to be very, very aggressive in drawing them in here, and encouraging people to make wagers."
And the who-is-helping-whom balance has reversed. "What's happening with Bridgeport's revival is contagious," Mr. Alford said. "We believe we can very much a part of the city economic recovery."
Dog racing buffs say they're just happy the greyhounds are back on track.
"I've been betting of the dogs for 25 years and I love coming here," said Michael Lucibello of New Haven. "I just hope they find a way to stay open."
Many regular track goers said this time they would bet on it.
"I'm a gambler and I wouldn't have bet a dollar that there would ever be living racing here again," said Steve Harrison, of New York, during a recent night at the track. "This track really is one of the best in the country, and I've seen them all. It looks like this time they really know what they're doing. I would bet now that they'll be around for a long, long time."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Trackside at the reopened Shoreline Star Greyhound Park in Bridgeport, where dreams of grandeur once crashed, but the greyhounds are racing again. (George M. Gutierrez for The New York Times)(pg. 1); For betting and eating, the food court at the Bridgeport greyhound track. (George M. Gutierrez for The New York Times)(pg. 6)

HEADLINE: Suit Due On School Financing

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
WHEN the county's schoolchildren return to their classrooms for the new academic year this week, they will be carrying more than new backpacks and supplies. Along with reams of lined paper and pens is their potential, as yet undiminished by difficult courses or unsympathetic teachers.
According to a lawsuit being prepared by the New York Civil Liberties Union, such potential is not realized equally because financing disparities and inequities, based largely on how the the state finances school systems through property values, leads to a significant disparity between students from affluent school districts and those from economically deprived systems. The suit cites 10 districts in the state, Mount Vernon and Yonkers among them. 
 For Mount Vernon and Yonkers, the fact that those districts are in Westchester means that the state formula for allocating aid does not adequately address their economic needs. The districts have traditionally been underfinanced, experts say, because the state school-aid formula is determined by property values, which are relatively high in the county, even though Mount Vernon and Yonkers -- among others -- are predominantly urban school systems with underprivileged students.
The issue of financing inequities is not limited to New York State. On a national level, there are 19 lawsuits in 16 states. Unlike recent cases in Vermont and New Jersey, where the remedy has frequently pitted affluent communities against less well-off neighbors, the N.Y.C.L.U. lawsuit is taking a different approach.
"People have the impression that this is a funding inequity lawsuit," said Donald Shaffer, a lawyer for the N.Y.C.L.U. who has been working on the case for the last few years. "We don't see it as a funding inequity lawsuit, although it is certainly a critical part of our lawsuit.
"There are two legal bases for our case. One is that the education article of the Constitution of the State of New York says that every child is entitled to a 'sound basic' education, and that there are hundreds of thousands of children who are not receiving a 'sound basic' education. The second is that most of those students happen to be minority students, and that the method of administration causes minority students to get fewer resources. Our argument is that the state system is providing an inadequate education and a racially discriminatory education."
The suit will seek a court order to compel the Legislature to find a more equitable system.
"I believe the case has a lot of merit," said Lawrence W. Thomas, a partner in the law firm of Donoghue Thomas Auslander & Drohan, who represents the Yonkers school board. "This is a case that should have been brought a long time ago. The formula is inequitable."
Ellis E. Cousens, president of the Yonkers school board, said: "The district has in fact joined hands with the city of Yonkers to work to eliminate inequity. We've lived with this inequity for many years. On the list of hot issues, this is up there. The proportionate impact on Yonkers is probably greatest within the county, or even the state. There's an ongoing operating portion of funding we don't get and accumulated debt service we have to pay. To the extent that our resources are inadequate, that's the issue."
At a time when pressures are being exerted on all districts to meet more rigorous academic standards, to improve student performance to meet the needs of the workplace and to use up-to-date technology, the issue is becoming significant.
"This has relevance to every taxpayer, every parent and every schoolchild in the state," said Michael Rebell, executive director of the Campaign for Fiscal Equity, a nonprofit advocacy organization, which has brought its own suit against the state on the same issue. "We've made a very clear decision that we want the case to lead to significant reform in the state, educationally and fiscally. We're taking seriously the new Regents standards and the idea of giving a 'sound basic' education to every child.
"This is not about taking from the rich to give to the poor. Every child in the state should have a meaningful opportunity to meet the new state standards. We expect the funding system to be shaken up, and potentially the case could benefit everybody. We don't want to leave anybody out. People ought to start thinking about the resources needed to implement Regents standards and feed that thinking into the remedies we're bringing to the lawsuit."
Mr. Shaffer said: "Our job is to lift education at the bottom, not reduce education at the top. There are many, many ways in which remedies can be instituted without necessarily taking away from districts that have adequate education. We are trying to engage in a public education process so every community understands it has a stake in improving education."

HEADLINE: Banco Popular to Open Site in New Rochelle

BYLINE: By F. ROMALL SMALLS 

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE

 BODY:
BANCO POPULAR, the largest bank of Hispanic origin in the United States, is bringing its mass-market popularity and bicultural appeal to Westchester.
Many Hispanic residents here are lauding the opening of a bank branch of the Puerto Rico-based financial institution as a major indicator of their growing significance in suburban New York. 
 Banco Popular has a network of branches in Puerto Rico, the Caribbean, New York City, New Jersey, California, Florida and Texas. And it expects to enter the southern Westchester market this fall.
With deposits of about $1.5 billion on the mainland, Banco Popular and its parent company, Popular Inc., with about $20 billion in assets, is among the 50 largest bank holding companies in the United States.
Although Banco Popular has branches in city and suburban centers of New Jersey, the opening this month of the New Rochelle branch marks the first full-service operation in New York State outside New York City, where there are 29 branches.
After conducting market research, Banco Popular set its sights on New Rochelle, where $500,000 was spent on renovations. "We are thrilled that Banco Popular has decided to locate a branch here in the city," Mayor Timothy C. Idoni said. "The bank is right across from the downtown entertainment site, the New Rochelle Center, and our whole downtown is in the middle of a major revitalization, and we are pleased that they have come here." The New Rochelle Center, a $175 million entertainment complex under construction on the former site of the New Rochelle Mall, is a 425,000-square-foot project, which will contain a multiplex cinema, ice skating rink, small retail stores and two restaurants. It is expected to open next summer.
Mayor Idoni said that more than 12 percent of the city's residents are of Hispanic origin, and their numbers are growing. The largest segment of New Rochelle's Hispanic residents is from Mexico, and Hispanic residents are the fastest growing minority group in the county. In the 1990 census, they represented 10 percent of Westchester's residents.
Jose Antonio Torres, senior vice president and general manager for Banco Popular's offices in New York and New Jersey, said that as a full-service commercial and retail bank it has an advantage in serving the community.
"First, we have a good location," he said. "It is on the corner of the former Chase Bank on Huguenot Avenue. We are improving the site with ATM machines. New Rochelle has a growing Hispanic population, coupled with a strong Afro-American population and a stable small-business cluster.
"We get loyalty from our customers because they find a home in our bank. We are able to relate, and that sets us apart from other banks."
Carlos M. Bernard, president of the Westchester Hispanic Chamber of Commerce and franchise owner of Sir Speedy Printing in Pleasantville, said: "The Hispanic community in Westchester is growing by exponential rates. It is projected that Hispanics will be the majority minority in approximately 2010. There are pockets within Westchester that have Latino communities, which are strong in numbers. These communities have needs that can and should be addressed by a Spanish-speaking bank. The fact that the bank is here means that the Hispanic community has achieved a significant amount of growth that makes it a significant player in both the political and economic sense."
Mr. Bernard said there are about 16,000 Hispanic businesses in the county. He added that Banco Popular's community-oriented services, which provide informational seminars on entrepreneurship and loan preparation, would greatly aid Westchester's Hispanic businesses. "They have been very aggressive," he said.
Banco Popular has helped many Hispanic businessmen obtain franchises like McDonald's over the past few years.
Mr. Torres said: "When it comes to commercial lending, we have been known to do the hand holding that most banks are not willing to do. Many banks are impersonal and volume driven. We are a relationship-driven bank."
Obtaining start-up capital and establishing a positive credit history are key factors for starting a small business, but many black and Hispanic residents find that they are often the hardest things to obtain.
Manuel Duran, owner of Duran Travel Enterprise here, emigrated to New Rochelle from Mexico City about 27 years ago. He said many Spanish-speaking immigrants face an uphill battle when starting a small business because it is hard to get credit. He also said a bank like the 102-year-old Banco Popular will be more sensitive to the needs of people wanting to start a small business.

HEADLINE: Raising Money a Goal At Sarah Lawrence

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
THERE is a joke sometimes told here about Sarah Lawrence College that the prestigious institution has two sets of stationery, one listing its address correctly as the gritty city of Yonkers and the other with its assigned mailing address of Bronxville, an adjacent enclave of expensive Tudor-style houses. The Yonkers address is used for paying taxes and conducting other day-to-day business, the Bronxville address for recruiting and conducting public relations campaigns.
Despite the fact that Yonkers is its governmental jurisdiction, the college uses Bronxville on publications and the Bronxville post office for mail delivery. That notwithstanding, Sarah Lawrence -- which is ranked among the top 40 liberal arts colleges in the United States by U.S. News and World Report -- has earned a distinguished reputation. William Van Duzer Lawrence, a pharmaceutical manufacturer who built the first houses in this area, established the college in 1926 as a tribute to his late wife, Sarah Bates Lawrence, and it admitted only women. It opened its doors to men in 1968, and this week, 1,250 students (only 25 percent of them male, however) returned to the campus. 
 In some ways little has changed here over the years. Many of the stone and stucco college buildings with their slate roofs and gracious entryways date from the days of Mr. Lawrence. The lay of the land -- 40 acres of lushly planted rolling hills -- is also much the same, according to the history books, although a new college sports center just opened on the south end of the campus. Even the walkway covered with wisteria that leads to the president's office looks today the way it looked in photographs of years ago.
But for the first time in 17 years, Sarah Lawrence has a new president -- Dr. Michele Tolela Myers, who became the college's ninth president last month. A social scientist and chairwoman of the American Council of Education, Dr. Myers succeeds Alice Stone Ilchman.
The new president is a petite, gray-haired woman who wears denim dresses and gets her brightly patterned reading glasses from New Mexico. As a transplanted Parisian, she has the style and elan one associates with women from the City of Light. As an educator, she is passionate.
"What defines Sarah Lawrence," said Dr. Myers, 56, who was born in Rabat, Morocco, raised in Paris and educated in the United States, "is its focus on the individual, on releasing the creative spirit."
"My dream has been a place like this," she added, "with its special commitment to pedagogy, the small seminars and one-on-one faculty-student relationships."
She is proud of Sarah Lawrence alumni like the author Alice Walker, the actresses Joanne Woodward and Jane Alexander, the White House political director Rahm Emmanuel and the television commentator Barbara Walters. Also, the author Dani Shapiro, another alumna, just published "Slow Motion," the confessions of a formerly spoiled, alcoholic daughter who discovered another aspect of life when her wealthy parents were involved in a catastrophic accident.
It is a college with no departments because "problems don't come in neat little packages," Dr. Myers said. At this school, dancers take history courses, "all academic fields talk to one another across boundaries" and the life of the mind is idolized.
It is nationally recognized for its academic structure, which combines small seminar classes with individual student-faculty conferences. The college pioneered graduate programs in women's history, health advocacy and human genetics, and it was among the first colleges to integrate the creative and performing arts into the liberal arts curriculum. In choosing students, Thyra L. Briggs, dean of admissions, said the college looks for people "with a passion, because there is no back row in the classrooms here."
She added, "We barely look at S.A.T. scores," explaining that the quality of student writing on entrance essays carries far more weight. Of 2,000 applicants last spring, the college accepted fewer than half. As rich as the college counts itself in its curriculum and staff, it is also an institution of higher learning where the annual tuition, room and board total more than $30,000 a year -- in part because the college has not increased its endowment over the years. Among those who have taught at Sarah Lawrence are the author Grace Paley, the writer and mythologist Joseph Campbell and the writer E. L. Doctorow. With the academic excellence of Sarah Lawrence well established by those who preceded her, Dr. Myers said her role as the latest president will be to upgrade the college's financial standing. Sarah Lawrence's endowment is $35 million. Dr. Myers said her charge is to make that figure $350 million.
Of 40 liberal arts colleges that emphasize undergraduate education and award at least 40 percent of their degrees in the liberal arts, U.S. News and World Report listed Sarah Lawrence 36th. It tied with Occidental College in Los Angeles. Amherst College in Massachusetts topped the list.
Swarthmore College in Pennsylvania and Williams College in Williamstown, Mass., which were second and third, respectively, on the magazine's list, have endowments of about $800 million each. Wellesley in Massachusetts, fourth, has an endowment of about $650 million. The endowment at Amherst is $539.8 million.
Sarah Lawrence was the first liberal arts junior college for women in New York State and one of the first in the United States. It opened with 150 students in October 1928 and was an immediate success despite the start of the Depression a year later. It was accredited as a four-year college in 1931.
Explaining that her job would be to travel and meet with alumni over the next two to three years to raise money, she said, "A lot of people assume we're very wealthy, when we're not at all." 
In many ways, the college dates back to the late 1800's, when Mr. Lawrence, the builder, envisioned a utopian community of artists, writers and other creative people who would leave New York City and move north to Westchester to live together in his well-designed houses. He used the Barbizon in the Fountainebleau forest in France as his model, bought land, hired architects and built Lawrence Park in Yonkers.
By the early 1900's, Mr. Lawrence expanded his dream to another 295 acres that he owned in Yonkers, building Lawrence Park West. In 1917, he built his family home -- a red-brick and half-timber mansion called Westlands, which now serves as the administration building for Sarah Lawrence College.
It is there that Dr. Myers has her office today, with its French doors, massive fireplace, walls lined with bookcases and a large, round oak table, which the new president said reminds her of a "good, old-fashioned kitchen table."
Dr. Myers has a 26-year-old daughter, Erika, who is a teacher, and a 21-year-old son, David, who is a jazz musician and student at Carleton College in Minneapolis. Dr. Myers is separated from her husband, Gail, an author with whom she has written several books. He lives in Oregon.
Dr. Myers comes from Denison University in Granville, Ohio, where she was president. Before that, from 1986 to 1989, she was dean of the undergraduate college at Bryn Mawr in Pennsylvania, where she was also an associate professor of sociology.
She earned her undergraduate degree in political science and economics in 1962 at the Institute of Political Studies in Paris and a master's degree and doctorate in communications studies at the University of Denver in 1966 and '67.

HEADLINE: New Residential District Is Born in Chicago

BYLINE: By JILL SCHACHNER CHANEN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
A HANDFUL of developers are creating a new residential neighborhood in a former industrial area of this city, just blocks away from the Loop central business district.
Called the Fulton River District, the area embraces about 10 square blocks. Within the next three years it will have as many as 3,000 units of newly constructed town houses and apartments in low- and high-rise buildings as well as loft conversions, according to current plans. 
 The area is bounded by the north branch of the Chicago River on the east side and the city's wholesale meat and produce market on the southwest side.
Developers are attracted to it because of the availability of relatively large tracts of vacant land so close to the Loop, said Tracy Cross of Tracy Cross & Associates, real estate market analysts in Schaumburg, Ill.
Because developers do not have to raze existing structures for their new projects, prices for newly constructed town houses and apartments are approximately $40 to $50 per square foot less than comparable properties being built in established city neighborhoods like Lincoln Park or Lakeview, Mr. Cross said.
"We would never have been able to afford our place in Lincoln Park," said Beth Wexler, 28, a real estate agent with Jameson Realty Group in Chicago who, with her husband, Michael, bought a 2,200-square-foot town house in Fulton Station, one of the district's new developments. "We paid approximately $150 per square foot. In Lincoln Park we could not have touched this same place for under $200 per square foot."
The construction of the first phase of Fulton Station, which will consist of 24 town houses and 80 apartments in two seven-story buildings, is two-thirds finished, said David W. Ruttenberg, a developer with the Belgravia Group.
Closings on two of the town houses have occurred and more will take place at a rate of one a week. The two apartment buildings also are nearly completed, he said.
Mr. Ruttenberg said he offered all the town houses when he began sales in the spring of 1997, and all of them now are sold. Only 104 of the 174 apartments planned in the total project have been offered for sale so far. Of those, 42 are under sales contract. The town houses range in price from $300,000 to $350,000, while the apartments are priced from $142,000 for a one-bedroom unit to $450,000 for three-bedroom duplex units on the top floors of the mid-rise apartment buildings.
The second phase of the development, which will be the completion of two additional apartment buildings with a total of 96 units, is financed. Construction is slated to begin on the third building this month, with completion scheduled for the fall of 1999. The fourth building should be completed by the winter of 2000.
Mr. Ruttenberg does not intend to expand the development beyond the current plans, in part because of the need to heavily landscape the three-acre parcel of vacant industrial property he is developing, including the creation of two parks to help change the feel of the neighborhood.
"It is necessary to attract the buyers that we want to come here sooner or later," he says.
The Fulton River District still has a distinctly gritty, industrial feel from the presence of working train tracks bisecting the area, numerous abandoned industrial sites and a few remaining working factories, including the Blommer Chocolate Company, which perfumes the area each day with the scent of its product.
At Kinzie Park, a new $120 million development that borders the Chicago River on one side and commuter train tracks on the other, developers plan to build 350 units on a six-acre parcel to create a "garden in the city" effect to attract buyers to their gated community of luxury town houses and apartments. The development will have brick-paved streets, fountains and a landscaped walkway along parts of the property that border the river, said Ronald B. Shipka Sr., president of Enterprise Development Company, which is developing the property in a joint venture with the Habitat Company of Chicago.
Plans for Kinzie Park call for 90 town houses, a 39-story apartment building with 186 units and a seven-story apartment building with 54 units. Sales prices range from $155,000 for a one-bedroom apartment in the high-rise to nearly $1 million for a 4,000-square foot town house bordering the river.
Mr. Shipka and his development partners say they believe that living on or near the Chicago River will soon be considered an amenity for which buyers will be willing to pay more, much as they do for proximity to Lake Michigan. The prices for the riverfront town houses have increased by $150,000 since they first began selling last fall.
IN all, 172 of Kinzie Park's units, including 45 town houses and 46 apartments in the mid-rise building, have been sold. Buyers include young families, professionals who work in the Loop and older married couples moving back to the city after their children have moved out of their suburban homes.
Because the entire project has been financed, according to Mr. Shipka, the entire project is already under construction. The mid-rise apartment building and 45 of the town houses will be completed first, with the closings scheduled for spring. The high-rise building will be completed in the year 2000.
These gated, luxury developments are a far cry from the first projects in the area, said Michael Lerner, president of MCZ Development Corporation, who is credited with starting the development trend in the Fulton River District.
Mr. Lerner began converting timber lofts out of vacant warehouses and other storage buildings in the district three years ago on a hunch. He had seen loft buyers stretch to move to other undeveloped areas. "This area was remote, but it did have the proximity to downtown Chicago," he said. "But the building just stood out there alone. There were no neighborhood amenities or conversions."
His success in selling out the first two projects in the area -- the 112-unit China Club Lofts and the 180-unit Clinton Street Lofts -- convinced him and other developers that the Fulton River District was ripe for more expensive development. Mr. Lerner is now completing the conversion of Randolph Place, the former headquarters of the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad, into a $100 million development of 350 apartments and a mix of commercial uses including a restaurant, spa and convenience store.
All but 10 of the units are sold, he reported.
AS buyers continue to flock to the Fulton River District, other developers are investing in more expensive residential projects. The Levy Organization recently sold almost a third of its vacant 3.3-acre parcel of riverfront property, where the Chicago River branches north, to Bejco Development Corporation, which will build a 38-story apartment building and four riverfront town houses that may be as large as 6,000 square feet each. Bejco's project will be linked to the Levy Organization's planned commercial development of two office buildings.
B. J. Spathies, president of Becjo, said the high-rise would house 140 to 160 apartments, to be sold at an average of $250 per square foot when they go on the market this fall. All the units will face the river, with unobstructed views of downtown Chicago, she said.
Ms. Spathies says she believes the growth of the area can support the prices she plans to charge. "It is a vibrant area," she said. "A lot of funky things are happening there. It also is an alternative to the congestion of Michigan Avenue."
Some buyers also see nothing but a rosy future for the Fulton River District.
Perry S. Good, a single insurance agent, said he bought a two-bedroom apartment at Fulton Station because he believed it would be a good investment. Three years ago, Mr. Good, 34, bought a loft apartment on the east side of the Chicago River in a then-developing neighborhood called River North and "watched the area go crazy."
"I think in two years this area will be more residential than River North." he said. "It will be totally different."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Construction of the first phase of Fulton Station, above, in the Fulton River District is two-thirds finished. The $120 million Kinzie Park gated community, below, is also under way. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Schools Expanding to Match Growth in Enrollment

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
WHEN children attending the Munsey Park and Shelter Rock elementary schools start classes Tuesday, they will be greeted by new classrooms and new upgrades to their buildings.
At Munsey Park, a total of 16 new classrooms have been added, four for kindergarten and the rest for the first and second grades. At Shelter Rock, which, like Munsey Park, is part of the Manhasset Public Schools district, five new classrooms will accommodate the school's sixth-grade pupils. Both additions are the design of Burton, Behrendt & Smith, architects in Patchogue. 
 The construction program is part of a $21.5 million districtwide upgrading of school buildings. Manhasset district voters overwhelmingly approved a bond issue for that amount in a referendum held two years ago.
With the booming economy of recent years and a strong housing market bringing in young families, almost every school district in Nassau and Suffolk is taking similar steps to add space. Two decades ago, many schools were being closed.
In Smithtown, for example, voters approved a $28 million bond issue 18 months ago that will add 47 classrooms to its eight elementary schools by September 1999 to meet a potential growth of 3,000 pupils over the next decade.
The district currently has an enrollment of 8,000. Two middle schools and one high school that had been closed will be reopened over the next five years.
Demand for school projects is such "that we are working on $90 million worth of construction and we are being interviewed for another $130 million worth," said Michael H. Spector, principal in charge at the Spector Group, architects in North Hills.
According to the New York State Education Department, enrollment in Nassau from kindergarten through 12th grade grew to 191,297 in September 1997 from 169,335 in September 1990, a 13 percent rise, with the largest increase -- 17,145 pupils -- occurring at the elementary school level. In Suffolk, the figures for the same period showed a 7.7 percent increase, to 231,418 from 214,840. There was a rise of 18,690 in the number of elementary school children, but a drop of 2,192 in grades 7 to 12.
The numbers of grade-school pupils are expected to continue growing through 2006 before leveling off. "The general picture, particularly in Nassau County and western Suffolk, has been a large increase in the number of elementary-school-age children for the last five to six years," said Lloyd K. Bishop, a planning consultant in Manhattan. "The primary reason is the baby boomer generation."
In the interim, schools are using every nook and cranny for classroom instruction, or are bringing in portable classrooms.
But space is not the only consideration facing school districts where some buildings date back many decades. New technology and new teaching methods are also demanding that major changes be made.
"We are creating different learning environments from the traditional boxes next to each other, and giving children an environment that is fun," said Roger P. Smith, a partner at Burton, Behrendt & Smith, the architects. "We are also designing larger classrooms because of the need for technology."
A $13.8 million renovation and expansion plan for the Amityville school district's Park Avenue elementary school, developed by the Spector Group, "will bring this young people's home away from home up to the year 2000," Mr. Spector said, "with the option based on dollars to hook up whatever technology they need today or three years from now, but with the potential to be competitive. Kids must be given an atmosphere in which to excel." The proposal will be presented to voters at a district referendum on Oct. 13.
Other Spector Group projects include renovations and additions to schools in Great Neck, where voters approved a $28 million bond issue in January. The Hewlett Woodmere district, another example, has already completed an $8.5 million renovation of its Hewlett elementary school and is about to have a demographic study to see what additional work is needed. And in Mineola, a study begun six months ago to see what types of upgrading and additions are needed will be completed shortly.
PLANNERS say that school boards have to plan carefully for the long term, since enrollment figures could fall after leveling off.
"We are at the tail end of the baby boomer generation and the next generation had the fewest number of children," noted Mr. Bishop, the Manhattan planner, "so you could again sit with a lot of extra space in the long term."
But for now, low interest rates, the phasing out of bond debt on past projects and the favorable economy, which has placed voters in a mood to spend on their schools, are all helping to push through bond referendums.
"Given the choice between having an inferior school with a lower tax rate, or a superior school with a higher tax rate, people are willing to pay the higher taxes," said Thomas Conoscenti, an economist and planning consultant with offices in Nesconset.
According to the Long Island Education Coalition, a group of school board, administration, union and other officials, Long Island schools generally enjoy high ratings. Their 1996 survey found that 50 percent of high school seniors graduated with a Regents diploma, compared with an average of 40 percent in the rest of the state. Out of every 100 graduates, 84 go on to higher education compared with 74 in the rest of the state. In 1997, the group reported, 34 of the 200 national Westinghouse scholarship winners came from Long Island.
And house values are strongly tied to school districts, real estate agents say. "If you buy in a good school district, you know the value will be there when you sell," said Ann Pollack, a broker with the Jan Kalman real estate agency in Woodmere.
"Buyers shop for a school district," said Marilyn Larsen, president of Lane Realty in Great Neck. She is handling sales at a North Hills project called Stone Hill, which lies within the Manhasset school district, and another called the Villages at Huntington, which lies within the Half Hollow Hills district in Dix Hills. Both districts have excellent reputations.
At Stone Hill, 60 of 82 houses have sold over the last 18 months, and at the Villages at Huntington 170 out of 248 have sold over the same period, with at least 65 percent of buyers families with school-age children, Mrs. Larsen said.
"One of the reasons we bought here was because of the Manhasset schools," said Lois Herzog, a registered nurse who, with her husband, Richard, a gynecologist, closed on a five-bedroom colonial in Stone Hill in July, moving there from a smaller house in the same school district. Of their four children, two are in elementary school and two are in high school.
"The district has wonderful programs, enriched classes that are very challenging, and our students get into wonderful colleges," added Mrs. Herzog, who is president of the parents' council at the Shelter Rock elementary school.
With a school tax bill for their new houses that is projected to be approximately $6,000 a year, "this is a real bargain when I think of what people spend on private education," she added. "I couldn't ask for a better education for my kids."
The rapid rise in school enrollment has caught some districts by surprise.
"We are experiencing two phenomena," said Mary F. Barter, district superintendent for the Three Village schools, whose district office is in Setauket: "One, the resale of existing homes because of the strong economy, and the influx of children as a consequence of new construction which is going up everywhere and often consists of very large homes." Several housing developments are under construction in the nearby Route 347 corridor.
Current projections are for a 10 percent increase in enrollment by 2007, amounting to 700 additional students, Dr. Barter said, adding, "We knew we were going to experience growth, but we thought it would occur at a more modest pace." Because of the anticipated demand, the district will present a plan to the community later in the year for additions to its existing buildings. The cost has not yet been established.
In the Half Hollow Hills school district, covering Dix Hills and Melville, a demographic study completed two years ago indicated a leveling off of enrollment over a 10-year period. A more recent study showed enrollment could increase by 3,000 students over the same period, said Kevin N. McGuire, the schools superintendent.
The district is taking an elementary school in Melville that was closed in 1990, and is reopening it in September 1999, adding five classrooms to the existing 25 and generally updating the building, at a cost of $8 million. Burton, Behrendt & Smith is also the architect of that renovation.
"People are investing in new and bigger housing, capital gains changes have been favorable for house sales, and interest rates are low, and all that happened at the same time," Dr. McGuire said.
"It's been good for the economy and it's been good for the country," he said, "but it's created some problems for us."

GRAPHIC: Drawings: Rendering of Munsey Park elementary school, above, where 16 new classrooms have been added. Proposed $13.8 million expansion and renovation of Park Avenue elementary school in Amityville faces a referendum. (Tom Pepper)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/The Reuters Building at Times Square;
A Corporate Headquarters Next to Bugs and Mickey

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
AS the next addition to the revival of Times Square, the Reuters building on the blockfront between 42d and 43d Streets on Seventh Avenue faces an unusual design challenge. It is intended to blend the dignity of a major corporate headquarters with a location that has Bugs Bunny and Mickey Mouse as its immediate neighbors.
The project is a joint venture of Reuters, the international news and financial services company, and the Rudin family, builders and owners of residential and commercial properties in New York City. Various Reuters operations, including a securities trading floor and television studios, will occupy 506,000 square feet of the 855,000-square-foot building, which will have the address of 3 Times Square. 
 "You have to try to satisfy a lot of constituencies in this area," said William C. Rudin, president of Rudin Management Company, the family's leasing and property management subsidiary. He said the building would have the brightly lit signs that are required by the zoning in the area, but said the approach can't be "too glitzy" because of the presence of the Reuters headquarters.
Nevertheless, with a Warner Brothers Studio Store across Seventh Avenue and a Disney store across 42d Street, the neighborhood is not going to be confused with Park Avenue.
Mr. Rudin said that the recent gyrations of the stock market would have no impact on the project. "We have our financing in place and the interest rate is locked in," he said. Prudential Insurance Company, the previous owner of the site, is providing both the construction loan and the 20-year long-term financing and has retained the right to place some signs on 42d Street.
As for the 30 percent of the office space and 80,000 square feet of retail space that still need to be leased, Mr. Rudin said the Times Square market was strong enough to resist stock market fluctuations. "We don't see the New York market being affected," he said. "There is no speculative building in the Times square area. If you build a good product, there will be demand for it."
With demolition of existing buildings at the site just getting under way, Reuters does not expect to move in until the spring of 2001, although some of the retail space may be occupied as much as a year earlier.
The building is being presented as the latest in high-tech, "green" development, although it will apparently not go as far in using environmentally sensitive techniques as the partially erected Conde Nast building at 42d Street and Broadway, which has a 4 Times Square address.
The Conde Nast building has photovoltaic cells, which convert sunlight into electricity without generating pollution, incorporated in the outer wall of the building. The structure, which is being developed by the Durst Organization, also includes two 400 kilowatt fuel cells to provide larger amounts of low pollution power and as a backup in case of a power failure.
Rudin executives say they will not put photovoltaic cells in the building wall but are still studying the economics and environmental consequences of fuel cells. "On photovoltaics, we just don't think the science is there yet," said John J. Gilbert 3d, chief operating officer of Rudin Management. He said the base building had been designed to incorporate fuel cells if studies show them to be cost effective and environmentally benign. "We are looking at everything they did across the street," Mr. Gilbert said.
Those evaluations are made easier because they are using the same firm, Fox & Fowle Architects, that designed the Conde Nast building as well as the same construction manager, Tishman Construction.
R OBERT FOX, a principal of the architectural firm, said energy conserving technologies, such as a facade that lets in natural light while blocking most heat energy, were being emphasized. He said the walls are so efficient -- and the amount of heat generated by people and machines so great -- that the building will not have to be heated, even on cold winter days.
He said both electric and gas-driven cooling units would be installed in the building, with the option of operating each based on electrical rates, which typically peak on weekday afternoons, but fall off at night.
The building was designed with its core structure -- which contains the elevator shafts, stairways and other common elements -- at the center, so that offices can ring the core for greater access to natural sunlight. Mr. Fox said the developers were considering interior lighting that dims as sunlight increases to conserve power usage.
As might be expected from the Rudins, who took an aging, empty office building at 55 Broad Street and transformed it into a high-tech center by installing advanced communications equipment, the Reuters Building will be heavily wired. In addition to electrical power, the building will have optical fiber and advanced copper communications gear plus antennas and satellite dishes on the roof for wireless communication.
There is also provision for future developments. "The amount of riser space in the building is well above the norm," said Glenn J. Elliott, senior vice president at Reuters for real estate, referring to the vertical passages that house the wiring. "We tried to figure out everything we could possibly need, then added 50 percent for the future."
Reuters will have five 750-kilowatt diesel-powered generators on the roof so that it can maintain operations in case of a power failure. Another will be installed to sustain operations of the building itself, with a pad provided for an additional one if needed.
Mr. Rudin said one reason Reuters decided to participate in the development of a new building, rather than rent space in an existing structure, is the freedom it gave the company to customize the design to its needs. For example, the floor that will house the Reuters Instinet subsidiary's trading floor will be 16 feet slab to slab, compared to just under nine feet for other floors.
The trading floor will be the eighth, which will place it above the brightly lit signs that will adorn the building.
Mr. Gilbert said that Reuters also had other reasons for choosing a new building. "Most importantly, it was a cost-saving alternative to a traditional lease position in a rising market," he said. He said being an owner also gave the company "an opportunity to create a brand image for the Reuters name."
Part of the image-creating will be done on a fourth-floor television studio that will be visible from the outside. With the lower part of 1500 Broadway, across Times Square at the northeast corner of 43d Street, being converted to broadcast ABC's "Good Morning America" show, the two studios could easily end up in each other's backdrop.
The original design for the building called for several news zippers, similar to the one across Seventh Avenue at One Times Square. But Mr. Gilbert said the zippers were now out of the picture in favor of full video displays.
THE retail space will be multilevel, including the lower concourse level and the first, second and third floors. Because the building will include an entrance to the Times Square subway station -- relocating it about 75 feet to the west, to where it was in the 1930's -- and a lobby for the office building, there will be less ground- floor retail space available than before demolition.
As a result, the developers say they have decided to try to attract three relatively large retail tenants, so that each will have adequate exposure at street level, rather than replace the gaggle of small stores that were previously there. (These stores operated on leases with six-month cancellation clauses that were invoked in March. All were closed by mid-August.)
"This is a difficult footprint to work with, because of the subway, the loading docks and so forth," Mr. Rudin said. To enlarge the site, the partnership bought a small building and driveway facing on 43d Street. But because the building housed offices for the New Victory Theater and the driveway allowed back-door deliveries to the theater, one of the loading docks in the new building will be for the New Victory. In addition, a new lobby for the theater will be provided at the concourse level on 42d Street.
With construction under way on both sides of Times Square and to the west along 42d Street, Mr. Rudin said the area is clearly re-established as an office location and retail destination. But he noted that the process of renewal had taken a long time. "My father was involved in effort to redevelop Times Square 25 years ago," he said.

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 7; Column 4; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 464 words

HEADLINE: .. and Bringing the Environment Into the Classroom

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS 

 BODY:

WHO -- Tanya Oznowich, 39, environmental education specialist for the state Department of Environmental Protection.
 
BACKGROUND -- After growing up in Ohio, Ms. Oznowich studied natural interpretation and environmental education at Slippery Rock University. She worked as a naturalist at several parks before coming to the Department of Environmental Protection, where she has specialized in environmental education for the past 10 years. 

ACHIEVEMENT -- She is credited by Environmental Commissioner Robert C. Shinn Jr. with being instrumental in getting the state Board of Education to include the study of the environment in the science requirements developed under the new core curriculum standards. She recently obtained a $30,000 grant from the federal Environmental Protection Agency to help teachers develop environmental curriculum.
 
MS. OZNOWICH'S GOAL -- "I want students to see that everything we do is linked. We sometimes forget we are part of the environment. We benefit from the environment, but we also disturb it and take a lot from it. The minute we are born we become consumers of natural resources and producers of waste. We have to be accountable. That is what the kids who will be making the decisions in the world in the future need to be taught. I don't want the environment to be forgotten."
 
WHAT CLASSES WILL BE LIKE -- "An environmental classroom is going to be a noisy classroom. It used to be teachers did a lot of talking and writing on the board. Now we want to bring kids outdoors or bring outdoors stuff inside. There will be a lot of interaction and a lot of hands-on learning."
 
A SAMPLE LESSON -- Groups of students in grades four to eight can be asked to plan a community on a lake based on what they consider to be priorities, such as stores, schools and ball parks. They have to take into consideration the natural environment based on geology. Then they are told the lakes are connected and the outflow of one is the inflow of the next. They may have to redesign the community and draw up a set of good rules to live by. "Studying the environment is a complicated blend of economics, government, politics, geography and math," Ms. Oznowich said.
 
PICK UP A PENCIL -- Consider a classroom project known as the pencil exercise. Students are asked to consider where the raw materials in a pencil came from, how it was produced, how much energy was used, how it was packaged, how it was transported and marketed and how many times it was handled before it got to the consumer. "It is a simple exercise to remind us of our connections. We all shelter and isolate ourselves. We think we are immune to what is around us, but in fact we are always having an effect on something somewhere else." KAREN DeMASTERS

GRAPHIC: Photo Tanya Oznowich, and environmental education specialist for the state Department of Environmental Protected, at Washington Crossing State Park just north of Trenton. (Frank C. Dougherty for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 5; Real Estate Desk
