HEADLINE: At Columbus Circle, A Circuitous Path To Columbus Centre

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
FOR most of this decade, Stephen M. Ross has been staring intently at the development opportunity of a lifetime -- right through the windows of his own office.
Mr. Ross is the chairman and chief executive of the Related Companies, which develops, owns or manages residential, retail and commercial properties worth more than $7 billion in 40 states. But he could not let go of what he saw from his Madison Avenue office, three-quarters of a mile across 59th Street: the hulking New York Coliseum on Columbus Circle. 
 "It's almost been an obsession with him," said his financial partner, William L. Mack.
Mr. Ross interrupted. "Let me ask a question," he said to Mr. Mack. "What's this 'almost'?"
At the end of July, Mr. Ross's obsessive pursuit paid off when companies that he, Mr. Mack and Kenneth A. Himmel control were awarded the Coliseum development site, for which they will pay about $345 million, by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the owner of the property.
To bid successfully for the site, the partners had to be nimble, as the real estate market and project guidelines kept changing. They added a 1,000-seat concert hall and deleted a 60-foot glass globe filled with restaurants; lost a rental apartment tower and gained one of the bluest chips in corporate America as an office tenant.
"Columbus Centre," as it is known (and spelled), is to begin rising in late 1999 or early 2000, after the Coliseum is razed. Although the stock market's volatility last week raised concerns about the future of many major business decisions, Mr. Mack, fresh from a meeting with his partners on Tuesday, said "We're moving full speed ahead."
As planned, the building is to have two 750-foot towers rising from an enormous base, with a total of 2.5 million square feet of space. It will cost about $1.3 billion, including land acquisition.
Within it are to be the headquarters of Time Warner, which the corporation will own as a 650,000-square-foot commercial condominium, plus 100,000 square feet of studios for its Cable News Network and NY1 television news operations.
Jazz at Lincoln Center will have its first permanent home, with a 1,000-seat concert hall, rehearsal studios and classrooms.
There will also be 325,000 square feet of restaurants and stores, a 425-room Mandarin Oriental Hotel, 325 condominium apartments and a 12-screen movie theater. Plus 400 to 600 parking spaces.
And to think -- Mr. Ross's first vision for the site in 1991 was Kmart.
As they described the evolution of Columbus Centre in interviews, the participants emphasized that in some ways, the most difficult task has just begun.
The design must evolve from conceptual renderings into detailed working drawings and then into a steel, glass and concrete solution to the three-dimensional puzzle posed by remarkably varied tenants. David M. Childs, a partner in Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, is working with Elkus/Manfredi Architects on the overall project and with Rafael Vinoly Architects on the Jazz at Lincoln Center hall.
No newcomer to the Coliseum site, Mr. Childs has been designing projects at Columbus Circle for 10 years now, having succeeded Moshe Safdie as the architect for the development team of Boston Properties, headed by Mortimer B. Zuckerman and Edward H. Linde.
In 1985, Boston Properties presented a plan by Mr. Safdie, who is best known for the Habitat housing complex in Montreal. It called for faceted, angular towers rising to 925 feet, with 2.7 million square feet of floor space -- or 18 times the area of the lot, where zoning rules would ordinarily permit a floor-area ratio of 15. Boston Properties was to pay $455 million for the site.
Opponents contended that the M.T.A. had effectively invited developers to ignore zoning constraints by placing a premium on getting the most money for the site. Among the critics was a young Joseph B. Rose, who was then chairman of Community Board 5 and is now chairman of the City Planning Commission.
"None of the ingenuity and gritty determination so evident in its financial dealings were expended on considerations of design or the relation of a future building to its context," Mr. Rose said at the time.
IN 1987, Acting Justice Edward H. Lehner of State Supreme Court declared the sale of the site null and void, saying, "government may not place itself in the position of reaping a cash premium because one of its agencies bestows a zoning benefit upon a developer."
Boston Properties brought in Mr. Childs. The 1988 proposal called for shorter towers, less density and a lower purchase price. Departing from Mr. Safdie's futuristic approach, Mr. Childs sought to evoke the more familiar imagery of twin-towered Central Park West apartment buildings.
Opponents were not placated, however. Boston Properties came back in 1989 with a project of 2.2 million square feet and towers 752 feet tall, also designed by Mr. Childs. This proposal enjoyed greater -- though by no means unanimous -- approbation.
But all the political support in the world could not change the fact that New York's economy had collapsed in the meantime. Nor could it dispose of continuing environmental litigation.
With the Coliseum sitting empty, the M.T.A. began looking in 1991 for operators to take over the hall on an interim basis, so the authority could earn rent while awaiting the closing of the sale to Boston Properties.
Enter Mr. Ross.
He proposed to install Kmart at the Coliseum. "People wanted to bring some activity to the site," Mr. Ross recalled. "The economy was terrible. And we thought it was a good way to create jobs."
Kmart executives toured the building. Discussions advanced as far as which Kmart subsidiary -- a Sports Authority sporting-goods store, a Borders bookstore, a Pace warehouse club -- would go on what floor.
Nothing ultimately came of this proposal, however, and in July 1994, after further attempts at revising the redevelopment project, Boston Properties withdrew.
To the outside world, the next two years looked like a time of little progress, characterized mostly by wrangling between the M.T.A. and the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani over the future of the site.
But Mr. Ross was not idle.
He reached out to Mr. Himmel, the president of Himmel & Company in Boston, a retail development concern responsible for the Pacific Place complex in Seattle, which is to open this month, and 730 North Michigan Avenue in Chicago, which opened last year. In the 1980's, at the Urban Development and Investment Company, Mr. Himmel developed Copley Place in Boston.
He and Mr. Ross had been friends for about 10 years, having come to know each other through an informal network of developers and investors called the Real Estate Round Table, which typically meets twice a year.
Prospective developers were also approaching Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, given its track record at Columbus Circle. "After Mort and Ed dropped out, we got calls from several people," Mr. Childs said.
One call came from Bruce Macleod, chairman of the buildings and grounds committee at Deerfield Academy, where Skidmore had designed a new pool house known as the Koch Natatorium. Mr. Macleod also happened to be president of the O'Connor Retail Group, which was then affiliated with the Columbus Centre team.
(Mr. Macleod is now executive vice president of the Palladium Company, a retail development concern that is jointly owned by the Related Companies and Mr. Himmel. Palladium will oversee the retail portion of Columbus Centre.)
The team began drawing up the broad outlines of a new project for Columbus Circle, together with Howard F. Elkus of Elkus/Manfredi, the designers of Pacific Place and 730 North Michigan Avenue.
"Office use was not a viable consideration," Mr. Ross said, "but we knew there would be television or movie studios." Mr. Himmel said movie theaters and restaurants were also part of the mix from the outset.
On the governmental front during this period, Mr. Rose, the Planning Commission chairman, said he had "extensive interaction" with Marc V. Shaw, executive director of the M.T.A.
After pushing and pulling between city and state officials, the authority issued a request for proposals in July 1996, with design guidelines largely developed by city planners. "We never were trying to design the building for the architects," said Mr. Rose. "We were trying to incorporate values into the project."
A key guideline is the division of the site by a "view corridor" at least 65 feet wide, centered on the middle of Central Park South. This guideline is to prevent the vista from being walled off. It effectively dictates multiple towers.
The towers can be no higher than 750 feet; for comparison, that is seven feet lower than Carnegie Hall Tower on West 57th Street. The eastern facade of the project must follow, and thereby reinforce, the curve of Columbus Circle.
Although a floor-area ratio of 15 would yield 2.2 million square feet, the guidelines set a limit of 2.1 million square feet. (Because "zoning floor area" allows for certain deductions, chiefly mechanical and below-grade space, the actual gross floor area will be closer to 2.5 million square feet, equal to the Empire State Building.)
In November 1996, Columbus Centre Partners, an alliance between the Related Companies and Himmel & Company, submitted its proposal.
It was to be financed in part by Mr. Mack's company, Apollo Real Estate Advisors, which represents state and corporate pension funds, college endowment funds, financial institutions and wealthy individual investors.
Among the eight other respondents were Daniel Brodsky and Bruce C. Ratner, Millennium Partners, Tishman Speyer Properties and the Trump Organization.
Columbus Centre, as first envisioned, was to have three towers. The north tower would have rental apartments. The southwest tower would have a hotel and condominium apartments. And the southeast tower, shorter and closer to Columbus Circle, would also have condominium apartments.
IN the base, stores were to be arrayed along either side of a broad, curving internal thoroughfare that paralleled the arc of Columbus Circle. That planned layout is still in effect.
As an esthetic piece de resistance, a glass sphere filled with restaurants was to rise above the fourth level of the base building.
Columbus Centre Partners survived the first round of elimination, to finish among five finalists in the spring of 1997. They raised their offer for the site to $262.5 million, from their initial $195 million bid.
That made the land acquisition too expensive to permit the construction of rental apartments. So the team turned to pursuit of an office tenant.
"This was a major turning point," Mr. Mack said. "One thing that won the day was the foresight to say this would work as offices without a tax abatement at a time when no new office buildings were being built in New York."
At the same time, Mayor Giuliani was beginning to press the M.T.A. privately to include a 1,000- to 2,000-seat theater in the project, although it was not yet determined who would operate it.
Word got out in July 1997 that the M.T.A. was on the verge of awarding the project to Millennium Partners, a development team that has transformed the area around Lincoln Center with three large retail and residential projects.
The Mayor threatened to exercise the city's veto in the selection process, in part because there was no theater in the proposal and in part because he said the authority was more concerned about the financial terms of the deal than the longterm benefits of the development.
While city and state officials were fuming at one another, Mr. Ross arranged through a mutual friend in July 1997 to meet Richard D. Parsons, the president of Time Warner, together with Mr. Himmel.
As Mr. Ross recalled that conversation: "We said, 'This isn't about renting space, this is about showcasing your company and making an icon for New York City.' Within the first 10 minutes, he totally understood."
Within 70 days, Mr. Ross said, the Columbus Centre partners had their answer: Time Warner would join the project.
By the fall of 1997, an advisory group convened by the city had met with potential theater users. "It became clear that the most promising operator for this space was Jazz at Lincoln Center," Mr. Rose said, "with the recognition that the space would be versatile and be available for more than jazz."
In March 1998, an addendum was issued to the original request for proposals, stating that it was "in the best interest of the M.T.A., the state and the city that the redevelopment of the site include a state-of-the-art cultural performance and education facility."
Specifically, the facility was to have 100,000 square feet of space for use principally by Jazz at Lincoln Center. The structural core and shell were to be built at the developer's expense and conveyed as a condominium unit to Jazz at Lincoln Center, which would be responsible for finishing, equipping, operating and maintaining the space.
The revised guidelines also incorporated features based on ideas generated by submissions and comments in the first round of submissions. These included a requirement for off-street loading and the integration into the project of the 58th Street subway entrance.
Mr. Ross and his partners submitted their third proposal in April 1998, describing their agreement with Time Warner and incorporating the jazz hall.
On July 28, the Columbus Centre group was designated to develop the site.
In their new plan, the partners have replaced the globe with a sloping glass oculus that would serve as a skylight over a circular atrium. Upper levels might be reached by a new kind of spiral escalator made by the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation.
Jazz at Lincoln Center is to be on the fourth level. The developers estimate it will cost $40 million to $45 million to build the basic structure, but it is not yet known whether the concert hall will take the form of a conventional auditorium with a raked floor or whether it will be more like a very big jazz club. Outside the hall will be an ample lobby leading to a terrace that overlooks Columbus Circle.
"At Avery Fisher Hall or the Met, you come out on the mezzanine and look at a plaza," said T. J. Gottesdiener, a Skidmore partner. "By contrast, here you're going to see Central Park and the Manhattan skyline. The difference will be phenomenal."
Spectacular views and a lively performance venue serve more than a civic purpose. They are meant to draw the public -- the shopping public -- all the way through the building and past the many stores.
"Getting New Yorkers to move through vertical retailing is a challenge," Mr. Himmel conceded. "They've got to have a sense that there is something so exciting up there that they've got to be part of the experience. If this works right, the magic of Jazz at Lincoln Center will draw you to the fourth level."
Although an approximation of the building layout has been drawn up, exact layouts are a long way from being determined. "I bet we'll go through a hundred schemes," Mr. Himmel said.
Mr. Childs is thinking about the tops of the towers. "We'd like to make them as memorable as the Chrysler Building," he said. "They would end in a great crescendo, a sparkle of glass, something of the new century, the new millennium, that explodes in light and crystals."
The lower facade is meant as a showcase for the merchants within. Mr. Himmel acknowledged that Copley Place, with its vast blank exterior walls, left something to be desired urbanistically.
"At the time, there was no choice," he said. "The retail world only viewed itself in the mall vernacular. Everything was inward-focused. Today, retailers express themselves to the outside."
THE only exterior elements of note on the Coliseum, which opened in 1956, are four plaques depicting governmental seals. They were designed by Paul Manship, the sculptor of Rockefeller Center's famous Prometheus. Not much thought has been given yet to the Manship plaques. "Columbus Centre is a large project and there would be a lot of opportunities to reuse them," Mr. Gottesdiener said. "I just don't know if it's the right place. But I'm sure they won't get hit by the wrecking ball."
Demolition of the Coliseum may begin next summer and is expected to last six months. Construction will probably take two and a half years, Mr. Himmel said.
Neighborhood opponents, led by the Committee for Environmentally Sound Development, are gearing up for battle again. Even if it were built on schedule and without lawsuits, however, Columbus Centre would not open until 2002 at the earliest. That is six years after the request for proposals was issued.
Mr. Mack, for one, sees a benefit in the drawn-out process. "The M.T.A. was able to realize a larger amount of money," he said. "The city and state were able to have Jazz at Lincoln Center in the project. And the study produced not only the best esthetic design but the best tenancy mix."
Of course, it is easier for Mr. Mack to take the long view because he has known the site since 1952. As a 12-year-old, he watched as a wrecking company owned by his father, H. Bert Mack, razed office buildings and theaters around Columbus Circle to make way for the Coliseum.
"So he's following his father's footsteps," Mr. Ross said, "in demolishing whatever is on that site."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 2; Column 5; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 802 words

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
A Roof Over Some Heads, For at Least a Little Longer

BYLINE: By Jennifer Preston; Jennifer Preston is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Faced with the prospect of 2,200 people becoming homeless this fall and winter, the Whitman administration decided last week that it would not hold fast to its 12-month time limit for some people who depend on the state's emergency housing assistance program.
The time limit was part of the package when New Jersey revamped its welfare program more than a year ago. The new law, which also places a five-year time limit on cash benefits and requires welfare participants to find a job, is credited with helping to produce a stunning reduction in the state's welfare caseload. 
 But with the decision to extend the time limit for housing assistance, the Whitman administration has in effect acknowledged that it might be more difficult than some policy experts first assumed for some of the state's poorest and most vulnerable residents to make it on their own.
"They are mostly disenfranchised from their families and from society," said Bonnie Chehames, director of Human Services in Willingboro, Burlington County, about many of the people who faced the prospect of losing their housing aid. "They tend to be extremely frail."
Under pressure from city and town officials, the Whitman administration agreed to lift the time limit on housing aid for those people whom caseworkers concluded were "unemployable." The state said that it would not end benefits for approximately 2,200 people, mostly childless adults, while it develops a permanent housing solution for them.
Another 637 childless adults have already lost their emergency housing benefits since July 1, state officials said. Caseworkers concluded that, unlike the others, they were physically able to find a job and someplace to live. State officials said they did not believe that any families had lost their housing assistance.
"This is crisis intervention for a handful of municipalities," said Jackie Tencza, spokeswoman for the state Department of Human Services. "The law is working in most of the state."
Why did the New Jersey League of Municipalities and city and town officials fight so hard for the state to continue providing emergency housing assistance benefits to chronically unemployed people, mostly childless adults?
Almost 40 years ago, the state Legislature adopted a bill, commonly known as the "poor law," requiring cities and towns to provide "support and relief" to the indigent.
While county governments, using state and Federal dollars, administer welfare programs to families, the state's cities and towns oversee the state's general assistance program for childless adults. Most of the participants are older men without children who receive monthly cash benefits from $140 to $210.
Because of the poor law, some local officials remain concerned that property taxes could end up paying for subsidized housing for the chronically unemployed unless the state comes up with a solution. There is also concern that the time limit on housing assistance could swell the ranks of the homeless.
"We want to have a permanent solution," said William Dressel, head of the New Jersey League of Municipalities. "We are pleased that the administration is taking this first step. But we are still only talking about a temporary solution."
Mr. Dressel said that the League intended to monitor the situation closely. "We don't want to see anyone slip through the cracks who is deserving of these benefits," he said. "At the same time, we want to make sure that people who are not deserving do not get benefits."
In addition to local government, social service organizations across the state are also beginning to feel the impact of the new welfare law's time limits, particularly on emergency housing aid. Some groups say they are providing services to more people even though the state's statistics show a decline in the number of people depending on welfare benefits and housing assistance.
"We are delighted that the state is acknowledging the lack of affordable housing and deciding to continue emergency assistance benefits for certain people," said Regina Purcell, associate director for social concerns for the New Jersey Catholic Conference. "But the state has to recognize that there are a lot of people coming into shelters that have not received emergency assistance benefits.
"There are more homeless people in our shelters, without state emergency assistance aid, than there are with it," she said. "And shelters, in certain areas of the state, are continuing to turn people away."
Ms. Chehames, the head of the state's Municipal Welfare Association, said she was hopeful that the state will help come up with a permanent housing solution. "Just to drop some of these people and make them homeless is not going to help them or help our communities," she said. "They are not going to go away."

NAME: Fred G. Wager

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 4; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1345 words

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
A Small-Town Mayor With Big-Time Dreams

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: WILDWOOD

 BODY:
THERE is much about the headaches of governance that Mayor Fred G. Wager is not at liberty to discuss because, at the moment, he is up to his neck in litigation. He needs to speak carefully. Still, he is steaming mad on behalf of his town, even if his shrug is good-natured when he says: "You want to sue us? Get in line."
Mostly, the problems stem from the casino. The Mayor has spent several years engineering a deal to turn 2.2 acres of municipal parking lot into an Indian-run gaming palace. The land transfer would settle the Delaware tribe's court claim that its ancestral lands, including all of Wildwood, were illegally seized a century and a half ago. But the state, objecting on several grounds, has gone to court to stop the deal. 

 The hostilities do not stop there, either. From the north, politicians from Atlantic County, and particularly State Senator William L. Gormley, have bashed Wildwood's latest attempt at revival. Mr. Gormley, citing the state constitution's prohibition of gambling outside Atlantic City, called the tribe's demands "repugnant," and then got rather personal about the Mayor. "He's an embarrassment to the city," the Senator told The Press of Atlantic City. "He's an embarrassment to municipal officials."
That is a lot of artillery for the Mayor of a place about the size of Bradley Beach and not quite as big as Lopatcong or Harrington Park. Mr. Wager (prounounced WAY-ger, with a hard "g") has 4,442 constituents. His job is classified as part-time, the salary $15,500 a year.
But this town, he says, needs full-time help. "We've got 26 percent unemployment," Mr. Wager said in a recent interview. "Our kids graduate from high school and we have no jobs. We have boarded-up buildings. Thirty-five percent of our children live under the poverty level."
As he spoke, Mr. Wager was sharing the floor with two friends, Bill Gannon, a motel owner, and John Nickels, who runs an entertainment pier. The three took turns describing how Wildwood's tourism operators helped Atlantic City 25 years ago in its lobbying for casino gambling, only to see their own businesses bled as the state Casino Reinvestment Development Corporation poured billions into Atlantic City.
And now, "we're pushing to get a little casino in Wildwood," Mr. Wager said. "We don't want alcohol in it, or hotel rooms. We're a family resort. We want mom and pop here. We're not looking for the high roller. No way in the world would we hurt Atlantic City."
About two years, ago, he said, Governor Whitman's administration made a gesture of help. "They sent 13 people down here from Trenton to see how they could help us, from every agency you could name. In the end, they didn't do a thing. We cried, and they wouldn't wipe away our tears. I even hired a bus to take them around the city." And these were members of his own party. (So is Mr. Gormley, for that matter.) "I'm the ward leader for the Republican Party here," Mr. Wager said. "We're the guys who get the vote out for them."
On Mr. Wager's desk is a photograph of Mayor and Governor, together on the boardwalk. (It looks a little puny next to the picture of Mr. Wager with Attorney General Janet Reno, a Democrat, taken last month at a conference in Washington on economic development for Native Americans.) He has not stopped imploring the Governor for help, even as her administration implores the Federal District Court in Camden to block his casino plan; last week the state, which opposes a casino on several grounds, got a judge's approval to enter the suit.
Mr. Wager's troubles have been compounded recently by reports that the New Jersey Sports and Exhibition Authority is scaling back its plan for a new convention hall in Wildwood. And for good measure, the Mayor has been named a defendant in a lawsuit by a nightclub whose license to hold dances for teen-agers was revoked last year.
But the job is not all litigation and political bickering. The Mayor is also a promoter -- he climbs on a boardwalk tram with a string band every Thursday night, for example -- and a socializer. He reports that he performs more weddings than anyone else in Cape May County. ("Why is that?" he asked, repeating a question. "Because I don't charge.")
Mr. Wager, born in Philadelphia 70 years ago, spent childhood summers in Wildwood and moved here to stay in 1952. He was a salesman, working for, among others, General Foods, but in 1955 he and his wife bought a hotel on Spencer Avenue. It was a family-run business, named the Germantown, that they ran until 1986. "I got up at 6:30, ran out and started selling at 9:30 and came back to help with dinner at 3:00," he recalled.
Mr. Wager's political career began in a moment, or maybe a week, of pique. The immediate cause was the city's removal of a loading-zone sign outside the Germantown. Mr. Wager called his councilman to demand an explanation, leaving a message. He left more messages, and then he went to the next Council meeting.
Facing the councilman, Mr. Wager recounted, "I said, 'I've called you five, six, seven times; could you please give me the courtesy of calling me back?' " When he got no apology, Mr. Wager said, rising from his desk to demonstrate, "I plunked down my business card and said, 'I'm running against you next time.' "
He did, and he lost by 12 votes. On his second try, in 1993, he won, then pushed successfully to change Wildwood's form of government from a council to a board of commissioners. He was elected Mayor (and one of the three commissioners) in 1995. Mr. Wager set out to extend Wildwood's tourist season and, through shows like the monster truck competition and the string band weekend in the fall, to make it "the event capital of South Jersey." The city raised its sales tax to pay for a new convention hall.
But most of all, Mr. Wager wanted a casino. He acknowledges that Wildwood had the idea before the Delaware tribe did; civic leaders plunged into research on Indian gaming that led them to Oklahoma and an agreement with the tribe. In 1995, Wildwood voters approved a referendum creating the tiny reservation.
The state contends that the tribe's lawsuit against Wildwood, filed in March, was a collusive maneuver, and Mr. Wager, while not putting it that way, has only praise for the tribal leaders. "They're wonderful people," he said.
On this hot morning, Mr. Wager offered to show off the blacktopped site near the boardwalk where the casino is supposed to rise. On the way, from behind the wheel of his Celebrity, he pointed out as many of his town's failures as he could spot. "They moved out," he said on the slow drive down Pacific Avenue, "This bank's gone; we don't have a big bank anymore. That store -- they closed." He shook his head at the Germantown Hotel, still open but not, he said, what it used to be.
On the boardwalk, Wildwood looked healthier. There were crowds, and Mr. Wager worked them, calling out to the locals. ("Growin' a beard?" "Dave!" "Eating again?") Passing the municipal restrooms on the beach, he announced: "She does a good job with those bathrooms, that girl. At $6.50 an hour. Sheesh!"
And while looking rather unmayoral as he strode forth in khaki shorts, white socks and black sneakers, Mr. Wager drew many waves. Along the arcades and pizza-stand counters, young men with the general demeanor of bouncers called him "sir." Of his constituents, he said, "I know them all; well, I've been in all their houses."
He stopped to see his wife, Ethel, who works at the Wildwood tourist center. ("We're Fred and Ethel," he said. "We're friends of Lucy and Desi.") Across the boardwalk, he ducked into Mr. Nickels's office and pointed out a chalkboard there that still bore the vote tallies on the casino referendum three years ago.
The rest of the day looked promising. There was an evening party for the police union, and in the afternoon Mr. Wager had to return an important and welcome phone call. It concerned an investor's proposal to open a 10-screen movie theater in Wildwood, which as of this summer is down to none.

HEADLINE: Keep Economics Professors Out of Phone Deregulation

 BODY:

To the Editor:
One grows a little weary of Alfred E. Kahn's efforts to rationalize the mess he made of the airlines (higher fares, inconvenience, delay and reduced safety from extra stops along the way) by trying to force similar advantages on customers of other regulated utilities ("Hung Up," Soapbox, Aug 30). 
 "Deregulating" local telephone service is just plain silly. How can local exchange carriers provide competitors with bulk-rate service priced so low that it can be resold at a profit below what Mr. Kahn says is an already artificially low price because of subsidies from overpriced business customers?
That Mr. Kahn's grasp of the problem is tenuous can be seen from his belief that it costs no more to serve business customers than residential ones. In general, large-business customers use small automatic switches to concentrate their calls from many lines to a much smaller number of trunks to the central office. As a result, trunks carry 8 to 12 calls an hour all day, while residential lines (at least those without Internet access, the vast majority) are seldom used more than five minutes an hour. Thus more switching capacity per line at the central office is required for business customers.
The actual technical problems involved are both interesting and challenging. However, they cannot be solved with principles offered by that most unprincipled group, tenured professors of economics who wish to inflict competition on others, no matter how much it costs or how it degrades service.
 
EE GOELLER
Haddonfield

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
David Jefferson and Dawn Comer

 BODY:
Dawn Renee Comer, the daughter of Dr. James P. Comer of North Haven, Conn., and the late Shirley A. Comer, was married on Martha's Vineyard yesterday to David Christopher Jefferson, the son of Jewel and Thomas Jefferson of Cambria Heights, Queens. The Rev. Frederick J. Streets, the Yale University chaplain, performed the ceremony at Trinity United Methodist Church in Oak Bluffs, Mass.
Mrs. Jefferson, 34, is a screenwriter and an actress in North Hollywood, Calif., and a screenwriting fellow at Walt Disney Studios in Burbank, Calif. She graduated from Northwestern University.
Her father is an associate dean of students and the Maurice Falk Professor of Child Psychiatry at Yale. He is also the director of the Yale Child Study Center's School Development Program. Her mother, a registered nurse, was a researcher at Children's House of the Yale Child Study Center.
Mr. Jefferson, 32, is a member of the technical staff at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., where he tracks the orbit of the satellites in the global positioning satellite system. He graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. His mother retired as a secretary at the Social Security Administration office in Jamaica, Queens. His father, also retired, was a supervisor for Dobbs Houses In-Flight Food Services at Kennedy International Airport.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SUNSET PARK;
Anti-Sweatshop Group Targets Sears

BYLINE: By MARCIA BIEDERMAN 

 BODY:
A Sunset Park group that includes children of sweatshop workers is using the Sears store on Bedford Avenue in Flatbush to open a national campaign against the retail chain, which it says sells clothing made under abusive conditions.
Members of the group, the National Mobilization Against Sweatshops, protested in front of the store on Aug. 23 and said they planned to return on Saturdays. 
 "Sears is telling parents to buy clothes for back to school, but parents shouldn't buy clothes made with abuse," said Trinh Duong, a project director at the Brooklyn office of the Chinese Staff and Workers Association, of which the anti-sweatshop group is a part.
The retailer carries girls' apparel made by Street Beat Sportswear, which has been sued by the Asian American Legal Defense and Education Fund. Ken Kimerling, a lawyer for the fund, said Street Beat relied on a Brooklyn contractor whose employees, he said, worked as many as 137 hours a week and that failed to pay minimum wages. The case is pending in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.
"It's my understanding that Street Beat was no longer providing work to this contractor in question at the time that this issue was being litigated," said a Street Beat spokesman, Gary Lewi.
The Asian American Legal Defense Fund has also sued Hua Great Procetech, the contractor used by Street Beat, in Federal court. The state, meanwhile, has filed criminal and civil charges against Jian Wen Liang, asserting that workers were illegally fired and were not paid. The State Attorney General's office said the Sunset Park factory had closed in late May and apparently relocated under a different name.
Paula Davis, a spokeswoman for Sears, which is not a defendant in the suits, said the retailer had begun an audit of Street Beat and its contractors. She said Sears has been assured by Street Beat that all goods sold to Sears were made in compliance with the law and that none were produced by Hua Great Procetech.
Mr. Liang's lawyer, Alfred Lui, said, "Workers have lied."
Mr. Lui is also president of the Chinese-American Economic Development and Employment Council, which he said organized a counterdemonstration to the recent protest at Sears. The police said there were about 500 counterdemonstrators, more than three times the number of protesters.
The anti-sweatshop group says it plans to keep the pressure on. Heidi Chua, its campaign coordinator, said its mostly English-speaking members hoped to improve factory conditions and help workers who may be afraid to complain. "People are working longer and longer hours," she said. "It's a community issue." MARCIA BIEDERMAN

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2147 words

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS IN TURMOIL: THE OVERVIEW;
A Compass for Those Choppy Seas

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
In reaching stomach-churning, sleep-depriving levels last week, the gyrations of the stock market seemed to restore meaning to an old Wall Street maxim:
 To invest is to choose between eating well or sleeping well.
Some investors, their dreams disturbed, headed for the sidelines. Some, accustomed to filets and refusing to concede that the great bull had snorted its last, rushed in to buy on what they hoped was Monday's 512-point "dip." 
 Most investors, with varying degrees of concern and confusion, probably did nothing, amid gathering worry that a healthy market correction might be turning into the first bear market in 25 years and that the world's economic problems could tip the American economy into recession.
As maxims go, it's hard to beat "First, do no harm." But paralysis in the face of change is another thing entirely.
Whatever your personal circumstances and the condition of your portfolio, financial experts say there are a number of steps that every smart household should at least consider in today's highly unsettled -- and sobering -- environment.
 
Turn Asset Allocation on Its Head
As the market boomed, brokers and other advisers kept cautioning that particular stocks or industries -- perhaps computers or cyberspace -- would inevitably prosper more than others, leaving investors' portfolios overweighted in those areas.
More broadly, with stocks bounding upward at more than 20 percent a year, investors who did nothing but watch could quickly find themselves deeper in equities than they had intended. The remedy, readily dispensed, was to pare back such positions, reinvesting elsewhere to maintain a sensible degree of diversification.
Now, after a downdraft, the opposite may apply. If too small a proportion of your portfolio's value is committed to an area you still favor, the right move would be to bulk up. As Brian Grodman, a financial planner in Manchester, N. H., put it: "This is the time to buy that Dell Computer. It's pure common sense."
Of course, buying a company that is still selling at 52 times its anticipated earnings may not seem sensible to everyone. But if your horizon is long term, your sleep sound and your portfolio skewed by the market's retreat, you might want to raise your exposure to stocks in general.
Abby Joseph Cohen, the indomitably bullish strategist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, increased her recommended stock allotment to 72 percent of assets from 65 percent last week, at the expense of cash and commodities.
Continuing to buy a favored stock as it declines -- when it's "on sale," to an optimist's eye -- is a form of dollar-cost averaging, one of the more sound investment strategies. By putting a specified sum of money into a stock at regular intervals, you get more shares for your money when prices are down. And for any given period, your average cost per share is lower than the stock's average price.
For the strategy to work, however, the company must be strong enough to ultimately prosper. And you must be disciplined enough to persist at times like these, when it may seem dicey to buck the market crowd.
 
Put Your Cash to Better Use
The sleeping-versus-eating test may send many investors in search of the safest havens, rather than in pursuit of reasons for buying more shares. And though Russians may have been driven lately to stash even more money under the mattress, Americans have numerous alternatives if fear or prudence dictates keeping a bigger part of their savings in cash.
The choices are different enough to be meaningful even for relatively modest sums -- and of much significance when parking, say, tens of thousands of dollars that you have pulled out of stocks.
Treasury bills -- Government i.o.u.'s sold at a discount and redeemed at face value at maturities that range up to a year -- are for the belt-and-suspenders crowd who insist on maximum safety and who will accept lower yields to avoid state and local income tax on interest. The return on the one-year bill was 4.66percent on Friday.
Interest rates are a bit higher on longer-term Treasury securities -- about 5 percent for two years and five years. But if you don't expect to hold these until maturity, be prepared for market prices to jump around; if you sell, you might get less than you paid.
Bond funds, including those that hold corporate issues, are another possibility. Shorter-term funds yield lower returns but are much less volatile. Whatever the horizon of the portfolio, experts caution against buying bond funds on the basis of advertised historical performance instead of current yields. You also need to be alert to sales, management and redemption fees, which can slash the return.
Bond funds with ultra-short-term holdings can offer higher returns than money market mutual funds with similar liquidity, but costs are typically higher, too. For many people, then, money market funds are likely the best place for stashing cash. These funds combine the convenience of a checking account with near-perfect liquidity and returns that can be more than double those paid on savings accounts. Unlike money market accounts at banks, however, money market mutual funds are not insured.
"It's the ultimate in flexibility," said Bruce R. Bent, president of the Reserve Funds, a mutual fund company based in Manhattan. Mr. Bent and a partner devised the money market fund in the early 1970's, creating what is now a $1.3 trillion industry.
Rates are averaging about 5.03 percent, and you don't have to lock up your money for a set period, as you would with a bank certificate of deposit. (A table listing money market fund yields is on page 26.)
There is often little to distinguish one money fund from another. But some have high minimum balances or other restrictions, like limits on the number of checks you can write. And note that, unless you're paying income taxes at very high rates -- the top Federal rate of 39.6 percent or a combination of state and Federal rates approaching that level -- you will almost certainly do better with a money fund that is invested in taxable short-term securities than in tax-exempt municipals.
"The vast majority of people would be better served by putting their money into taxable funds," said Mr. Bent, whose firm offers both kinds.
 
Take Money Where You Can Find It
When the economy and the stock market were both barreling ahead, some people got a bit carried away -- including those who thought it reasonable to carry credit card balances with 18 percent interest rates when they could make 30 percent a year by keeping that money in the stock market.
Now the odds have clearly shifted, said Gerri Detweiler, an adviser to Debt Counselors of America, a Rockville, Md.-based educational group whose sponsors include lenders. "The stock market is a risky place, while paying off your credit card is a guaranteed high-return, tax-free proposition," she said.
That is especially true if you select the card wisely. Ms. Detweiler recommends searching out one with a fixed, moderate rate and ignoring those splashy offers of cards with low teaser rates that jump after six months or a year to the high teens.
Even then, she said, make it a habit to pay your balance each month -- and pay on time. Growing numbers of card issuers are imposing fees as high as $29 for being just a couple of days late with a payment, no matter how little you owe.
There are other easy ways to trim debts and to lower interest payments if you've grown less sanguine about the performance of your investments. For instance, making extra payments on your mortgage can sharply reduce your interest payments over time, effectively putting money in your pocket.
"The roof over your head is substantially more secure than investing in the stock market," said Marc Eisenson, co-author of a new book, "Invest in Yourself: Six Secrets to a Rich Life" (John Wiley & Sons, 1998, $22.95).
Refinancing your mortgage is another possibility, though mortgage rates, hovering above 7 percent, have not fallen as sharply as might be expected, given the tumbling yields on Government bonds. An overarching principle here, of course, is that any cost-cutting is more valuable than it appears because, with state and Federal taxes, a dollar saved is worth as much as $1.50 earned.
Another principle is to take free money when it's offered to you. Even if you are worried about the market's trajectory, it's hard to make a case against accepting the company match on your contributions to a 401(k) plan or other savings programs.
"It is very important to continue to fund these plans," said Mr. Grodman, the New Hampshire financial planner. Despite the current unease, people should remember, he said, that "this is just one week or one month in the time horizon of their investment life."
 
Make Your Job a Better Investment
Have a lot of faith in your company's prospects, even though the stock has been beaten down? Maybe it's time to talk to the boss about the makeup of your pay package.
Not everyone has the necessary clout. But in light of lower share prices, some people whose compensation includes stock or options might succeed in arguing for an earlier or larger grant. Or they might ask to renegotiate their package: instead of $300,000 in cash, the arrangement could be $200,000 in cash plus some form of stock.
That, of course, is not the career move of someone who has a weak stomach. And benefits consultants expect that employers, anticipating queasiness to prevail among their staffs, may move in the opposite direction.
"Companies may start to look at performance-based cash plans," said Donald L. Lowman, managing director for compensation at Towers Perrin, the management consulting firm. In other words, old-fashioned bonuses could supplant stock-based incentive plans if the markets continue to slide.
This might also be a time to reassess a broader range of priorities in life, some of which may have been shoved aside in fin-de-siecle careerism and obsession with money. The tumble of the stock market could force a realization that there is more to life than work and its material rewards.
To Mr. Eisenson and his co-authors, the idea is to find your own balance of investments -- "a portfolio not just of stocks and bonds but one that includes investments in yourself and in your family."
But for most people, that will take quite an attitude adjustment; after all, their job is their chief economic asset. So even though the unemployment rate is at its lowest since the Nixon Administration, some people are bound to conclude that it wouldn't hurt to make an extra effort at the office. Or, perhaps, to think about some sideline work in case a weakening economy brings renewed bouts of corporate downsizing.
 
Mine the Rubble for Gold
Experienced investors know that markets nearly always overreact, but only a minority find the nerve to search out -- and actually buy -- the inevitable bargains. Sooner or later, though, solid stocks that have been tossed aside indiscriminately will be uncovered, often by those value-oriented investors who concentrate their hunt on a group that has been most thoroughly trashed.
"I look for an asset class that's way down," said Cynthia Meyers, a financial planner in Sacramento, Calif. -- as long as it is something that fits an investor's risk tolerance. These days, for example, she might ask clients if they can stomach gyrations in technology stocks.
For some investors, companies like Microsoft might qualify as good values, as would companies in other industries -- makers of farm equipment and other heavy machinery, for example. Other investors shop for companies whose stocks have more or less held up, like regional banks, figuring they may take off when the market steadies.
There is even value in losing money -- though it may be especially painful if the stock in question recently let you gloat over handsome paper profits. Losses, if actually realized, can minimize taxes by offsetting profits from the sale of other assets. You can even create such a loss without giving up on what you still think is a good idea or running afoul of rules barring wash transactions; you can switch, say, from Exxon to Mobil stock, or from one growth mutual fund to a similar one.
And if you're interested in passing along assets to children without subjecting the transfer to the gift tax, a drop in stock prices means that you can give them more shares before you and your spouse reach your annual limit of $20,000 per child.
In these iffy days, though, the single smartest thing to do may be to make a basic change in thinking -- and then to act accordingly.
"There's been a kind of greedy attitude, a naive assumption that we can invest in anything and it will go up," Ms. Meyers said. "It's good now that clients do see that downs come with the ups."

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL: Sport Utilities With Training Wheels;
'98 Isuzu Amigo: A Brawny Little Brute

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
MINI-SPORT utilities are for poseurs who covet the look, not the function. Face it: the real appeal of the wildly popular Subaru Forester, Toyota RAV4 and Honda CRV is comfort, splendid road manners and a great view of traffic.
One significant exception has been the Jeep Wrangler, the Jeep closest in spirit to the tough, simple general-purpose vehicles that landed with the Allies at Normandy. Now the Wrangler has to make room for some newcomers, including the Isuzu Amigo, a brawny little two-door beast with serious off-road capability and impressive V6 power to match. The downside is a harsh ride, wretched side vision and sticker shock. 
 The Isuzu Amigo made its debut in 1989 as a stripped-down utility for the young at heart. It was noisy and underpowered, and the canvas roof over what would otherwise have been the rear of a very small pick-up truck offered minimal protection against the elements. But it was cheap as four-wheel-drive vehicles go, cute and a great hit with people in their 20's.
The new 1998 Amigo (the old model rode into the sunset in 1994) still comes with a canvas top and soft plastic windows in the back. But a hard-roof option is planned as a 1999 model. Both versions offer more of what appealed to buyers of the old Amigo, plus an optional dose of muscle and luxury.
The base model has a 2.2 liter, 130 horsepower, four-cylinder engine, lean for a 3,335-pound truck. But the optional 3.2-liter, 205-horsepower aluminum V6, producing 214 pounds of torque at a modest 3,000 R.P.M., provides oomph.
All that power could be downright dangerous hitched to the primitive suspension of the earlier-generation Amigo. But the Isuzu engineers did their homework: while the vehicle feels heavy, it accelerates out of corners with impressive stability and only modest body roll. Anti-lock brakes and a somewhat mushy five-speed manual gearbox are standard.
I didn't try to navigate the Great Dismal Swamp in my test vehicle. It was fine, though, on poorly maintained dirt roads.
The Amigo is noisy at highway speeds, with the canvas top chattering in the wind. The stiff shocks guarantee that you feel every bump. And the backseat resembles a church pew, with the saving grace that it folds down easily to add cargo capacity.
But the front seats are comfy and supportive. The fit and finish are up to Japanese standards -- though the truck is manufactured in Indiana. And the stereo speakers are a cut above economy grade.
Apart from the busy, bumpy highway ride, the Amigo's only big fault is the big rear "C" pillars that stiffen the frame but create huge blind spots on both sides. Check that: there's also the price. While a two-wheel-drive version can be had for a shade more than $15,000, four-wheel drive and the V6 engine push it close to $20,000. A lot of money for your average surfer dude.

INSIDE TRACK: -- A versatile mini-ute, aimed at the macho end of the youth market.

GRAPHIC: Photo: With the Amigo, Isuzu has a mini-utility worthy of challenging the Jeep Wrangler.

HEADLINE: VIEW;
Sell the Range Rover; It's Ford Time

BYLINE: By William Grimes 

 BODY:
SO, the long slide begins. This time, though, instead of being boiled in oil, like they were in 1987, investors look as though they will get a slow poaching. If 1989 was a head-on at 60 miles per hour, 1998 is more like running out of gas on the Garden State just after you enter the express lanes.
Still, a hundred points here, a hundred points there -- pretty soon it begins to add up, and the formerly flush will have to start trading down. After nearly seven fat years on Wall Street, America may be poised for a life style retooling. 
 It will be subtle. Chastened by the last market crash, the Wall Street winners spent their cash with a lot less flash this time around. There are no swaggering figures on the scale of Michael R. Milken, Donald J. Trump or Ivan F. Boesky. There was less cocaine, more Deepak Chopra.
The arrogance of the 1980's gave way to humble gratitude in the 90's. America enjoyed the party for as long as it lasted, but always there was the nagging sense that midnight would arrive, the lights would dim and everyone would have to go home. It was fun while it lasted, but it had to end, and the end, in retrospect, could have been predicted.
Hemlines, historically an accurate leading economic indicator, plunged right down to the ankles this spring, anticipating the Dow's dive. And could it have been anything other than an omen when several Manhattan restaurateurs were rounded up last month for selling illicit Cuban cigars, the very emblem of the 90's-style Master of the Universe?
No one is going to be trading in a Cohibo for a Tiparillo, but adjustments will be made. The signature 90's car, the sport utility vehicle, will not go away, but the proud owner of a road-ruling Range Rover 4.0 may sneakily consider downsizing to a Ford Explorer. And if the market continues to contract, there's always a Kia Sportage. Have your eye on a Porsche 911? Try thinking Volkswagen Bug. Same basic shape.
At Manhattan's top steakhouses, the double magnums of Petrus will go back to the wine cellar. Instead, several sommeliers around town predict, the bonus babies who pushed the Bordeaux prices straight through the roof will return to comfort wines. "They'll go back to California, to wines like Beringer Private Reserve Cabernet, or anything by Phelps," said Andrea Immer, the wine director at Windows on the World. "When you're in a depressed state of mind, you don't get experimental."
Daniel Johnnes, the wine director at Montrachet, looks into his crystal ball and sees strange things. For the cult wines of the 90's, he said, look to Spain or Chile, where they turn out wines Wall Street wouldn't gargle with a year ago. "They might want to look for the boutique beers out of Belgium," he added helpfully.
Thanks a lot.
Although their wine sales might sag at the top end, restaurants could do well out of a market correction. "Good food is one of the last things you give up," Clark Wolf, a restaurant consultant, said. "You're more likely to give up your trip to that clever little island off the coast of whatever, so we may actually see more restaurant-going."
But count on the menu to change as foodies come eye-to-eye with a bear market. New Yorkers have been gobbling foie gras and truffles fast enough to create shortages. A more chaste cuisine may lie around the corner, not the comfort food of the early 90's but less indulgent fare. "We are going to find new peasant foods," Mr. Wolf predicted. "I see herbs. I see turkey burgers."
If it does nothing else, a punctured Dow could thin out the surplus population of cell phones, easing the pressure on area codes and eliminating the widespread pretraumatic stress syndrome associated with potential loss of one's 212 status. With luck, ugly additions like 908, 773 and 847 could be recalled.
Better yet, the market should let the air out of grossly distended Internet stocks. The 80's had junk bonds. The 90's have Yahoo and Amazon.com. and, if ever a scapegoat figure is going to emerge from the current mess, Bill Gates, supreme lord of the Net, could be it. The Justice Department's antitrust case against Microsoft comes up soon, and a comeuppance for its chief executive, Mr. Gates could ease a lot of social tension.
Mr. Gates replaced "greed is good," Gordon Gekko's famous 80's mantra, with a shambling, Jimmy Stewart style. There's a lot of free-floating anxiety in the air. Mr. Gates could be the man for the moment, a lightning rod for a lot of bad feelings.
Fashion looks as if it's right on the money, or lack of it. Although riding a wave of prosperity, designers hedged their bets for this fall, sneaking in more luxurious fabrics, fondling a little fur, but keeping the look dressed-down. It's a lot easier to climb down from cashmere than a Christian Lacroix pouf skirt, the image of late-80's excess. As though anticipating the recessionary mood, designers from Marc Jacobs to Calvin Klein have invested in a new color this season: gray. Gray is perfect. It suggests mild depression rather than black despair.
Meanwhile, someone ought to check in on Ira Rennert, the reclusive industrialist, out there in Bridgehampton. Is that house he is planning still going to be 72,000 square feet? Or is he maybe thinking of a nice four-bedroom Cape Cod?

GRAPHIC: Photos: Cars that harmonize with the market: during the boom, a Range Rover, top; now, a Ford Explorer Sport, center, or a Toyota Rav.

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Mixed Signals for Big-Ticket Buying

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
DON'T tell Chuck and Donna Gulland that last Monday's stock selloff was just one of those market dips of no lasting consequence. The couple were supposed to close last Tuesday on the sale of their home in Sunnyvale, Calif. "We had everything we owned packed," said Mrs. Gulland, who expected to turn over the keys of her three-bedroom, two-bath home to Antonitta and Joseph Blazina of San Jose.
"We walked in expecting to sign the last papers," Mrs. Gulland said, "and we were told the deal was off." The 1,700-square-foot home was to have sold for $489,900. 
 The Blazinas balked, unnerved by the stock market's effect on prospective buyers of their own five-bedroom home.
A few weeks earlier, those candidates were competing to meet the Blazinas' asking price of $589,900 -- behavior in keeping with the super-heated Silicon Valley real estate market, where home prices have been appreciating at double the national average.
But as the stock market continued to slide from the peaks set in July, and after scores of prospects had walked through the home the weekend before Monday's plunge, only a single offer -- $30,000 below the asking price -- was still on the table.
"We got scared," Ms. Blazina acknowledged. There could be weeks of uncertainty in home prices, she said, fueled by the stock market turmoil. So the Blazinas chose to forfeit their $15,000 deposit and scrapped the Gulland deal.
"Better to take the sure loss than maybe gamble," Ms. Blazina said, "and it could be more then."
The good times aren't over in Silicon Valley, or other enclaves where affluence rose with the raging bull market. Expensive homes are still being bought -- and cars and boats and baubles, too.
But stories like those of the Gullands and Blazinas are popping up in even the most comfortable circles, as big-ticket purchases are reconsidered in light of the markets' tumble of the last two months.
For example, some clients of Farid Saatchi, owner of F & S Jewelry in Manhattan, were less enthusiastic than usual last week.
He said one customer, who earns her living investing, changed her mind about buying $15,000 of unset diamonds. "She wanted to wait and see what happens," Mr. Saatchi said. "People slow down on everything. They get nervous."
And the market's whipsaw slowed the buying impulses of two serious prospects for Business Jetsolutions, a Dallas company that sells ownership shares in private jets. Michael C. Riegel, a vice president, said both clients were executives in stock funds.
"They asked to delay," said Mr. Riegel, who valued the now-dormant deals at less than $500,000 apiece. "I think they'll be back with us in a number of weeks."
Mr. Reigel's optimistic outlook is widely shared in the ranks of the affluent -- or even the reasonably comfortable.
In fact, instead of putting the brakes on spending, some Michigan consumers saw the stock market's weakness as a sign to buy -- cars, that is.
In recent years, some longtime customers of the Pontiac-Olds-GMC dealer in Frankenmuth, Mich., had neglected their annual rite of selecting a new model. "Most bought a new car every year," said Michael D. Young, the owner of the dealership, adding that many customers are former auto workers, eligible for a manufacturer's discount.
He said one of the customers explained his absence as a consequence of the surging market. "Why draw 20 grand out of the market when it's earning 20 percent?"
Within the last 10 days, though, four such customers came in with cash in hand, ready to buy. "They put it off because they wanted to put their money in the market," Mr. Young said. "When it dropped, it put them over the edge."
Garth Blumenthal, general manager of Fletcher Jones Motorcars, a Mercedes-Benz dealership in Newport Beach, Calif., said it sold 90 new cars the last five days of August. "It's a pretty typical or better-than-average month-end," he said.
"Our business isn't affected by Asia and Russia," he said, referring to the regions whose financial crises may well have prompted the market's decline. "Interest rates play a very strong role," he said.
THEN there were those who left the market before the plunge. Gary R. Clifford, a luxury yacht broker for Richard Bertram & Company in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said his customers weren't troubled by recent market turmoil because "a lot of people are already liquid."
Some buyers favoring Bertram's Italian boats were already in cash, anticipating that the dollar would weaken against the euro, Europe's new currency, when it is adopted next January, he said.
Mr. Clifford said he personally sold three yachts, for more than $1.7 million each, in the last month, and overall sales at Bertram have been normal. "No one's canceled."
Bertram's confidence is reflected in its inventory, which includes an $8.8 million, 118-foot Benetti yacht that is to be displayed at a boat show in January. "For us to put these very expensive products in stock means we are very aggressive," Mr. Clifford said.
Far from Fort Lauderdale, Wayne W. Crosby, a real estate broker in Midland, Mich., ignored any losses in his stock portfolio and was set to complete a purchase sometime this week of a 40-foot pleasure boat costing $300,000. "With low interest rates, you can't own it any cheaper," he said.
William B. Brennan, co-owner of Brennan Marine Sales in Bay City, Mich., who is selling the boat to Mr. Crosby, said: "I don't ever recall it making a difference in our sales. People don't sell stock to buy a boat."
They sometimes do, though, to buy jewelry, according to Alfredo J. Molina, a jeweler in Phoenix. "My product is looked on as diversification of assets," Mr. Molina said. "We've had a record year. A lot of people have been taking profits."
Last Monday and Tuesday, for example, Mr. Molina said, customers bought a $60,000 five-carat emerald ring, a $450,000 ruby-and-sapphire bracelet and a $145,000 diamond necklace.
While buying jewelry can be seen as a flight to hard assets during uncertain times, Mr. Molina said he thinks his customers justify their purchases for a different reason. "They believe in enjoying their money," he said. "None that I've talked to are running for cover."
Nor is he. Mr. Molina is expanding his shop by 4,200 square feet and adding Spanish jewelry by Carerra y Carerra, Chopard Swiss watches and Cartier accessories. "Finding merchandise is the biggest challenge," he said.
An equally bullish appraisal for luxury sales came from Anthony J. D'Ambrosio, executive vice president of Tourneau Inc., the Swiss watch retailer whose line includes $3,000 Rolexes and $75,000 Patek Philippe timepieces.
"The reality is, the best products we can't get enough of," he said from his Manhattan office, adding that Tourneau customers enjoy showing off their financial success.
"You can't take your Van Gogh into the boardroom, or a restaurant or to the beach," Mr. D'Ambrosio said. "People who do well in the market are people who are experienced; it doesn't affect their spending."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Donna Gulland and her husband, Chuck, were preparing to move out of their home in Sunnyvale, Calif., when a potential buyer backed out because of the drop in the market. (Peter DaSilva for The New York Times)
