HEADLINE: The Nation;
Postcards From a What-Me-Worry Summer

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
SURE, Jamie Dimon, the co-chairman of Salomon Smith Barney, had to fly home from his August vacation in Europe when the market fell over 500 points last week. But after noodling with his Bloomberg terminal, and conferring with colleagues, he headed right back once the Dow regained some of its steadiness.
Suzanne Daub, owner of Nantucket.net, an Internet cafe on the Massachusetts island, noticed in recent weeks more people coming in to check stock quotes -- most with a beach towel on one arm and a smile. 
 Now is the summer of our blithe ambivalence.
On the surface, the country has been faced with weeks of turmoil. "If someone sat down on July 4th and made a list of predictions for the political and economic outlook, most of them would have been wrong," said David Blitzer, chief economist at Standard & Poor's Corporation in New York. "Everyone thought Monica Lewinsky would go away, she didn't. We thought we knew Russian policy. People thought the Asia crisis was taking a step back, but it reawakened."
Yet Americans are far from depressed. News about falling currencies, market fluctuations and sexual peccadilloes seem less harbingers of bad times than distractions from the steak and hot dogs on the grill. While a few polls indicate that some Americans are concerned about the distant future, the reigning sentiment out there now is one of relative satisfaction.
"The public feels the media is out of touch with day-to-day life," said Michael Harrison, editor of Talkers Magazine, a trade publication for talk radio and television shows. "It is a time of uncertainty, but people base their confidence or lack of it based on what is happening in their own lives."
So where is the outrage, as Bob Dole once demanded? It is apparently limited to those beachgoers vexed by the twittering cellular phones of their neighbor on the next towel.
"People were pacing back and forth on the beach in East Hampton looking very stressed," said Jason Weisenfeld, an executive at Barneys New York. "It was very out of character."
But that is not the lot of most Americans. Though more of them own mutual funds today than before, most are passive investors, doing pretty much what their broker tells them, and are in for the long term. Those sophisticated enough to manage their own money are far too wealthy to let one downturn scare them.
With the horrific exception of recent terrorist bombings and last week's airplane crash, many crises of the summer of 1998 have lacked human drama. Who will say, as they did with the death of Princess Diana, "Where were you when Russia devalued the ruble?"
Some, though, simply see opportunity in the losses. "With the Asia collapse, everyone says it is terrible," said Richard Gelfond, the co-chief executive of the Imax Corporation, in a phone interview from his home in Southampton. "We are saying to theater owners that real estate prices there have fallen so much that they can open theaters at a fraction of the cost."
People who were more connected to the economic vicissitudes had their summer vacations marred. "When the world's events are dominating the news, taking a vacation is not going to happen," lamented Lisa R. Berkowitz, the vice president and director of marketing and communications for Harper Business, a unit of HarperCollins, the publisher. "Between the stock market and Russia, everyone in public relations cringes. You're afraid to leave the office."
Then there are those who have taken vacations to give the appearance of indifference to crisis -- only to have to cut them short. Like Bill Clinton. Bringing his problems with him like so much carry-on luggage, he went to Martha's Vineyard -- a place where others may have been trying to escape him -- then promptly returned home to deal with military action against terrorist targets.
Speaking of politics, things could be better. "It has been a rough summer for political folks," said Chris Lapetina, a partner at Global Strategy Group, a democratic polling firm in New York, where a primary election is just around the corner. "Those who think about the global financial situation are thinking about that more than the political situation here, and that is very frustrating for our candidates. People just are not focused in at all."
And while many chief executives are relaxing at their summer homes, some of the workers in Wall Street's trenches -- brokers, traders and analysts -- will respond to the question of what they did this summer with one word -- panic.
"I am a prisoner of my own vacation," lamented Thomas H. Hanley, a managing director at Warburg Dillon Read, who analyzes bank stocks. "First, there was Hurricane Bonnie. Then, there was the market. Calls. Faxes. Messages. Traders. Media. I've been doing this for many years, but this has been the most difficult summer I can remember in 25 years." Mr. Hanley was so stressed he recently locked himself out of his Southampton house.
Abby Joseph Cohen, the investment strategist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, simply took her computer along on vacation. During market turmoil in early August, she sent reassuring faxes from Israel to clients. "Nothing ruined my wonderful trip," she said. "I don't ever really turn off. I go into standby mode."

HEADLINE: The Nation: Confidence Counts;
Everybody's Measuring Consumer Fears. Big Deal.

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
LAST week, as the stock market tumbled, President Clinton's political embarrassments deepened and Russia's financial crisis snowballed, the biggest fear suddenly became fear itself.
Never mind that the economy is in its best shape in decades, that unemployment and inflation are remarkably low, the budget is balanced and the Federal Reserve is content to leave interest rates alone. The newest worry is that all the scary headlines will so unnerve consumers -- whose spending has been a key source of the economy's strength in recent years -- that sheer pessimism will keep them away from malls, car dealerships and the housing market, igniting a recession. 
 "It's about psychology as opposed to money," said Nicholas Perna, chief economist at Fleet Bank. "I'm absolutely convinced that people identify the stock market with the economy. When the market is tanking, they know things can't be good."
 
A Case of Vapors
Mr. Perna, revealing something of a pessimistic streak himself, said he expected the economy to turn extremely sluggish or worse. But the notion that a national case of the vapors -- as opposed to a scarcity of jobs, income or wealth -- can cause an otherwise healthy economy to swoon calls for some skepticism.
As David Wyss, chief economist at Standard & Poor's DRI, put it late last week, "As far as getting spooked, it takes an awful lot to scare an American."
 
Historic Highs
Economic forecasters track two monthly indexes of consumer confidence religiously. Even though economists disagree on how important consumer confidence is and even what the indexes measure, they agree that confidence has been hovering at historical highs for the past few years and that spending has been remarkably strong.
The older survey of confidence, begun in 1947, is conducted by the University of Michigan. The newer one was started in the late 1960's by the Conference Board, a New York-based research organization, and is more familiar to the public.
Each employs slightly different sampling techniques, asks different questions and tabulates its results at different times of the month. The Michigan survey is available only to paying clients, while the Conference Board's index is released to the press.
In trying to gauge consumer confidence, the surveyors are actually trying to capture the expectations of households in three basic areas: personal finance, economic conditions and buying conditions. Both surveys ask five questions, but add others from time to time to monitor consumers' changing concerns.
In the Michigan survey, two questions focus on the respondents' financial situation. Two other questions have to do with opinions about overall economic conditions and the final one asks whether now is a good time to buy a major appliance. The Conference Board's questions focus more on job availability and less on personal finances.
Michigan conducts a phone survey of 500 households and the Conference Board mails questionnaires to 5,000 households, and after the answers are collected they are are combined into the indexes.
 
Parallel Track
Both confidence measures generally move in sync with consumer spending, and every recession has been preceded or accompanied by a sharp drop in confidence. Similarly, every recovery has been preceded or accompanied by a rebound in confidence.
Both the size and duration of the change in confidence make a difference. It takes about a 10 percent decline over a month or two to register as a significant shift, and it's not just the change in confidence but the level that counts. "Anything above 90 indicates strong spending," said Lynn Franco, an economist at the Conference Board.
In August, the Conference Board's index was 133, close to the high of 140 set in the late 1960's. "It could drop 20 points without necessarily signaling a sharp slowdown in spending," Ms. Franco said.
The Michigan index is close to 105, also near its high. But after last week's drop of 411.43 points in the Dow Jones industrial average, economists will be looking for signs of consumers' reaction in both September indexes.
 
Questions of Value
There is disagreement among economists as to whether confidence measures are useful for predicting future spending patterns or spotting turning points in the economy. The benchmark study of confidence, published in the American Economic Review shortly after the 1990-1991 recession, concluded that the indexes are useful but limited in value.
A more recent study by two economists at the New York Federal Reserve, Sydney Ludvigson and Jason Bram, suggests that the Conference Board index may be a more useful indicator. "Consumers seem to spend more when they feel good about future job prospects than they do when they think business conditions are favorable," Ms. Ludvigson said.
The most notable episode in which the consumer confidence index was the first true sign that the economy was heading into a recession was in the summer of 1990, when Iraq invaded Kuwait and oil prices doubled within a matter of days. Confidence plunged, and within weeks spending stalled and the economy was in a nose dive. Lots of economists, including the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, were caught by surprise.
Many drops in confidence are too small or too short to affect spending. When political events lead to drops in confidence at a time when the overall economy looks healthy, the drop is almost always temporary. In October 1987, for example, the Dow plunged 500 points, or 20 percent, in a single day, and the next month the Conference Board's index dropped 20 points, to nearly 100. But perhaps because an export boom was under way, consumers recovered their spirits within a couple of months, and the index bounced back.
Richard Curtin, the economist who runs the Michigan survey, points out that by the late 1980's consumers had figured out that employment, income and economic growth no longer moved in sync with the stock market -- as they had in the 1960's and 1970's. "In 1987, consumers saw no repercussions for income or employment growth from the stock market decline and therefore mostly ignored it," Mr. Curtin said.
At the same time, surges in confidence related to politically popular events but not supported by improvements in the economy also tend to be short-lived. Consumer confidence surged after the Persian Gulf war, but the indexes quickly fell again because the economy and job growth remained sluggish.
Other economists don't see much of a cause-and-effect relationship at all between confidence and spending, but see the indexes as useful nonetheless.
"Confidence is more of a summary measure of things that affect spending than a specific cause in its own right," said Ed McKelvey, an economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York.
 
Helpful Previews
In general, forecasters say the real importance of measuring confidence has less to do with the power of psychology than the timeliness of the reports. Confidence surveys come out two weeks before the Government's monthly employment reports and a month to six weeks before reports on consumer spending.
If consumer sentiment reflects their perception of the job market and business conditions, then it is a convenient preliminary reading for economists.
"There's no denying it's important, but the main thing that makes it interesting is that it comes out on a timely basis," said one forecaster. "If you could see the September employment numbers or the Conference Board survey, you'd rather see the jobs numbers."

HEADLINE: The Nation: Roll 'Em;
Feeling Secure Is a Risky Business

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AMERICANS who never fought a war or feared a depression could be forgiven for imagining a risk-free world. Living high and mighty, consuming more than their share of the world's food and fuel, feeling secure within their borders and even reasonably safe outside them, they could envision a boundless zone of security in which American money and power and culture and technology would insure some sort of peace.
But when markets tumble into turbulence, wiping out $4 trillion of the world's wealth, and a plane to Switzerland, home of stolid banks and precise watchworks, plummets from the sky, and the United States hurls missiles at an armed theosopher in Afghanistan, inviting retaliation against American emblems everywhere, the odds in the big casino can feel like they are shifting back to the house.
 
More to Lose
At least subconsciously, people calculate those odds every time they board a plane or take a flier. Today the well-off may have reason to feel at risk: They have more to lose, more creature comforts, more paper profits. Global crashes can stir the survivalist inside the most confident suburbanite. 
 Risk was a great thing when new worlds and new frontiers beckoned and the risk-takers had little to lose. Now millions of people crowd the coasts, living in more expensive properties built more shoddily than a generation ago, and more vulnerable to oceans and storms and quakes. Beyond the nation's borders, in the world's financial markets, people are also living nearer to the edge, in riskier ways, closer to the winds of rising storms. As prosperity has grown, risk has grown with it.
How do people deal with invisible global forces? Mostly, they don't.
"We have no reference point to calculate our probabilities," said Howard Kunreuther, co-director of the Center for Risk Management and Decision Processes at the Wharton School. "So, we forget. It's very costly to be scared every moment. We say, 'This isn't going to happen to me.' And then we're surprised if it happens."
Is the world really more risky than it was 40 years or 40 days ago? If so, why? As the rigid cold-war past melts into the fluid present, where the chances of being vaporized by a nuclear bomb from Vladivostok are down, but the chances of being wiped out by a currency crash in Jakarta are up, calibrating these dangers is complicated. It has energized an increasingly interesting field: risk analysis, a school of thought built from risky business: managing nuclear power, launching rockets, building dams, curing cancers, combating terrorists, buying insurance, managing mutual funds and pension plans, playing the markets -- the gamut of global gambles.
Risk, it turns out, can be quantified. But a sense of security cannot.
"What is risk?" asks Yacov Y. Haimes, president of the Society for Risk Analysis. "Risk is measurable, and composed of two parts: What could go wrong and what are the consequences? Now, safety is something else. Safety is the level of risk that's acceptable to you. Today in America we are seeking more comfort. We can afford more comfort. We expect more comfort. Go to Phoenix, in Arizona -- in a desert, they have lawns.
 
Linkages
"Now, is our world more dangerous?" he said. "It is. We are asking more of it, more comfort and therefore we are more vulnerable. The more secure we are, the more we feel the danger of losing our security. There are easy ways to inflict major pain with no major effort. People can intrude on our financial and national-security systems in much easier ways. This is because of the interconnectedness of the world and its infrastructures."
"This interlinkage," a Presidential commission warned in October, "has created a new dimension of vulnerability, which, when combined with an emerging constellation of threats, poses unprecedented national risk."
This more interwoven world may remind people of an old high-school biology lesson: that everything is connected to everything else. It calls to mind a principle of chaos theory -- that a butterfly flapping its wings in Mexico can set off a chain of disturbances that causes a hurricane in China. In the same way, a plunge in the Indonesian rupee causes chaos with the Russian ruble -- and, conceivably, with the United States Treasury, and millions of mutual funds, pension plans and young children's college savings.
"It's not only my small world any more," said Kathleen S. Gurney, chief executive officer of Financial Psychology Corp., which counsels investors, investment advisers and companies on risk-taking. "My world extends into places I have no way of gauging. I am dealing with psyches I don't understand any more. My sense of prediction is no longer as solid and as true for me. I don't have the same self-confidence I had two weeks ago. If I'm feeling this way, others must be feeling this way."
 
A Butterfly's Wings
Others in the world of the calculated risk do share that assessment. "In fact, there is more risk," said Tom Hutton, president of Risk Management Solutions, Inc. "Risks are being driven by a more complex set of factors." Mr. Hutton feels safer flying than driving, but the airport he uses, in San Francisco, "handles dramatically more flights than it used to, so the risk there increases exponentially."
"Go back to the butterfly that can cause a hurricane," he said. "When you see the linkages between something happening in Indonesia, a country most people can't find on a map, and its impact on the world economy, when you can make those connections and see the number of things that could cause a world financial crisis, you see more risk.
"We expect our borders to provide safety, and they don't anymore," he said. "When you and I were growing up people had faith in the Government, and that allowed them to be comfortable. That faith has been disturbed. Both the perception of risk and the risk itself have changed as people see they have linkages to parts of the world they didn't think affected them."
Readjusting people's sense of risk without scaring them senseless is itself a risky business. When Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned of "irrational exuberance" awhile ago, he was saying that Americans were underestimating their risks, and that the boom (or the bubble) of the 90's was feeding American culture with the notion that things would always rise and never fall -- a dangerous idea, since markets, like planes, do crash, and sometimes for similar reasons, like a loose bolt somewhere in the big machine.
 
Reality Check
This may unsettle those who dreamed of a risk-free world. "How can people assess their tolerance for risk when they've never had a loss?" Ms. Gurney said. "People have grown up in a society where they have never experienced terror, never lived through a war, never gone through a depression. Some have made fortunes overnight. They began to believe in magic."
In days gone by, people turned to leaders in times of risk. "Can you name a world leader who is strong today?" Ms. Gurney said. "Someone we can count on? Someone we can trust? We have no one we can look toward."
Another risk miscalculated: A President averse to taking chances in the public realm risked his political life for seconds of private pleasure, and so lost power to soothe people who may have reason to be scared.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:

DRUGS
Medicine for the Market
 
While the broad market slid, drug companies' shares climbed after the F.D.A. recommended approval of taxmoxifen as a means to reduce the risk of breast cancer. Zeneca Group P.L.C., which makes the drug, and Barr Laboratories, which sells its generic form, rose sharply. But Zeneca A.D.R.'s ended the week down $1.25 at $37.0625. Barr shares faired better, gaining $4.9375, to close at $33.3125. Barr also benefited from F.D.A. approval of its "morning-after" Preven Emergency Contraceptive Kit. Genentech rose, but fell back, ending the week off 25 cents at $68.75 after the F.D.A. approved its Herceptin biological drug to treat metastatic breast cancer. 

PILOTS' STRIKE
Clinton Rebuffs Plea
As the pilots' strike against Northwest Airlines snarled holiday travel plans in the Midwest, President Clinton rejected a call on Thursday by Gov. Arne Carlson of Minnesota to order the pilots back to work. The White House called on the two sides to return to the bargaining table, and they were to have met yesterday in Chicago with a Federal mediator. The pilots, who are demanding increased job security and higher pay to make up for cuts they took in 1993 to save the airline from bankruptcy, turned down the carrier's initial offer. Northwest says it cannot afford to meet the pilots' demands and has laid off more than half its 51,000 workers, saying that it could not afford to pay them while it was not operating.
 
SALES
Gains for Retailers
American retailers had fairly strong sales for August, with same-store sales -- those for stores open at least a year -- up 3.5 percent, according to the Goldman Sachs retail composite index. Wal-Mart's gain was 7.6 percent. In New York, retailers were counting on a strong September, as tax-free shopping kicked off back-to-school sales. Justin Cotto, 6, left, strains as his father, Norty Cotto, buttoned up a school uniform shirt at Lazarus for Kids on West 125th Street. . . . General Motors, still struggling from July strikes, reported that car and light-truck sales fell 36.4 percent in August, giving the industry as a whole a decrease of 6.6 percent, despite an increase in American sales for nearly all other auto companies. Ford was up 8.1 percent; Chrysler, 3.5 percent, and Toyota, 10.9 percent. American sales of Daimler-Benz's Mercedes cars surged 75.8 percent.
 
THE ECONOMY
Flashing Mixed Signals
Unemployment, as expected, held steady at a low 4.5 percent last month. . . . The industrial economy continued to show vigor in July, with new factory orders flowing in at the strongest pace in eight months, growing 1.2 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $335.2 billion. . . . Sales of new homes, however, fell 1.6 percent in July, to 886,000 units at an annual rate, which was more than expected. . . . Growth in workers' productivity posted the smallest gain in nearly two years in the last quarter -- 0.1 percent, though that was better than a preliminary estimate of a drop of 0.2 percent.
 
RUSSIA
Losses and More Losses
President Clinton, meeting with President Boris N. Yeltsin in Moscow, delivered a sober lecture to Russian leaders and the Russian people about the hard realities of capitalism and the price of international support for relief from Russia's financial mess. The crisis has closed banks, left millions of workers unpaid and caused the collapse of the Government. He signaled, however, that the West would step up its aid if the Kremlin pressed ahead with tough economic changes. Western banks and investment funds, particularly German institutions, that bet on Russia disclosed losses that totaled in the billions of dollars. Among those reporting sizable losses were Citicorp, Bankers Trust, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Barclays and Nomura Securities.
 
THE WORLD
The Malaise Spreads
The Finance Minister of Mexico, Jose Angel Gurria, who runs a vigorously growing economy with surging exports and thousands of new jobs being added daily, lamented how the Asian and Russian economic crises have battered stock prices in Latin America. "It has nothing to do with Mexico," he said of the outside problems. "There is a lack of differentiation" among traders. Asia's troubles were seen anew in South Korea, where nonperforming bank loans surged 11.8 percent between March and June to $21.4 billion, and riot policemen were called in to quell strikers. Above, a worker's family tries to block the officers' way at Mando Machinery in Asan. In Malaysia, the Finance Minister, Anway Ibrahim, was dismissed after the Government imposed currency controls.
 
COMPANIES
Bell Atlantic Buyouts
Bell Atlantic, only weeks after agreeing to a new contract with its unionized workers, extended a voluntary buyout offer to some of its management employees. . . . Royal Dutch/Shell and Texaco agreed to combine their European refining and marketing businesses, a step toward cutting costs and capacity. . . . Union Pacific, still recovering from some of the worst congestion in railway history, announced a plan to improve and, in some cases, ration its service. . . . Delta Air Lines, after failing to reach an agreement with its pilots, dropped plans to link its routes with United Airlines. The plan had been the cornerstone of a marketing partnership announced in April.
 
PEOPLE
The Show Goes On
Livent Inc. named Todd Haimes, the artistic director of the Roundabout Theater Company, as its artistic director, supplanting Garth H. Drabinsky, Livent's co-founder and the producer of "Ragtime" and several other lavish Broadway musicals. Livent's new managers, led by Michael Ovitz, suspended Mr. Drabinsky and a vice president last month, citing accounting irregularities. . . . After a series of weekend meetings in which Boeing directors, in the words of Philip M. Condit, the chairman, concluded that there had to be "significant changes in the composition of the management team," Ronald B. Woodard, 55, quit as president of the company's jetliner business.
 
THE S.E.C.
Auditing the Auditors?
The Securities and Exchange Commission, concerned about millions of dollars of consulting work that branches of Big Five accounting firms now do for companies that are audited by the same firm, wants the auditors to meet annually with company directors to explain why their independence has not been compromised. After recent disclosures of accounting irregularities at a dozen public companies like Cendant, Sunbeam and Livent, Lynn Turner, the S.E.C.'s chief accountant, told the 15-month-old Independence Standards Board that its current requirement -- a letter attesting to independence -- was not tough enough.

HEADLINE: First Step for Social Security

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska says Americans should be allowed to invest some Social Security contributions on their own because the average monthly benefit, $744, is "not enough to give most retirees the standard of living for which we should hope" (Letters, Aug. 9). 
 The way to start bolstering benefits is to extend the 6.2 percent FICA tax to all income above the present ceiling of $68,400. After all, high-income households are capturing most of the real income gains the economy has generated in the last two decades.
 
RICHARD B. DU BOFF
Bryn Mawr, Pa., Aug. 9
 
The writer is an economics professor at Bryn Mawr College.

HEADLINE: Resentment Still Aimed At Chinese In Indonesia

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia

 BODY:
More than three months after huge riots swept the city, the back lanes of Glodok, Jakarta's Chinatown, are still strewn with ash and bricks and bits of broken glass. Multi-story department stores are fire-blackened shells; small shops are rubble.
On an alleyway near a Buddhist temple, old men drink coffee and look over their shoulders when they talk. 
 "We are always the scapegoats," said a 50-year-old ethnic Chinese shopkeeper who lost his shop during the three days of rioting in May, the week before President Suharto stepped down. "People tell us to leave, but we have nowhere to go. We are Indonesian, but people here don't recognize us as Indonesian. So we have no country, no home and no guarantee of our future."
The shopkeeper, who said he was afraid to give his name to a reporter, said he had seen the anonymous pamphlets that have been circulating lately, warning of further attacks. He said he had also seen the small painted circles and triangles that have appeared on Chinese-owned shops and homes, ostensibly marking them for arson or looting. "They are just trying to sow terror," he said.
But he said he was too poor to join the exodus of tens of thousands of ethnic Chinese who have fled the country, in several waves of panic, as rumors of new riots have swept Jakarta and other cities like Semarang, Surabaya and Solo.
Although the shopkeeper and others like him lack the means or connections to leave the country, many more prosperous members of the ethnic minority have found haven overseas.
At the same time, the country's wealthier Chinese, who control many of its big businesses, are said to have transferred billions of dollars of cash abroad, dealing a severe blow to Indonesia's prospects for economic recovery.
Though they make up little more than 3 percent of Indonesia's population of more than 200 million, ethnic Chinese are the nation's trading class, from shopkeepers to billionaire managers of multinational conglomerates, and they control as much as 70 percent of the Indonesia's private economy. They are also among the country's young and well-educated professionals, own many of its factories and form the backbone of the distribution network for food and other commodities.
In addition, an angry backlash among overseas Chinese in other Asian countries could do long-term damage if this economically powerful group decides to take its business elsewhere. In one of the most concerted political actions this loose-knit international community has ever taken in recent years, ethnic Chinese have staged protests in Hong Kong, Taiwan, the Philippines and the United States, as well as in China itself.
Their anger has been inflamed by reports that organized groups of rioters engaged not only in the burning and looting of Chinese-owned shops but in the systematic humiliation and rape of ethnic Chinese women.
"Indonesia: rapist capital of the world," read a banner at a recent demonstration in the Philippines. In China, the official People's Daily said in a commentary, "These criminal acts have sparked grave concern and strong indignation among the people in China and the overseas Chinese community."
Human rights groups and women's shelters here in the capital, Jakarta, have reported that more than 160 women and girls were raped in the rioting last May. They say 20 of these women died as the result of the assaults, some by suicide.
But their reports have been undermined by a failure to bring forward any victim who could give a first-hand account, by what now appear to be slipshod methods of collecting data, and by what may have been a disinformation campaign in the distribution of horrifying but inauthentic photographs of purported victims. Women's advocates say these pictures, distributed over the Internet, could be part of a campaign by people trying to increase the fears of ethnic Chinese.
Although human rights investigators stand by their accounts, saying the victims are too traumatized to talk publicly, these lapses have opened room for doubt.
Women's Affairs Minister Tutty Alawiah, one of the leaders of a Government investigation into the reported rapes, said, "The team has been conducting an investigation for one-and-a-half months now but has found no woman who fell victim to gang rape or who claimed to have been raped during the May riots."
And Gen. Wiranto, the chief of the armed forces, dismissed the reports as "simply a rumor that did not have strong supporting evidence."
The unemployed shopkeeper in Glodok, sipping his glass of coffee, said he had also heard of the rapes but did not know anyone who had been involved.

HEADLINE: Miami Succumbs to Cuban Serenade

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 5

 BODY:
At a recent nightclub concert before a word-of-mouth audience of fewer than 200 people, the Cuban singer-songwriter Carlos Varela surveyed the room from the stage and said, "This looks like a concert in Havana."
But between the standing ovations, the shouted requests for songs and the tears, it was obvious on which side of the Florida Straits he found himself. "I came in '80!" one woman yelled. "I came in '98!" a man piped in. "I was born here!" another man said. 
 For Mr. Varela, who sings of present-day Cuba, warts and all, playing Miami meant the first few baby steps into a market virtually closed to him because he lives in Cuba. In cultural exchanges allowed in recent years under the American economic embargo of the island, Cuba-based artists have toured all over the United States, but they have generally skipped Miami, where many Cuban-Americans shun them as envoys of the Cuban Government and take offense at their presence in exile territory.
But last week, performers from Cuba took Miami by storm. Mr. Varela put on his show here before leaving this week for appearances in Chicago and Madison, Wis., while a powerhouse group of Cuban musicians, including the virtuoso pianist Chucho Valdes and his group Irakere, headlined the annual music industry conference known as Midem Latin America and Caribbean Music Market.
"You're giving me the happiest moment of my life," Francisco Repilado, a 91-year-old traditional guitarist who is featured on the 1998 Grammy-winning album "Buena Vista Social Club" and who is better-known as Compay Segundo, told his audience at the conference. "I've traveled throughout Europe: London, Madrid, Switzerland, Germany. And why not here?"
Many outside South Florida may ask the same question, wondering how people who promote the cause of democracy in Cuba can turn around and censor artists from the island. Only two years ago, protesters hurled insults and spat at those attending a concert by a Cuban jazz pianist, Gonzalo Rubalcaba, who did not even live on the island but had not publicly repudiated its government.
A few months later, a Little Havana restaurant planning to showcase a Cuban actress-singer, Rosita Fornes, was firebombed. And last year, Midem failed in its effort to showcase Cuban artists because of an ordinance that prohibits Miami-Dade County from doing business with Cuba or anyone who does business with Cuba. (This year, the problem was solved when the fund-raising to coordinate the music conference locally became strictly a private effort.)
A more auspicious climate has greeted Cuban performers this year. Isaac Delgado, a salsa singer; Vocal Sampling, an a cappella group; Gema 4, another a cappella group; the band La Charanga Habanera and Mr. Varela, who first performed here last March, have played here at different times with no major incidents. Longtime residents speculate that a confluence of factors may be at work, including the impact of the death last November of Jorge Mas Canosa, the most powerful exile leader advocating a hard line toward Cuba, and Pope John Paul II's call for reconciliation in his visit to Cuba in January.
But a look at the audiences that come to see the Cubans offers the best explanation: generally black Cuban-Americans turn out for Mr. Delgado; Cuban, Latin American and young for Mr. Varela; a mixed bag of music lovers for Mr. Valdes. It is a sample of changing demographics, and generations, in Hispanic Miami, which by now includes the tens of thousands of Cubans who migrated over the last two decades and grew up with much of the music that has been banned in this corner of the United States.
"They know the artists, they know the songs, they know the words," said Maria Romeu, whose marketing company, Luna Media, has promoted and co-produced several of the concerts. "Miami has a new portion of the population that hears that music and it is infectious."
But new and old Miami still coexist, and the appearance of an artist from Cuba sets off contrasting raw emotions. On the evening of Compay Segundo's performance at the Miami Beach Convention Center last week, a group of about 400 demonstrators waved little Cuban flags, chanted "Liberty! Liberty!" and held up signs that read: "Castro's rats" and "Stop using Uncle Sam's money to promote your Cuban hell." The group included former political prisoners in Cuba, Cuban-American musicians and older exiles for whom culture equates with politics if Fidel Castro's Government is involved.
"This intransigence of ours is a just intransigence," said Miriam Sifontes, 51, a medical clinic owner. "Castro is an assassin."
Inside the convention hall, meanwhile, the scene was almost reverential. Interspersed among Midem's international delegates were Cuban-Americans, including one man who sat with a cellular phone perched on his shoulder. He said his grandfather in New York was listening.
Mr. Varela's concert at Starfish nightclub here three nights later was even more jarring. Some women cried openly during some songs, and two men left the room at one point, overcome by emotion. Mr. Varela, 35, who played accompanied only by acoustic guitar, is often described by music critics as the voice of Cuba's disgruntled youth, a writer in the tradition of Bob Dylan and Bruce Springsteen who writes verses like "Freedom only exists when it belongs to no one" and "What are windmills for, if there are no Quixotes left?"
"He gets as real as anyone gets to describe Cuba," said Carlos Betancourt, a 32-year-old Cuban-American painter who visited Cuba for the first time this year out of curiosity. "It was a very sad concert and that's my definition of Cuba: a very sad country."
Mr. Varela's inspiration is not criticism, however, but "the Cuban's illusion of transforming things," he said in an interview.
Although he tours internationally and plays concert halls in Havana, Cuba has banned some of his music from the radio. So has Miami, as it does with other Cuba-based artists.
Mr. Varela said he had received nothing but love and respect in Miami and that his shows here had been unusually intense because the public "wants to condense all their longings in a two-hour concert." But noting the commercial radio ban of his music, and the fact that he and other Cuban performers so far have mostly played concerts for select audiences or in small venues with little advance publicity, Mr. Varela said he hoped for the day he could "fill stadiums and sell records."
"Let's make no mistake," said Mr. Varela, always the realist, "I have not sung in Miami."

HEADLINE: King Hussein's Illness Shifts Spotlight to Prince

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: KERAK, Jordan

 BODY:
King Hussein has reigned for 45 years, more than twice as long as Ahmed Thneibat has been alive. But now the King is undergoing cancer treatment for the second time in six years, and Mr. Thneibat and other Jordanians are apprehensive about what is to come.
"Rest assured, I am not over and done with yet," the King, who is 62, said in a televised address to his people from the Mayo Clinic in Minnesota in July. But he also left the impression that he is determined to prepare the country for the prospect that he might not return, saying in the same speech, "There is life and there is an end to life, and that is the way with everyone." 
 Few in Jordan doubt that power would pass to Crown Prince Hassan, the King's younger brother and closest adviser, who has been the designated heir to the throne for more than three decades. He has been Regent in the King's absence, which is expected to last until at least November.
But many Jordanians and foreign observers say they wonder whether a King Hassan could prove as successful as King Hussein in guiding Jordan through the kinds of storms that have been a main feature of the country's recent history.
"People are worried; they think there could be trouble," said Mr. Thneibat, 18, who like all but a minority in this close-knit country of 4 million has known no King but Hussein, who took power in 1953 at age 17.
Kerak, a southern city crowned by a Crusader fortress, has long been a base of support for Jordan's monarchy. But riots broke out here two years ago over an increase in the price of bread, a reminder that loyalty has limits. Now the public mood is again turning volatile, a result of a crippling water crisis, severe economic problems and rising disillusionment over peace with Israel.
Over tea and hummus in a simple cafe adorned with black-and-white portraits of the country's current and former Kings, Mr. Thneibat spoke for many in saying he hoped that a King Hassan might prove more vigorous than his brother in addressing the economy. But as he and other Jordanians try to conceive of a new era, a bigger question may be whether a King Hassan would inherit his brother's capacity to chart his own course, even when it means forging ahead of public opinion.
"It's a minefield, and he doesn't have what it takes to cross it safely," Labib Kamhawi, a prominent human rights campaigner, said, spelling out one view. "He doesn't have the charisma the King had. He doesn't have the broad base of support. And he would take power at a time when the power of the Hashemite dynasty is at a very low ebb."
People close to Prince Hassan say that he shares King Hussein's deep commitment to Jordan's peace with Israel, though it has borne little fruit and has little domestic support. That assessment is shared by most foreign analysts, who say they are confident that the departure of King Hussein would not cause Jordan to back away from promoting a broader settlement of Arab-Israeli disputes.
But diplomats do say that Hassan, as King, may have less latitude to promote the peace than his brother, in part because hostility toward Israel has deepened among Jordanians, and in part because the Crown Prince has rarely displayed his brother's magnanimous style.
"There's still a great deal of uncertainty about the Crown Prince," a Western diplomat said. "He's not his brother. He doesn't have a common touch, and he gets his information from briefing papers whereas the King gets his information from the people."
The Prince has declined interview requests during the King's illness and has played the role of caretaker, not addressing the doubts about him. But in what may have been an attempt to defuse some criticism, he did convene an unusual meeting in late August that included leaders from all of Jordan's political parties, including Islamists who form the main opposition bloc.
The prospect of a Jordanian leader with untested domestic prestige is particularly worrying to Israelis, who are nervous about Yasir Arafat's pledge to declare an independent Palestinian state in the West Bank and Gaza Strip next May, when the Middle East peace plan begun by the Oslo accords is supposed to be completed.
At 51, Prince Hassan is nearly 12 years younger than the King, who will turn 63 on Nov. 14. Hassan was 6 when Hussein took power on May 2, 1953, succeeding his grandfather, King Abdullah -- who had been assassinated in Jerusalem in 1951 as Hussein stood at his side -- and his father, King Talal, who stepped down in favor of his son after less than a year in power.
Since his 18th birthday in 1965, Prince Hassan has been the country's designated No. 2, and he is described in an official biography as having "constantly served as King Hussein's closest political adviser, deputy and confidant, as well as Regent in his absence." He earned a degree in Oriental studies from Christ Church College, Oxford University, and has worked tirelessly within Jordan to promote scientific study and better integration of the region's economy. He took part in the negotiations that led to Jordan's peace agreement with Israel, met with Benjamin Netanyahu even before Mr. Netanyahu was elected Israel's Prime Minister, and has close ties to most Arab leaders.
Still, he has always seemed in many ways the King's alter ego, more comfortable in a tie and blue blazer than an Arab headdress, and more disposed toward academic-style oratory than toward the emotional eloquence of his older brother.
Some of his admirers say that he could not have been expected to show more color as Crown Prince; his mission, they say, has been to stay in the background. "He's been in the shadow of a very important historic figure, so it will be prudent to judge him only after he takes center stage," said Mustafa Hamarneh, director of the Center for Strategic Studies at the University of Jordan.
But in listing the qualities that have made the King such a dominant figure, most other analysts give prominence to some that are not readily transferable.
"The majority of Jordanians would side with the King even if they think he is wrong," said Fahed Fanek, an economist who is one of Jordan's most popular newspaper columnists. "Ninety percent of the population of Jordan was born after the King took power. They know that he was indispensable in leading the country to safety. So even if they think he was wrong, they give him the benefit of the doubt."
After renal cancer in 1992 and a prostate operation in 1997, the King was found to have lymphoma this summer after nearly a year in which he had been suffering from inexplicable fevers. A statement issued by the Mayo Clinic said that the disease is "highly treatable with chemotherapy," which the King began in July, but it also mentioned a need for plenty of rest.
So far the King has displayed a vigorous public face, even flying his own jet to Washington after completing the first and second of six scheduled rounds of chemotherapy. On the first of those trips, he and his wife, Queen Noor, dined privately on a White House balcony with the Clintons, and even now, two months into what is expected to be at least four months of treatment, Jordanian officials say that he consults by telephone with Prince Hassan at least once a day.
It was the King, Jordanian officials say, who assumed the leading role in orchestrating a change of Government in August, replacing a team tarred by evidence that its mismanagement was to blame for a water crisis so severe that Saudi Arabia and Syria sent emergency stocks to the rescue. And even while recuperating at his private home in Washington, he has met with the new Government, led by Fayez Tarawneh, a former Ambassador to the United States and Foreign Minister.
In the months ahead, Jordanian officials expect the country's affairs to be administered along a kind of triangle between Amman, Washington, and the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. But people familiar with the King's health say that his resistance to disease has been weakened by the chemotherapy and that it is likely to diminish further as the treatment progresses.

HEADLINE: Schools Struggle With a Dearth of Bus Drivers

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
The pay is low, the hours short and irregular and the cargo can be difficult to handle.
So consider it a small miracle when the school bus arrives -- especially this year, when tight employment is making it difficult for many school districts to find drivers. 
 Even schools with a full roster of drivers worry that the sudden absence of a few will put routes in chaos, forcing maintenance workers, mechanics and supervisors to take to the wheel, and forcing children to wait, wait, wait.
"It's a day-by-day thing to keep enough drivers," said Russell Martin, owner of Rains & Martin Inc., a school bus contractor in rural Bolivar, Mo.
No wonder there is trouble. The job generally is part time, with hours split between morning and afternoon runs. Benefits are minimal, if they exist at all. Also, school wages do not compete with what people can get elsewhere in these days of low unemployment.
As Mr. Martin describes it, a driver might work an hour and a half in the morning and the same amount in the afternoon, earning $27 to $33 a day. In addition, licensing requirements have become stricter, protecting children but creating paperwork.
Then there is the load.
"When you have a bus driver that has upwards of 60 students with their back to them and having to drive the vehicle, it gets to be a little more tedious than some people actually want to deal with," said Steve Washington, director of transportation for Hampton City Schools in Hampton, Va., where drivers are full-time employees.
To get drivers, school districts and contractors have turned to the Internet and direct mail advertising. Some are also giving raises and bonuses and treating drivers a little more kindly, the same moves that many school districts are making to try to attract teachers.
Drivers in Wake County, N.C., are getting a 30 percent increase over three years and a $300 bonus if they recruit a new driver who holds the job more than 90 days. The new hire gets a $250 bonus. Drivers are honored at monthly events and a yearly banquet.
"We just recognize them as much as we can in trying to keep them," said Wyatt Currin, interim transportation director.

HEADLINE: Shore Towns Give Summer Favorable Review

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: SEASIDE HEIGHTS, N.J., Sept. 4

 BODY:
Bobby Dee, a k a Robert DiPeso, counted out the quarters for the players at the Gift Wheel at Bobby Dee's Casino ("Nobody leaves without a TV!") on the Wildwood boardwalk and pronounced the summer of 1998 a good one.
"The weather was excellent, the water was clean, the families showed up," he said. "That equals a good summer for us." 
 Mr. DiPeso's contented appraisal found plenty of echoes up and down the region's shoreline as the last week of unofficial summer drew toward its Labor Day finale.
Sure, dramatic reporting about Hurricane Bonnie scared some visitors away toward the end of August, and rain in June kept Jones Beach in New York from matching last year's turnout. But for a part of the country that equates summer with sand and salt water, with quiet family seafood cookouts and the raucous honky-tonk of the boardwalk, the season just ending was clearly a success.
"People have disposable cash and they're roaming around looking for entertainment," said David Shotwell, senior administrator of the Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association, the annual Christian jamboree on the Jersey Shore. "You can just tell by the number of people who don't know where the bathrooms are that we're getting a lot of new people.
"They may have stumbled in here by accident," Mr. Shotwell continued, "but we sure try to make sure they come back."
Jennie Masher and her daughter Jill were among Mr. DiPeso's contestants at the Gift Wheel -- no TV yet -- which is like a wheel of fortune game in a real casino, but stays legal by offering prizes instead of cash. Fourteen members of Mrs. Masher's extended family had come down for a week from Troy, N.Y., which is also the number of years since their last visit.
"We had been here before and wanted to come back with the kids," said Mrs. Masher, a homemaker. "It's been fun because there's a lot to do, and the kids like it."
Tourism agencies are still far from knowing the final count of hotel taxes, beach tag sales, parking lot receipts and all the other measures of the summer's financial impact.
Still, there are some fragments of early data to suggest that it was a good season: the Connecticut Office of Tourism reported that tourist stops at highway information centers were up 5.7 percent and that the $6.8 billion in hotel and motel taxes collected in June was well above last year's $4.5 million.
On the southern Jersey Shore, a collection of a similar tourism tax to build a new convention center in Wildwood was 34 percent ahead of last year's level through June.
Atlantic City's hotels topped last year's extraordinary 94 percent occupancy rate with a 97 percent filled rate through August, according to Linda Conlin, executive director of the Office of Travel and Tourism in New Jersey's Department of Commerce and Economic Development. And Ms. Conlin said an informal survey of shore businesses also produced an upbeat bottom line: "Equal to last year's good summer season, if not surpassing it," she said.
Tourism spending amounted to $25.5 billion in New Jersey last year and accounted for 623,000 jobs, according to the department. Spending totaled $14 billion on the Jersey Shore, which supported 267,000 tourism-related jobs.
Shore tourism officials said that water quality across the region was not the problem it had been several years ago, when algae blooms, pollution and medical debris washing ashore made frequent headlines. In New York, Hurricane Bonnie actually scoured an outlying sandbar and deposited more beach sand on the Fire Island shoreline, said Gerard Stoddard, president of the Fire Island Association.
Good beach weather during July and August took crowds to Long Island's South Shore as well, but summer visits to Jones Beach State Park decreased to 3.9 million this year from 4.4 million last year because of rainy weekends in June, said the superintendent, Joseph F. Lescinski.
If there was a problem, it was that Labor Day came a week after the end of August, the traditional finish line, so that many young ride operators, ticket takers and pizza waiters were gone for the final week.
"Most of our workers come from the Toms River School District, which, without any thought or consideration for the tourist industry, reopened its doors on Sept. 1," said Bill Irwin, general manager of the Casino Pier and Waterworks arcade and amusement park, which employs 700 seasonal workers in Seaside Heights. "That left us a bit short-handed."
Mr. Irwin and other natives of the Jersey Shore know that, for all the year-to-year sameness the summer seasons seem to share, a lot has changed.
The rise of the dual-career family has meant that few visitors take a house for the summer the way they used to, said Vicki Clark, director of marketing for the Cape May Chamber of Commerce, so rentals tend to be for shorter periods, and are more often made on a spur of the moment.
Some things never change, however. J. R. and Terri Bale and their two boys, from New Providence, N.J., have a three-week rental with Mrs. Bale's mother and her sister's family in Seaside Heights this summer, just the way Mrs. Bale's extended family, the Azzolinas, the Giaimos and the Valentis, shared summer rentals when she was growing up. "We always had a house when I was a kid," Mrs. Bale said. "Then we grew up into teen-agers and we didn't want to do that with everyone's parents, and it ended. But now, maybe we're starting it all over again with our own kids."
Charlie Dolan, a food broker from Kearny, bought a house with his wife, Jo-Ann, on the bay side at Chadwicks, a few miles up the barrier island from Seaside Heights, partly to give their seven grandchildren a taste of what the shore was like in the old days.
"Growing up as a kid, we'd leave the day after school ended and stay for two months," he said. "We made new friends every summer."
Out on the beach behind Mr. Dolan, Robert Gluck had reached page 239 of "Buddenbrooks," which is less than halfway through Thomas Mann's masterpiece. "A couple of days," he said, when asked how long it had taken him to get that far in his heavy seaside reading. "Three months," his wife, Cindy, corrected.
But no matter -- Mann was on his face in the sand, and Mr. Gluck was content just to be there, with the sound of the surf thumping a few hundred feet away.
"If you grew up coming to the shore, you get to a point where if you don't smell the brine and feel the sand between toes, you're missing something," said Mr. Gluck, a freelance writer. "You wait for summer to come, and then it comes, and then it goes by fast, because you're having fun."

Robert Gluck, wearing a hat in Chadwicks, N.J., said summer was not the same "if you don't smell the brine and feel the sand between toes." (Photographs by Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. AND JAPANESE CONFER BUT DIFFER ON ECONOMIC CURES

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5

 BODY:
The economic policy leaders of the world's two largest economies, the United States and Japan, spent hours here Friday night talking about the heightened risk of global recession and a further spread of the turmoil that has engulfed Asia, Russia and now Latin America. But they left this morning with no new plans, and an uneasy sense that Japan and the United States remain on different wavelengths about how quickly countries must act.
The discussion over dinner on Nob Hill included Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and Kiichi Miyazawa, the former Prime Minister who reluctantly agreed to take the job of Finance Minister last month during Japan's deepest recession since the end of World War II. 
 At the dinner's end, American officials said they feared that Japan's leaders still did not accept the premise that Japan's huge banking crisis and its moribund economy were a major cause of the turmoil that included a stomach-churning dive on Wall Street this week, huge market drops and instability in Latin America and deepening chaos in Russia.
The astounding descent of the ruble, which has dropped 63 percent since Aug. 17 and has begun to lead to food shortages and tremendous inflation, led the British Government today to announce that a meeting of deputy finance ministers from the world's largest economic powers, the Group of 7, was planned in London, probably in the coming week, to map out a new Russia strategy.
But in a sign of the growing split between Tokyo and Washington, Japanese officials bristled at the mounting American pressure and suggested that they were being made scapegoats for problems that are unrelated to Tokyo's seven years of economic mismanagement.
"How can Japan's recession be responsible for an economic malaise in Latin America or Russia?" asked a senior Japanese official, who insisted on anonymity. "Japan has been overly criticized. My concern is that if anything happens to the U.S. economy, everyone will point to Japan and say it is responsible."
The meeting took place as Mr. Rubin and Mr. Greenspan, who in ordinary times often outdo each other at understatement, issued warnings that the world economy is in a particularly fragile state.
Only hours before the dinner, Mr. Greenspan, in a speech at the University of California at Berkeley, cautioned that "it is just not credible that the United States can remain an oasis of prosperity unaffected by a world that is experiencing greatly increased stress." He appeared to open the door to the possibility that the Federal Reserve might consider a cut in interest rates if more evidence arose that downturns on three continents were beginning to stall the American economy.
Mr. Rubin, in a conversation as he flew from Washington to his meeting here, said that "these are clearly extremely difficult times in the world economy and world financial markets."
"This is an unprecedented situation in a host of respects," said the Treasury Secretary, who experienced several major market drops in his 26 years on Wall Street as a trader and then co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs, the investment banking firm. "The number of countries experiencing difficulties at once is something we have not seen before."
The speed at which hundreds of billions of dollars that flowed into emerging economies in the 1990's have flowed out was also unprecedented. The inflow occurred, Mr. Rubin said, because "investors got progressively less rigorous about risk."
Now they see risk everywhere, Mr. Rubin and other Treasury officials note, and they rarely discriminate between countries with deep problems and countries that are simply fighting off economic contagion. A global credit crunch has resulted, with countries that lived off of huge flows of international investment now unable to obtain it at any price.
"We are in a situation which is indeed a dangerous one, by far not fully rational," said Michel Camdessus, the managing director of the embattled International Monetary Fund, which has been charged by its many critics with exacerbating the crisis it stepped in to abate.
Mr. Camdessus, speaking in Washington at the conclusion of a meeting of Latin American finance ministers who had come to plead for relief, said: "The degree of panic going on -- this is, indeed, clearly exacting an excessive and unfair pressure on a large number of countries."
For Mr. Camdessus, that is a significant change of tone. In January, he signed an agreement in Indonesia with President Suharto that he declared would restore confidence -- and saw the country dissolve into violence, economic chaos and political upheaval that forced Mr. Suharto's resignation. Early this summer he declared that there was no crisis in Russia, and a huge one erupted within weeks.
"The whole tone has changed, for everyone," said Jeffrey Garten, the dean of the Yale School of Management, a former top official in the Commerce Department. "A few months ago people were talking about seeing the light at the end of the tunnel. Now the only hope is keeping the world economy from total deterioration. And you get a sense that this is all now truly left to Adam Smith's invisible hand -- it's beyond any country's ability, any institution's ability, to control."
For their part, Mr. Rubin and Mr. Greenspan, speaking frequently by phone and at their weekly breakfast meetings in Washington, are choosing their words with extraordinary care. Neither, for example, has used the phrase "global recession" in public. They fear that the phrase alone might cause more selloffs and make continued turmoil a self-fulfilling prophecy. But Mr. Miyazawa, speaking in Japanese at a news conference here Friday evening, used a close equivalent to the term. And at one point he broke into English to discuss how the failure of a major Japanese bank, the Long Term Credit Bank of Japan, "might result in systemic risk for the United States and for Japan."
"Systemic risk" is the phrase used by monetary authorities to describe how the failure of an institution or a severe market drop in one economy can course through the global economy, setting off a cycle of events elsewhere.
For Mr. Miyazawa, 78, the return to San Francisco to plead for "more patience" to deal with Japan's problems had odd historical echoes. In 1951, as a young, English-speaking bureaucrat, Mr. Miyazawa was a central behind-the-scenes player in the negotiation of the peace treaty between Japan and the United States -- signed here -- that ended the American occupation of his country and set it on the path to become an economic superpower. In the ensuing half-century, Japan has often turned to Mr. Miyazawa, whose contacts in Washington run deep, to deal with what the Japanese call "gaiatsu," or foreign pressure. He grew up in the Japanese Finance Ministry, and assured his dinner partners on Friday night -- in the presence of the ministry's officials -- that he could deal with powerful bureaucratic resistance to reform of Japan's economic system.
But he was less sanguine about his ability to get Japan's Parliament to act quickly on financial rescue legislation. The key dispute is whether to allow a huge infusion of taxpayer money to the banking system to rid it of bad loans.
Mr. Rubin left little doubt about his position on that question. He called for the "aggessive and timely use of public funds" to stabilize the banking system, and he said at a news conference that "everywhere I go, Japan is at the center of discussions" about how to get the world economy back on track.

Clinton Urges Confidence
 WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (Reuters) -- President Clinton sought to calm American economic jitters today, saying the American economy was moving in a positive direction despite global financial turmoil that has pummeled stocks.
"For all the quicksilver volatility in the world's financial markets, the American economy is on the right track," Mr. Clinton said in his weekly radio address.
He added, however, that the United States was affected by overseas financial events and that it was crucial for Congress to help promote stability by approving funding for the International Monetary Fund.
Mr. Clinton also urged Congress to maintain fiscal discipline and reserve any budget surpluses pending reform of the Social Security retirement system, and said he would work to win passage of education measures that would assure long-term prosperity.

HEADLINE: Hey New York: Listen Up! 12 Ideas From (Gasp) Out of Town;
Looks Like a Bus, Acts Like a Subway

BYLINE: By ALISON GARDY 

 BODY:
A bus system as speedy as a subway? It exists in the city of Curitiba in southern Brazil, which depends on a futuristic bus system to transport more than half its 2.3 million inhabitants every day.
Features include a two-way bus lane down the middle of major traffic arteries and a specially designed bus shelter resembling a horizontal cylinder on a raised platform. The shelter is accessible to handicapped riders and provides complete protection from bad weather. 
 Passengers pay their fares upon entering the cylinder. When a bus pulls up, the driver aligns sliding doors on the side with those on the side of the cylinder. When the doors open, people exit and enter the bus with the speed and efficiency of subway riders.
Residents of Curitiba, 310 miles south of Sao Paulo, seem to like their bus system. Even though they had the second-highest car ownership rate in Brazil in the early 90's, with one in three owning a car, the use of gasoline was 30 percent lower than in eight comparable Brazilian cities, and air pollution levels were among the lowest in Brazil, according to a study by an urban development adviser for the United Nations Development Program.
A bus that moves with the speed of a subway would seem like a boon in New York, where fast is never fast enough. A city bus, with steps to climb, fares to pay on board and slower-moving pneumatic doors, stops at curbside for an average of seven seconds per passenger, compared with a city subway, which stops at platforms an average of one second per passenger.
So why not a Curitiba-style bus system for New York? The Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the city's Department of Transportation ran a five-week experiment using a similar system in downtown Manhattan from April to May 1992, along a route that connected the World Trade Center, Staten Island Ferry, South Street Seaport and City Hall. The trial revealed that the Curitiba bus model might be more appropriate for the fringes of New York.
As Larry Gould, director of operations analysis at New York City Transit, explained, "Most people use the subway for the long haul and use the buses to connect to the subways." So the Curitiba model would work better for New Yorkers in densely populated, far-flung areas like Co-op City in the Bronx and Starrett City in Brooklyn, which represent "the extremities of the system that don't have subways but do have heavy ridership" on buses, Mr. Gould said. He added, "I don't think it is applicable to Manhattan streets, where you have people getting on and off a lot."
Upper East Side residents along far-flung York Avenue might beg to differ. ALISON GARDY

HEADLINE: Hey New York: Listen Up! 12 Ideas From (Gasp) Out of Town;
Going Their Way, Going Your Way

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIR 

 BODY:
For New York City taxi passengers, a ride in a cab is often a solitary experience and sometimes a pricey one. But in Madison, Wis., the Badger Cab Company offers a fairly affordable way to get to point B, along with company in the back seat.
Since its founding 52 years ago, Badger, named after the state animal, has shunned meters in lieu of a shared-ride system. A Badger passenger may share the cab with as many as four other riders, and a few packages. 
 The company's 115 drivers double as couriers, directed by dispatchers from time to time to pick up a parcel here or drop off an envelope there. This may make for a trip that's a little longer than it otherwise might need to be, but the discounted fare is worth it to some people, particularly the elderly and students like Jennie Capellaro.
"It's the economic way to go," said Ms. Capellaro, 26, a history major at the University of Wisconsin. "It is cheaper." About 40 percent cheaper than a trip on a metered cab, said Tom Royston, the operations manager of Badger, which bases its fares on a zone system. For a ride from the Dane County regional airport to the State Capitol, a distance of roughly five miles, Badger charges $7.25, compared with around $12 for a metered cab ride.
While some passengers hail Badger cabs, the typical customer calls to be picked up. The dispatcher usually assigns the fare to the nearest car. "The bottom line is that they are all going in the same general direction," Mr. Royston said. "You might zigzag six blocks one way or three blocks another, but you would not go backward or five miles out of the way."
Badger's formula of bargain fares and methodical dispatching has made it the cab of choice in Madison. A 1997 city survey found that among the three cab companies in Madison -- the other two use meters -- Badger had the most paid passengers: 890,921, compared with 526,636 and 248,704 for its competitors. It was a close second in revenues.
But could such a business work in a place as congested and time-conscious as New York City, where the Taxi and Limousine Commission estimates the average medium-distance ride in a yellow cab is 2.19 miles and costs $6.50?
Not likely, said Hal Morgan of the International Taxi Cab and Livery Association, a trade group in Kensington, Md. "Most of the time, people take cabs because they are time sensitive," he said, noting that in New York City, yellow cabs are banned from having dispatch radios, which makes carefully planned combined routes nearly impossible.
Allan Fromberg, a spokesman for the Taxi Commission said there was no single company in New York that specializes in shared rides. But the city's 35,000 radio-dispatched liveries are allowed to take passengers to multiple destinations, he said, as long the rides are prearranged. "It can be done," he said. "It really is at the discretion of the passenger and the company." RICHARD WEIR

GRAPHIC: Photo: GROUP TAXI RIDES/MADISON, WIS. -- Five passengers and some packages may share a cab, but it's "the economic way to go," says a University of Wisconsin student. (Bill Mayer for The New York Times)(pg. 16)

HEADLINE: August 30-Sept. 5;
A Summit Trip Like No Other

 BODY:
When President Clinton met with President Boris N. Yeltsin in Moscow, the near collapse of Russia's economy was on his mind, but there wasn't much to be done beyond expressions of support if Russia stayed the course of reform.
The Russians and Americans also concluded an agreement that would let American satellites give Russia dependable warnings about missile launchings around the world. The satellites were originally put up to safeguard America against Russian missile launchings. But now there is another danger: errors could be made by the deteriorating Russian early-warning system, leading to an accidental nuclear war. Thus the American backup. 
 After Russia, President Clinton proceeded to Northern Ireland, where he was greeted as a peacemaker (see box below), and the Irish Republic, where he praised the country's prosperity as a fruit of peace. He also resumed facing reporters' questions about his relationship with the former White House intern Monica S. Lewinsky.

HEADLINE: Clinton Trip Fails to Silence Doubt on His Domestic Clout

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: LIMERICK, Ireland, Sept. 5

 BODY:
It has been a question from the start of President Clinton's five-day trip to Russia, Ireland and Northern Ireland this week: will his domestic troubles affect his ability to function abroad as the nation's leader?
The answer, from the President's aides, has been a resounding and unanimous no. 
 But others are not so certain, and a strong piece of evidence came from Moscow on Friday, when Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, the Acting Prime Minister, announced measures to try to pull Russia out of its economic tailspin.
Less than a day after Mr. Clinton left Moscow, where he delivered a series of stern lectures on fiscal and monetary responsibility, Mr. Chernomyrdin proposed an "economic dictatorship" that would include a huge infusion of new rubles to prop up failing banks, almost certainly a prescription for a burst of inflation and a step that Mr. Clinton specifically warned against.
To be sure, Mr. Chernomyrdin is in a tough battle for confirmation and Russia's internal politics are little influenced by outside forces. But it was clear that Russia's leaders either were not listening to Mr. Clinton's lectures or they did not fear the effects of defying him.
Other evidence came on the front pages of American newspapers all week, which were dominated by stories not of Mr. Clinton's diplomacy but of the slow progress of his penitence over his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.
Mr. Clinton took questions twice from reporters, during a news conference on Wednesday with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and a Friday meeting with Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland.
Both appearances were overshadowed by questions about Ms. Lewinsky, and the coverage in the United States focused almost exclusively on the President's calibrated regrets over the affair.
Scholars say it is impossible to separate a President's domestic fortunes from his prestige abroad. Although Mr. Clinton remains popular overseas -- particularly in Ireland, where he is given credit for supporting efforts that led to the Northern Ireland peace accord this year -- leaders recognize that even without the Lewinsky scandal, Mr. Clinton is a lame duck with a little more than two years remaining in his term, if he completes it.
"It is difficult to be damaged goods at home and to be effective abroad," said Dmitri K. Simes, director of the Nixon Center research organization in Washington and a longtime foreign policy aide to Richard M. Nixon during his Presidency.
Mr. Simes said that many Russians have written Mr. Clinton off, not only because he is crippled by domestic difficulties but also because Russians perceive him as being too close to Mr. Yeltsin, who is widely reviled by his countrymen.
Mr. Clinton today lacks the moral authority to be "a lasting partner for the Russians, particularly during the post-Yeltsin era," Mr. Simes said.
Mr. Clinton's aides insisted that the President was not hampered in his ability to do his job by the low cloud of scandal hanging over him.
Michael D. McCurry, the President's press secretary, said on Friday that Mr. Clinton operated in "parallel universes" -- battling scandal at home while conducting high policy abroad -- and declared that the two did not intersect.
Asked whether Mr. Clinton's authority had been diminished by the Lewinsky matter, Mr. McCurry replied: "It clearly has not been, and I think the President takes some satisfaction in that. He dealt with world leaders on this trip and is confident that he continues to do good work in the interest of the American people as he fulfills his constitutional responsibilities."
In a less guarded moment, Mr. McCurry conceded that the Lewinsky matter had "detracted" from the main missions of the trip -- encouraging Russian leaders to stick to the course of economic reform and urging Catholics and Protestants in Northern Ireland to press ahead on the road to reconciliation.
But Mr. McCurry and other aides blamed the press for an unhealthy obsession with the Lewinsky matter and for drowning out the President's message. "It's all so circular," said one of Mr. Clinton's top foreign policy aides, his voice tinged with bitterness. "You ask the questions and then you write that Clinton was forced once again to deal with Lewinsky. It hasn't come up in one meeting that we've had on this trip."
But if the Lewinsky matter did not arise in meetings, neither did foreign leaders rally to the President's defense, at least not in public. Mr. McCurry assured reporters that Mr. Clinton had received many messages of encouragement from leaders around the world, but declined to identify any of them.
Neither Mr. Yeltsin nor Mr. Ahern spoke on the President's behalf as he took questions about the scandal. Nor did Tony Blair, the British Prime Minister, with whom Mr. Clinton spent the day in Northern Ireland on Thursday. Mr. Blair offered Mr. Clinton private solace and public support during a visit to Washington last January, shortly after the President's relationship with Ms. Lewinsky was first disclosed.
The trip has taken Mr. Clinton from meetings in a Moscow gripped by political and economic crisis to a meeting with families of the victims of the car bomb in Omagh, Northern Ireland, to a festive rally in the streets of Limerick this morning. Mr. Clinton's mood has shifted as dramatically as the settings: somber in Moscow, mournful in Omagh, upbeat in Limerick.
Mr. Clinton was hailed as a peacemaker in his appearances in Northern Ireland and Ireland the last three days, and he clearly reveled in the warmth of his reception here.
Everywhere his message to the Irish was the same: though terror will surely return, the will to peace will overcome those who seek to destroy it.
Looking out over a sea of waving American and Irish flags among the crowd packed into downtown Limerick this morning, Mr. Clinton said, "As we mourn the losses in Omagh and the three little boys who were killed and taken from their parents' arms, remember there will still be efforts by the enemies of peace to break your will, to get you to turn back, to get you to lose faith."
"Don't do it," the President implored the enthusiastic throng of thousands. "Don't do it. This is you at your best. Do not let them break your will."
Mr. Clinton spent the afternoon pursuing the real reason he came to southwest Ireland today, playing golf at the historic course at Ballybunion.
