HEADLINE: Amory Bradford, 85, Times General Manager

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
Amory H. Bradford, a former vice president and general manager of The New York Times who was the chief negotiator for the Publishers Association in the bruising 114-day New York newspaper strike in 1962-63, died Friday at his home in Edisto Beach, S.C. He was 85.
A Yale-educated Wall Street lawyer, Mr. Bradford joined The Times in 1947 as a special assistant to the publisher, Arthur Hays Sulzberger, and over the next 16 years became a company director, The Times's business and general manager and an important member of management. 
 Long before satellites and computers, former associates recalled Friday, Mr. Bradford had visions of The Times as an economically strong newspaper of global influence, with editions in Paris for European consumption and on the West Coast for what was to be the start of a nationwide readership.
Allying himself with Orvil E. Dryfoos, Mr. Sulzberger's son-in-law, who became publisher in 1961, Mr. Bradford engineered the company's purchase of the Gaspesia Pulp and Paper Company in Canada to insure newsprint supplies. He also saw cost-saving automation as the economic wave of the future, and he regarded unions, inefficiency and low productivity as roadblocks.
By the early 1960's, he had become chairman of the New York City Publishers Association, made up of the city's eight major newspapers, and was president of the New York Regional Plan Association. He had also launched The Times's short-lived International edition, had formulated plans for its West Coast edition, and appeared to have positioned himself for The Times's presidency.
But his personal and professional ambitions finally hit a rock.
On Dec. 8, 1962, the printers' union launched what was to be the longest and costliest strike in New York newspaper history, a 114-day marathon. The Publishers Association chose Mr. Bradford as its point man in negotiations with Typographical Union No. 6 and its president, Bertram A. Powers.
They were natural enemies from the start. Mr. Powers, a high school dropout, was a tough, relentless negotiator, the embodiment of a gut-fighter up from the streets. Mr. Bradford, an Ivy League aristocrat, impeccably dressed and 6 feet 4 inches tall, was accustomed to snapping orders at pliant subordinates.
As the strike dragged on, it became clear to insiders that the clash of two personalities was prolonging the dispute; the publishers began to have doubts about Mr. Bradford.
When the walkout ended on April 1, 1963, The Times published a two-page account by A. H. Raskin, its labor reporter. Only a few paragraphs were devoted to Mr. Bradford, but they were damaging. In his memoirs, "My Life and The Times," Turner Catledge, for many years The Times's chief news executive, said Mr. Bradford had gone to him and to Mr. Dryfoos to try to get the article suppressed. "He made it clear he did not want the story published, or least those portions about him," Mr. Catledge related. But the article was published.
After calling Mr. Bradford "handsome, articulate and aloof," Mr. Raskin wrote: "One top-level mediator said Mr. Bradford brought an attitude of such icy disdain into the conference rooms that the mediator often felt he ought to ask the hotel to send up more heat. Another mediator, who called Mr. Bradford the possessor of the keenest mind on the management side, said he operates on a 'short fuse.' " The publishers admired his "independence and assurance," but "they are occasionally galled by his imperiousness," Mr. Raskin added.
Two months later, Mr. Dryfoos died, and Mr. Bradford's hopes for the presidency faded. On June 20, 1963, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger was named president and publisher of The Times, and Mr. Bradford issued a statement saying he was "not in agreement with the proposed plan of reorganization," and resigned.
Amory Howe Bradford was born in Springfield, Mass., on Oct. 1, 1912, the son of a Congregational minister, and grew up in Rutland, Vt., and Providence, R.I. He graduated from Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., in 1930, Yale in 1934 and Yale Law School in 1937. He practiced law with Davis, Polk Wardwell & Reed in New York for a decade, except for Army intelligence service in World War II.
After leaving The Times in 1963, he was a consultant to the Ford Foundation for programs in Greece, Turkey, Switzerland and Italy, and, in 1964, he became an executive with Scripps-Howard Newspapers.
In 1965, he was appointed by the Commerce Department to set up a $23 million program that created 3,000 jobs in Oakland, Calif., a city of hard-core unemployment. Drawing on the experience, he wrote a novel, "Oakland's Not For Burning" (David McKay, 1968).
In 1970, Mr. Bradford headed a Nixon Administration study group that designed and recommended the new Federal Environmental Protection Agency substantially in the form that was accepted by the President and Congress. He later called it his most satisfying accomplishment.
In later years, Mr. Bradford acknowledged having become a jobless alcoholic, and confided to friends that he once came close to suicide. But he began psychiatric treatment, quit drinking and radically changed his life style. He began studying massage and psychotherapy at the Esalen Institute in Big Sur, Calif.
Harrison E. Salisbury, a Pulitzer Prize-winning foreign correspondent for The Times, wrote in a 1980 book about The Times, "Without Fear or Favor," that Mr. Bradford had become "a sort of guru," and said: "The last time he attended a reunion in the Thousand Islands with his fellow Yale Skull and Crossbones members one remembered Amory lounging in the nude while they sat on the beach in their trunks. In fact, he went nude for most of the day."
From 1978 to 1982, Mr. Bradford lived in a van, traveling in the United States, Canada and Mexico, occasionally revisiting Esalen. He practiced gestalt therapy in Arlington, Vt., from 1982 to 1987. He and his wife, Laurene, also taught massage.
In recent years, he had been writing his memoirs. In a statement he composed for his own obituary, he said that his "final years were intensified by the practice of Siddha Yoga meditation, taught by Swami Muktananda, to whom he was introduced by his daughter Madhavi in 1976."
Besides his wife, Mr. Bradford is survived by three daughters, Carola Lea, of Lyme, N.H., Madhavi Bradford, of Carbondale, Colo., and Deborah Bradford, of Aspen, Colo.; two sons, Peter, of Peru, Vt., and David, of Brattleboro, Vt.; his first wife and the mother of his five children, Carol Noyes, of Syosset, N.Y.; a sister, Jean Page, of Concord, N.H.; a brother, J. Allyn Bradford, of Cambridge, Mass.; two stepdaughters, Rebecca Waggoner, of Walnut Creek, Calif., and Kate Dow, of Rutland, Vt., and eight grandchildren.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 7, 1998, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An obituary on Sunday of Amory Bradford, a former vice president and general manager of The New York Times, referred incorrectly to the secret society he joined at Yale. It was Skull and Bones, not Skull and Crossbones.

HEADLINE: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.;
Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 5

 BODY:
In the final months of the Hole, anarchy was everywhere. The Hole, the most oppressive section of Chicago's notorious Robert Taylor Homes housing project, was coming down.
Gang members shot at a moving van outside one of the Hole's three high-rise buildings. Moving crews tried to hurry out each day before drug dealers commandeered the elevators. 
 Lenzie Jones packed his grandchildren's clothes for the movers but did not know what to do with their mother's belongings. She had fled a few days before, after the drug gang she hawked heroin for accused her of stealing and beat her with a baseball bat and a two-by-four.
Angela Smith frantically swatted cockroaches and attacked stains in her kitchen. An inspector from the building she wanted to move into was coming to scrutinize her housekeeping. If she failed, she would lose the apartment she had set her heart on.
Katie Sistrunk, who at 45 had reared 13 children in the Hole, had no idea where she would go, days before her building was to be emptied. Juanita Williams, 74, was so paralyzed over leaving her apartment of 25 years that she stayed after the water and gas were shut off, until police officers removed her.
On a scale not seen in decades, the Federal Government is helping cities clear slums again, but this time they are slums it helped create: public housing projects crippled by flawed policies and mismanagement and overwhelmed by poverty and crime.
From Hartford and Newark to Denver and San Francisco, 100,000 apartments in the nation's worst public housing projects are being razed under a Federal program called Hope VI. The plan is to replace them with smaller developments that mix families of different incomes, while moving thousands of tenants into privately owned buildings.
In Chicago, where high-rise housing projects are corrosive landmarks of poverty and racial segregation, the demolition will be nothing less than seismic: the city wants to raze 11,000 apartments, nearly 40 percent of its public housing for families, over the next 15 years.
And in a city whose housing projects contain 11 of the nation's 15 poorest census tracts, and where buildings in five large projects are being demolished, nowhere is the challenge greater than at Robert Taylor, the nation's largest housing project, much of which is "considered the worst slum area in the United States" according to its landlord, the Chicago Housing Authority.
The Hole, at the project's southern end, was the first section to go, demolished in July. But the authority wants to tear down all of the project's 28 high-rises, all 4,321 apartments.
The challenge is not just for the 11,000 people who will leave Robert Taylor, a population 99 percent black, so poor that nearly half of the adults live on less than $5,000 a year, and so isolated that many are unfamiliar with life beyond the grim monoliths that shadow the Dan Ryan Expressway on the South Side for nearly two miles.
It is a test for Chicago as housing officials try to eliminate a ghetto by placing most of Robert Taylor's tenants in private apartments. The goal is to disperse the project's concentrated poverty without introducing or aggravating social problems in the new neighborhoods. Success will require communities to accept as neighbors people they have long been happy to have out of sight. But already a pattern is emerging of tenants from housing projects being moved mainly to poor black neighborhoods, some as rundown and unsafe as the high-rises they left.
Ninety-six percent of Robert Taylor adult residents are unemployed and little may change if they are simply moved. So a second goal of Hope VI is to ease tenants off Government dependence. In Robert Taylor, the housing authority is spending $1.5 million of its initial $25 million Hope VI grant on social services, trying to place as many residents as possible in high school equivalency courses, training programs and jobs.
Some tenants need more basic help: clothes to wear to interviews with prospective landlords, help arranging electric and gas service, classes on such housekeeping skills as cleaning carpets and operating garbage disposals.
The distance between Robert Taylor and the outside world is not lost on the tenants. "Goddamn public aid penitentiary," Esther Jones, 41, said in June as she left the project after 12 years.
Other complications in relocating residents reflect the conditions at Robert Taylor.
Residents who needed temporary housing could not move for weeks because they were identified with the Mickey Cobras, the gang that controlled the Hole, while the apartments available were in a Robert Taylor building controlled by a rival gang, the Black Gangster Disciples.
Some tenants had criminal records, drug problems or erratic rent-paying habits that had been tolerated at Robert Taylor but could disqualify them for new housing.
Citywide, housing officials are trying to help tenants get the support they need, without stigmatizing them. They are also trying not to arouse community opposition to the newcomers. "I don't really need a not-in-my-backyard backlash right now," said Wanda White, the housing authority official supervising the relocation.
 
Hard-to-Place Tenants
Difficult Move To Private Sector
Angela Smith, 23, hauled out of her apartment anything broken or filthy: ice cube trays, baby shoes, a radio. She asked friends who were smoking marijuana to leave. The housekeeping inspector was coming.
"I got nowhere for people to sit," she fretted. She threw out her cockroach-infested couch and chairs a year ago. She and her children shared one bed and sat on milk crates and the hood of a large hair dryer. But roaches persisted. They crawled over her newborn son.
Like most people in the Hole, Ms. Smith was desperate to leave, but not for another housing authority apartment. Virtually all of the Hole's residents wanted Federal rent subsidies known as Section 8 certificates, which would allow them to rent their own housing.
Nationally, Hope VI wants Section 8 and the private market to replace 60 percent of the destroyed units, though some advocates for the poor worry that will worsen already severe shortages of housing and leave tenants with undesirable places to live. New York has largely ignored Hope VI because demand for its public housing is so high.
Robert Taylor is unusual because no new public housing will be built on the cleared site. Instead, smaller mixed-income developments and an industrial area are planned. Some public housing is planned nearby.
The demand for Section 8 housing makes relocating tenants harder. The housing authority's success in finding enough landlords willing to accept them in enough communities to avoid reconcentrating them has been limited since it began moving tenants from other housing projects in 1995.
According to an analysis by The Chicago Reporter, a monthly magazine that focuses on racial issues, the great majority of Section 8 placements have been in poor black neighborhoods on the South and West Sides.
Already some Robert Taylor tenants have had to move twice because of disputes with landlords or perilous conditions.
Aldermen have begun calling to say that their constituents are concerned about Section 8 tenants moving in, Ms. White said.
To find apartments for the Hole's tenants, the housing authority contracted with a private relocation agency in February. The agency's job included taking tenants to see apartments and helping with things like applications, credit checks and arranging utilities.
But tenants must satisfy landlords' expectations for cleanliness and conduct, and the housing authority expected the agency to be a hand holder: coaching tenants on how to dress for interviews, or making sure they were prepared for housekeeping inspections.
Ms. White said that after several months she replaced the agency for showing homes in too few neighborhoods and for not giving tenants enough help.
The agency's president, Pam Gecan, said her staff had expected the authority to give that help to difficult tenants. She said gunfire in the Hole sometimes made her workers afraid to visit clients. It was the tenants, she said, who tended to request certain neighborhoods, because they were familiar.
Billy Kimmons, for example, a 23-year-old former gang member who now works as a school patrol officer, was rejected by several landlords and finally moved near a church he attended in a poor minority neighborhood on the far South Side. Ms. Smith chose Woodlawn, a struggling neighborhood near Robert Taylor, because her grandmother lived there.
Ms. Smith was a typical Robert Taylor tenant, a young single mother. She said she left her mother's home at 17 because of problems with her stepfather, living on her own at Robert Taylor since. She had three children, Nathaniel, 5, Keosha, 3, and Shamari, 4 months. Her younger sister, Aderonke Akanni, who said she left home at 13 after her stepfather abused her, also lived with her.
Life in the Hole was chaotic. Ms. Smith said the father of her children beat her. She struggled on welfare, falling behind on her $44 monthly rent. She did not permit her children to play outside the apartment because gang violence made even hallways dangerous.
"It's scary," she said. "They shoot just to shoot."
Despite the turbulence, Ms. Smith and her sister were driven to improve their lives. Ms. Smith, petite and spirited, is studying for a high school equivalency diploma and plans to study nursing. Ms. Akanni, 18, works at a Lady Footlocker store and takes classes toward her equivalency diploma.
Applying for a Section 8 apartment, Ms. Smith was organized and efficient. She quickly assembled birth certificates, Social Security cards and her son's report card to prove he attended school.
But the housekeeping inspector for her new landlord was unimpressed. Ms. Smith said he complained about writing on the walls, lack of furniture and her friends -- who had moved their marijuana smoking to the hallway. Just weeks before her building was to be emptied, she failed the inspection.
Crestfallen and angry, she had to search for an apartment again, while living with her mother. Finally, in July, she got one.
"Weren't nobody smoking weed in my house," she said about failing the inspection. "And nobody going to be fixing up this raggedy place when you're fixing to move. They know this is the projects, right?"
 
Decline and Fall
Public Housing Becomes Hell Hole
The Robert Taylor Homes, named for Chicago's first black housing authority chairman, was among the last housing projects built in the city. Begun in 1959, it completed a four-mile corridor of public housing along State Street. While its new high-rises were welcome replacements for a shantytown, they quickly became the nation's largest government-sponsored ghetto.
Housing projects in Chicago are starkly identified with race and poverty. From the beginning, city officials used them, along with the expressways being built at the same time, to contain the city's growing population of poor blacks. Of Chicago's 67,000 public housing families, 97 percent are black.
In 1969, six years after completion of the last buildings, the three that became known as the Hole, Congress changed public housing policy with disastrous results for projects nationally. Instead of a fixed rent, tenants would pay a percentage of their income.
At Robert Taylor, working families moved out as their rent rose while neighbors on welfare paid almost nothing. Housing officials, wary of discrimination suits, stopped screening tenants. Single mothers as young as 16 were given apartments.
As the project filled with impoverished people, rent income fell and maintenance had to be cut. Tenants threw things off exterior gangways that linked apartments, so they were covered with steel grating, like a prison. Leaks and broken windows went unfixed. Elevators and hallways reeked of urine.
In Chicago's projects, "everything that could have gone wrong went wrong," said Joseph Shuldiner, the executive director of the housing authority, who was brought in to fix an agency so inept the Federal Government took it over in 1995.
"Once you get a population that is beginning to create problems, then you have trouble attracting people," he said. "The managers said, 'They're not letting me screen -- the heck with it.' Then your maintenance stinks. It just becomes a steamroller effect."
In a housing project with 20,000 residents at its peak but few men, gangs got an early hold. Violence and drugs devastated generations. As families moved out, vacant apartments became havens for drug dealers. Gangs ripped out metal detectors installed at entranceways and cut the wires of intercoms intended to screen visitors.
In the Hole, clusters of drug dealers brazenly hawked heroin and cocaine, forming gantlets in the entranceways. The wind whipped crack vials like shrapnel.
The police were frustrated by gang lookouts and the ability of dealers to vanish into high-rise hideouts. Dealers became so cocky that recently a gang member waved a roll of money at a group of housing officials and offered to buy the Hole for $1 million.
"I guess that's why they call it the Hole," said Deborah Mardis, a resident for 20 years. "You fall in and you never get out."
Ms. Mardis managed to leave in 1994, but her son Dequan, a gang member, kept returning. In January, visiting a girlfriend at a rival gang's building, he was shot six times. He survived.
After a shooting the next day, parents kept children home from the elementary school across a parking lot from the Hole, then formed patrols to escort them to class.
In February, a man was killed crossing from the Hole to Disciple territory. In March, postal workers did not deliver mail for a day because of shooting. One April weekend, a man was killed and another wounded. In June, a 9-year-old was shot. In August, a police officer investigating drug dealing was critically wounded. A 16-year-old and two 17-year-olds were charged.
"A long time ago, I decided that to survive here, you had to be crazy, chemically saturated, Christian, or some kind of character," said a woman called Cat Lady, a squatter in the Hole who rescued cats trapped in vacant apartments. "If we could gather the children, I'd do that."
 
Troubled Families
Stubborn Problems Hinder Relocation
Mary Bee Christian handed her sons vanilla cones she had bought from an ice cream truck and made a beeline for the bedroom with what she had bought for herself: $5 worth of crack and $20 of heroin. Using a lottery ticket to scoop the heroin and a tube from a light fixture as a crack pipe, Ms. Christian snorted and smoked her speedball.
When Willie, 7, shouted that the boys had finished eating, Ms. Christian replied, "Then watch some cartoons." When her lighter ran out of fluid, she told Willie and his brother, Jhonell, 6, to go to their room, so they would not see her light her crack pipe at the kitchen stove.
Her father, Lenzie Jones, at 61 stooped and leather-faced, watched helplessly. "Oh, Mary," he said, "Do you have to do that now?"
One of the toughest questions facing housing officials is how to deal with intensely troubled families. Their problems could not only cripple their adjustment to a new home but could also harm their new neighborhoods.
"You have to make it better for the people you are relocating," said Ms. White, the housing authority official, "but you also have to make it better for the people who will be their neighbors."
Robert Taylor has two devoted and savvy relocation specialists to work with families. In early 1997, they began untangling complications for the nearly 300 families in the Hole. Now they are doing the same in the next two buildings scheduled to come down.
Making repeated visits, sometimes working nights and weekends, they sort out who is on each lease -- and therefore entitled to new housing -- tell tenants of problems such as unpaid rent, and explain their options: Section 8 subsidies, another housing project, or "scattered site" apartments, which are managed by the authority but are not in a project. They also arrange moves, pay security deposits and visit families in their new homes.
But the authority's relocation workers face many of the same problems as the private agencies. Tenants miss appointments, waffle on housing choices, misunderstand instructions. Because few have telephones, it is difficult even to check on them.
Once families move, visiting them can take two months, because of the staff's workload.
When the relocation specialists encounter problems like drug abuse and child neglect, they refer them to the housing authority's social services department, which arranges for help from government agencies.
Responses are slow, said Ms. White, who is making improvements intended to insure families' problems are monitored closely.
Another challenge is determining if some families are so troubled that they should be turned out of public housing entirely.
Under a Federal court order in the 1970's and 1980's, Chicago moved 7,100 families out of segregated public housing and into rent-subsidized apartments. Central to the highly praised program was intensive counseling for families and its ability to screen out troubled people.
That kind of screening is much harder when entire buildings are being emptied. "That was a huge criticism, that we have people not being compassionate and it's just the get-them-out syndrome," Ms. White said. "On the flip side, you have the fear that we're just transferring problems."
In the Hole, Mr. Jones and his daughter presented one of the toughest situations. As a result, they were among the last people to leave their building, and then they moved only to temporary housing with about 25 other families with difficulties.
Trying to protect Mr. Jones and his grandchildren from his drug-addicted daughter, housing officials split them up in April. They knew that in March Ms. Christian's boyfriend hit Mr. Jones with a crowbar to make him give up the children's welfare money.
Mr. Jones was given an apartment in another Robert Taylor building for himself and the children. Ms. Christian was supposed to stay away.
Housing officials could have tried to evict Ms. Christian from the project because of her drug use. But one of the relocation specialists, Brenda Hunter, who grew up in Robert Taylor, said she knew Ms. Christian would then impose on her father, so instead she was given an apartment of her own -- rent-free, because she had no legal income.
But Ms. Christian's apartment was in the same building as her father's, and she began staying with her father and children, planning to rent or lend her apartment.
Like so many other tenants, Mr. Jones wanted a private apartment, so Ms. Hunter and her partner, Sonya Franklin, arranged an interview with CHAC Inc., the agency hired by the housing authority to see that tenants qualify financially for rent subsidies. On a late April day, he dressed up in a white hat with a yellow feather from a church giveaway, but the interview did not go well.
Since the apartment in the Hole had been leased in his daughter's name, he was told, the Section 8 program could not help him until the housing authority added his name to the lease. And because his daughter owed $250 in back rent, no one living there could get a rent subsidy until the debt was paid.
"This is the Government," the interviewer, Patrice Halliburton, said apologetically. "You can't bend the rules."
Mr. Jones wilted, bewildered by the red tape. He went back to his temporary apartment, where later that day his daughter came in with the ice cream for her boys and the drugs.
A well-meaning but overwhelmed man who had spent most of his life in housing projects, working at jobs like spray painting barrels, Mr. Jones had trouble asking for help. He had no phone. When a gang war broke out in June, even Ms. Hunter and Ms. Franklin were afraid to visit.
Once, Mr. Jones fetched the police to stop Ms. Christian and her boyfriend from stealing his furniture, clothes and the children's food. The next day, he armed himself with a meat cleaver when they tried to return.
Having lost what she called her "advertising job," shouting out to drug buyers "Hurricane" and "Chaos," the names of heroin, Ms. Christian turned to prostitution.
Ms. Christian blames herself for ravaging her family and sometimes she resolves to stop using the drugs. In June, she checked into a short-term detoxification program, then came home and read stories to her son. At other times she said, "All I know is to go out there and do my hustle and get myself some wake-up so I can function."
By late July, the family owed nearly $500 in rent and Mr. Jones's welfare payments had been cut in half because he had missed an appointment with a caseworker.
In early August, housing officials met with each of the temporarily relocated families, most of whom were behind on rent. At least four were told they would be evicted, Ms. Hunter said. No family will be permanently moved until back rent is paid.
Ms. Hunter said Mr. Jones had told her he was going to try to pay his rent so that she could begin trying to get him a Section 8 subsidy. The rent has not been paid, but Ms. Hunter said she was not giving up.
"We definitely don't want him to get left behind," she said.
 
Problems and Promise
Complex Family Poses Dilemma
Katie Sistrunk was packing, getting ready to move any day. Then, in January, the letter came.
The private agency screening people for the apartment she wanted had rejected her. The letter cited "many problems with this family," including "gang affiliation" and "poor rent-paying habits." It said two of her teen-agers had quit school "to pursue a career in crime, i.e. robbing and stalking innocent people."
Much of the letter was wrong. In part, it confused Ms. Sistrunk with a sister arrested on drug charges. It was just the first hitch in her effort to maneuver her large and complicated family through the housing bureaucracy and out of the Robert Taylor Homes.
With gravelly voice, Ms. Sistrunk is a passionate advocate for herself, 13 children, 28 grandchildren and dozens more relatives. Her family is so identified with the Hole that one son, 27-year-old Henry, wears a tattoo of the three high-rises.
But the Sistrunks also illustrate the complexities of many families in Robert Taylor. One family may have members who have succeeded against bleak odds and members whose criminal behavior could result in eviction under public housing rules, or could prevent them from getting private housing.
Over 27 years in the Hole, the Sistrunks made undeniable strides. They relied little on welfare, living mostly on income from Ms. Sistrunk's former husband. Amid squalor, the children ironed their jeans and T-shirts. Three children have attended college. One, on a basketball scholarship, expects to graduate with an architecture degree. But five of Ms. Sistrunk's grown children have criminal records, some involving weapons or drugs, court documents show.
"They've got tons of problems," Brenda Hunter, the relocation specialist, said, "but they got a lot going for them, they do."
Ms. Hunter does not volunteer sensitive information like arrests to prospective landlords. And she tried to get the private agency that rejected Ms. Sistrunk to reconsider.
"Our approach is toughness combined with natural mercy and humanity," said Joseph Shuldiner, the authority's executive director. "We have to be realistic."
In moving, Ms. Sistrunk wanted dignity and choices for her family.
She lobbied housing officials until six of her grown children got rent-subsidized apartments. Then her 24-year-old son, Joe, was charged with cocaine possession and her two youngest children, ages 16 and 17, were charged with interfering with the police during the arrest.
Charges against the teen-agers were dropped, but Joe was in jail the day he was to sign his lease. The family sent his girlfriend to sign for him.
For herself and her two youngest children, Ms. Sistrunk wanted one of the housing authority's new scattered-site apartments. She rejected one. Twice, she accepted apartments but was told they had been taken. She phoned high housing officials. Two days before her building was to be emptied, she rounded up other tenants and threatened not to leave.
"They tell me about one thing, then they switch it," she thundered.
Finally, Wanda White, while on vacation, guaranteed Ms. Sistrunk a place that she wanted so she would not have to move to temporary quarters. Aware of the Sistrunks' complicated history, Ms. White decided they had great potential to succeed.
"You have to have some flexibility to look at people individually," Ms. White said.
Ms. Sistrunk moved out in June carrying an urn with the ashes of her former husband, who died in March, salt for good luck, and her daughter's prom glass, a proud symbol of her high school graduation.
She passed a drug dealer yelling "Bubble on State," code that the police were nearby.
"I am so sick of that 'Bubble on State,' " she whispered. "What they should have did is torn it down many years ago and saved a lot of mothers' sons."

HEADLINE: High Stakes and Antes in State Races

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 2

 BODY:
Not so long ago, State Senator Edward N. Warren ran for re-election every two years by handing out combs. Thousands of combs. Thousands of green combs (because Mr. Warren is from Greenville) with his name embossed in white type.
"I'd go out to the restaurants where the farmers go for breakfast, like Tom's in Greenville and Bum's in Ayden, and I'd pass out my combs," said Mr. Warren, a 68-year-old former high school principal who has served in North Carolina's Legislature for 18 years. "I'd always just tell people that I don't have any hair, so I have no need for them." 
Mr. Warren, a Democrat, still hands out combs. But in the past four years, he has also become conversant in the modern politics of television advertising buys, polling cross-tabulations and targeted direct mail. While he once spent no more than $30,000 to hold on to his Senate seat, his 1996 campaign cost $210,000. This year, he may have to spend more.
"It's just out of control," Mr. Warren said. "I never thought I'd see it in my career, but that's the real world in North Carolina these days."
In fact, it has become the real world for lawmakers in virtually every statehouse in the 1990's. With control of legislatures at risk in a remarkable number of states, and with states inheriting vast new responsibilities from Washington, the once quaint business of legislative politics has become intensely competitive, sophisticated and costly.
After decades of hidebound, one-party domination, nearly a third of all legislative chambers are now within theoretical striking distance of a switch in partisan control. In several chambers, like the Michigan House of Representatives, the California Assembly and the Wisconsin Senate, control has changed multiple times in the last six years. To be sure, some states have long had closely contested and relatively expensive legislative elections, but now even the once-solid South, where the state legislatures were the last bastion of Democratic control, is in play.
This new competitiveness, driven largely by Republican inroads in this decade, has led to a sea change in the tactics of legislative campaigning, said dozens of lawmakers, political consultants and authorities on state government interviewed this week.
Television advertising was once considered absurdly inefficient in legislative races because media markets are typically far larger than districts. But it is now commonplace, and not just on cable. Legislative leaders make extensive use of polling to determine how to allocate their party caucuses' financial resources. Partisan messages and policy positions are formulated with the help of focus groups.
With states playing a crucial role in welfare, education, taxation and criminal justice, the national political parties are placing renewed emphasis on legislative campaigns, and so are interest groups. And the political stakes are only rising, because the elections in 1998 and 2000 will determine which parties control the redistricting process after the next census. All of that has led to skyrocketing costs -- and a need for ever-greater fund-raising.
"Targeted races are running two to three times what they cost in the early 90's," said Kevin R. Mack, director of the Democratic Legislative Campaign Committee. "It's almost a Congressionalization of state legislative campaigns."
In California two years ago, two Assemblymen, Rusty Areias and Bruce McPherson, spent a combined $3.49 million in trying to move up to the State Senate, a race won by Mr. McPherson, a Republican. Total spending on legislative races in that state increased to $105 million in 1995-96 from $15 million in 1975-76, the Secretary of State reported.
North Carolina's recent experience demonstrates that campaign inflation is not limited to large states with high advertising rates. As the General Assembly here has become a partisan battleground, with the Republicans gaining a slim majority in the House of Representatives in 1994, the cost of campaigning has soared.
In 1996, candidates from the two major parties in North Carolina spent a total of $13.6 million on their campaigns, according to a study by Thad Beyle, a political scientist at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. After accounting for inflation, that was an increase of 81 percent over the amount spent in 1994, and an increase of 172 percent over 1992, Mr. Beyle reported.
The main reason for the increase in spending is that legislative politics have destabilized in the 1990's after decades of calm.
From 1972 to 1994, Democrats were as prevalent in state legislatures as plaid sport coats. They controlled the majority of statehouses and exerted little effort in maintaining their power. They were particularly dominant in the South in those years, a period when Democrats controlled every legislative chamber and never held fewer than 71 percent of the region's legislative seats, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures.
In North Carolina, the Democratic campaign strategy consisted of little more than "hearing at the grocery store that Senator Joe was in trouble and sending him $500," said Senator Roy A. Cooper, the Democratic majority leader. But in 1994, as Republicans took control of Congress, they also asserted themselves on the state level. Republicans entered that election with control of 8 legislatures and emerged with 19, while the Democrats were left with 18. Twelve legislatures were divided with each party controlling one chamber.
Two years later, the Democrats rebounded a bit, taking control in 20 states to the Republicans' 18, with 11 states divided. In the South, Democrats hold only 62 percent of all seats, and Republicans control both chambers in Florida and Virginia, as well as the House of Representatives in North Carolina and South Carolina and the Senate in Texas.
This year, in the 46 states with elections in at least one house, the parties are separated by six seats or fewer in 23 chambers, a staggering level of competitiveness.
Adding to the instability is the onset of term limits, which will dislodge large numbers of incumbents in several states. In Michigan, for instance, where Democrats hold a 6-seat majority in the House, term limits will open 67 of 110 seats this year. In the Arkansas House, 49 of 100 seats will be open because of term limits.
Even as they consult pollsters and cut television ads, many lawmakers lament that the new professionalism of legislative politics has transformed their political culture.
Like their Congressional counterparts, they complain that fund-raising monopolizes their time. The reliance on big money has given new power to legislative leaders and their centralized fund-raising committees, which collect contributions for their party caucuses and then distribute cash to the most vulnerable members. It has heightened the influence of lobbyists, interest groups and political action committees.
Here in North Carolina, Senator John H. Kerr, a Democrat from Goldsboro, used to shun money from political action committees on principle. This year, Mr. Kerr said, he can no longer afford to be pure.
"When your opponent is running 30-second commercials and dropping all these mailings," Mr. Kerr said, "you've got to be able to combat that, to do background research, to poll."
Representative Daniel T. Blue Jr., a Democrat from Raleigh and a former Speaker of the House, said the cost of campaigning had made public service "unachievable for ordinary folk." The influence of check-bearing lobbyists, Mr. Blue said, "just pervades everything that goes on here."
All too often, he added, policy proposals seem to be shaped by out-of-state pollsters with an eye on November. Compromise is often sacrificed for political positioning.
This week, for instance, the General Assembly here was deadlocked over a proposal by House Republicans to eliminate the state's inheritance tax. Senate Democrats agreed to a partial repeal, but Republicans did not budge. "Apparently it polls very well," Mr. Blue said.
The impasse in Raleigh has contributed to the longest legislative session in the state's history. And legislative leaders worry that the demands on lawmakers' time will make it difficult to recruit candidates for an increasingly full-time job that pays $13,951 a year and $104 a day in expenses. Senator Leslie J. Winner, a Democrat from Charlotte, is quitting this year after three terms because the job now keeps her apart too often from her 9-year-old daughter, Lily. One of Lily's poems, which Ms. Winner has posted in her office, is "dedicated to my mother, who's always in Raleigh."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 9, 1998, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about the increasing cost and competitiveness of state legislative elections misstated the party control of the Virginia Legislature. Republicans do not control both chambers; they control the Senate, and Democrats hold a narrow margin in the House of Delegates. There are 50 Democrats, 49 Republicans and 1 independent in that body, and the Speaker is a Democrat.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS IN TURMOIL: A LONG VIEW;
Veteran of '87 Sees Less Cause for Alarm

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
AS the world's stock markets wobble wildly, Asian economies sink into recession, Russia slams the door on its creditors and American and foreign financial institutions make provisions for billions in losses, the Treasury and the Federal Reserve are hastily dusting off their primers on financial crisis management.
Amid the current turmoil, few of the world's financial leaders have much to say publicly. But some who have seen markets plunge before believe the reaction to recent events is overwrought. 
 One is E. Gerald Corrigan, who as president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for a decade was the nation's financial fireman at the time of the 1987 stock market crash.
There is suddenly too much pessimism, Mr. Corrigan said in an interview last week. Stressing the current capital strength of the American financial system and the absence of major credit problems, he argued that the world was better positioned to withstand stress than it had been in the 1980's.
"Suddenly all news is bad news, after a period when all news is good news," said Mr. Corrigan, 57, now a managing director at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "The truth, as always, lies somewhere in between."
In an interview from Montana, where he was on vacation after the Kansas City Federal Reserve's annual conference in Jackson Hole, Wyo., Mr. Corrigan underscored that he is today a Wall Streeter, without inside knowledge of Government efforts to deal with the new round of turbulence. It has been nearly five years since he stepped down as president of the New York Fed after a long career.
Yet as Mr. Corrigan readily acknowledges, there is some truth to the maxim "Once a central banker, always a central banker." And he is married to one, as well; last October, he wed Cathy E. Minehan, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston. Mr. Corrigan, the Fed and Goldman, Sachs have all said they have established procedures to guard against potential conflicts of interest.
While the roots of today's turmoil are structural problems in Asia's economy -- weak banking systems, for example, and Japan's paralysis -- the surprise is that Russia is now roiling world markets, Mr. Corrigan said. He called the country "kind of the wild card."
That, he said, is "because while its economy is nowhere near big enough to have much effect on world markets," it has caused "political anxiety, and its contagion effect has been greater than anyone expected."
What "got markets very nervous" about Russia, he said, was the Government's declaration, effectively, of a unilateral moratorium on paying both foreign and domestic bonds and its further moratorium on the foreign currency liabilities of Russian companies.
Such steps are anathema to central bankers, Mr. Corrigan said. Debt moratoriums "fundamentally seem to be so in conflict with the whole fabric of the credit system," he said.
"This raises the question:, If it could happen there, could it happen somewhere else?" he added.
Still, Mr. Corrigan argued, the prospect of debt repudiation is not as threatening as it was in the 1980's. "If you look at the system as a whole, we are not nearly as leveraged as we were in the mid- to late 80's," he said. "Some institutions will take some lumps here. But none of this should be remotely life-threatening for the system."
That is a sharp contrast to the days after Black Monday in 1987, when the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 22.8 percent in a single trading session. "If you go back to the stock market crash of '87, especially the Tuesday or Wednesday, every newspaper was laden with stories about credit problems," Mr. Corrigan recalled. "That's not the question today."
Instead, the question today is how to prevent the collapse of economies in countries ranging from Thailand to Russia. Asked what remedies he might suggest, Mr. Corrigan referred to "Sovereign Financial Crises: Facing Realities and Building a More Secure Future," a paper he wrote in May. It strongly suggests that prevention is far preferable to searching for cures.
"Once a crisis strikes, the country, its creditors, its investors and the official community are left with nothing but bad choices," the paper states. Mr. Corrigan argues instead for better and more prompt dissemination of economic information, tougher conditions on lending, increased financial resources for the International Monetary Fund and stronger banking systems.
From his office at Goldman, Sachs, Mr. Corrigan has had a hand in trying to manage some of the recent crises. He has advised South Korea and Thailand as those countries seek to pull themselves up from Asia's continuing woes; earlier, he consulted with the Mexican and Argentine Governments.
At the New York Fed in the early 1990's, Mr. Corrigan also worked with Russian leaders, forming a friendship with President Boris N. Yeltsin and becoming chairman of the Russian-American bankers' forum, which has sought to provide training and technical help to the Russian banking system.
Despite the current tangle of international financial problems, Mr. Corrigan keeps faith in the world's ability to withstand the current buffeting. "Financial markets are really quite resilient," he said. "They really can handle most things -- unless there is the perception or reality of major credit problems in the system."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 13, 1998, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption last Sunday with an article comparing the economic environments of 1987 and 1998 misstated the middle name of a former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York who said the world economy was now in a better position to withstand stress. He is E. Gerald Corrigan, not Daniel.
